webTitle: McGrath plays Eric the Eel as Yuvraj upsets Aussies

fields.headline: McGrath plays Eric the Eel as Yuvraj upsets Aussies
fields.trailText: On Thursday we were saying the ICC Knockout needed an upset. On Saturday it got one: Australia, the favourites, were knocked out in their first game, soundly beaten by India.
fields.body:
On Thursday we were saying the ICC Knockout needed an upset. On Saturday it got one: Australia, the favourites, were knocked out in their first game, soundly beaten by India.

While one Roy of the Rovers story was coming to an end at Wembley, another began at the Nairobi Gymkhana, as an unknown 18-year-old hit 84 against the world's best team, then took a great catch and, for good measure, pulled off a direct-hit run-out to get rid of the world's best one-day batsman, Michael Bevan. Yuvraj Singh didn't just make a name for himself: he lit the flame of a somewhat flickering tournament. He was Cathy Freeman and Ian Thorpe at the same time.

The role of Eric the Eel was played by Glenn McGrath. About 99 per cent of the time, McGrath is utterly reliable - Angus Fraser with more pace and less grace. But when he is bad, he is very bad. It happened at Lord's in May 1997, when he served up half-volleys for Ben Hollioake to flick nonchalantly over midwicket. It happened at Edgbaston a couple of weeks later, when Nasser Hussain made 200 on a seaming pitch. It happened at Lord's in 1998, when Sachin Tendulkar alternately drove him on the up or pulled him into the Tavern. And it happened in Nairobi on Saturday. Tendulkar hit three sixes in consecutive overs from McGrath, who responded by sledging. The umpires didn't apply the new five-run penalty, but instead a subtler form of punishment came into force. So much time was wasted by McGrath's posturing - and the retrieval of the ball, as he conceded 61 off just nine overs - that Australia were docked two overs from their reply.

So David beat Goliath. It was excellent news for the tournament, which was in danger of being a damp squib. A competition with ICC in its name was bound to cock a few things up and the most glaring error has been the price of the tickets - ranging from three days' wages for the average Kenyan up to about five weeks' worth. The indigenous population can't afford that, but it seems that the Indian community can. The Gymkhana will be reasonably full for at least one more match, when India take on England or South Africa in Friday's second semi-final.

Whether the result was good for England is arguable. It means that their path to the final is no longer blocked by the world's best two teams. But it gives South Africa an even greater incentive to win tomorrow, as their bogey team has been conveniently removed for them. And the nature of India's victory means that even if England beat South Africa, they will still have to face formidable opponents in the semi-final. They still have to climb twin peaks: it's just that one of the peaks is not the one they were expecting.

India have two wins under their belt already, they are expert exponents of one-day cricket on flat tracks, and after a spell of depression, they are suddenly on the up. Players accused of match-fixing have been jettisoned and their replacements have made an instant impact. The seam attack has been strengthened by the arrival of Zaheer Khan, who has impressed people with his pace and accuracy. And the world's best one-day top order just got even better, with Tendulkar, Sourav Ganguly and Rahul Dravid now backed up not just by Singh but by Vinod Kambli, a man who, when he fills in his hotel breakfast order form, ticks the box marked ENGLISH BOWLING.

India v England would be a mouthwatering contest. But first England have to overcome the odds and see off South Africa. Duncan Fletcher said at the weekend that it would help that England have already sampled the conditions - the high altitude and the unexpectedly pacy Gymkhana pitch. He may not be aware that South Africa were here a year ago, for a quadrangular tournament called the LG Safari Cup. It was between Kenya, Zimbabwe, India and South Africa. You can guess who won. You can also guess which explosive left-hander hit a hundred for them at a run a ball.

Altitude will hardly be a problem for the South Africans. The tennis-ball bounce might be. Allan Donald is a great bowler in both forms of the game but he can be expensive when the ball doesn't swing for him. If McGrath, Gillespie and Brett Lee can take a pounding, so can Donald, Pollock and Nantie Hayward. But the same applies, twice over, to whoever is asked to fill the size-12 boots of Alan Mullally. Against Bangladesh it was Mark Alleyne, whose military medium was cannon fodder, conceding 26 in three overs. Against South Africa it is more likely to be a Yorkshireman. This could be Paul Grayson, the Essex slow left-armer plucked from his winter job in a brewery in the wackiest England selection since Vince Wells made the World Cup squad. Or it could be Matthew Hoggard, a proper bowler, who takes wickets but also takes poundings - in his only England appearance so far, in the Lord's Test, he took one from Franklyn Rose. You wouldn't back either of them against Lance Klusener. But if India can beat Australia, anything can happen.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com. To read his previous piece, on England's victory over Bangaladesh, click here

fields.headline: Out of his league
fields.standfirst:
Keegan shows himself the red card
Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: It was hearing Jack Straw advising her on TV to consider her position which last week persuaded the head of the National Lottery Commission, Dame Helena Shovelton, that her number was up. It was England football supporters saying the same thing in less decorous language which on Saturday evening determined Kevin Keegan to offer his resignation - instantly, and without even waiting for England's next World Cup qualifier with Finland on Wednesday. He had come to the same sad conclusion after England's surrender to Germany which our football correspondent David Lacey arrived at when he was chosen: that he simply was not up to the job.
fields.body:
It was hearing Jack Straw advising her on TV to consider her position which last week persuaded the head of the National Lottery Commission, Dame Helena Shovelton, that her number was up. It was England football supporters saying the same thing in less decorous language which on Saturday evening determined Kevin Keegan to offer his resignation - instantly, and without even waiting for England's next World Cup qualifier with Finland on Wednesday. He had come to the same sad conclusion after England's surrender to Germany which our football correspondent David Lacey arrived at when he was chosen: that he simply was not up to the job.

The England coach was not directly to blame for David Seaman's goalkeeping blunder which cost his country the match, but he had to take the blame both for his side's inert performance and above all for a team selection which blighted its chances right from the start. His candour does him credit, in an age when few resign except under pressure and even fewer blame their departures on their own imperfections. In every other sense, this has been a sad episode.

To judge from the views which have poured into websites, most fans believe there are only two options for filling the vacancy. First: Terry Venables; second: someone else. Someone else, this time, might not be English. One ingenious pundit says the FA should go back to Fulham, where they found Mr Keegan, and hire his French successor, Jean Tigana. Stuffy old cricket dared to do it, engaging the Zimbabwean Duncan Fletcher, and last season's performance suggests it may have paid off. Yet any foreign import who takes the job will need to be a stupendous success, since otherwise the sort of obloquy which came the way of Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle and others will break out all over again, but this time with added xenophobia. Even the Sun, contenders should be aware, knows the French for "turnip".

fields.headline: Daum agrees to drug tests
fields.trailText: Germany coach-elect Christoph Daum has agreed to supply urine, blood and hair samples for tests in order to prove he has never taken cocaine.
fields.body:
Germany coach-elect Christoph Daum has agreed to supply urine, blood and hair samples for tests in order to prove he has never taken cocaine.

Daum, who is due to take over from Rudi Voller next summer, has been engulfed by recent sex and drugs allegations and is determined to "protect" his name. The samples will be sent to an independent laboratory in Cologne and the results will be available in about four weeks.

Daum told a press conference today: "I was forced to do this because of my responsibility towards my family and my club. I also had to protect my good name.

"However, I won't give the result of the test to the media, but to my family, DFB president-in-waiting Gerhard Mayer-Vorfelder, Franz Beckenbauer and Leverkusen general manager Reiner Calmund.

"Obviously these people have the right to announce the outcome to the German public."

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's "tactically inept" transfer talk falls a bit short, sad to say
fields.trailText: Unsurprisingly, the vacant England job is top of the agenda for most of the papers. The Sun claims Arsenal are prepared to give the FA permission to speak to Arsene Wenger, but Gunners chairman Peter Hill-Wood is sure his French coach will turn down any offer. "He wouldn't say yes to the job. He would be crazy to take it. And Arsene Wenger is not crazy - he is far too sensible." Alright, alright, we get your point.
fields.body:
Unsurprisingly, the vacant England job is top of the agenda for most of the papers. The Sun claims Arsenal are prepared to give the FA permission to speak to Arsene Wenger, but Gunners chairman Peter Hill-Wood is sure his French coach will turn down any offer. "He wouldn't say yes to the job. He would be crazy to take it. And Arsene Wenger is not crazy - he is far too sensible." Alright, alright, we get your point.

Bobby Robson would take the job if he was offered it, though. "If I received a call from someone at Lancaster Gate in the next few days, I would answer it," the 67-year-old former England manager says.

Robson's phone is unlikely to ring, though, according to the Daily Mail. Aime Jacquet, the man who led France to the 1998 World Cup, is the result of an FA search which mysteriously began "a month ago". Jacquet was by all accounts prepared to move to London for the Chelsea job, and this has given the FA encouragement.

The paper of choice for middle Englanders with nothing better to do than moan about how expensive it is to take their 4x4 down the local shops also claims that Rangers boss Dick Advocaat could be a "surprise" choice.

Other names mentioned in various journals include Alex Ferguson, Leicester boss Peter Taylor, Premiership success stories John Gregory and Bryan Robson, Celtic manager Martin O'Neill, Uncle Tom Cobleigh and - surprise! - Terry Venables.

But enough. Rumours will now turn its attention to domestic matters.

Spanish sports daily Marca reports that Deportivo La Coruna midfielder Slavisa Jokanovic will complete a move to Chelsea today. "The club wants to sell me and I agree with the conditions they are offering," the 32-year-old Yugoslavian announced.

Barcelona midfielder Jari Litmanen fancies a move to the Premiership. "I have heard that certain clubs are interested," announced the lifelong Liverpool supporter. How much the injury-prone Finn would enjoy the hurly-burly of the English game is another question - read Simon Kuper's article on the former Ajax player.

Leeds will not pay £60,000 a week to employ Steve McManaman, according to chairman Peter Ridsdale, who has branded a weekend report "a complete kite-flyer". Ridsdale also denied plans to sell Michael Bridges to Newcastle. "He's only been on the bench for two matches, everyone says it's important that we build up a strong squad and as far as I am concerned Michael is a highly valuable member of that squad so he is going nowhere," he told Teamtalk.

John Gregory wants to take Liverpool defender Steve Staunton back to Aston Villa. Teamtalk also suggests Sheffield Wednesday striker Gilles de Bilde could be turning up at Doug Ellis Towers on loan.

Manchester United have taken 22-year-old Danish goalkeeping prospect Jesper Christiansen on trial.

fields.headline: The best Paul Newman scene
fields.standfirst: Where the money is
fields.trailText: Where the money is
fields.body:
Having discovered that bank-robber Henry (Paul Newman) faked the stroke which led to his transfer from jail, small-town nurse Carol (Linda Fiorentino) and her husband Wayne (Dermot Mulroney) have taken him to a remote bar.

"It's funny," Henry explains, "the kind of stuff you can get shipped into a prison library. Tantric Buddhism. Mind control. Auto-hypnosis. You got to gather up all that stuff, find out what you need, and make it work for you."

Carol and Wayne look stunned.

"I did that. All day, all night. Every day, every night. Like I was in training."

Wayne nods.

"Yeah. I played sports."

"Yeah, well, faking a stroke isn't exactly an Olympic event, but I got to tell ya - if you know they're going to be sticking pins in you, and you know there's going to be guards 24 hours a day waiting for you to screw up on the hustle, then you know it ain't good enough just to be playing possum. You've got to be a possum. A dead possum. So you work. You learn to funnel everything down, so finally all you are is a heartbeat."

He closes his eyes.

"What can I tell you? You get to a place like that, it's some kick in the ass. After a while, you can shape it, and mould it, and squeeze it."

He opens his eyes.

"Hey, I can make every heartbeat sound like Frank Sinatra."

See also: Butch Cassidy and The Sundance Kid, Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, The Hustler

Don't see also: Message In A Bottle

Pointless trivia: This January, on his 75th birthday, Paul Newman burned his tuxedo on the grounds he was "through with formality."

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: Never a dull moment in the world of unmetered internet access. Breathe and LineOne were the first to kick up a fuss about 24/7 internet access not meaning 24/7 internet access. Now Freeserve and The Free Internet Group/Excite are having a pop at so-called heavy users who are abusing their generosity. Both are about to create a war between themselves and the hardcore massive who spend their lives online. 'Tis a pity that Freeserve has grown up to be such an ogre - it used to be such a dear, sweet thing. Media Guardian is still awaiting an audience with the elusive John Pluthero, two months after requesting an interview. We're not holding our breath.
fields.body:
Never a dull moment in the world of unmetered internet access. Breathe and LineOne were the first to kick up a fuss about 24/7 internet access not meaning 24/7 internet access. Now Freeserve and The Free Internet Group/Excite are having a pop at so-called heavy users who are abusing their generosity. Both are about to create a war between themselves and the hardcore massive who spend their lives online. 'Tis a pity that Freeserve has grown up to be such an ogre - it used to be such a dear, sweet thing. Media Guardian is still awaiting an audience with the elusive John Pluthero, two months after requesting an interview. We're not holding our breath.

On the subject of Freeserve, punters were further angered last week by slack customer service. On reporting a serious site bug on the webmail service which had existed for a week, one such punter was told that Freeserve didn't administer the service, fobbing off said individual to another customer service email. After much toing and froing, Fsmail Support said it was fixing the "intermittent problem" and the punter should keep trying. The problem was still there at the time of writing, and by the sound of things, it's going to be around for a while, given that the two guys who developed the system have tootled off to LShift. Tsk. Freeserve will never win friends and influence people with that attitude, but then, judging by its fondness for breaking stories in the FT, the only people it wants to impress these days are city types and business partners.

My astute colleague on mediatheguardian.com - the one who goes by the moniker "The Monkey" - asked "what's in a suffix?" on Monday, and penned a diary story about how Associated New Media was said to be adopting a new strategy of using the mail.co.uk suffix (à la femail.co.uk) for its planned websites. Jokingly, Monkey suggested that, as Associated had already registered travelmail.co.uk, shopmail.co.uk, moneymail.co.uk and financialmail.co.uk, the only remaining juicy combination was showbizmail.co.uk, which at the time was still available. "Better snap it up quick," advised Monkey, not realising that someone would do just that in merely a matter of hours. Right then, this week's available domain name of the week is glamourmail.co.uk, and I've started the stopwatch.

No one in the new media industry has yet learned the subtle nuances of the word gossip nor the correct meaning of NDA (non disclosure agreement), as shown by the complete lack of knowledge among new media types about BA's plans last week. Thankfully, the ad agencies have a well-structured grapevine and know just how much to leak to well-meaning journos. So we now know that BA is planning a lifestyle magazine portal for BA Miles, which is to spend £6m on marketing. Was it really worth all the secrecy when Media Guardian put in a call to BA's press office?

 Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com

fields.headline: Up in smoke
fields.standfirst: The government's policy on tobacco ads is in disarray.  Jade Garrett  says they should have seen it coming.
fields.trailText: The government's policy on tobacco ads is in disarray. Jade Garre says they should have seen it coming.
fields.body:
Last December saw a flurry of tobacco advertising in cinemas nationwide, on poster sites across the UK and throughout the national press. Tobacco advertisers ploughed vast budgets into what they thought would be their last ad campaigns to run in the UK. Many also paid for final "goodbye" campaigns to sign the brands off once and for all.

That was before the European Court of Justice overruled the European Union's plan to ban tobacco advertising - a big embarrassment to the UK government, which had promised the ban in its manifesto.

The government has come in for considerable criticism from the UK's ad industry for its handling of the affair.

"Everyone tried telling the government that this would happen but it got on its high horse and wouldn't listen," says Rupert Howell, president of the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising.

"The outcome was completely inevitable and the government should have been prepared to reach some compromise. The only option it left the tobacco industry was to take it to court."

It was a small victory for the tobacco advertisers, buying them more time, but within hours Yvette Cooper, the public health minister, declared her determination to introduce a bill in the Queen's Speech curbing cigarette promotion. And when it does eventually come into force, the UK ban is likely to be much tougher.

The government has suffered a serious loss of face ever since the four big UK tobacco companies (Gallaher, Imperial, BAT and Rothmans) challenged the EU directive on tobacco advertising and sponsorship in 1998.

In June this year a Commons committee revealed that ad agencies had consistently tried to get round government attempts to ban tobacco advertising.

Its report claimed the ad industry had used its "creative talents to undermine government policy and evade regulation".

Evidence was submitted by four ad agencies - Mustoe Merriman Herring Levy, which handles Imperial; M&C Saatchi, which has Silk Cut; CDP, which works with Gallaher; and TBWA, which has Marlboro.

The findings were that voluntary agreements - which stipulate that tobacco companies must not, for example, advertise in magazines that have a young readership, nor within 200 metres of schools, nor in shop windows, and that all ads must be sanctioned by the ASA prior to release - had served the public badly.

The committee's report concluded that regulations were seen by ad agencies as hurdles to be side-stepped and legislation banning advertising as a challenge - a policy to be undermined by whatever means possible.

With this in mind, Nick Mustoe, the chief executive at Mustoe Merriman Herring Levy, says that the government's aggressive stance means that "we could see a blanket ban on advertising as soon as next spring, assuming that they can push through primary legislation smoothly. This is now likely to be more far-reaching. It could completely ban all print and poster advertising, and put a block on all point-of-sale material as well as all database marketing, loyalty schemes and brand extension work."

John Carlisle, the director of public affairs at the cigarette companies' trade body, the Tobacco Manufacturers' Association, is now unlikely, it seems, to get his wish to retain the voluntary code of practice. But he says the industry will fight for its right to retain direct communication with its customers.

He also points out that the Human Rights Act, which came into operation this month, may make it difficult for the government to ban the flow of literature between tobacco companies and smokers who ask for it.

After so many false starts for the ban, there is currently little agreement between tobacco companies on how to react to Cooper's determination to impose a UK ban.

As the December deadline loomed last year, M&C Saatchi designed and created hundreds of large inflatable women, wearing split silk dresses and holding signs that read "it's not over till the fat lady sings". Those dolls have been in storage ever since, but they could finally get to see the light of day as early as next March.

fields.headline: My New Media
fields.standfirst: Julie Meyer, founder of firsttuesday.com
fields.trailText: Julie Meyer, founder of firsttuesday.com, talks to Carolyne Ellis.
fields.body:
Favourite sites? Nerve.com. It's new and very irreverent. It's the erotic side of life. Peoplesound.com, because I love to find new music that echoes the old music that I love. Ezoka.com, which is a B2B marketplace. It helps to save money. Peoplenews.com because people are curious about people - they like to see who's on the list, find out who's who, who's being talked about.

Last online purchase? This is really embarrassing. I bought the George Gilder technology report from gilder.com. They predict technology trends.

Most recent technological faux pas? I sent a virus email to my friends - one with a woman's name in. It went through my address book, sending emails to everybody, and gobbling up their email.

Main news sources on web? Netimperative, tornado-insider and redherring.

Most persistent spam emailer? God knows how, but I end up on people's joke distribution list. I get three jokes a day from an Indiana University professor of finance who I don't even know.

Time spent on web? Any time I'm not sleeping and/or in a meeting - so up to 15 hours a day.

Next boo.com/clickmango? It will be one of the venture capital companies, but I can't say which one.

Least useful site/s on web? The search engines, because they don't give you information the way you want it. They've got this technology which searches for words and you get stuff back which has no relation to them on the web.

Most useful site? A little company called kizoom, which gives you personalised information, anywhere in the UK, across the board - exactly what technology should be doing for us. It delivers just-in-time information to your WAP phone. It's the hottest company just now.

What screensaver do you use? Our firsttuesday.com logo.

Most irritating thing about the web? That it's just not fast enough and it's still forcing me to be connected to a wall somewhere. I want the wired world to be wireless, and I want it right now.

Do you bother with old media? Absolutely. I haven't watched TV since I was 12, but I read the Wall Street Journal every morning, and the Financial Times. I have two six-foot tall bookcases of magazines - from Vogue to Red Herring to Industry Standard, Revolution, Marketing Week. You name it. I'm a magazine junkie. Radio occasionally, but not consistently, no.

Interview by Carolyne Ellis

fields.headline: Alien concepts
fields.standfirst: Something strange is happening to US tabloids. They are trying to go upmarket.  Edward Helmore  reports
fields.trailText: Something strange is happening to US tabloids. They are trying to go upmarket. Edward Helmore reports.
fields.body:
It could be the most shocking tabloid story in America - and one that they can't print. Splashed across newspaper delivery lorries making their rounds in the northeastern states of America are the words, "No Elvis. No Aliens. No UFOs." It's not, of course, that aliens have stopped abducting, or that Elvis no longer eats at Burger King, it's just that the new management at American Media, publisher of the National Enquirer, the Globe and the Star, has decreed that readers will no longer be hearing of it.

America's tabloids are undergoing a reinvention under the leadership of David Pecker, a 48-year-old alumnus of the French company that publishes glossy magazines such as Elle and George. He believes that the way to halt the precipitous drop in readership that all the supermarket tabloids have suffered over the past decade is to take them upmarket.

It was the Star that first alleged Bill Clinton's affair with Gennifer Flowers and it was the Enquirer that revealed OJ Simpson's ownership of a pair of Bruno Magli shoes - the very same that his wife's murderer apparently wore. Moreover, much of the running in the tales of Monica Lewinsky, John Kennedy Jr and murdered child beauty queen JonBenet Ramsey was made by the tabloids. But despite these successes, readership is falling. The National Enquirer's circulation has dropped from 3.1m in 1994 to 2.1m last year. Over the same period, the Star's figures slid from 2.8m to 1.8m and the Globe's from 1m to just over 800,000.

Under Pecker, American Media is attempting to re-brand, re-position or tweak its seven major titles to cover the spectrum from country music (Country Weekly) to the sensational to the super-weird: the National Examiner will focus on strange human interest stories; the Star on celebrity; the National Enquirer on credible, news-driven tales; the Globe will still dish the dirt on celebs; the Sun will focus on a more mature readership, with health-orientated and religious articles, and Weekly World News on nonsense such as the wedding of the world's fattest man.

Although Pecker has no news background and his experience is in accountancy and marketing, he has a clear idea of the role tabloids need to play to win back readership. "What tabloids stand for is to expose the hypocrisy of the rich and famous," he says. When he took over the company last year, he commissioned 5,000 consumer interviews to discover why only one out of eight people who flip through an American Media title at the supermarket checkout buys it. The answer? "They were fascinated. But they didn't believe it."

On his arrival, Pecker issued an edict: no more autopsy shots, no more Elvis sightings, no more UFOs. The tabloids would be entering an era of respectability, in which big-name advertisers would buy space, readers would return and journalists would want jobs. "The easiest way to look at it is, if a big Hollywood story breaks, the Enquirer would do investigative stories, the Star would cover the impact on the celebrity's career, and the Globe would really do the spicy parts of the story," Pecker says.

After banning adverts for psychic healers and miracle remedies, the titles have begun to attract new advertisers. The Enquirer has been redesigned with a sleeker, all-colour look, bolstered by an extra $3m for the editorial budget and backed with a $50m advertising campaign. In line with a new Enquirer slogan, "Get it first. Get it fast. Get it Right", old-style headlines such as "Kills Pal And Eats Pieces Of Flesh" have been toned down. And although Pecker defends his titles' chequebook jour nalism he has put a stop to traditional tabloid set-ups.

But many doubt that US tabloids can really change. "I can't imagine a transformation that would give them credibility," says Bob Steele, a specialist in journalistic ethics at the Poynter Institute in St Petersburg, Florida. "Good for them if they want to respect themselves. The question remains: What do they stand for as a news organisation?"

But 5m Americans who buy Pecker's tabloids know exactly why they do so, even if they don't believe everything they read. Will tamer tabloids succeed? Pecker thinks so: "I expect our current revenues of $500m will grow to $5 billion in 10 years, and we would be involved in magazines, internet, books, TV, movies and more." But no Elvis.

fields.headline: Opportunity knocks for Grayson
fields.trailText: It can be distinctly helpful to have the national captain as a county colleague. Paul Grayson was summoned to Kenya on the insistence of his Essex team-mate Nasser Hussain even though England's coach Duncan Fletcher admits he has scarcely seen him play.
fields.body:
It can be distinctly helpful to have the national captain as a county colleague. Paul Grayson was summoned to Kenya on the insistence of his Essex team-mate Nasser Hussain even though England's coach Duncan Fletcher admits he has scarcely seen him play.

Now, only three days after arriving as cover for the injured Ashley Giles, Grayson is contemplating his England debut in the ICC Knockout Trophy quarter-final tomorrow. He has been told to prepare to face South Africa, a hint that England will not stick faithfully to the XI that crushed Bangladesh by eight wickets last Thursday. It would complete an extraordinary few days for the left-arm spinner, who was selling beer for an Essex brewery that day.

If Grayson is selected, however, England must drop another player from the rest of the tournament. No country may have more than 14 in their squad and presumably either Giles or Vikram Solanki would be sacrificed to accommodate Grayson. Once a switch is made it cannot be reversed.

Grayson's only previous representative cricket was an England Under-19 tour of Australia 10 years ago. Since then he has experienced frustration at Yorkshire, leaving in 1996 to resurrect his career at Essex. The nearest he has since come to international recognition was inclusion in England's pre liminary 32-man World Cup squad two years ago.

After his first net practice yesterday Grayson, 29, said: "I was in and out of the side at Yorkshire and felt it was time for a change because I'd been there since I was 16. I feel more relaxed at Essex and better able to express myself. And certainly men such as Keith Fletcher, Graham Gooch and of course Nasser have helped me a lot.

"I've opened the batting for Essex for the past couple of years and I often bowl at the death in the one-day game. So I feel confident when operating in tight situations, although I'm not the biggest spinner of the ball.

"I've never given up hope of playing for England; I feel my best four or five years are yet to come. But I know that, apart from cricket followers, not many people have heard of me. They probably think that Paul Grayson fella must be talented: he's played rugby for England and now he's been called up by the cricket team!

"It was certainly a shock when David Graveney [England's chairman of selectors] called on Thursday to tell me to get ready to fly here. I don't know if I have a chance of playing against South Africa but I've been told to prepare as if I'm going to play."

Grayson was best man at Darren Gough's wedding in 1993, and the following year the roles were reversed. And they teamed up successfully at the players' golf day on Saturday.

fields.headline: Chailly
fields.standfirst:
RCO/Chailly
Royal Festival Hall, London *****
fields.trailText:
RCO/Chailly

Royal Festival Hall, London *****
fields.body:
It is almost 40 years since the British musicologist Deryck Cooke introduced his "performing version" of Mahler's Tenth Symphony and there have been at least three other attempts at an alternative completion since. But Cooke's has remained the most authoritative. Some conductors have refused to have anything to do with the score, preferring to conduct only the first movement of the Tenth, which Mahler completed before his death. But the younger generation, led by Riccardo Chailly and Simon Rattle, have been its consistent champions.

Chailly recorded the work while head of the Berlin Radio Symphony Orchestra, and now he has introduced it to the Royal Concertgebouw. The orchestra with the finest Mahler pedigree in the world played the Tenth Symphony for the first time in June, and on Friday brought it to the Festival Hall.

When conducted by Chailly (and Rattle, too) the work is utterly convincing. OK, the second movement, the first of the two scherzos in the arch-like scheme, is weak. But then none of Mahler's symphonies (save possibly the Sixth) is free of weaknesses; that unevenness is part of his creativity.

The rest of the work has many extraordinary moments; it is a farewell to life (and Alma especially) as eloquent as the Ninth, yet different: far less resigned and far less comfortable.

Chailly always makes that edge of anger and despair tell. He times the first movement's climax in a screaming nine-note dissonance perfectly, gives the incessant central movement a terrifying inevitability, and unfolds the final pages of the symphony with ethereal tenderness. But he is not afraid to let the rough edges show, too, or to give the Concertgebouw's fabulous wind players licence to shape their solos.

Such a towering performance could have been savoured on its own, but there was also Mahler to begin the programme: the five Ruckert songs delivered with effortlessly-judged variation of colour and phrasing by the baritone Matthias Goerne. The way he darkened his voice for the final stanzas of "Ich bin der Welt" was a minor miracle in its own right.

Radio 3, Wednesday, 7.30pm.

webTitle: Uncaring image must change, says leaked Barclays report

fields.headline: Uncaring image must change, says leaked Barclays report
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Barclays is to parachute in 10 top executives to new regional offices in a desperate effort to eradicate its image as a greedy, uncaring, sub-standard bank.
fields.body:
Barclays is to parachute in 10 top executives to new regional offices in a desperate effort to eradicate its image as a greedy, uncaring, sub-standard bank.

The initiative to tackle its damaged reputation is revealed in a leaked report in which executives frankly admit the "significant impact" on its brand by the negative publicity generated earlier this year by cash machine charging, closures and the £30m potential pay deal of chief executive Matt Barrett.

The "PR and image restoration plan", dubbed project Phoenix, was submitted to the bank's executive committee in June and recommends the appointment of a "brand tzar" to oversee the image restoration following the furore generated by its "big" advertising campaign.

The report acknowledges that the bank's products do not meet the standards of its rivals. "It is felt that the group has become idle internally on value proposition and been too hooked on premium pricing and customer inertia," the report said. The report warns that the bank is regarded as "the ringleader of anti-consumer measures" and "arrogant". It also sets out a plans to create a "proper audit trail" to review communications in an attempt to prevent documents being leaked.

In what industry sources regarded as the most basic of PR practices, the report calls for "one positive PR announcement a month" linked in an 18-24 month programme of initiatives.

This programme would involve targeting customer, community and social affairs, rural and inner city support initiatives.

The report calls for the bank to prove that its "big" advertising campaign does mean it is not uncaring. "Being 'big' means the group can donate £20m per annum to a community and social affairs programme."

A Barclays official said the report's summary was what the bank needed to do to learn from experiences earlier this year.

"It is felt that the group has become idle internally on value proposition and been too hooked on premium pricing and customer inertia," the report said. The report warns that the bank is regarded as "the ringleader of anti-consumer measures" and "arrogant". It also sets out a plans to create a "proper audit trail" to review communications in an attempt to prevent documents being leaked. In what industry sources regarded as the most basic of PR practices, the report calls for "one positive PR announcement a month" linked in an 18-24 month programme of initiatives. This programme would involve targeting customer, community and social affairs, rural and inner city support initiatives. The report calls for the bank to prove that its "big" advertising campaign does mean it is not uncaring. "Being 'big' means the group can donate £20m per annum to a community and social affairs programme." A Barclays official said the report's summary was what the bank needed to do to learn from experiences earlier this year.

fields.headline: Deep, dark drum'n'bass
fields.standfirst:
Reprazent/ MJ Cole
Manchester Academy ****
fields.trailText:
Reprazent/ MJ Cole
Manchester Academy ****
fields.body:
"Wanna take a ride on the wild side?" asks Elizabeth Troy and a few hundred faces light up as the band start to play their hit single Sincere. The irony is that MJ Cole wouldn't recognise "wild" if it jumped up and bit them on the backside.

One song slides into another as Cole sits on the left of the stage composing slick pop symphonies on his keyboard while a singer and MC take centre stage with Troy. All nine tracks elicit much hip-shaking and wolf whistling, but the song that creates a collision of bodies is the ultra smooth, romantic paean Crazy Love. Tonight MJ Cole managed to make the coffee-table music of the millennium sound positively energetic.

It is only two years since Reprazent won the Mercury music prize with New Forms, but drum'n'bass is no longer deemed fashionable or relevant. Reviews of Reprazent's new album, In the Mode, have reinforced this - saying it sounds dated and predictable. The Bristol eight-piece would beg to differ, and so would tonight's audience.

While Die, Krust, Rob, Suv, Si-John and The Zealous Missionary (Size himself) build layers of tension, MC Dynamite spends the whole gig pacing up and down the stage delivering superb vocal licks. Things get even better when singer Onallee joins them for old favourites Brown Paper Bag, Railing and Heroes.

New tracks In and Out, Balance Chaos and Out of the Game find Reprazent swimming in deeper, darker waters - and it works brilliantly. One track that doesn't translate well live is the new single, Who Told You You Could Do That? The band try their hardest but Dynamite can't quite muster the aggressive raps. They follow it up with a breathtaking new track called Heavy Rotation. The set closes with mellow renditions of Trust Me, Share the Fall and Brown Paper Bag (again). As long as Reprazent are around, drum'n'bass is alive and kicking.

Reprazent and MJ Cole play UEA, Norwich (01603 505401), tomorrow, then tour.

fields.headline: Red Marauder
fields.standfirst:
Red Marauder
Tramway, Glasgow ****
fields.trailText:
Red Marauder
Tramway, Glasgow ****
fields.body:
A sleeping bag covered in red sequins lies on the floor. It's the loveliest thing, like a jewel, but warm and inviting . Though uselessly ornate, it is madly covetable. It makes you think about plundering, pilfering, or at least climbing inside. It threatens to make a marauder of you. The bag, by Neal Beggs, is the first thing you see as you step into this confident and, in places, thrilling show of work by 1998 graduates of Glasgow School of Art's well-regarded postgraduate programme.

Each artist was commissioned by Tramway to produce new work for this exhibition and, though there is no linking theme, there is something approaching commonality in tone: spare, underplayed almost, a small gesture rather than grand, an absence of overt political engagement (which you might expect from the title) and, instead, a fascination with stories, the everyday, the stuff around us.

Ian Balch strews six interconnected works around the huge space under a long title: Is she forever seeking, even though she does not know it, something he has lost? It's a phrase that could apply to trying to fathom, in an unlabelled show full of small objects, whose work is whose. You soon get to know Balch's, though: small, almost missable quirks, with unexpected impact. Tiny bits of what could be industrial objects painted in metallic paint, fuschia, apple green and turquoise.

Mary Redmond treats her materials as if they are sweeties to produce a playfulness, a punky energy in her work, which in fact consists of corrugated iron, metal fencing and sickly pink fabric. She has an eye for making us look again at things we give no more than a glance - a red plastic chair, broken bed frame, straggly bits of wire.

Though much of Redmond's impact is in the misalliance between the materials she selects and their place in the gallery, she has a fine eye for dramatic detail: the pink leatherette crumpled over a broken bed-frame; the busted chair hung up on the wall like a useless bunch of keys - they are intriguing fragments, broken stories.

Acts of appropriation run through the show, keeping up that marauding theme. Alan Michael's paintings beg, steal and borrow from album sleeves, work by American artists, posters and magazines. Kevin Kelly's Monkey Palace - a zoo with no captive animals - explores "the ubiquity of the monkey". Yes, that's right. That means the PG Tips adverts of old, and much more monkey business besides.

Until November 5. Details: 0141-422 2023.

fields.headline: Mademoiselle Colombe
fields.standfirst:
Mademoiselle Colombe
Bridewell, London *
fields.trailText:
Mademoiselle Colombe
Bridewell, London *
fields.body:
The London Stage Company has apparently commissioned Phyllis Nagy and Rebecca Prichard, two of the most exciting young writers around, so why it should launch itself with this tired tat is a mystery. Jean Anouilh's boulevard comedy probably looked old-fashioned on its premiere in 1951, the decade that gave us Beckett, Ionesco and John Osborne. Now it looks as if it came out of the ark. It gets a production to match - slow, lugubrious and full of the kind of fussy acting that went out with the actor-manager. There were times during this three-hour evening when I longed to spontaneously combust.

The play is set in 19th-century Paris. Julien, a would-be musician, turns up at the theatre where his mother the famous actress and Grande dame Madame Alexandra is playing. Mother and son are estranged, largely because they see life very differently. He detests the theatre; she revels in it. He loathes her way of life and accounts of her sexual exploits; she loves telling tales about her lovers and husbands.

But Julien has a problem. He has been called up for military service, is determined to do his duty, but realises that this will leave his young wife, Colombe, and small baby alone and destitute. Only his mother can help, and she does, taking Colombe into the company. The inevitable happens as Colombe discovers the plea sures of the stage and life.

I assume that the audience is supposed to initially take Julien's part and only gradually come round to the view that Colombe's journey is not one from innocence to corruption but from puritanism to pleasure. The message is that Madame Alexandra might be an old monster but she is a wise one, aware that if you have fun yourself you also give pleasure to others. But the route by which we get there is so well-signposted and so full of artifice that it doesn't make for an interesting journey, particularly as truth is constantly sacrificed to bon mots and whimsy. The only thing that seriously interested me was the complete and mysterious absence of the baby. Presumably, like the play, it quickly gave up the ghost and died of neglect.

As Madame Alexandra, Honor Blackman gives one of those star turns that make you feel dizzy to watch and as Colombe Sophie Bold has charm but little depth. This is just the kind of evening that gives weight to those commentators who gleefully queue up to write theatre's obituary.

Until November 5. Box office: 020-7936 3456.

fields.headline: Banks braced for 'windfall tax'
fields.standfirst:
Industry claims it faces charges of up £400m a year to pay for social security accounts
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: High street banks face a recurring "windfall tax" of up to £400m every year to pay for the government's planned universal bank, according to industry executives.
fields.body:
High street banks face a recurring "windfall tax" of up to £400m every year to pay for the government's planned universal bank, according to industry executives.

Bankers say they that under current proposals the industry will have to stump up running costs - estimated to be at least £150m and as much as £400m - for more than 3m bank accounts used by people on social security.

One banking source said: "Is it time to throw up a levy on banks - a windfall tax? This is money we are being asked to pay up and our shareholders might want to know [why]."

Bankers are anxious for clarification of the government's estimates of the cost, and the state's contribution, to running the bank which is being created to help facilitate the payment of social security di rectly into bank accounts rather than cash.

The government will tell the banks this week precisely what the cost is and how it will be met. Ministers will also tell the banks that it should be run by one institution with the cost shared across the industry and expects the financial services sector to display its "social responsibility". The government has made it clear that it does not intend to levy a "windfall tax" in the way it did on utilities three years ago. Many of the banks believe the universal bank in post offices duplicates existing efforts and lacks commercial logic because it will always run at a loss.

This is because they expect the account holders, predominately people on social security, to withdraw all their money on the day it goes into the account, giving the bank no opportunity to make a profit. Industry experts are reluctant to reveal their estimates of the cost of running the universal bank but they range from £150m to £400m for each year of the bank's operation. The £400m appears to based on the amount of money the Post Office faces losing as a result of the automation of benefits payments.

The concern about the recurrent nature of the cost ap pears to have mounted following a meeting last month between Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, and the chief executives of the big banking groups.

Alan Johnson, the Post Office minister, said last night: "Some points have since been raised by the banks and we will respond to these fully in the next few days."

One banking source said: "The government needs £400m [to cover lost revenues for the Post Office]. This is a tax recurring every year."

Another industry source, who put the cost lower, in the region of £150m, still saw it as a "lot of money" to provide bank accounts to an estimated pool of 3.5m people - a cost of at least £50 per person per year.

The Treasury, refusing to comment on the size of estimates, said that discussions would continue.

fields.headline: Courtney's Brummie sunsplash
fields.standfirst:
Courtney Pine
The Drum, Birmingham ****
fields.trailText:
Courtney Pine
The Drum, Birmingham ****
fields.body:
The multicultural Drum arts centre in Birmingham's Aston district is the perfect venue for Courtney Pine and his mission to bring Brit-jazz out of the shadows and closer to the mainstream. After a blast of Pine's polyglot polyrhythms, audiences can find themselves speaking in new tongues.

The atmosphere inside is feverish and intense. People are standing on chairs, screaming and punching the air. Some are wiggling their hips as if at the Reggae Sunsplash in Jamaica. As Pine stands at the microphone and claps his hands above his head, the floor starts to bounce up and down like the Forth Bridge in an earthquake. A rock star would be delighted with the reaction, though he'd be surprised to find his audience was 95% black.

And I thought this was supposed to be jazz, where the cognoscenti pay homage to the artists' daunting mastery of advanced harmonic theory and chord substitutions. Not that Pine can't play a harmolodic scale with the best of them, but he's been fighting this particular war ever since he was a teenager. For some, "jazz" will always mean Miles Davis, John Coltrane and Charlie Mingus, but that was 40 years ago. Pine has already absorbed the post-war greats of American jazz. Now, he's squaring up to the tougher task of forging a modern - and authentically British - musical idiom.

I'm not convinced by the directions Pine pursues on his new CD, Back in the Day: I don't follow how respectful Joan Armatrading cover versions or extracts from Curtis Mayfield's soul catalogue square with Courtney's aim of developing a language that will reach a younger audience. But Pine seems to find all the justification he needs when he gets in front of a live audience and starts blowing the house apart. His band, dressed in a carnival of patterns and colours, erupts with thunderous expertise and joie de vivre. Cross-rhythms dart and surge.

Pine himself is a walking encyclopedia of advanced saxophony, ripping out fiery Coltrane-esque note clusters and plumbing the tenor's bass register like a musical Jacques Cousteau. At the climax of the set Pine stood, arms outstretched, sustaining an absurdly long note through a feat of circular breathing. For a finale, he played an unaccompanied rendition of Bob Marley's Redemption Song, the audience quickly picking up the chorus. Then, with a symbolic flourish, he whipped off his beret and shook out the braided locks beneath. He may be pure musician, but there's an increasingly confident showman in there, too.

Courtney Pine plays the Fleece and Firkin, Bristol (0117-945 0996), on Thursday, then tours.

fields.headline: Swedes up LSE offer
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Swedish company OM Gruppen hinted yesterday it was willing to make a higher offer in its bid to takeover the London Stock Exchange. OM's present offer of around £800m was rejected last week by a majority of LSE members. But the company which operates the Swedish bourse believes the price is the only problem with its bid.
fields.body:
Swedish company OM Gruppen hinted yesterday it was willing to make a higher offer in its bid to takeover the London Stock Exchange. OM's present offer of around £800m was rejected last week by a majority of LSE members. But the company which operates the Swedish bourse believes the price is the only problem with its bid.

"OM feel they've already won most of the arguments. They feel the strategy has been accepted. The superior technology has been recognised. And that they have management to take things forward," a company spokesman said. "That really just leaves the money issue," he added.

Reports yesterday suggested OM could raise its bid to more than £1bn. Its offer values a LSE share at about £25, below Friday's close of £29.50.

The LSE has described OM's bid as "derisory", and so far the Swedish company has approval of just 1% of shareholders. It has extended the offer period until October 23.

A spokeswoman for the LSE refused to comment on the story. "If OM are going to make another bid, that is up to them," she said.

Until now, OM has insisted that its superior management, technology and service made up for the low offer, but the LSE has responded by promising to shake up its leadership and speed up change in a bid to woo back the disgruntled smaller brokers.

In a speech on Saturday the chairman of the exchange, Don Cruickshank, pledged to listen to the critics whose opposition helped scupper the London exchange's plans to merge with the Deustche Börse earlier this year.

fields.headline: Clearlake
fields.standfirst:
Clearlake
Manchester University ****
fields.trailText:
Clearlake
Manchester University ****
fields.body:
Clearlake are actually from Brighton. But, in their heads, they're citizens of Clearlake where Auntie Humane runs the Play'n' Slay kindergarten abbatoir, and where Finch-Mooking and synchronised rioting are popular pastimes.

Live, there is little evidence of such eccentricity. Singer- guitarist Jason Pegg (rake thin, wide eyes peeping from beneath blonde, page-boy hair) has a quiet star quality, but essentially they're four indie blokes. "We started playing it on Sunday," Pegg remarks, of the perfectly gloomy Sunday Evening, "but it's just become more irrelevant as the days have gone by." Granted, he's a little odd but it's low-key which, given Clearlake's tendency to grandiose, windswept epics, is just as well. They're extravagant enough as it is.

"The song is king," Pegg has declared, previously. And their songs are, indeed, disarmingly heartfelt. Thankfully, they're not set in some imaginary hybrid of Trumpton and Royston Vasey. Instead, Clearlake, the place, is a distant backdrop that gently informs their peculiarly English mixture of whimsy, romantic lyricism and dry, everyday observation.

Similarly, they hover above a bizarre confluence of musical influences; Klaus Wunderlich, The Smiths, The Cardiacs and prog-rockers Caravan, to name but a few. Many songs are almost movements that can turn on a penny, the pastoral folk-harmonies, and almost chintzy psychedelia of, say, Life Can Be So Cruel, weaving Clearlake into a lineage you can trace back through XTC to Pink Floyd.

Lyrically, even, Pegg flits between the romantic - musing on the quality of sunlight in winter - and the direct and pithy. "If you don't like yourself," he asks, "how will anybody else?"

Their two singles thus far, Don't Let The Cold In and Winterlight, are quite sublime. Both are Spector-ish whirlpools of sound, supercharged guitars, reminiscent of both Ride and the Cocteau Twins, creating a vortex for the unbowed Pegg. Half Syd Barret, half Damon Albarn, he's the boy-balladeer, straining for the stars like Scott Walker's scrawnier brother.

Merging intelligence, a certain artifice and raw emotion is difficult. But there's something genuine and ambitious about Clearlake's kaleidoscopic music, and something rather innocent and unstructured about their crazy world. Take it all as seriously as you will. The songs, however, will possess you.

Clearlake play the Junction, Cambridge (01223 511511), tonight, then tour.

Similarly, they hover above a bizarre confluence of musical influences; Klaus Wunderlich, The Smiths, The Cardiacs and prog-rockers Caravan, to name but a few. Many songs are almost movements that can turn on a penny, the pastoral folk-harmonies, and almost chintzy psychedelia of, say, Life Can Be So Cruel, weaving Clearlake into a lineage you can trace back through XTC to Pink Floyd. Lyrically, even, Pegg flits between the romantic - musing on the quality of sunlight in winter - and the direct and pithy. "If you don't like yourself," he asks, "how will anybody else?" Their two singles thus far, Don't Let The Cold In and Winterlight, are quite sublime. Both are Spector-ish whirlpools of sound, supercharged guitars, reminiscent of both Ride and the Cocteau Twins, creating a vortex for the unbowed Pegg. Half Syd Barret, half Damon Albarn, he's the boy-balladeer, straining for the stars like Scott Walker's scrawnier brother. Merging intelligence, a certain artifice and raw emotion is difficult. But there's something genuine and ambitious about Clearlake's kaleidoscopic music, and something rather innocent and unstructured about their crazy world. Take it all as seriously as you will. The songs, however, will possess you. Clearlake play the Junction, Cambridge (01223 511511), tonight, then tour.

fields.headline: Tavener's prison premiere with a choir of inmates
fields.standfirst:
Ikons of Light
Royal Festival Hall/ Pentonville Prison, London ***
fields.trailText:
Ikons of Light
Royal Festival Hall/ Pentonville Prison, London ***
fields.body:
It's easy to be blinded to the qualities of John Tavener's music. For his devotees, Tavener's sensuous spirituality is a serene corrective to the complexities of musical modernism. For his detractors, the directness of his musical language and his intention to make music a form of religious iconography, signal a disengaged personality who would ignore the richness of the modern world. The South Bank's three-week series Ikons of Light presents Tavener's work alongside his inspirations, from Byzantine choirs to Stravinsky: it gives a rare opportunity to assess Tavener's music on its own terms.

In the first week, Tavener's Agraphon, written in 1995, was striking. A setting of the poetry of Angelos Sikelianos, the piece was performed on Wednesday by Patricia Rozario (one of Tavener's champions), with Richard Hickox and the City of London Sinfonia. The text, based on folk tales of Christ's life, is earthily descriptive. Christ admonishes the disciples for ignoring a dead dog; Jesus sees the rotting corpse as a route to the divine. Founded on Tavener's technique of repeating large paragraphs of material, the varied setting encompasses apocalyptic peals of timpani for "the harsh lightning of God's justice", while the soprano's concentration represents Jesus's rapt contemplation.

The work's rigorous focus on melodic fragments betrays Tavener's love of Stravinsky. The London Sinfonietta's Saturday concert presented Stravinsky's 1956 Canticum Sacrum, the work that made Tavener decide to become a composer, alongside Tavener's The Protecting Veil, his most popular work.

On the surface, the contrasts between the two composers are obvious: Stravinsky's complexity seems rooted in a different conception of music from Tavener's slow-breathed melodiousness. Yet the performances, from cellist Raphael Wallfisch in The Protecting Veil, and conductor David Atherton, revealed the connections between these musical icons. Atherton turned the austere Canticum Sacrum into a kaleidoscope of structure and spirituality. The same humanising zeal was at the heart of The Protecting Veil, as Wallfisch's impassioned playing caught a large-scale drama behind the surface of Tavener's static architecture.

The most telling demonstration of the human engagement of Tavener's music came in the London Sinfonietta's concerts in Her Majesty's Prison, Pentonville, London. A choir of inmates gave the world premiere of Tavener's In One Single Moment. Their gritty performances movingly articulated the solidity of Tavener's seemingly simple idiom.

Often when Tavener attempts to integrate worldly concerns into his musical universe, characters are reduced to ciphers. His casting of the saxophone as the evil agent of temptation seems naive, as does his use of the kaval, a primitive woodwind instrument, as a metaphor for preternatural goodness. The work's violent contrasts were, however, well defined by conductor Richard Hickox and a starry team of soloists.

fields.headline: Sitkovetsky
fields.standfirst:
Camerata/ Sitkovetsky
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester ****
fields.trailText:
Camerata/ Sitkovetsky
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester ****
fields.body:
To conduct a Mozart or Bach concerto while also playing the solo part is difficult but normal, and in fact historically correct. To try the same with mature Beethoven, and particularly with his violin concerto, would seem foolhardy. There are many violin concertos with technically harder passages, but none that so challenge the soloist's poise.

It is never cool to admire a musician just for doing something difficult. But Dmitri Sitkovetsky's achievement was jaw-dropping. Certainly there were tentative moments in the first movement, and the Manchester Camerata were probably as nervous as anybody. But once things got moving they turned the piece into pure chamber music. The delicacy of the interchanges in the slow movement was magical; and in the closing passages of the last movement they generated an electricity beyond what I have ever experienced in the work. Sitkovetsky's consistently vital and assured playing was as astonishing as his consistent individuality of interpretation.

Earlier he had been both conductor and arranger, with his adaptation of Dohnanyi's Serenade for String Trio as a work for string orchestra. In its new guise, this marvellous work becomes a welcome addition to the repertory. There may be passages that are hard for an ensemble, though. The plucked lines in the second movement have the kind of shape that can be made graceful by a solo player but tended to sound pedestrian in the hands of a group of musicians concentrating on getting them together. But the warmth of the Camerata strings glowed so often that everybody must have been grateful for Sitkovetsky's imaginative, stylish arrangement of a work that is far too rarely heard.

He opened the concert, and the Manchester Camerata's new season, with a marvellously judged reading of Haydn's Symphony No 102. Sitkovestky's does not look like a normal conductor: he stands there almost like an old-style bandmaster. But every detail was made to seem effortless, and the wit of the music flowed gloriously.

fields.headline: Bye Kevin, Hi Wilko
fields.standfirst: All change at Lancaster Gate as Howard Wilkinson picks up the pieces again
fields.trailText: All change at Lancaster Gate as Howard Wilkinson picks up the pieces again.
fields.body:
Gloomy England begin life without their most optimistic supporter, Kevin Keegan, this morning. The manager who has always been honest to a fault took a close look at himself minutes after succumbing to Germany and recognised he could take England no further. Amid frantic, emotionally fuelled scenes in the dressing room the Keegan era - never a dull moment - was over.

After beating the old foe in Euro 2000, probably his finest hour-and-a-half at the helm, he expressed his hope that the tide of German superiority had turned. 'I hope we make them pay as we've had to pay,' he purred. Four months later, defiance gave way to doom as he paid the ultimate price and walked away from football. He leaves England playing catch-up one game into World Cup qualification.

Japan and South Korea in the summer of 2002 looks a very, very long way away, no matter how you look at it. In the short term it is destination Helsinki, and if England want any chance to revive a qualification campaign which began in the worst possible taste, victory is essential.

As Gareth Southgate points out: 'We've got to regroup quickly and make sure we win on Wednesday to rectify things immediately. In qualification for Euro 2000, we lost our opening game in Sweden and drew the next game at home to Bulgaria. We have to make sure we lift ourselves. Players will be stung into action.'

And how they need to be, to prevent the possibility of another competition faltering against Scandinavian opposition. The 1984 European Championship was scuppered by a goal from Denmark's Alan Simonsen. Norway's turn came when a 2-0 triumph began the rot which accounted for Graham Taylor and the 1984 World Cup. Sweden took up the baton in the turbulent approach to Euro 2000. Is it time for Finland?

England fly to Helsinki this week in a state of turmoil. They will be bolstered slightly by Greece's 1-0 home win over Finland yesterday thanks to Panathinaikos striker Nikos Liberopoulos's goal. But, while that result means England are not yet out of the reckoning, Finland showed enough tenacity to suggest they will be no pushovers at home and that, coupled with England's own current lack of self-belief, could yet lead to an upset.

All of which Howard Wilkinson, the man responsible for picking up England's shattered morale and selecting a team to claim much- needed points (with David Beckham, the most influential player, a worrying doubt), is aware of.

In temporary charge for the second time, he faces a far more critical task than on his previous experience, when a 2-0 defeat in a friendly against France at Wembley saw his charges thoroughly outclassed as the World Champions taught England a lesson.

As did Germany yesterday. For two nations wallowing in the international doldrums during last summer's European Championship, there couldn't have been a greater contrast in the way they have responded. Rudi Voller's men were well drilled, moved fluently, and each player looked comfortable with his role, to make them an individually and collectively efficient outfit.

Southgate admitted England did not do themselves justice: 'Everybody will have their opinions on formations but we have to take responsibility as players. I don't think we played well enough in the first half. We didn't perform. We livened up in the second half but we were chasing the game then.

'We didn't look like creating enough chances and we've given away a sloppy goal. It's bitterly disappointing to be beaten by them. The first game of the group, against Germany, the last game at Wembley . . . we all wanted to go out on a high. It didn't happen.'

A sense of shock shuddered through the old stadium as the last hurrah turned into a wake. After the debacle of Euro 2000, a creditable draw in Paris last month was supposed to herald a new dawn for England. It turned out to be yet another false one.

Why did they fail to carry that confidence through? Why did players in key positions struggle to spark? Paul Scholes and Nick Barmby, in particular, were poor imitations of the creative attacking forces expected of them.

David Seaman is also under fierce scrutiny for the blunder so ruthlessly capitalised on by Dietmar Hamann. Southgate tried to exonerate the 37-year-old keeper, suggesting they were all culpable.

'We didn't get a wall organised in time. Dave wanted two men in front of it and I think we were all looking at each other, waiting for each other to get in the wall. He couldn't see it until very late and it skidded up off the surface. It's not a question of blaming David at all. We need to sit down and have a think about the way things have gone. We'll probably watch the game again and see things we could have done differently.'

Perhaps Finland will choose a different video to psyche themselves up, by borrowing the legendary Norwegian commentary from the moment England's Scandinavian troubles began: 'We beat the best in the world! We beat England! Lord Nelson, Lord Beaverbrook, Sir Winston Churchill, Sir Anthony Eden, Clement Attlee, Henry Cooper, Lady Diana . . . Maggie Thatcher, can you hear me? Maggie Thatcher, your boys took one hell of a beating!'

Keegan said that if he left one legacy, he at least left a team with good spirit. That was hard to detect as they made their final journey down the Wembley tunnel, a grim-faced set of silent, sorry, shameful players.

Another 90 minutes of hurt to add to the annals. Reaction to Keegan's departure was - under FA orders - restricted to pursed lips and evasive eyes. Now it's time for the supposed cream of the country's footballers to stand up, speak up, play up, and be counted.

fields.headline: Germans polish off Keegan
fields.standfirst:
England 0 - 1 Germany

England v Germany: a rivalry of two halves

England under Sven - Observer special
fields.trailText: Wembley is history, as is England's all-too-brief period of respite against the Germans and Kevin Keegan's tenure as manager.
fields.body:
Wembley is history, as is England's all-too-brief period of respite against the Germans and Kevin Keegan's tenure as manager.

Collecting their second successive victory in World Cup qualifying Group Nine, and consigning England to an ominous defeat which finally made Keegan's hold on the manager's job untenable, Germany played as if their defeat in Euro 2000 was somewhere between a blip and a bad memory.

For England all their bad memories are now flooding back, complete with the familiar elephant trap of a game against little-known and easily underrated Scandinavian opponents in three days. They had gone into this game full of confidence after their draw in France and that epoch-ending victory in Belgium, but a combination of a heavy pitch and a return to normal standards of Teutonic efficiency sucked out all their energy and creativity.

It was easy to imagine, after a performance as grey and soggy as the shocking weather, that it might be another 34 years before England can beat this lot.

Especially as England spent 77 minutes chasing the game. Germany would have been well content with a draw from this fixture, but as England allowed them to take the lead from a shambolic set- piece as early as the 13th minute, the pattern of the afternoon was set. Germany have only ever lost one World Cup qualifying game, and they did not earn a record like that by refusing gifts or failing to protect a lead.

It was obvious from the opening 10 minutes that Germany under Rudi Voller were going to be a different proposition from the spiritless bunch who looked so bereft of inspiration in Charleroi. Within that space of time, the dangerous Mehmet Scholl had already demonstrated skill and steel, as well as intelligently drifting out to the right to make it more difficult for Gareth Southgate to mark him.

England attempted a high- tempo opening, with David Beckham coming in from the right to add authority to the midfield, though their movement was predictable. Tellingly, Andy Cole was caught offside twice in the opening exchanges, on the first occasion demanding and receiving a pass from Beckham when the linesman's flag was bound to be raised.

Germany are supposed to be the predictable party in this long rivalry, but they effectively laid that jibe to rest moments later, taking the lead with as smart a goal as Wembley has seen in all its 77 years. There appeared no immediate danger when Paul Scholes gave away a free-kick against Michael Ballack 25 yards out, which presumably explains why England thought they had all day to organise a wall. David Seaman was too busy barking out orders to Tony Adams and company to notice Dietmar Hamann shaping to take the kick quickly - though the goalkeeper managed to compose himself right at the last moment - and the Liverpool midfielder's shot was as sharp as his reactions.

Seaman has recently been talking about setting himself a target of the World Cup finals in 2002, but being beaten low to his left by a shot from well outside the area hardly bodes well for a 37-year-old, even assuming England get to Japan and Korea.

Just to prove Germans have a sense of humour, the travelling supporters spent the rest of the first half accusing the English of only singing when they are winning. The rather witless response from the home fans was 'Stand up if you won the war', which suggests English terrace humour is not what it was. Then again, neither is the football.

A ripple of excitement passed through the crowd when Beckham shaped to take a free-kick from a similar range to Hamann's, though the comparison was not flat tering. Beckham took an age, then when the shot finally came it flew straight into Oliver Kahn's midriff.

Marco Bode then went close with yet another free- kick after Adams had fouled Scholl, before Cole received a yellow card for a tackle from behind on the same player.

Cole did bring a couple of saves from Kahn just after the half-hour but England's best chance of the first half came just before the interval, when Adams found space to meet a Beckham free-kick with a glancing header, but Kahn responded with his best save, diving low to his right to hold the ball.

England brought on Kieron Dyer for Gary Neville at half-time, calling time on Southgate's midfield career by switching to a back three, with the substitute operating as right wing-back. It looked like a gamble, but at least Dyer looked the part, injecting pace and enthusiasm into a flagging English attack and almost immediately producing a cross from the right which Jens Nowotny had to scramble clear from Cole.

The downside was space behind Dyer for the Germans to attack, an invitation accepted by the irrepressible Scholl after 52 minutes, when he skipped almost unchallenged on the left and into England's penalty area. An extravagant check took him past Martin Keown but Scholl scuffed his shot and Seaman was able to redeem himself with a save low to his left.

Far from sitting on their lead Germany were actively looking for another goal, alert enough to realise that England's desperation was forcing them to take risks in defence. England kept going forward doggedly, though Paul Scholes was not enjoying one of his better days and there was depressingly little for Cole or Michael Owen to work with. Beckham pro duced a fingertip save from Kahn on the hour with a fiercely dipping shot from 25 yards, but it was significant that England had been reduced to hopeful efforts from outside the penalty area.

Beckham was narrowly wide with another long shot four minutes before making way for Ray Parlour in the 82nd minute. Scholes and Dyer came into the game more in its closing stages, but Germany should have had a second when Nowotny and Bierhoff got in each other's way seven minutes from time. A few boos could be heard at the end. It was a sad way to leave Wembley, but at least it didn't go to penalties.

England: Seaman, G.Neville (Dyer 46), Adams, Keown, Le Saux (Barry 77), Beckham (Parlour 82), Southgate, Scholes, Barmby, Cole, Owen. Subs not used : Martyn, Heskey, Wise, Phillips.

Germany: Kahn, Rehmer, Nowotny, Linke, Deisler, Ramelow, Hamann, Bode (Ziege 86), Ballack, Scholl, Bierhoff. Subs not used: Lehmann, Rink, Beinlich, Wosz, Baumann, Neuville.

Referee : Stefano Braschi (Italy).

An extravagant check took him past Martin Keown but Scholl scuffed his shot and Seaman was able to redeem himself with a save low to his left. Far from sitting on their lead Germany were actively looking for another goal, alert enough to realise that England's desperation was forcing them to take risks in defence. England kept going forward doggedly, though Paul Scholes was not enjoying one of his better days and there was depressingly little for Cole or Michael Owen to work with. Beckham pro duced a fingertip save from Kahn on the hour with a fiercely dipping shot from 25 yards, but it was significant that England had been reduced to hopeful efforts from outside the penalty area. Beckham was narrowly wide with another long shot four minutes before making way for Ray Parlour in the 82nd minute. Scholes and Dyer came into the game more in its closing stages, but Germany should have had a second when Nowotny and Bierhoff got in each other's way seven minutes from time. A few boos could be heard at the end. It was a sad way to leave Wembley, but at least it didn't go to penalties.
