Germany: Kahn, Rehmer, Nowotny, Linke, Deisler, Ramelow, Hamann, Bode (Ziege 86), Ballack, Scholl, Bierhoff. Subs not used: Lehmann, Rink, Beinlich, Wosz, Baumann, Neuville. Referee : Stefano Braschi (Italy).

fields.headline: Keegan's shambles
fields.standfirst:
When will English football stop harking back to old glories, rather than acknowledging them honourably and moving on? Not until it has a team to drag its game into the modern era, it seems

England under Sven - Observer special
fields.trailText: It was the last refuge of the inadequate. Half-time neared, England were a goal down and a sizeable section of the crowd sullied the ever-dampening occasion. 'Stand up if you won the War,' they sang.
fields.body:
It was the last refuge of the inadequate. Half-time neared, England were a goal down and a sizeable section of the crowd sullied the ever-dampening occasion. 'Stand up if you won the War,' they sang.

When will English football stop harking back to old glories, rather than acknowledging them honourably and moving on? Not until it has a team to drag its game into the modern era, it seems. And that is unlikely to happen until it gets a coach able to do justice to a talented group of players ill-served by its leaders. That coach is not Kevin Keegan, who thankfully has gone.

Even if England achieve victory in Finland on Wednesday night must not disguise the shortcomings of a coach and transmitted to his team. Hang the cost, the FA should accept that Keegan, a decent man out of his depth and feeling forced to be untrue to himself last week by lying to the media, that the unequal struggle was over for him before this match.

The lesson of Terry Venables's era as coach was that in modern international football it is vital not to lose the numbers game in midfield, that to fail to match the opposition there was to be outmanoeuvred. In Glenn Hoddle's time, it was evident that movement up front by thoughtful, lively attackers was crucial. The bridge between the two was Teddy Sheringham, a player who caused midfield opponents to drop deeper, defenders to worry whether to stay or step forward.

Keegan seemed to have absorbed little of the evidence and trends of the past five years. In fact, he seems to have absorbed little of the evidence of his own period in charge. His method, such as can be discerned, appeared to be that he took advice from all around him - senior players, coaching staff - then did exactly what he was planning to do all along anyway, ignoring precedent, mixing and matching selections. It was knee-jerk management.

Yesterday, for example, the starting selection featured five defenders and five attackers and the team duly had a them-and-us feel about it, always likely to be stretched as Newcastle United used to be on their bad days. They turned Keegan's hair grey. England has given him bags under the eyes. Sleepless in Slough.

Among the plethora of pointers from Charleroi in the summer was that a willing but bemused Gareth Southgate is ill-suited these days to a holding role in midfield and that David Seaman's time had probably gone in the English goal. The promise of Paris was seen in a formation that had a lone striker backed by a floating figure, in the shape of Paul Scholes, who could balance the equation in midfield and disrupt a defensive formation.

It had the bonus of bringing David Beckham's talents into positions of more frequent influence and even of pleasing the players, who believed they were at last operating in a system that showcased their talents. So what Keegan's response? Play two up front, Southgate in midfield and push Beckham wide on the right.

You could just about see what Keegan was attempting. Just about. Southgate was to drop in between Martin Keown and Tony Adams when England were defending. The full-backs Gary Neville and Graeme Le Saux were to push forward, taking Germany's wing-backs with them, enabling Beckham and Nicky Barmby to tuck inside rather than be marooned on the flanks. Scholes was to dart between Andy Cole and Michael Owen.

The reality was, however, that it was a selection neither fish nor fowl. Freed of some imagined obligation to pick Alan Shearer, England should have been able to field a more mobile, flexible attacking force but it was back to the two up with Keegan unable to be brave and keep either Cole or Owen on the bench, preferably Cole. It is all very well plonking the two best strikers in the country together but if they not seeing a ball which is 65 per cent the opposition's possession, goal chances are bound to be few and far between.

As early as the ninth minute, Adams was charging forward to berate his strikers for their lack of movement - England were becoming as predictable as the Germans were in Charleroi. Keegan duly changed things for the second half and you can bet that Adams had much to do with it. Southgate was withdrawn into the back three that suits his game-reading abilities better and Kieron Dyer replaced Neville to play wide on the right, freeing Beckham for more creative work.

But on a day of so many memories, this was of Poland in 1973. Much huffing and puffing failed to yield and equaliser. Not long after, Sir Alf Ramsey was gone. 'We are out of intensive care but still in hospital,' said Franz Beckenbauer after the recent win over Greece that got their World Cup campaign off to a winning start. The English patient is not that sick, it has just not received the proper care and attention.

fields.headline: Keegan quits after German defeat
fields.standfirst:
'I am not the man for the job'

Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: England manager Kevin Keegan sensationally resigned last night after his side slumped to a humiliating 1-0 defeat by Germany in the last match staged at Wembley.
fields.body:
England manager Kevin Keegan sensationally resigned last night after his side slumped to a humiliating 1-0 defeat by Germany in the last match staged at Wembley.

The decision is a devastating blow to England's hopes of qualifying for the World Cup.

It has plunged the national team into chaos just four days before the crucial match against Finland in Helsinki.

Keegan, who was appointed just 20 months ago, told shocked players and FA officials of his decision in the dressing room minutes after the defeat by England's deadly rivals.

Rejecting appeals from the FA chief Adam Crozier to remain in his post, Keegan was last night replaced by technical director Howard Wilkinson, who will be in charge for Wednesday's match as acting manager.

In an emotional outburst live on television, Keegan confessed that he lacked the qualities to continue in international management, adding that the angry reaction of England fans at the final whistle confirmed his decision.

Fighting back tears, Keegan said: 'I just don't feel I can find that little bit extra that you need at this level to find a winning formula. I couldn't have asked for more effort from the players. I've kept them together, they enjoy playing for England, they enjoy winning more and that's what we have not been able to do.

He added: 'I just feel I have given it my best shot, I don't want to go and outstay my welcome. The fans made me realise not only did they put me in the job but by what they were saying when we were coming off, they feel it's time for me to go. That's where the power should be. But it was 1,000% my decision.'

Tony Banks, the former Sports Minister who resigned to lead England's abortive bid for the 2006 World Cup, last night expressed sorrow and regret that Keegan had quit and blamed 'half-arsed journalists' and 'self-appointed experts' among fans for forcing him out.

'It's sad but from his point of view, I can understand what he's done. Tomorrow morning he will be crucified by every journalist in the country, none of whom have ever organised a successful football team. I know the guy well and have a great deal of affection for him.'

Alan Shearer, Keegan's captain during the disastrous Euro 2000 campaign, saluted the decision.

'You have to admire his honesty and openess,' he said. 'He's obviously hurt and very disappointed. The players have to take responsibility. We haven't as a team played well enough.'

But Keegan's decision was not received so sympathetically by England fans streaming away from Wembley lasy night as the rain pounded down and their world cup hopes disintegrated.

Ian Hart, 37, an engineer from Rotherham, South Yorkshire, said: 'I can't believe he's done it. The haste of it all. He could at least have stayed until the game on Wednesday against Finland which now that we have lost to the Germans, we've got to win if we are going to qualify for the next World Cup.'

Claire Connolly, a 22-year old leisure centre manager from London, added: 'It's just one bad result today. The team played well in the second half and deserved at least one goal if not two. It was one of those days - just one of those performances. I've been a football fan all my life and that happens. There's no need to give it all up after one of those days.'

Other fans, however, expressed delight at his decision, blaming him for poor tactics. Steve Liles, 34, an information technology manager at NatWest Bank from Worcestershire, said: 'That's excellent news. When I saw the team for today's game, I knew we would lose. Keegan couldn't change. He just stuck with the same team that didn't deliver in Euro 2000.'

Steve Rudkin, 31, from Stamford in Lincolnshire, added: 'That's right. The Germans have beaten Spain 4-1 and Greece since Euro 2000. Now they have beaten us. They have learnt the lessons of the summer, Keegan hasn't. We all wanted him to succeed. We all remember what a great player he was for England. But in the end he was not up to the job.'

 Terry Venables was immediately installed as 4/1 favourite to become the new coach. Other contenders included 6/1 Peter Taylor; 7/1 John Gregory; 8/1 Bryan Robson; 10 Peter Reid; 12/1 Arsene Wenger; 14/1 Alan Curbishley, Marcello Lippi; 16/1 David O'Leary; 20/1 Alex Ferguson;; 20/1 Howard Wilkinson 25/1 Harry Redknapp; Gianluca Vialli; 33/1 Ray Hodgson; 40 Glenn Hoddle; 50 Bobby Robson and 100 Graham Taylor.

webTitle: Public told not to give to homeless

fields.headline: It's official: Thou shalt not give money to beggars
fields.trailText: A high-profile campaign instructing people not to give money to beggars is to be launched by the Government, The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
A high-profile campaign instructing people not to give money to beggars is to be launched by the Government, The Observer can reveal.

Funded by the taxpayer, the £240,000 advertising blitz is to be unveiled four weeks before Christmas. The move will reignite claims that Ministers and the Government's 'homelessness tsar' are unsympathetic to the street homeless.

Rory Gillert, deputy chief executive of the Big Issue , said: 'Telling people what to do in this way is ridiculous. Often people who are begging are not actually homeless. Not giving to them doesn't help get people off the streets at all.'

A government official last night defended the adverts, which will appear in national newspapers and magazines at the end of November.

'We want to encourage people to volunteer or give gifts in kind [to beggars] or to charities rather than stopping to give cash,' the official said.

The campaign has been awarded to Leith, the advertising agency which has just won a new £10 million contract to promote Carling beer and whose other clients include Tennent's, Grolsch and Standard Life. An agency spokesman said yesterday: 'The Government has forbidden us from discussing this.'

The Rough Sleepers' Unit (RSU), set up two years ago by the Cabinet Office, was embroiled in controversy last year when Louise Casey, appointed as homelessness tsar by Tony Blair, criticised soup runs and handouts as 'misplaced goodwill'.

Officials claim that the RSU has reduced the number of people sleeping outside from 1,800 to 1,200 since 1998. It has pledged to cut that figure to 600 by 2002. Five years ago as Shadow Home Secretary, Jack Straw pledged that a Labour Government would clear the 'squeegee merchants, beggars and winos' from the streets. The promise was greeted with horror from homelessness campaigners and civil liberties organisations.

The Big Issue's Gillert added: 'If the public are told not to give money to beggars at Christmas, many are likely to do exactly the opposite.'

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Ascot evacuated after coded bomb warning
fields.body:
Ascot evacuated after coded bomb warning

A coded bomb warning given by telephone to London's Charing Cross Hospital led to the evacuation of thousands of racegoers from the grandstands at Ascot. The meeting was abandoned.

Doctor's abortion claim

Claims that Dr Everett Julyan was rejected for a house officer's post because he refused to perform abortions are being investigated by North Glasgow Universities Hospitals Trust.

Newborn boy found dead

The body of a newborn boy was found in a wood near Portaferry Road, Co Down. Police believe the mother may be in need of urgent medical attention.

Masked men beat driver

A driver was in a stable condition in hospital after being seriously injured by two masked men who beat him with baseball bats on the M606 near Cleckheaton, West Yorkshire. They had rammed his car.

Films take the biscuit

Rare news films dating from before 1912 have been found in a biscuit tin at the Regal Cinema, Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire. The films are to be restored and shown to the public. One shows Edward VII attending the Quorn Hunt.

Disabled swim
Billy Strathdee, a disabled former soldier who served in Northern Ireland and the Gulf war, swam the Firth of Forth yesterday for charity. Strathdee, 36, of Prestonpans, East Lothian, lost a leg in a car accident six years ago.

Escaped killer held in France

Britain has 38 days to seek the extradition from France of convicted murderer Robert Hamilton, 47, who has been on the run for 17 years since escaping from Sudbury Open Prison. He was being held in Montpellier.

Woman dies in freak weather

Betsy Cohler, 65, of Sheffield, died of head injuries she suffered when a boat was hit by a freak wind in the Firth of Clyde on Thursday. The police said that there were no suspicious circumstances, but a report would be sent to the procurator-fiscal.

McKellen urges gays to come out of the closet

The first British 'coming out' day for gay, lesbian and bisexual people was held yesterday. The event was organised by National Friend, an umbrella support group.

Among its supporters was actor Sir Ian McKellen, pictured above. He said 'coming out' was a journey which ended only 'when there is no one in the world from whom the truth is withheld'.

He added: 'I have yet to meet anyone who regrets leaving the closet or cupboard, fit only for moths and skeletons.'

fields.headline: 'Insane' daredevil skis down Everest
fields.standfirst: Extreme sports hero slides to a record
fields.trailText: Triumphing over extreme cold, treacherous ice and people dismissing him as mad, Slovenian Davo Karnicar yesterday became the first person to ski non-stop down Mount Everest.
fields.body:
Triumphing over extreme cold, treacherous ice and people dismissing him as mad, Slovenian Davo Karnicar yesterday became the first person to ski non-stop down Mount Everest.

After a dramatic plummet over almost sheer cliffs of snow, boulders and ice, 38-year-old Karnicar emerged exhausted but exhilarated in his base camp after five hours of skiing that gave new meaning to the words off piste.

At one stage he had to speed over stretches of ice that collapsed and broke underneath him and could have sent him tumbling into the deep crevasses that dot the mountain.

'I feel only absolute happiness and absolute fatigue,' he said after his successful run landed him in the record books and notched another in a series of bizarre firsts for conquerors of Everest that already includes launching a paraglider from the 8,850-metre summit.

The descent by the father of three had been seen by many as insanely dangerous. The Darwin Awards website, which documents and applauds foolhardy deaths, called the descent 'madness' and urged people to log onto internet broadcasts of the attempt. 'Keep your eyes peeled for a live Darwin Award,' it said.

However, the only body to make news yesterday was a corpse of an unknown mountaineer which Karnicar zipped past as he descended, one of an estimated 120 cadavers thought to litter the slopes. For Karnicar it was a reminder of the potential perils of his sport, but it did not stop him.

'This mountain is always full of surprises, seeing a dead man out there was a really shocking experience,' he said.

Thanks to strategically placed cameras on the mountain and one attached to his safety helmet, hundreds of thousands of people in more than 70 countries witnessed his descent on the internet. During the run more than 650,000 hits were registered on the expedition website - www.everest.simobil.si - jamming it for a time as others tried to access the site.

Those successful in logging on shared in the drama. At one stage Karnicar prompted deep concern after he failed to radio in to his support team just before he negotiated a notorious outcrop called the Hillary Step. But there had been no disaster. It was just the extreme weather hampering the operation of his radio batteries.

In fact the conditions were so severe that he abandoned plans to rest on the summit before attempting to descend. Instead, suffering from fatigue, as soon as he reached the top he put on his skis and flung himself back down the mountain.

He had already skied down Mont Blanc, the Matterhorn, the Eiger and Annapurna, but Everest was the last great challenge of the extreme side of the skiing world.

Tackling the mountain had already cost Karnica two fingers in 1996 when a failed attempt saw him get frostbite as a fierce storm lashed the peak.

Karnicar comes from an illustrious skiing family in Slovenia and took part in his first Himalayan skiing expedition in 1989. Since than he has been tireless in raising funds and sponsorship for more expeditions, with Everest as the eventual goal.

'Extreme skiing, is my sport, my thinking and life itself,' he said.

Mountain of facts
Compiled by Dorota Nosowicz

Age: About 60 million years old

Elevation: 29,035ft (8,850m). New height, 6' greater than was thought, calculated in 1999

Name in Nepal: Sagarmatha (means 'goddess of the sky')

Name in Tibet: Chomolungma ('mother goddess of universe')

Named after: Sir George Everest, British surveyor-general of India in 1865. Once known as Peak 15

Location: Latitude 27 59' North, longitude 86 56' East. Its summit ridge separates Nepal and Tibet

First ascent: 29 May, 1953, by Sir Edmund Hillary, and Tensing Norgay, above, via the South Col route

First solo ascent: 20 August 1980, by Reinhold Messner, via the NE ridge to North Face

First ascent by an American: 22 May, 1963, James Whittaker, via the South Col

First ascent by a woman: 16 May, 1975, Junko Tabei, via the South Col

First oxygenless ascent: 8 May, 1978, Reinhold Messner, and Peter Habeler, via the South-East ridge
fields.bodyText: Triumphing over extreme cold, treacherous ice and people dismissing him as mad, Slovenian Davo Karnicar yesterday became the first person to ski non-stop down Mount Everest. After a dramatic plummet over almost sheer cliffs of snow, boulders and ice, 38-year-old Karnicar emerged exhausted but exhilarated in his base camp after five hours of skiing that gave new meaning to the words off piste. At one stage he had to speed over stretches of ice that collapsed and broke underneath him and could have sent him tumbling into the deep crevasses that dot the mountain. 'I feel only absolute happiness and absolute fatigue,' he said after his successful run landed him in the record books and notched another in a series of bizarre firsts for conquerors of Everest that already includes launching a paraglider from the 8,850-metre summit. The descent by the father of three had been seen by many as insanely dangerous. The Darwin Awards website, which documents and applauds foolhardy deaths, called the descent 'madness' and urged people to log onto internet broadcasts of the attempt. 'Keep your eyes peeled for a live Darwin Award,' it said. However, the only body to make news yesterday was a corpse of an unknown mountaineer which Karnicar zipped past as he descended, one of an estimated 120 cadavers thought to litter the slopes. For Karnicar it was a reminder of the potential perils of his sport, but it did not stop him. 'This mountain is always full of surprises, seeing a dead man out there was a really shocking experience,' he said. Thanks to strategically placed cameras on the mountain and one attached to his safety helmet, hundreds of thousands of people in more than 70 countries witnessed his descent on the internet. During the run more than 650,000 hits were registered on the expedition website - www.everest.simobil.si - jamming it for a time as others tried to access the site. Those successful in logging on shared in the drama. At one stage Karnicar prompted deep concern after he failed to radio in to his support team just before he negotiated a notorious outcrop called the Hillary Step. But there had been no disaster. It was just the extreme weather hampering the operation of his radio batteries. In fact the conditions were so severe that he abandoned plans to rest on the summit before attempting to descend. Instead, suffering from fatigue, as soon as he reached the top he put on his skis and flung himself back down the mountain. He had already skied down Mont Blanc, the Matterhorn, the Eiger and Annapurna, but Everest was the last great challenge of the extreme side of the skiing world. Tackling the mountain had already cost Karnica two fingers in 1996 when a failed attempt saw him get frostbite as a fierce storm lashed the peak. Karnicar comes from an illustrious skiing family in Slovenia and took part in his first Himalayan skiing expedition in 1989. Since than he has been tireless in raising funds and sponsorship for more expeditions, with Everest as the eventual goal. 'Extreme skiing, is my sport, my thinking and life itself,' he said. New height, 6' greater than was thought, calculated in 1999 Name in Nepal: Sagarmatha (means 'goddess of the sky') Name in Tibet: Chomolungma ('mother goddess of universe') Named after: Sir George Everest, British surveyor-general of India in 1865. Once known as Peak 15 Location: Latitude 27 59' North, longitude 86 56' East. webTitle: Thailand launches manhunt after another Briton is raped

fields.headline: Thailand launches manhunt after another Briton is raped
fields.trailText: A British student has been brutally raped on the holiday island of Phuket in Thailand. The crime has shocked the country's large backpacker community, still distressed by the murder in August of British tourist Kirsty Jones in a Thai guesthouse.
fields.body:
A British student has been brutally raped on the holiday island of Phuket in Thailand. The crime has shocked the country's large backpacker community, still distressed by the murder in August of British tourist Kirsty Jones in a Thai guesthouse.

In the most recent incident, the 22-year-old woman from Lanarkshire was stripped, beaten and raped, then abandoned in a graveyard last Tuesday evening during a religious festival. She had walked into town on her own, leaving her ill boyfriend in their hotel, to watch a fire-walking ceremony at a local shrine.

Authorities on the island are anxious to prevent the case damaging the country's vital tourist industry. In response, Thai police have launched a massive manhunt and officers have been ordered to arrest the rapist within seven days. The unprecedented pressure is thought to be a direct response to criticism over police handling of the investigation into the death of 24-year-old Kirsty Jones.

Her partially naked body was found in her room at a guesthouse in Chiang Mai, a popular tourist destination. Last month Andrew Gill, 32, from Northern Ireland, was charged with her rape and murder and faces the death penalty if convicted. Police are still searching for an accomplice.

DNA tests had originally cleared Gill but he was charged with co-ordinating the rape on behalf of someone else. Gill was the last person reported to have been seen with Jones, from Brecon, Powys, on the night before her body was found.

Last month, the government replaced the chief investigator, saying he had failed to make progress in the case. His removal followed criticism that police had bungled the investigation and made unwise and confusing public statements.

He initially claimed that Kirsty had had consensual sex during which she had been strangled accidentally. This was later revised to murder, and then to rape and murder.

Four years ago, a Thai monk addicted to amphetamines was jailed for life after raping and murdering a 23-year-old English solicitor. The badly decomposed body of Johanne Masheder, from Cheshire, was found at the bottom of a ravine used by monks to dispose of rubbish near Kanchanaburi, 80 miles south-west of Bangkok.

The monk, Yodchart Suephoo, 25, who had joined the Khao Poon temple after serving two years for rape, admitted pushing Masheder into the ravine. The monk denied raping her, but admitted raping another Western tourist the previous year.

fields.headline: Ronnie was mad but I was bad, says Reggie in song
fields.standfirst: Posthumous pop CD by Kray puts record straight on Ronnie, race hate and McVitie killing
fields.trailText: Posthumous pop CD by Kray puts record straight on Ronnie, race hate and McVitie killing
fields.body:
Gangland killer Reggie Kray has reached out from beyond the grave to lay to rest one of the most enduring myths surrounding the relationship between the twins.

Since the pair were imprisoned in 1969, almost all of their biographers have insisted that Ronnie - certified insane and by far the more violent and unpredictable of the twins - was responsible for leading his brother astray.

Crucially, Reggie had been forced to murder Jack 'The Hat' McVitie in a room full of their cronies to show solidarity with Ronnie, who had shot George Cornell at the Blind Beggar pub the year before.

Now, Reggie has set the record straight - to pop music. In a singing voice that is more of a growl, Reggie insists Ronnie was blameless and had not unduly influenced any of his actions. He relieves Ronnie of responsibility for anything that happened in his past and insists the blame should lie with himself alone.

The song is one of five tracks on a limited-edition CD, Freedom of Thought , out tomorrow, in which the one-time thug condemns racism and declares his undying love for his wife, Roberta. Re-corded shortly before his death from cancer last Sunday at the age of 66, the CD will be available through specialist retailers and over the internet. All profits will be donated to charity.

In 'What Did He Do?', a pop song penned by Reggie Kray during his last days in custody, he condemns those who murder simply because of the colour of someone's skin. The lyrics make an emotional plea for the men responsible for the murder of Stephen Lawrence to be brought to justice.

He recorded the song after hearing that the Acourt brothers, two of the five men originally charged with Lawrence's murder, had bragged that they were 'the new Krays' and that Ronnie and Reggie were their heroes.

Kray wrote the words to one other track - 'Kissable' - and performs the other three. In a strong but aged voice, Kray speaks rather than sings his lines. All the music is provided by Greg Bone, a producer known for his work with the likes of Westlife, Sting and Kylie Minogue.

'Reg was never willing to apologise for what he did,' says Rob Ferguson who is behind the CD. 'But he was keen to deter others from a life of crime. This portrays a very different side of him from that most people expect. He always felt very strongly about the Lawrence case. He was many things, but he was never a racist and the fact that the suspects were idolising him made him sick.'

Two years ago Kray wrote a letter to Stephen's parents expressing his sympathy for their loss.

The original songs on the CD form part of a legacy of more than 500 poems, plays and lyrics which Kray com posed. He also produced dozens of paintings and wrote and replied to thousands of letters. 'He was prolific,' said one friend, 'but at the same time, he did have an awful lot of time on his hands.'

But while Kray insists the murder of McVitie was his own idea, he sheds no light about what actually happened the night he was killed. He had been persuaded to attend a party in Evering Road, but was ambushed as soon as he entered the flat. Kray pulled a gun, put it to his head and pulled the trigger. Nothing happened. Kray pulled the trigger again and nothing happened. McVitie began to fight back and Kray picked up a knife that was on a nearby plate and stabbed him repeatedly in the face and chest. Many believe that Kray had only intended to frighten McVitie and stabbed him only after being attacked.

This week also sees the publication of Kray's memoirs of his 32 years in prison. In A Way of Life he chronicles his stays at some of Britain's most notorious jails, from his days on remand to his attempts to gain parole.

His funeral will take place on Wednesday at St Matthew's Church in Bethnal Green. Huge crowds are expected to line the route of the procession, which will pass through the main Kray East End stamping ground.

webTitle: Love, honour and obey - or die

fields.headline: Love, honour and obey - or die
fields.standfirst: For many young Asian women in Britain marriage means abuse, and even death to satisfy 'family honour'. This domestic terror, inflicted by husbands, parents and other relatives, has long been submerged. But now, as the taboo subject comes out in the open, will thousands of wives have safer lives?
fields.trailText: For many young Asian women in Britain marriage means abuse, and even death to satisfy 'family honour'. This domestic terror, inflicted by husbands, parents and other relatives, has long been submerged. But now, as the taboo subject comes out in the open, will thousands of wives have safer lives?
fields.body:
The rugged dry hills of northern Pakistan are almost 4,000 miles from the rolling dales of northern England. But if you stand at the corner of some streets in Bradford or Derby or Huddersfield they feel a lot closer. Old men, their beards dyed orange with henna, rest in the evening sunlight on their way to the mosque. Boys, in white round prayer caps and the traditional baggy trousers worn in Karachi or Peshawar, play cricket with a makeshift bat. Women pull their headscarves tight up to their eyes when a stranger walks past.

Rukhsana Naz grew up in streets like these. A bright, educated woman, she had been married at 16 to an older man. At 19, she was pregnant by her childhood sweetheart. Her mother told her the child was 'an insult to [her] husband'.

When she refused an abortion and demanded a divorce, Rukhsana was invited to a family dinner where her brother, Shazad, strangled her with a skipping rope. Her mother, Shakeela, helped hold her down. Her actions had 'shamed' the family, the court was told.

Rukhsana Naz's killers were jailed last year. In June 1995 another Pakistani girl was run down and crushed to death by her brother-in-law for a similar offence in Bradford. Tasleem Begum was 20 and had been married for four years to an older Pakistani man. She too fell in love. She too transgressed traditional codes of behaviour and brought shame on her family.

Such killings are not rare in South Asia and the Middle East. There are 5,000 of these 'honour killings' every year across the world, according to a recent UN report 'Living Together, Worlds Apart: Men and Women in a Time of Change'. They occur both in the rural areas, where age-old traditions, value codes and modes of justice still hold sway, and in the cities, where newer tensions have sparked increasing violence towards women. Supporters say the killings maintain social order in changing times; critics allege that chauvinistic men use the 'family honour' as a pretext for punishing women who want more freedom.

In the United Kingdom honour killings are also happening. The Observer has found that the deaths of Tasleem Begum and Rukhsana Naz fit into a broader pattern of violence against women within the South Asian community.

Since Tasleem Begum died, nearly five years ago, there have been at least 20 other deaths in Britain that can be connected with ideas of 'honour', as well as hundreds of acts of lesser violence. Campaigners claim the honour code - and its accompanying concept of shame - is a key factor in the repression of the rights of tens of thousands of Asian women in Britain.

Recent cases involving 'honour' in the UK include:

 A Wakefield man axed to death by family members for continuing an affair with a younger female relative. Beheading is a way of committing an 'honour killing' in rural southern Pakistan.

 A 49-year-old man in Bradford, Jahangir Hussein, jailed last year for murdering his wife and two daughters because he (wrongly) thought they were having affairs.

 Mohammed Merheban, a 25-year-old who killed his friend and brother-in-law whom he suspected of having an affair with his wife. He told Liverpool Crown Court he had committed the murder because his honour had been insulted. A family member told the court that, if he had not acted, 'he would not be allowed to live within that society. That is how people are brought up.'

 A woman in Nottingham who died after being kept in her house for 24 hours a day, seven days a week, and a woman in Birmingham who was chained to her kitchen sink for months on end to prevent her leaving the home and behaving immodestly.

 Jaspal Sohal, a west London woman battered to death by her husband with a hammer. He saw killing her as preferable to having her leaving him and 'damaging his izzat' (personal honour).

 A young Sikh woman who married a Hindu man having her home burnt to the ground by her family.

 A prospective son-in-law blinded in one eye by his fiancée's Sikh brother - on the orders of his father - because he 'was not good enough'.

 A series of suicides of young women told that they could not marry their lovers because they were from the wrong religious background or caste.

There are many other cases involving serious violence where the 'honour' of some of those involved has been important. Legal documents studied by The Observer reveal a host of lesser incidents. They include cases of women being slapped after being seen talking to a man 'without permission' in the street or walking without a veil or even going to work.

And there are, as with all domestic violence, tens of thousands of cases that are never reported to the police.

Home Office specialists say that, in the UK, women who come to the attention of the police have been assaulted on average 30 times. Philip Balmforth, a police community officer who works with Asian women in Bradford, told The Observer he received about 300 requests for help from victims of abuse, abduction or forced marriages last year, twice the total of 1995. Last year 120 women came to him for help after being subjected to violence within the family. A quarter of those were assaulted by relatives other than their partners.

He estimates he hears less than 1 per cent of such incidents. An Essex police report of 1998 refers to 'gross under-reporting' of such attacks throughout Britain and in the South Asian community in particular.

'These girls are caught by a double whammy,' said one refuge worker who did not want to be named for fear of reprisals. 'If they are in a strict environment, they are more likely to suffer abuse. But they are less likely to report it.'

Tjinder lives in east London. She is in her twenties, articulate and self-confident. She was married young to a friend of her father's and is now living in a refuge. Through an intermediary she told her story to The Observer . The details are kept vague to protect her and her family.

'During the first year of our marriage there were indications my husband was abusive,' she said. 'There were things he would say that I wouldn't like. [Soon] the violence became a regular feature in our lives. I found myself having sex with him to keep him from beating or raping me. I was under enormous pressure not to talk about it.'

When Tjinder did tell her in-laws about the assaults, she was told that she 'ought to be careful because as far as everyone in the community was concerned her husband was an honourable man and if she tried to leave him both their izzat would be questioned. When she spoke to her own family about the abuse their response was harsh.

'They told me bluntly that no one would take me in... Your brothers are not going to put you up and your father is not going to give you roti (bread). Those were their very words,' Tjinder said.

Tjinder was interviewed by Ayesha Gill, a sociologist at the University of Essex. In the past year she has spoken to hundreds of such victims of domestic violence. 'Asian women are taught to hide problems that may bring shame on the family or the community,' she said. Other researchers say the pressure of living up to expectations is a key factor in the high suicide rates for young Asian women.

Many of those suicides concern police. In March last year Uzma Shaheen and her two-year-old daughter burnt to death in her own home. Her last words - screamed down the telephone to the emergency services as she choked on the smoke filling her bedroom - blamed her husband for lighting the fire.

Shaheen was on the point of leaving her arranged marriage, a court heard this year, and had visited support workers dealing with abused women. Her husband was acquitted of killing her after a judge heard evidence that Shaheen had contemplated burning the house down and committing suicide in the months before her death.

Other suicides lead to 'Romeo and Juliet' headlines in newspapers. In one tragic case this year a young Sikh woman hanged herself after being told by her parents that her relationship with a Muslim boy should stop.

Such pressure to conform, combined with high expectations, can lead to massive strain on young women. Veena Raleigh, an epidemiologist who has studied suicides among Asian women, said the tight-knit domestic unit with a strong sense of family pride could be a contributory factor.

'Such a close institution has tremendous pay-offs such as very low delinquency and very high educational achievement,' she said. 'But a problem is that women have no self-identity. You are a mother or a wife or a sister. You are never yourself. That leads to tremendous pressures.'

In some cases suicide has nothing to do with failing to live up to expectations of a loving, if demanding, family. Some of those that Philip Balmforth, the community officer with Bradford police, deals with involve women who have been prisoners in their own homes. He has rescued young Pakistani women who, but for the journey from Manchester airport to a Northern town, have never left their flats or houses.

Last winter Balmforth managed to get a woman out of a flat where she had been kept by her husband, a drug user. The marriage had been arranged in Pakistan and the woman could not speak English. 'We had to teach her how to use money, how to use telephones, how to take the bus.'

Growing concern about a related issue - forced marriages - recently led the Home Office to set up a working group. Though the analysis was useful, its key achievement was breaking the taboo on publicly speaking about such an subject, experts say.

But any government involvement is fraught with difficulty. There are estimated to be only around 100 forced marriages a year. Domestic violence - and the value systems that legitimise it - is a far thornier issue.

Some fear that focusing on 'honour and shame' can lead to the Asian community being stigmatised and stereotyped. Baroness Uddin of Bethnal Green, who co-chaired the forced marriages report, told The Observer it risked reinforcing old and dangerous prejudices.

However, activists such as Hanana Siddiqui of the Southall Black Sisters, say that, though the Home Office insists 'multicultural sensitivity' will not lead to 'moral blindness', the Government is wary of taking on the leaders of ethnic communities over cultural traditions.

It is important to emphasise that, overall, levels of domestic violence in the Asian community in Britain are probably lower than the national average. Nor can religion be blamed. Muslim, Hindu and Sikh religious leaders all stress that their faiths are non-violent and abhor violence to anyone, especially women. Optimists say that, as the Asian community becomes more assimilated and the older, conservative traditionalism dies away, the issue will resolve itself.

Often the victims of violence are women born or educated in the UK whose aspirations are very different from those of older family members.

Shamshad Hussain, the Bradford community worker, remains worried. Change, she says, has to be carefully managed.

'Unless we all unite to take an honest and strong, intelligent and open stance on this issue now, you are likely to see a backlash of traditionalism by young people, particularly young men, as a defence against Western values that threaten them and their traditional position.'

For many Asian women in the UK, Hussain points out, it is already too late.

He estimates he hears less than 1 per cent of such incidents. An Essex police report of 1998 refers to 'gross under-reporting' of such attacks throughout Britain and in the South Asian community in particular. 'These girls are caught by a double whammy,' said one refuge worker who did not want to be named for fear of reprisals. 'If they are in a strict environment, they are more likely to suffer abuse. But they are less likely to report it.' Tjinder lives in east London. She is in her twenties, articulate and self-confident. She was married young to a friend of her father's and is now living in a refuge. Through an intermediary she told her story to The Observer . The details are kept vague to protect her and her family. 'During the first year of our marriage there were indications my husband was abusive,' she said. 'There were things he would say that I wouldn't like. [Soon] the violence became a regular feature in our lives. I found myself having sex with him to keep him from beating or raping me. I was under enormous pressure not to talk about it.' When Tjinder did tell her in-laws about the assaults, she was told that she 'ought to be careful because as far as everyone in the community was concerned her husband was an honourable man and if she tried to leave him both their izzat would be questioned. When she spoke to her own family about the abuse their response was harsh. 'They told me bluntly that no one would take me in... Your brothers are not going to put you up and your father is not going to give you roti (bread). Those were their very words,' Tjinder said. Tjinder was interviewed by Ayesha Gill, a sociologist at the University of Essex. In the past year she has spoken to hundreds of such victims of domestic violence. 'Asian women are taught to hide problems that may bring shame on the family or the community,' she said. Other researchers say the pressure of living up to expectations is a key factor in the high suicide rates for young Asian women. Many of those suicides concern police. In March last year Uzma Shaheen and her two-year-old daughter burnt to death in her own home. Her last words - screamed down the telephone to the emergency services as she choked on the smoke filling her bedroom - blamed her husband for lighting the fire. Shaheen was on the point of leaving her arranged marriage, a court heard this year, and had visited support workers dealing with abused women. Her husband was acquitted of killing her after a judge heard evidence that Shaheen had contemplated burning the house down and committing suicide in the months before her death. Other suicides lead to 'Romeo and Juliet' headlines in newspapers. In one tragic case this year a young Sikh woman hanged herself after being told by her parents that her relationship with a Muslim boy should stop. Such pressure to conform, combined with high expectations, can lead to massive strain on young women. Veena Raleigh, an epidemiologist who has studied suicides among Asian women, said the tight-knit domestic unit with a strong sense of family pride could be a contributory factor. 'Such a close institution has tremendous pay-offs such as very low delinquency and very high educational achievement,' she said. 'But a problem is that women have no self-identity. You are a mother or a wife or a sister. You are never yourself. That leads to tremendous pressures.' In some cases suicide has nothing to do with failing to live up to expectations of a loving, if demanding, family. Some of those that Philip Balmforth, the community officer with Bradford police, deals with involve women who have been prisoners in their own homes. He has rescued young Pakistani women who, but for the journey from Manchester airport to a Northern town, have never left their flats or houses. Last winter Balmforth managed to get a woman out of a flat where she had been kept by her husband, a drug user. The marriage had been arranged in Pakistan and the woman could not speak English. 'We had to teach her how to use money, how to use telephones, how to take the bus.' Growing concern about a related issue - forced marriages - recently led the Home Office to set up a working group. Though the analysis was useful, its key achievement was breaking the taboo on publicly speaking about such an subject, experts say. But any government involvement is fraught with difficulty. There are estimated to be only around 100 forced marriages a year. Domestic violence - and the value systems that legitimise it - is a far thornier issue. Some fear that focusing on 'honour and shame' can lead to the Asian community being stigmatised and stereotyped. Baroness Uddin of Bethnal Green, who co-chaired the forced marriages report, told The Observer it risked reinforcing old and dangerous prejudices. However, activists such as Hanana Siddiqui of the Southall Black Sisters, say that, though the Home Office insists 'multicultural sensitivity' will not lead to 'moral blindness', the Government is wary of taking on the leaders of ethnic communities over cultural traditions. It is important to emphasise that, overall, levels of domestic violence in the Asian community in Britain are probably lower than the national average. Nor can religion be blamed. Muslim, Hindu and Sikh religious leaders all stress that their faiths are non-violent and abhor violence to anyone, especially women. Optimists say that, as the Asian community becomes more assimilated and the older, conservative traditionalism dies away, the issue will resolve itself. Often the victims of violence are women born or educated in the UK whose aspirations are very different from those of older family members. Shamshad Hussain, the Bradford community worker, remains worried. Change, she says, has to be carefully managed. 'Unless we all unite to take an honest and strong, intelligent and open stance on this issue now, you are likely to see a backlash of traditionalism by young people, particularly young men, as a defence against Western values that threaten them and their traditional position.' For many Asian women in the UK, Hussain points out, it is already too late.

webTitle: Test-tube antibodies will fight killer bugs

fields.headline: Test-tube antibodies will fight killer bugs
fields.standfirst: Scientists develop synthetic human defence cells to save weak patients
fields.trailText: A drug that mimics the human body's primary defence against disease is about to be tested on British patients. Scientists have developed synthetic human antibodies in a bid to counter deadly fungal infections that kill hundreds of hospital patients every year.
fields.body:
A drug that mimics the human body's primary defence against disease is about to be tested on British patients. Scientists have developed synthetic human antibodies in a bid to counter deadly fungal infections that kill hundreds of hospital patients every year.

The £10 million project - spearheaded by scientists at Manchester University - has taken 15 years to develop and could herald a radical new approach to treating deadly infections, say scientists. 'Our first target will be infections caused by the yeast candida albicans,' said one of the project's leaders, microbiologist Professor James Burnie. 'After that, we will target bacteria such as methicillin-resistant staphylococcus aureus, or MRSA. All these are major killers in hospital wards.'

Candida albicans is a common infection which causes thrush - though the genital infection is usually prevented from spreading by the body's immune system. However, many people in hospital have weakened or non-existent immune defences. These include Aids patients, those undergoing chemotherapy for cancer, new-born babies, and kidney dialysis patients. Unchecked, a candida infection can sweep through them, lining their windpipes and guts, and spreading through their organs, choking the body like weeds.

Powerful antibiotics are effective, though only in about 50 per cent of cases. The remainder die within 24 hours.

'Patients with weakened immune systems cannot make enough of the specific type of antibodies that are needed to block the invading yeast cells,' explained another project leader, Professor Ruth Matthews. 'We aim to provide them with a synthetic substitute.'

First, the team examined patients who had survived candida infections and isolated the antibodies they had made to fight off the invading yeast cells. Then they pinpointed the piece of genetic material that was responsible for the manufacture of those antibodies, and created a synthetic version of it.

This sliver of DNA was then inserted into bacteria and grown in vats. Under the direction of the new gene, the bugs started to manufacture anti-candida antibodies. 'The trick was getting our bacteria to make antibodies in the vast quantities that we needed,' said Burnie.

To do this, Burnie and his colleagues established their own biotechnology company, Neutec Pharma, which has received more than £7m venture backing from the investment group 3i and the Dutch bank ABN Amro. After years of development work, the company this year succeeded in producing sufficient quantities of synthetic antibodies to begin clinical trials.

Trials using anti-candida antibodies - to be marketed as Mycograb - are set to begin in a few weeks. 'Early tests will merely establish if our drug has toxic side-effects,' said Matthews. 'Then full trials will reveal to what degree patients are helped by Mycograb. We hope to see significant clinical improvement.'

Scientists at Neutec Pharma have also begun manufacturing antibodies to counter deadly antibiotic-resistant superbugs such as MRSA, and plan to launch trials next year. 'We are going to re-stock patients' front line of defences against infections,' said Burnie. 'It is very promising.'

webTitle: George V meddled in war decisions

fields.headline: George V meddled in war decisions
fields.trailText: King George V, the obsessively correct monarch who died after uttering the famous profanity 'Bugger Bognor', interfered so much in the military operations of the First World War that the Prime Minister threatened to resign, according to new research.
fields.body:
King George V, the obsessively correct monarch who died after uttering the famous profanity 'Bugger Bognor', interfered so much in the military operations of the First World War that the Prime Minister threatened to resign, according to new research.

The monarch not only considered turning out the politicians and installing a military government in their place, but repeatedly blocked political appointments and installed officers loyal to his camp instead.

The revelation that the king wielded such power will shock many experts because of the monarch's determination to conceal the true extent of his involvement. Documents describing the king's interference were uncovered by Professor Ian Beckett, one of Britain's leading military experts, during rare access to archives at Windsor Castle.

Beckett discovered that, although the monarch ensured that he appeared to be on the periphery of the war effort, he was so determined to control the armed forces that David Lloyd George accused him of attempting to form a military dictatorship.

Beckett, whose essay will appear in Leadership in Conflict, to be published next month, found that the king's interference reached such a height that the Prime Minister accused him of inciting an armed forces' mutiny.

The climax was when Lloyd George threatened to provoke the Government's resignation, forcing the king into a more hands-off app-roach. 'He [the king] was a blunt and powerful man who believed firmly in his right to govern and was not afraid to express his displeasure,' said Beckett.

amelia.hill@observer.co.uk

webTitle: It's no joke. We laugh to impress our bosses

fields.headline: It's no joke. We laugh to impress our bosses
fields.standfirst: The serious side of sniggers, giggles, chortles and guffaws
fields.trailText: Nice one, boss. The enduring mystery of why we laugh has been solved: we giggle, snigger and chortle to ingratiate ourselves with our superiors.
fields.body:
Nice one, boss. The enduring mystery of why we laugh has been solved: we giggle, snigger and chortle to ingratiate ourselves with our superiors.

According to new research, laughter is an 'acoustic response to a situation' - the equivalent in humans of birdsong - which is all to do with social signals and very little to do with humour.

Even a baby will laugh into its parents' delighted faces because it is pre-programmed to please its providers.

A team from the University of Maryland in Baltimore, led by neurobiology and psychology professor Robert Provine, have collected 1,200 'laugh episodes' by eavesdropping on people in public places around the world.

The results show that people in power rarely snigger, although everyone will laugh more with dominant individuals, whether tribal elders or employers, than with equals. In short, when the boss laughs, everyone laughs. The pattern holds true around the world. In India, men of lower castes giggle when addressing men of higher castes, but never the other way round.

'They are controlling the emotional climate of the group,' said Provine, whose book, Laughter: A Scientific Investigation, is published in the US next week. Provine goes as far as to say that giggling may be a feminist issue: women are far more likely to laugh at men - and ingratiate themselves with the opposite sex - than men at women.

Listeners, especially women, laugh more often when the speaker is male.

Earlier studies have shown that people are 30 times more likely to laugh in social settings than when they are on their own.

Even nitrous oxide, or laughing gas, loses its effect if someone takes it when they are alone, according to experiments done by German psychologist Willibald Ruch at the University of Düsseldorf.

'Laughter is only rarely a response to jokes,' Provine said. 'It is the quintessential human social signal. It solidifies relationships and pulls people into the fold.'

The oft-heard cliché of the 'evil laugh' is true.

The two teenage Columbine High school killers who laughed as they killed classmates were showing solidarity with each other and a dismissiveness towards their terrified targets, said Provine.

'Laughter is a probe into such fundamental questions as why humans can speak but other apes can't,' he said.

A laugh is usually one short exhalation of breath chopped into staccato segments lasting a fifteenth of a second each and spaced one-fifth of a second apart.

Laughter is also contagious: in 1962 an epidemic of laughter among African schoolgirls in Tanganyika lasted for six months and forced officials to close down the schools.

But while you can catch it from others, you cannot induce it in yourself.

Even tickling yourself is a non-starter. Now experiments by Sarah-Jayne Blakemore, of University College London, may have finally revealed why that is. The neuroscientist used brain scans to look at the responses of volunteers who either tickled themselves or were tickled by a robotic tickler.

She found that when you move your hand to tickle yourself, your brain predicts your moves and blocks the sensory response. If someone else tickles you, it is a surprise and the brain cannot control the touch.

Laughing so hard that you have to hold on to something becomes 'a signal of trust in one's companions, a ritual disarming in effect,' said Provine.

Provine says laughter, like most human behaviour, has evolved through communication.

In an embarrassing or threatening situation, laughing may deflect anger. If an aggressor joins in, the risk of confrontation may become less.

webTitle: Letter: Ethnic composition of the UK

fields.headline: No official line
fields.trailText: On 3 September you published an article on the future ethnic composition of the UK. Your newspaper consulted me by telephone on speculative claims, from political sources, of which I was previously ignorant, that there could be a white minority in the UK in 100 years' time.
fields.body:
On 3 September you published an article on the future ethnic composition of the UK. Your newspaper consulted me by telephone on speculative claims, from political sources, of which I was previously ignorant, that there could be a white minority in the UK in 100 years' time.

In paraphrase I was happy to be quoted to the effect that, first, it is simple arithmetic that any group growing at a faster rate than others must eventually become the majority if growth rates remain constant and if the group(s) retain their identity.

Second, the suppositions behind such extrapolation are likely to change; the birth rate of immigrant groups may well converge to national average; immigration is, at least in theory, under government control.

As I made clear to your newspaper, no 'analysis' or 'calculation' has been made from 'official' or other sources, other than the elementary extrapolation of current estimated growth rates which anyone can do.
David Coleman
Reader in Demography
University of Oxford

fields.headline: The big issue :  It's abuse (not sex) that's bad
fields.trailText: • What a relief it was to read Nigella Lawson (Comment, last week) for until her article I thought I was alone or perhaps going mad.
fields.body:
 What a relief it was to read Nigella Lawson (Comment, last week) for until her article I thought I was alone or perhaps going mad.

As a child I encountered physical and mental abuse at home from a stepmother who subscribed to the notion that discipline meant punishment meant violence. In other words, both my brother and myself were beaten senseless. By the time I was 13 I was being sexually abused by a young lodger in my grandmother's house. It was clearly an unequal relationship based on his power over me and was both criminal and morally unacceptable. While I would wish neither of these scenarios on any child I am bound to say that the sexual abuse which was non-penetrative and did not involve physical violence was infinitely preferable to the regular beating and humiliation of my stepmother.
Iain Macdonald
Edinburgh

 How Nigella Lawson can differentiate between the abuse of 14-year-old boys and girls is certainly beyond me. I suffered abuse at the hands of a female teacher and I can assure Ms Lawson that the long-term psychological effects on me weren't that I 'relished my initiation', as she would have everyone believe.

As far as her remark about a boy 'having the will' to participate, I'm sure that not all schoolgirls who are abused are raped. She obviously knows nothing about basic sex education such as an erection being a reflex action - especially for boys at the age of 14.

I would suggest she return to school, only please, not as a teacher. Please don't lower your standards again.
Name and address supplied

 If I, as a 14-year-old, had been seduced by a woman 21 years my senior, my mother might (possibly) have been upset, but I would have been delirious. Thank heavens Nigella Lawson writes sensibly about sex. Unlike Germaine Greer, whose view of sexuality seems increasingly nun-like and hectoring. With or without pornography, most of us want more sex more often.
Harry Novak
Heighington
Lincoln

 For all that she may have danced around it, Nigella Lawson perpetrated the usual reductivist view of boys who have been abused, that they 'must' have wanted it, enjoyed it and participated in it, simply by the virtue of needing an erection. This unsympathetic view in no way understands the nature of abuse perpetrated on males, the psychological and emotional damage of being in a sexual situation and not being an equal.
Tom Weir
Dromahaire
Leitrim
Ireland

 How young does a boy have to be before Nigella Lawson would accept that sexual abuse by an older woman is invasive and damaging? Ten? Six? Three? Lawson thinks that sex is cynical and exploitative. The paedophiles agree with her. That's why they go to jail.
Andrew Ravensdale
London N1

fields.headline: Ingrams wrong
fields.trailText: When I read Richard Ingrams' Week (Diary, last week) I was reminded of President Reagan's famous jibe, 'there he goes again'.
fields.body:
When I read Richard Ingrams' Week (Diary, last week) I was reminded of President Reagan's famous jibe, 'there he goes again'.

In his column, he repeated a mistake he made some months ago by stating that, in its adjudication on the matter of share dealings at the Mirror , the Press Complaints Commission ruled that the paper's editor 'had done nothing wrong'. In fact the opposite was the case: we issued the strongest rebuke we have ever done and ruled that the Code had been seriously breached. I doubt the same mistake will occur again - the great strength of self regulation.
Lord Wakeham
Chairman, PCC
London EC4

fields.headline: Ethical spending
fields.trailText: • I would argue with your interpretation (News, last week) that ethical consumerism is a passing fad.
fields.body:
 I would argue with your interpretation (News, last week) that ethical consumerism is a passing fad.

We found a third of the population are committed to ethical purchasing, 17 per cent of consumers frequently buy products on ethical grounds and as many as 62 per cent have looked for at least one ethical label. The evidence leads me to conclude that the market is set for continued growth. Ethical consumerism is here to stay.
Simon Williams
Head of Corporate Affairs
The Co-operative Bank
Manchester

fields.headline: Is it truth or exploitation?
fields.trailText: • On page five of the News section last week, you show a tragic video-still showing a young boy suffering unimaginable cruelty, followed by an article condemning the circulation of such images for profit.
fields.body:
 On page five of the News section last week, you show a tragic video-still showing a young boy suffering unimaginable cruelty, followed by an article condemning the circulation of such images for profit.

On page one, there are two tragic video-stills showing a young boy suffering unimaginable cruelty, printed large and prominently to increase sales. You need to establish where you stand on such issues, as currently you are practising what you condemn.
Dominic Norman-Taylor
London WC1

 I was surprised at the biased observation of The Observer in the report about the killing of Rami Aldura and the shooting of his father, Jamal. I watched the news item on the television the previous night and it seemed to me it was clear that the stone-throwing Palestinians were being shot at by the Israeli army. However, in my view you have downplayed and watered down this horrifying killing of innocent civilians, in particular children, by an occupying army by using the phrase 'Caught in the crossfire'.
Shaheen Shibli
Ashtead
Surrey

On page one, there are two tragic video-stills showing a young boy suffering unimaginable cruelty, printed large and prominently to increase sales. You need to establish where you stand on such issues, as currently you are practising what you condemn. Dominic Norman-Taylor London WC1  I was surprised at the biased observation of The Observer in the report about the killing of Rami Aldura and the shooting of his father, Jamal. I watched the news item on the television the previous night and it seemed to me it was clear that the stone-throwing Palestinians were being shot at by the Israeli army. However, in my view you have downplayed and watered down this horrifying killing of innocent civilians, in particular children, by an occupying army by using the phrase 'Caught in the crossfire'. fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: Vietnam's Nobel nominee held
fields.body:
Vietnam's Nobel nominee held

Police in southern Vietnam detained Nobel Peace Prize nominee Thich Quang Do, deputy leader of the outlawed Unified Buddhist Church of Vietnam, for distributing aid to Mekong delta flood victims in defiance of a government ban.

Poachers skin tiger in zoo

Poachers broke into the Nehru Zoological Park in Hyderabad and slit the throat of a Royal Bengal tiger before skinning it and stealing the pelt, officials said.

Japan hit by aftershocks

Hundreds of aftershocks hit south-west Japan after an earthquake on Friday which injured at least 120 people and damaged thousands of homes.

Berlin escape tunnel rediscovered

The remains of the largest tunnel under the Berlin Wall, through which 29 people escaped in 1962, have been discovered. The flooded tunnel has now been closed.

Singapore airport's jumbo plan

The third passenger terminal being built at Singapore's Changi Airport will be designed for Airbus Industrie's A3XX 'jumbo' jet, due to be flying by 2006.

New light shed on Pompeii ruins

A new lighting scheme has been switched on at Pompeii, as part of plans to open the the ruins of the Roman city at night.

Grand Duke abdicates

Luxembourg's Grand Duke Jean yesterday stepped down as monarch of the European Union's smallest and richest (per head) state, abdicating in favour of his son, Henri. A signature and brief embrace between father and son ended a 35-year reign which saw Luxembourg change from an industrial backwater into a centre for financial services and satellite communications.

Prime Minister Jean-Claude Junckerin expressed regret at his departure.

fields.headline: Anarchist plots
fields.trailText: The report by Paul Harris and Nick Paton Walsh about fuel protest leaders plotting to cut power (News, last week) made scary reading. We have been assured time and again that the fuel protest 'just happened', that it had not been pre-planned.
fields.body:
The report by Paul Harris and Nick Paton Walsh about fuel protest leaders plotting to cut power (News, last week) made scary reading. We have been assured time and again that the fuel protest 'just happened', that it had not been pre-planned.

We now read that the plan to grid-lock the National Grid has been under discussion for 12 months! Do we still believe that the fuel protest 'just happened'? This sounds more to me like the actions of a group of anti-democratic anarchists than William Hague's 'fine upstanding people'.
Michael Yates
Giggleswick
North Yorkshire

webTitle: Letter: The increase in prison suicides

fields.headline: Prisons damage the damaged
fields.trailText: The worrying increase in prison suicides (Comment, 24 September) is just the tip of the iceberg. When I was imprisoned for seven months earlier this year, self-harm was a weekly, if not daily, occurrence: people cutting their arms, using scourers on their skin or overdosing on tablets.
fields.body:
The worrying increase in prison suicides (Comment, 24 September) is just the tip of the iceberg. When I was imprisoned for seven months earlier this year, self-harm was a weekly, if not daily, occurrence: people cutting their arms, using scourers on their skin or overdosing on tablets.

It was an indication of the pain caused by prison, which many found unendurable to the extent of wanting to end it all, or finding solace only in expressing their pain in physical terms.

Few of my fellow inmates were dangerous, and many of them were very vulnerable people. They were forced to endure systems which I found to be basically inhumane.

Prison suicides are the most obvious symptom of the way our penal system damages the inmates who endure it, many of whom are already damaged by life.
Ruth Wyner
Cambridge

fields.headline: Plastic hippos trample prudes
fields.trailText: India is in the throes of a modest sexual revolution. After two centuries of Victorian prudery, you can see couples holding hands in Delhi parks as they wander past the Moghul tombs. There is even kissing on TV. And teenage girls hang out after school in internet chat rooms, flirting with male classmates.
fields.body:
India is in the throes of a modest sexual revolution. After two centuries of Victorian prudery, you can see couples holding hands in Delhi parks as they wander past the Moghul tombs. There is even kissing on TV. And teenage girls hang out after school in internet chat rooms, flirting with male classmates.

But in one corner of India's capital the sari has not just slipped a little but has fallen off entirely to reveal a bare midriff. It all happens at Djinns, Delhi's hippest bar/nightclub, not far from a major traffic intersection where lepers beg. Here the young élite rich come to party. They might even get off with each other, behaviour unthinkable a decade ago.

With its naff plastic hippopotamus, red London phone box and fake hunting memorabilia, Djinns may resemble a Frog and Firkin pub, but that is not the point. It is one of the few places in India where it does not feel like India. None of the girls wears traditional dress - they flaunt micro-skirts, dinky designer handbags and sheer tops. The boys sport Armani shirts, shiny black loafers and floppy haircuts.

Having talked my way in - itself something of an achievement - I struck up a conversation at the bar with Rajiv. He claimed to have made his money from exporting garments. He liked London and had visited Equinox, the Ministry and other London clubs.

How easy, I asked, was it to meet girls here? 'The thing about Indian girls,' Rajiv explained, 'is that they are very shy at first. But once you get to know them they fuck like wild.'

On the dance floor behind him, a couple of top-heavy Sikhs bopped away to the latest rave tracks. On a balcony above, the club's Indian DJ waggled his arm in the air. Girls in sequined evening dresses working for Chivas Regal took photographs of the suitably glamorous. Over in the darker recesses, several matronly chaperones wearing salwar kameez sat around looking bored. Everyone in Gucci, Prada or Armani seemed to be having a good time.

The designer labels are just one consequence of India's blossoming consumer revolution, which began in the early Nineties when the country's previously closed economy was opened up for the first time.

What gives Delhi its unique hedonistic frisson is that much of the money being spent in places such as Djinns - where a half-pint of lager costs £2.50 - is not strictly earned. The capital is full of bureaucrats. And in India bureaucrats are synonymous with corruption. While a handful of the boys and girls at Djinns are the progeny of newly-rich IT experts, most have politicians or senior civil servants for parents. 'They are a thoroughly spoilt bunch. If they get into trouble their parents always get them off the hook,' one Indian friend told me.

But it is not just the young heterosexual rich who are enjoying India's gradual sexual awakening. In another Delhi hotel, the capital's first gay bar has just opened. Its customers are almost exclusively middle-class, educated and English-speaking. Yet the bar marks a modest beginning, in a country where homosexuality is still technically illegal and many gay men find themselves bullied by relatives into unhappy arranged marriages.

Back in Djinns, it is 2am and time to go home. A procession of chauffeur-driven BMWs and Mercedes swoop down from the hotel car park. The drivers are taking their charges back to monstrous, Dallas-style 'farmhouses' in south Delhi, complete with swimming pools and mock-Grecian porticos, and to huge flats in Delhi's plusher colonies.

The lepers, meanwhile, have knocked off and gone home too.

fields.headline: Carlos the Jackal: 'It's not over'
fields.standfirst: The terrorist who was the world's public enemy No 1 tells his story from his cell for the first time
fields.trailText: For nearly two decades, he was the world's most notorious and feared terrorist, a defiant killer who claimed responsibility for the deaths of 83 people and was linked to the most audacious hijackings of the Cold War era. Since being imprisoned in Paris's La Santé prison in 1994, however, little has been heard from Ilich Ramírez Sánchez, better known as Carlos the Jackal.
fields.body:
For nearly two decades, he was the world's most notorious and feared terrorist, a defiant killer who claimed responsibility for the deaths of 83 people and was linked to the most audacious hijackings of the Cold War era. Since being imprisoned in Paris's La Santé prison in 1994, however, little has been heard from Ilich Ramírez Sánchez, better known as Carlos the Jackal.

But, replying in writing to questions from a French magazine, the 51-year-old spoke freely about his reign of terror. He relished describing his years of cocaine, women and bombings - and recalled his betrayal by the socialist and Arab states who protected and sponsored him in the Seventies and Eighties.

Ramírez appeared laconic and unrepentant. By turns light-hearted and then spouting the anti-imperialist rhetoric that marks him out as a Cold War throwback, the former international revolutionary described himself as 'an old lag'. But he still complained about the conditions of his imprisonment: 'Total isolation, visits forbidden, thus all activity. I'm even forbidden French lessons!'

He says: 'Each day I read the paper and listen to news on the radio and I'm allowed two walks of an hour each. Each night I read, I write, and sometimes I watch the television - news disinformation programmes. Sometimes I tune into Radio Latina, megaphone of the Colombian olig-archy.' Asked what he missed most, Ramírez replied: 'Above all, the warmth of my two wives, and also ... the warmth of my next wife!'

The Venezuelan-born terrorist is serving a life sentence for the murders of two French Secret Service agents and a Lebanese national during a gun battle at his Left Bank apartmentin 1975. He is widely believed to be responsible for the seizure of 11 Opec Oil Ministers in Vienna in 1975 and the 1976 Palestinian hijacking of an Air France jet to Uganda. He has also been linked to the massacre of 11 Israeli athletes at the Munich Olympics in 1972 and is still under investigation for four terrorist bombings in France.

Replying to Le Vrai Papier Journal , Ramírez expressed no remorse. 'Our "collateral damage" (as the Nato jargon has it) is nothing compared with the dismemberment of Yugoslavia, not to mention the other aggressive wars which stain the French flag with innocent blood.'

Ramírez had a private army of terrorists for hire that operated out of Eastern Europe. 'We could go freely to all the socialist countries, 10 sub-Saharan countries, the majority of Arab countries, and four Asian countries. That's to say, their security services would not threaten us.'

Asked if he had become an irrelevance, the terrorist replied: 'My actions and those that continue to be led by my comrades play a role, minor but not negligible, in the anti-imperialist struggle.'

But Ramírez conceded that the days during which he was protected by Libya's Colonel Gadaffi, Syria's President al-Assad, the Stasi secret police in East Germany, among others, were over thanks to the accommodations that Arab and former socialist states had made with the West in recent years.

'From the arrival in the Kremlin of Yuri Andropov (pupil of Beria), the Warsaw Pact countries became hostile to revolutionaries. The Arab countries, submitting to the Yankee swinging of the stick "anti-terrorism" and the carrot of "financial aid", were pushed to betray the militants on their territory. Syria is the best example of it.'

The CIA and French Secret Services gave themselves licence to kill Ramírez, who sought sanctuary in Sudan. But he was betrayed by the very leaders of the country's Islamic revolution who had offered him protection. His drinking and womanising upset those leaders, who concluded he could not be trusted. 'Henceforth, I intend to turn away from women and cocaine, to put myself in conformity with the new republican morality,' he said sardonically. He claimed he was betrayed by the Sudanese 'for money'. In 1994 French agents, eager to seek revenge for the killings of colleagues nearly 20 years earlier in Paris, abducted him from his villa near Khartoum with the assistance of the Sudanese, drugged him and hauled him back to Paris in a sack to stand trial. Ramírez maintains the abduction was illegal.

Did he fear assassination now? 'Jean Baklouti (former assistant director of the French security services) said that he had attempted 33 actions against me! How many more must have been tried by other countries. I don't fear for my life. I am a Muslim!' What did he want inscribed on his tomb? 'Below my name, this: "Salim Saliom Mohammed - Habib Allah".'

In a letter to Jeune Afrique magazine two years ago, Ramírez nominated Osama bin Laden as his successor to lead the struggle against 'imperialist aggression'. He hailed the Saudi dissident as the new scourge of the West.

Asked now if there is a 'nouveau Carlos', the terrorist replied: 'Is that a new commercial product cloned from Beaujolais?' Then he added: 'Before me there was a Carlos, and there will be others, rest assured.'
