fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Kate's not the only member of the Winslet clan to earn a living as a performer. Her father Roger and sister Beth have also developed a taste for the limelight. But any talk of a British 'acting dynasty' is, they say, ridiculous
fields.trailText: Kate's not the only member of the Winslet clan to earn a living as a performer. Her father Roger and sister Beth have also developed a taste for the limelight. But any talk of a British 'acting dynasty' is, they say, ridiculous.
fields.body:
Beth Winslet: We grew up in a small terraced house on a main road in Reading. It wasn't a wealthy upbringing, but we were really happy. Dad was always entertaining. He'd take me, Mum, my elder sisters Anna and Kate, and my younger brother Josh on holidays to the seaside. One of my earliest memories is being at the beach on the Isle of Wight and Dad doing a moonie. And just as he did it a lady walked past with a baby in a buggy. And we all rolled around laughing.

At home there was always lots of singing and putting on plays. We'd tap dance in the kitchen and get told off and have to scrub the floor. And we went to see Dad's plays. He was like the majority of actors: often out of work or doing tiny bit parts like Snug the Joiner, or a baker who was shut in his own oven. Kate is an extreme example of success, and being her sister hasn't made me think it's any more achievable. People say: 'Well, if your sister's doing it, so can you.' But she's a rare talent and most people aren't that fortunate.

I joined an amateur dramatics group when I was 10 and did lots of plays. At school, I had the mickey taken out of me because I had big Mick Jagger lips and the hugest mouth. After leaving school at 17, I joined the National Youth Theatre, got an agent and did a BBC drama, The Scold's Bride. The following year I made the film Bodywork (opens nationwide on 20 October) and met Gareth [Rhys Jones] who wrote and directed it. We're expecting a baby next month. I've always been family oriented and I'd found Gareth, so it seemed like the right time to start a family.

Dad has sat back and let each of us make our own way, go down our own paths and make our own mistakes. But he's been there when we've needed him. I went through a bout of illness when I was 17 and Dad was the one who took me seriously. Mum told me to take a paracetemol and lie down. I ended up in hospital needing an operation.

To call the Winslets an 'acting dynasty' is ridiculous. Although, I guess it does run in the family: Dad's aunts were in a vaudeville troupe, my uncle was an actor, and my grandparents founded a theatre company. Maybe if acting hadn't been around me I might have done something different. But I am pursuing other things in between acting: I've been working at a Rudolph Steiner school, which I love, and I'm about to start assisting a silversmith. And after years of hanging in there with acting, Dad is now gigging as a singer with his own songs.

Roger Winslet: I was kind of surprised that Beth and her sisters have all pursued acting. At the end of the day they have done what they wanted to do. I don't think there is any rivalry between them. That would smack of competition. They all accept their natural gifts as individuals. Kate's success hasn't been a strain or a problem. You try to take things in your stride and not let the family unit change.

I always felt that I could be an actor, but didn't get any breaks in the professional world. It's a bit of a sad way of life if you aren't getting the work to sustain you. It is a great life when you do get a job, experiencing the camaraderie of working with other actors. But I always had long periods between acting jobs, and these downtimes have been particularly difficult periods in my life. All my children have been sympathetic in a constructive way.

In between I'd do casual unskilled jobs, such as construction work. I do see elements of myself in Beth. She's stubborn, like I can be. We think similarly. I think she conceals her feelings sometimes, whereas I'm probably a bit more open and volatile. They all have a tremendous sense of fun, and relish the chance to come up with a dry comment every now and then. None of them wanted to be great scholars, they've educated themselves.

It was during a fairly traumatic time in my life when I felt what it was to have a strong family around me. I was in a boat accident and needed reconstructive surgery on my foot. Two years later, when I was finally out of plaster and moving about - although still with great difficulty - I went back on the boat for a three-week trip. I had to go back to stop dreaming about it. Now, when I look back, I realise the accident could have been a lot worse. I could've lost my leg.

I didn't get married until I was 28, then didn't start having children for another four years. I think it's wonderful that Beth and Kate are pregnant. We are as close as most families and try to get together on Sundays, if possible, and at Easter, Christmas and on birthdays.

I don't think I'm a very wise person. I'm pretty dumb at times. I wanted the girls to be as honest as they can to other people and themselves. And to be aware of what a tough business the acting game is. Success doesn't come easy. As youngsters they seem to have made their own way, and long may it continue.
fields.bodyText: Beth Winslet: We grew up in a small terraced house on a main road in Reading. It wasn't a wealthy upbringing, but we were really happy. Dad was always entertaining. He'd take me, Mum, my elder sisters Anna and Kate, and my younger brother Josh on holidays to the seaside. One of my earliest memories is being at the beach on the Isle of Wight and Dad doing a moonie. And just as he did it a lady walked past with a baby in a buggy. And we all rolled around laughing. At home there was always lots of singing and putting on plays. We'd tap dance in the kitchen and get told off and have to scrub the floor. And we went to see Dad's plays. He was like the majority of actors: often out of work or doing tiny bit parts like Snug the Joiner, or a baker who was shut in his own oven. Kate is an extreme example of success, and being her sister hasn't made me think it's any more achievable. People say: 'Well, if your sister's doing it, so can you.' But she's a rare talent and most people aren't that fortunate. I joined an amateur dramatics group when I was 10 and did lots of plays. At school, I had the mickey taken out of me because I had big Mick Jagger lips and the hugest mouth. After leaving school at 17, I joined the National Youth Theatre, got an agent and did a BBC drama, The Scold's Bride. The following year I made the film Bodywork (opens nationwide on 20 October) and met Gareth [Rhys Jones] who wrote and directed it. We're expecting a baby next month. I've always been family oriented and I'd found Gareth, so it seemed like the right time to start a family. Dad has sat back and let each of us make our own way, go down our own paths and make our own mistakes. But he's been there when we've needed him. I went through a bout of illness when I was 17 and Dad was the one who took me seriously. Mum told me to take a paracetemol and lie down. I ended up in hospital needing an operation. To call the Winslets an 'acting dynasty' is ridiculous. Although, I guess it does run in the family: Dad's aunts were in a vaudeville troupe, my uncle was an actor, and my grandparents founded a theatre company. Maybe if acting hadn't been around me I might have done something different. But I am pursuing other things in between acting: I've been working at a Rudolph Steiner school, which I love, and I'm about to start assisting a silversmith. And after years of hanging in there with acting, Dad is now gigging as a singer with his own songs. Roger Winslet: I was kind of surprised that Beth and her sisters have all pursued acting. At the end of the day they have done what they wanted to do. I don't think there is any rivalry between them. That would smack of competition. They all accept their natural gifts as individuals. Kate's success hasn't been a strain or a problem. You try to take things in your stride and not let the family unit change. I always felt that I could be an actor, but didn't get any breaks in the professional world. It's a bit of a sad way of life if you aren't getting the work to sustain you. It is a great life when you do get a job, experiencing the camaraderie of working with other actors. But I always had long periods between acting jobs, and these downtimes have been particularly difficult periods in my life. All my children have been sympathetic in a constructive way. In between I'd do casual unskilled jobs, such as construction work. I do see elements of myself in Beth. She's stubborn, like I can be. We think similarly. I think she conceals her feelings sometimes, whereas I'm probably a bit more open and volatile. They all have a tremendous sense of fun, and relish the chance to come up with a dry comment every now and then. None of them wanted to be great scholars, they've educated themselves. It was during a fairly traumatic time in my life when I felt what it was to have a strong family around me. I was in a boat accident and needed reconstructive surgery on my foot. Two years later, when I was finally out of plaster and moving about - although still with great difficulty - I went back on the boat for a three-week trip. I had to go back to stop dreaming about it. Now, when I look back, I realise the accident could have been a lot worse. I could've lost my leg. I didn't get married until I was 28, then didn't start having children for another four years. I think it's wonderful that Beth and Kate are pregnant. We are as close as most families and try to get together on Sundays, if possible, and at Easter, Christmas and on birthdays. I don't think I'm a very wise person. I'm pretty dumb at times. I wanted the girls to be as honest as they can to other people and themselves. And to be aware of what a tough business the acting game is. Success doesn't come easy. As youngsters they seem to have made their own way, and long may it continue.

fields.headline: Easy driver
fields.standfirst: William Fotheringham, the Observer's cycling correspondent, can't understand why people find the Tour de France so gruelling but BMW's new 330d SE Touring might have something to do with it
fields.trailText: William Fotheringham, the Observer's cycling correspondent, can't understand why people find the Tour de France so gruelling but BMW's new 330d SE Touring might have something to do with it.
fields.body:
There is no going back if you're driving the Tour de France route. The world's greatest bike race travels along the world's longest one-way street: 2,500 miles of closed roads around France lined with impassive gendarmes and screaming cycling fans, an interminable sens unique which always ends on the Champs Elysées.

As a spectacle, the Tour is as much a 2,000-strong parade of motor vehicles as a bike race. The 180 cyclists are hidden somewhere among the floats bunging out freebie publicity material, the imposing blue BMW motorbikes of the Garde Republicaine, garish vehicles carrying corporate guests, and cars bearing spare bikes and wheels. Unless they are strung out over an Alpine pass, the skeletally thin cyclists with their farmers' tans take only a couple of minutes to pass. The cars keep coming for hours and hours, and simply heighten the crowds' sense of anticipation.

Apart from les coureurs, they have come to see the 'publicity caravan' (the 'junk train' to aficionados) - 250 vehicles advertising everything from insurance to mail-order clothing, including trick motorcyclists, go-karts with oversize gas cylinders on top, cabriolets from which hotpant-clad go-go dancers dance at impossible angles, and 8ft-high coffee machines on vans.

To be strictly accurate, the crowds have not come to see, but to scrabble for the free samples - canvas washing bags, sachets of coffee, bags of sweets. It is a child's dream and a parent's nightmare. On Bastille Day this year, a 12-year-old boy was killed when a car containing public relations people from a race sponsor left the road. Given that an estimated 10 million roadside fans, some drunk and all hyper, watch the race each year, it is a wonder there are so few accidents.

On the Tour, everything that can be done is done on the move. Cyclists receive medical attention hanging on to the race doctor's car at 30mph, and have their gears adjusted by mechanics hanging out of car windows. Corporate hospitality is a carefully choreographed waltz between cars driven by former Tour stars driving as close to the cyclists as safety permits, and plush mobile homes where uniformed hostesses serve caviar and champagne.

The Tour's caravan takes over smaller venues such as Briançon, a little fortress town in the Alps, which was gridlocked for a whole evening as the race vehicles merged with the cars and camper vans of thousands of cycling fans. That night, Britain's only cyclist in the race, the young David Millar, was outraged at spending two and a half hours sitting in the bouchon to go 15 miles to his hotel, and this after some eight-and-a-half hours in the saddle.

As much attention goes into choreographing the four-wheeled show as into running the two-wheeled race. Parking is carefully planned, but always overflowing. Elaborate routes are devised for getting the Tour's cars through start and finish towns. Each 'family' - media, organisation, publicity caravan, teams - is segregated. Where the Tour starts and finishes is dictated as much by the need to find 2,000 car and lorry parking spaces as by aesthetic, sporting or commercial considerations.

Each year since my first Tour in 1990, before I leave I come across a kindly, naive person who will ask 'and will you cycle, too?' A hollow laugh accompanies the answer: like all those who follow the grande bouclé - the 'great belt' as it circumnavigates France - home for the four weeks is a car. Not because following the Tour entails sleeping in the car but because as each stage brings fresh countryside, a hotel which can be dive or château, a hôtel de ville or a marquee in a meadow serving as press room, the car interior is the only surrounding which stays the same.

As well as the story of Lance Armstrong or Miguel Indurain, each Tour for me is the story of my car: a black box with no air conditioning during a particularly hot summer became known as 'Hole'; an eminently forgettable motor earned the name 'Pig'; a flighty young thing seemed to suit 'Sarah'. This year, it was the Tour of 'Le Bimmer' - a BMW 330d SE Touring to give it its full moniker - and we spent four weeks getting to know each other. And there were so many added extras in Le Bimmer that it took me almost the whole month to discover all of them.

The Tour offers every motoring environment from Alpine passes to autoroutes, and Le Bimmer loved them all. There was power to spare uphill - even packing three adults and their luggage. 'Diesel' is a term used in cycling to refer to a cyclist who has superlative stamina, but no speed - the 330d, however, has plenty of the latter. There is none of the hesitation expected from a diesel engine, and a far better response than many petrol engines when overtaking. The bumph says it delivers 184bhp and 390NM of torque - a Tourman would say it surges forward like a sprinter flying out of the pack.

On less-than-smooth roads, the ride was somewhat harsh - mostly due to the ultra-low-profile tyres and sports suspension - but this was a small price to pay for the traction when it came to hairpinned descents from the great Alpine cols, taken as if on rails with never a hint of tyre squeak or rear-end float. Autoroutes - as you would expect from a German product - were devoured smoothly and silently.

Inside, attention to detail was ever-present, but never fussy. Extra storage space under the boot floor - although this would still be a tight fit for a family above the toddler stage - automatic headlight wash, central elbow rest at the perfect height. And optional gadgets, such as the Global Positioning System: perfect for finding a stage start in darkest, downtown Nantes. Occasionally, it provided perverse pleasure as I drove onwards, ignoring the electronic voice imploring me to make a u-turn.

The biggest surprise, though, was the cost of running 'Le Bimmer' through France: she sipped as daintily as a Parisienne at her morning café au lait - between 37 and 40 miles per gallon over the 5,000 miles, depending on terrain. In France, diesel (joyously), costs as little as 50p per litre at most supermarkets, and so I slipped back in time to the days when you could travel 450 miles and fill your tank for well under £30.

I spent most of the Tour wondering how Lance Armstrong managed to go so fast for so long on his anorexic diet: somehow, Le Bimmer pulled off precisely the same feat on four wheels as he did on two.

 The Observer sailed with Brittany Ferries. For all enquiries, call 0870 5 360 360; or go to www.brittany-ferries.com.

fields.headline: French revolution
fields.standfirst: Herbert Ypma may have travelled the world in search of hip hotels and inspiring interiors. But for luxurious elegance, he'll always have Paris
fields.trailText: Herbert Ypma may have travelled the world in search of hip hotels and inspiring interiors. But for luxurious elegance, he'll always have Paris.
fields.body:
Herbert Ypma has one of the most enviable of lives. He spends his days researching glossy, coffee table books about hotels and interiors. His Hip Hotels series has given him the perfect reason (as if any were needed) to travel to exotic and far-flung destinations and check into some of the world's most luxurious and stylish hotels. His books on interiors and architecture have taken him from Mexico to Morocco, where he photographs kasbahs, mud castles, hotels and markets, designed to inspire, and make his readers dream. In Sweden, he has explored the Ice Hotel which is allowed to melt each year and is then rebuilt; in Chile, he has sought out the remote Hotel Explora, perched high above a waterfall in the wilds of Patagonia.

Needless to say, he's a hard man to track down. His publishers never know quite where he is, or where he might be going. He himself is not quite sure where he lives anymore. Hip Hotels France will be out next spring. Right now he's working on the next volume of Hip Hotels, an edition devoted to interesting and unusual places to stay for between £20 and £80.

In between Hip Hotels, however, Ypma has been spending quite a lot of time in Paris, working on his new book, The Paris Interior, to be published in early November. The aim of the book, he says, was to define the very essence of the Parisian interior. There are mountains of books out there covering everything from Paris apartments, monuments, cafés and restaurants to bridges and metro stations, but they all, he says, miss the point. His idea was to spell out the precise elements that add up to the typical Parisian interior.

'Whether in an ad for perfume or a film by the likes of Polanski or Bertolucci,' he writes in the introduction, 'we recognise a Parisian setting before we are told - if indeed we are told at all. Why? Because there is a visual language at play that is unique to Paris.' It starts with the Louis XVI chair, and goes right through to the wooden panels of the boiserie, integral to most apartments in the city.

'You cannot separate the history of Paris and its interiors,' he explains on the phone during a brief touchdown somewhere in France. 'There are definite things that you can pinpoint as Parisian style.' Element number one is undoubtedly the Louis XVI chair. 'It's an incredibly well-designed piece of furniture,' he says, a design classic that is simultaneously of its time and timeless, more popular now (in terms of numbers produced) than at the time of the Bourbons. Then, the nobility would muse over the design and detail of their specially commissioned chair for days on end. It was their status symbol, in the same way as a certain car or handbag might be today.

'It was a period when furniture manufacturing was briefly elevated to the status of high art,' he writes. Each chair would have been painstakingly hand-made by specialist craftsmen. Louis XV's bureau du roi took a team of craftspeople seven years to finish, and every chair that was commissioned for his palace would have been given the same treatment.

It is this understanding and love of the art and craft of furniture that has helped to define the Parisian style. In Britain, the Industrial Revolution was all about mass-production and cutting costs. In France, however, there was a culture of making large numbers of a product, but by hand - irrespective of the amount it would cost or the time it would take. There is an ingrained love of luxury, although today it is the style and shape of the furniture made for Louis XV and XVI that are imitated, rather than the quality of the craftsman-ship. 'It is almost impossible to conceive of a stylish Paris interior without its Louis XV or Louis XVI chairs: whether upholstered with tapestry or plain silk, they can be found in almost every grand hotel or chic apartment.' Oh, and if you are wondering, the way to i tell the difference between Louis XV and XVI is simple: just take a look at the legs.

The earlier king favoured curved legs, while Louis XVI preferred his straight and tapered.

Paris interiors did not end with the 18th century, however. According to Ypma, they are very much alive and well today. Alongside the elements of style guaranteed to make an appearance in the Parisian apartment, including the clock, ('They were such objects of desire,' he says. 'If you commissioned a clock, you would have it made in your style'), chinoiserie, wood panelling, parquet floors, and the odd touch of the rococo, is the objet trouvé.

'I think history can be really intriguing and fascinating,' says Ypma. 'An apartment without something from the past lacks a story.' And the perfect place to find something with a story is the flea market. Paris has several, from Clignancourt to Porte de Montreuil, each throwing up a seemingly endless supply of antiques, junk, novelties and - a favourite of Ypma's - copper pots. Sunday mornings are the time to go out in search of that Louis chair, the little crystal chandelier, or the baroque candlestick. The more faded and distressed, the better. It's all about character and eclecticism; bringing the interiors and furniture of the past to life by mixing unusual pieces, and making something out of nothing.

Although Ypma himself does not have a Paris apartment, he has had no shortage of rooms to inspire him. He visits the city about 20 times a year, and is, of course, no stranger to some of the best and most characterful hotels. There's the Montalambert on the Left Bank, which he says is 'pretty, small and elegantly designed'; L'Hotel, near the Ecole des Beaux Arts, where all the rooms are different and 'very funky, if a little run down'; or the Lancaster, which is more traditional and classical. Even if he doesn't know where he is going to be from one week to the next, one thing is for sure: wherever he is in Paris, he can feel secure that there will be a Louis XVI chair to rest his weary, well-travelled legs.

fields.headline: Stress busters
fields.standfirst: Modern life can be hell. So help control your stress levels by changing what - and when - you eat and drink
fields.trailText: Modern life can be hell. So help control your stress levels by changing what - and when - you eat and drink.
fields.body:
I am certainly not perfect when it comes to eating properly. It's normally stress that throws my eating habits out of kilter, when, bar breakfast, the day can whizz by without much more than the odd piece of fruit passing my lips. So, believe me, when you're lurching from one crisis to the next, I understand only too well how hard it can be to take the time to eat nutritious food. I therefore thought that I'd devote this week's column to taking you through what's good to eat when your stress levels are running high.

The most important thing to know is what to eat and drink at the end of the day to help you to wind down. It can mean the difference between collapsing into bed totally exhausted but unable to switch off, or secure in the knowledge that you have given your body what it needs to get a good night's sleep. The complex group of carbohydrates are your greatest ally in this respect. A bowl of pasta, risotto or polenta, a jacket potato or a helping of mashed potatoes, will all have a calming effect that will lull you into a deep, body-nurturing sleep.

When deciding on a sauce, however, remember that the excessive amounts of fat in creamy, buttery or oily sauces are hard for a stressed, sensitive stomach to digest, especially if it has had very little food over the course of the day. If food isn't eaten, digestive juices aren't produced, and the liver slows down accordingly. If you then pick up a fatty food, like a kebab, burger or fish and chips, on the way home, it will sit heavily in your stomach, waiting until there are sufficient digestive juices to break it down.

Because the body doesn't tolerate undigested fat well, it will try to get rid of it as quickly as possible, causing you to suffer from heartburn or even to rush to the loo.

So opt for a tomato-based pasta sauce or a risotto made with stock. Avoid fried foods in favour of grilled or baked ones. Both adults and children often tolerate cooked vegetables better than raw salad ingredients, which can be hard for a stressed gut to digest in the evening.

Tempting as it is to hit the bottle with a vengeance when you are under stress, remember that alcohol on top of anxiety aggravates the body's adrenaline response and disrupts sleeping patterns. And if drunk on an under-nourished as well as anxious stomach, alcohol can wreak absolute havoc, lowering your blood-sugar levels and making you feel ravenous, so that when you do eventually get round to eating, you tend to eat too much too quickly. Then, not only will your gut complain throughout the night, but you'll probably feel slightly hung over in the morning. Drinking alcohol on an empty stomach can also weaken the muscle lining holding the top and the bottom of the stomach taut, making you more prone to heartburn. Because the presence of food in the stomach cushions these negative effects, postpone the booze until after you've eaten. Ideally, you would make your body a caffeine-free zone and instead drink plenty of water. Dissolving a few drops of essential oil, such as lavender, bergamot, neroli or juniper, in your bathwater can also have a calming effect.

Steadying your blood-sugar levels is as important in the morning as it is during the rest of the day, and a bowl of honey-coated or sugary breakfast cereal, a Danish pastry or a sweet drink will send them surging upwards.

fields.headline: Hard for hearing
fields.standfirst: If deafness can be detected soon after birth, why are some children not diagnosed until they reach school?
fields.trailText: If deafness can be detected soon after birth, why are some children not diagnosed until they reach school?
fields.body:
All parents of young children dread the 'terrible twos', when seemingly overnight their charming toddler mutates into a raging monster. But when Alice Ford turned two it was different.

A family holiday abroad descended into nightmare for parents Andy and Angie. By the end of the short flight, Andy had blood running down his neck where Alice had torn at him with her nails. During the stay, Alice had not only pushed another child into the deep end of a swimming pool, where he had to be rescued by lifeguards, but she had also shoved an entire restaurant table into the harbour.

For Andy, a computer-company project manager, and Angie, a teacher, who live in Sheffield, it was the last straw. They had been concerned for some time that Alice's development seemed slow, her speech poor and her hearing variable. But every time they raised their anxieties with health professionals they were told not to worry. Even though Alice failed her health visitor's hearing test at nine months, they were reassured when she sailed through the re-test weeks later and passed a further test, for speech, at 18 months. Returning from holiday, they were so desperate that they consulted a child psychologist, who recommended simply ignoring Alice for two hours every time she misbehaved.

After a few weeks, she was transformed into a calm, compliant child. With hindsight, Andy believes it was the cruellest thing he has ever done. 'We are wracked with guilt about it,' he says. 'It breaks my heart.'

What Andy and Angie now know is that Alice is deaf. She was born deaf. Yet, despite her parents' repeated concerns and after numerous tests, Alice's deafness was not diagnosed until she was more than three-and-a-half years old. By this time, Andy and Angie were so convinced she could not hear that they did their own test - hiding behind Alice and asking her to repeat words. Alice, it transpired, had somehow taught herself to lip-read. Once a speaker was out of sight, she failed to respond.

Finally, the Fords were granted a thorough hospital hearing check which proved Alice had moderate to severe hearing loss. She was almost four - just two months off starting school - by the time she had hearing aids fitted. Andy remembers the moment well. 'She smiled the most enormous smile she had ever smiled in her life,' he says.

Now 11, Alice has just started secondary school after doing well in her junior-school exams. But Andy is certain her education has suffered from her late diagnosis.

'I think it took her virtually all of junior school to catch up,' he says. What makes matters worse is knowing that Alice's deafness could have been detected within a few days of birth through a simple, quick and safe test developed more than 10 years ago, but still not universally available.

About 840 children are born each year in the UK with permanent deafness, mainly due to genetic damage to the cochlea or auditory nerve. So it makes sense that all children are called at around eight months old for a routine hearing test performed by health visitors to detect permanent hearing problems.

The trouble is that the check, called the infant distraction test, is woefully unreliable. It detects at best 60 per cent, at worst 18 per cent, of permanent hearing loss, according to studies. Like Alice, many deaf children sail through with flying colours, while children with perfect hearing frequently fail and have to go for further checks. In fact, most hearing problems are actually detected by parents or health professionals independently of the test. Even so, more than half of children born deaf are still undiagnosed at 18 months, and a quarter are not diagnosed until more than three-and-a-half, according to the National Deaf Children's Society (NDCS). Late diagnosis, the society warns, delays giving vital help to deaf children - such as hearing aids and cochlea implants - and can cause lasting problems with the child's language, education, behaviour and even mental health.

Yet there is a test, the transient-evoked otoacoustic emissions (TEOAE) test, which can be done in hospital within days of birth, by inserting a tiny probe into a baby's ear, and which is almost foolproof. Developed in the 80s, it takes minutes, is totally safe and costs less than the health-visitor test. But the TEOAE is performed routinely on newborn babies in just a handful of UK hospitals. Generally, it is used only when family history suggests a baby might be deaf, despite the fact that 90 per cent of deaf children are born to families with no such history.

This summer, the government announced pilot studies beginning next year to introduce TEOAE for all newborn children in 20 areas in England. But national TEOAE screening of all babies - replacing the health-visitor test - will not begin until possibly two or three years later. In that time, another 400 deaf children a year will go undiagnosed, and suffer in silence, like Alice.

Evidence that the TEOAE works better than the infant-distraction test is already inarguable, according to John Bamford, professor of audiology at Manchester University. A study comparing the two tests found 96 per cent of deaf children were identified by nine months with the TEOAE but only half with the health-visitors' test.

The main problem, he says, is that the infant-distraction test is subjective and dependent on circumstances. Introduced nationally in the 60s, it involves two health visitors: one holding the baby's attention, while the other stands behind the child making noises with special rattles and other equipment. Hearing is assessed by the baby's ability to turn towards the sounds. But in a busy health clinic, the test is often distorted because babies turn towards other noises, shadows, and even a health visitor's perfume. This means deaf children often pass the test while hearing children fail, causing unnecessary anxiety for parents and clogging up hospital clinics.

The TEOAE is not only significantly better at detecting deafness, it also does it earlier, allowing help to be given sooner. Bamford says: 'There is now quite good emerging data that the earlier you identify children with a significant hearing problem and offer intervention - whether parental information or devices like hearing aids - the quicker the benefits.'

An expert group investigating the issue, for which Professor Bamford was a member, recommended national TEOAE screening in 1997. Further delay means more deaf children will go undiagnosed and untreated before national screening comes in, warns Bamford, although he accepts the need to iron out teething problems through pilot studies.

Even health visitors support abandoning their test in favour of neonatal screening but, according to the Community Practitioners and Health Visitors Association, they also back pilots first.

Susan Daniels, chief executive of the NDCS, which has campaigned for over 10 years for neonatal screening, is less content. Although delighted at the government's pledge to bring in national newborn screening, the 'most important development for deaf children since the invention of the hearing aid,' she sees no reason to wait.

'We believe there is enough information today, from the States and other areas in Europe doing national screening, to be able to roll this out as soon as possible,' she says. Indeed, a law was passed in the US last year supporting newborn-deafness screening in every state. She adds: 'The importance of early diagnosis just cannot be overestimated. Parents need to know as soon as they possibly can.'

Diana Glover, who has two out of three sons born deaf, supports that whole-heartedly. Second son Robin's hearing problems were dismissed by health professionals as 'glue ear', a common childhood complaint when fluid gathers behind the eardrum, until he was finally diagnosed with profound deafness at 19 months. Younger brother Benjamin was diagnosed within weeks of birth and had hearing aids fitted at three months, followed by a cochlea implant at two years. The difference, she says, is still obvious. Robin, now 17, is studying A levels at a school for deaf children and still struggles with language, while Benjamin, eight, is managing well in mainstream education.

'I can see, with two deaf boys, the difference that early diagnosis makes,' says Diana. 'If you find out your child is deaf it is going to be a shock anyway, but if you have time on your side to make important decisions and for them to get used to hearing aids, it's so much more rewarding than finding you have missed so many crucial months and they are way behind.'

Now hear this

About one in every 1,000 babies is born deaf in the UK. A further 160 children become permanently deaf every year, mostly through meningitis. In addition, most children under five have bouts of 'glue ear', but this normally clears up on its own.

Only a handful of UK hospitals perform the transient-evoked otoacoustic emissions (TEOAE) test on newborn babies. Most only do the test when there is a family history of deafness. Almost all health districts invite children for the infant-distraction test, performed by health visitors, at between six to nine months. Nine out of 10 British children undergo this test. Studies show its success in detecting hearing problems varies from 18 to 60 per cent. Most children who fail the test have normal hearing. The government has promised to introduce national neonatal screening using the TEOAE test - but not until it analyses the results of 20 pilot studies due to begin next year.

 If you're worried about your child's hearing, call the NDCS helpline (020 7250 0123) weekdays 10am-5pm.

fields.headline: Brew ha ha
fields.standfirst: Naturally brewed Japanese soy sauce is worth making a fuss over
fields.trailText: Naturally brewed Japanese soy sauce is worth making a fuss over.
fields.body:
I could survive without wine, possibly even without Cohiba cigars, but not without my bottle of Kikkoman's soy sauce. If you are someone who grabs any old brand of soy sauce from the supermarket shelves, you will think I'm mad. Why in the world would I crave such a salty seasoning? The answer, of course, lies in its deliciously complex, savoury taste, achieved I might add, by a careful balance of roasted wheat, defatted steamed soya beans, and a couple of Aspergillus moulds, all of which are then cultured and gently fermented for six months.

Soy sauce can vary widely in taste and appearance. It can be light or dark, thick or thin, sweet or salty. The Chinese, for example, tend to make quite salty, intensely flavoured soy sauces, while the Indonesians are famed for their viscous, sweet Kecap. The Japanese have refined the art so that every sauce has a purpose: Their light, amber-coloured salty sauce (usu-kuchi shoyu) is used for seasoning, as it won't spoil the look of a dish; while their dark, intensely flavoured Tamari sauce, made solely from fermented soy beans, is reserved for refined dipping and Yakitori sauces.

The one soy sauce you should avoid like the plague is a synthetic one - in other words a soy sauce that has not been naturally brewed. Aside from containing hydrolysed vegetable protein, hydrochloric acid, caramel and corn syrup, rather than just soy beans, wheat and salt, you can tell it is synthetic by the lack of that essential word 'natural' on the label.

My affection for Kikkoman's soy sauce began many years ago with my fondness for a stir-fried supper. Unwittingly, I bought a bottle and discovered that it added a wonderful depth of flavour to my food. The wheat subtly imbues the sauce with an underlying mellow sweetness, perfect for enhancing the taste of beef, duck or chicken. This led me on to marinades, honey chilli dips, crunchy noodle salads and nasi gorengs. All part of life's essentials, especially when followed by a soothing Cohiba and a glass of Rémy Martin.

fields.headline: Four of the best
fields.standfirst: Bloody Ploughmans, Knobby Russets, Green Custards Jim Ainsworth knows his apples
fields.trailText: Bloody Ploughmans, Knobby Russets, Green Custards Jim Ainsworth knows his apples.
fields.body:
Despite the one-track Golden Delicious mentality of many supermarkets, Britain has hundreds of apple varieties. Bloody Ploughman is named after a 19th-century Perthshire agricultural worker shot by a gamekeeper for scrumping apples; in compensation his widow was awarded the bag of fruit and threw them away in disgust. They grew, mutated (as apples do), and are now red with a ribbed skin, and a light sweet taste. Green Custard, which has been around since Elizabethan times, derives its name from costard, a general term for apples, which were one of the items sold by costermongers.

Knobby Russet looks most unappetising, and Kent tastes wonderful, but varies wildly in size, so you won't find either in a supermarket. But you will find them among the 2,300 varieties kept by Brogdale Horticultural Trust (Brogdale Road, Faversham, Kent, 01795 535 286), which opens its doors for an apple festival from 11 to 22 October.

Scores of events on Apple Day (21 October) celebrate the diversity and local distinctiveness of apples and orchards. There are tastings, displays, advice, identification parades, games, quizzes, artwork, songs, poetry readings, juicings, you name it, everywhere from Cambridge University Botanic Garden, via a National Trust walled garden near York, to Sulgrave Manor near Banbury (with a cookery demonstration by Sophie Grigson). Contact Common Ground (020 7267 2144).

The Royal Horticultural Society's Garden (Wisley, Woking, Surrey 01483 224 234, and Rosemoor, Great Torrington, Devon, 01805 624 067) also offers apple events (19 to 22 October) with plenty of varieties to taste, as well as advice on the best trees for home planting - Kidd's Orange Red from New Zealand is a particularly reliable Cox-style variety. Some are new crosses such as Fiesta (the fruit commonly sold as Red Pippin), others are traditional varieties that have dropped out of cultivation because they don't suit commercial interests: Ashmead's Kernel may be a dull colour, but is a 'connoisseur's apple'.

Farmers' markets are another good way to try different varieties and support local enterprise. Although economics dictate that an increasing proportion of Anne Stanier's apple crop be turned over to cider varieties, she still sells Discovery, Worcesters, Lambourne, Cox, Russets and Blenheim Orange under the banner of Croft Fruit Farm (at Ledbury Market in Herefordshire on the fourth Wednesday of the month). For details of your nearest farmers' market contact the Soil Association (Bristol House, 40-56 Victoria Street, Bristol, 0117 929 0661).

Apples have long been a part of the David-and-Goliath struggle between small growers and big supermarkets. According to John Breach of the British Independent Fruit Growers' Association, 70 per cent of the apples we buy come from abroad, and big buyers usually incline towards a glut of the cheapest fruit on the international market. British growers, unable simply to produce apples out of a hat once in a while, lose out: native apple acreage has consequently halved over the past 15 years. For sheer interest and variety, as well as supporting home industry, buy apples from a local source where possible. For details of farm-gate and PYO sales, write to the Farm Retail Association (PO Box 575, Southampton, SO15 7ZB) and enclose a first-class stamp, or call 02380 362 150.

fields.bodyText: Despite the one-track Golden Delicious mentality of many supermarkets, Britain has hundreds of apple varieties. Bloody Ploughman is named after a 19th-century Perthshire agricultural worker shot by a gamekeeper for scrumping apples; in compensation his widow was awarded the bag of fruit and threw them away in disgust. They grew, mutated (as apples do), and are now red with a ribbed skin, and a light sweet taste. Green Custard, which has been around since Elizabethan times, derives its name from costard, a general term for apples, which were one of the items sold by costermongers. Knobby Russet looks most unappetising, and Kent tastes wonderful, but varies wildly in size, so you won't find either in a supermarket. But you will find them among the 2,300 varieties kept by Brogdale Horticultural Trust (Brogdale Road, Faversham, Kent, 01795 535 286), which opens its doors for an apple festival from 11 to 22 October. Scores of events on Apple Day (21 October) celebrate the diversity and local distinctiveness of apples and orchards. There are tastings, displays, advice, identification parades, games, quizzes, artwork, songs, poetry readings, juicings, you name it, everywhere from Cambridge University Botanic Garden, via a National Trust walled garden near York, to Sulgrave Manor near Banbury (with a cookery demonstration by Sophie Grigson). Contact Common Ground (020 7267 2144). The Royal Horticultural Society's Garden (Wisley, Woking, Surrey 01483 224 234, and Rosemoor, Great Torrington, Devon, 01805 624 067) also offers apple events (19 to 22 October) with plenty of varieties to taste, as well as advice on the best trees for home planting - Kidd's Orange Red from New Zealand is a particularly reliable Cox-style variety. Some are new crosses such as Fiesta (the fruit commonly sold as Red Pippin), others are traditional varieties that have dropped out of cultivation because they don't suit commercial interests: Ashmead's Kernel may be a dull colour, but is a 'connoisseur's apple'. Farmers' markets are another good way to try different varieties and support local enterprise. webTitle: Sidney Poitier: Making of an icon

fields.headline: Making of an icon
fields.trailText: Philip French considers the development of Poitier's career and his enduring effect on the Hollywood machine.
fields.body:
During the first 50 years of American cinema, blacks were assigned the roles of maids, waiters, porters and cheerful slaves content with their lot. The great dancer, Bill 'Bojangles' Robinson, was only allowed on screen in his late fifties to dance with Shirley Temple; America's greatest black actor, Paul Robeson, had to come to Britain to find parts worthy of him.

Today, Hollywood is full of black stars - James Earl Jones, Danny Glover, Morgan Freeman, Eddie Murphy, Denzel Washington, the list goes on. What happened in between? The answer is Sidney Poitier, who was both a beneficiary of, and significant contributor to, social change. Freeman generously acknowledged the debt he and his generation owed him when Poitier received the American Film Institute's Life Achievement Award in 1992.

After the Second World War, Hollywood made biopics celebrating black-face singer Al Jolson and produced problem pictures starring white actors about blacks passing for white. Then in No Way Out (1950) Joseph L Mankiewicz broke the mould by casting the unknown 26-year-old Poitier as a black intern confronted by racist hoodlum Richard Widmark in an American city on the brink of inter-racial warfare. It was a strong role in a film so outspoken for its time that it wasn't shown in the South and was censored in some northern states.

The tall, handsome, quietly spoken Poitier gave substance to a saintly, forgiving character, whose banked-up anger was expressed through those hypnotic eyes that penetrate and interrogate his antagonists and his audience. This was the first of a succession of understanding doctors, lawyers, social workers, teachers and cops that he was to embody over the next 20 years. They made him the first black superstar, 'an actor for all races' as one observer called him.

His three finest films of the 50s were Richard Brooks's The Blackboard Jungle (1955), where he was an angry but sympathetic pupil at a New York trade school challenging Glenn Ford as the representative of a prejudiced social system; Martin Ritt's Edge of the City (1957), in which he befriended a bewildered John Cassevetes on the New York waterfront and had a showdown with racist foreman Jack Warden; and Stanley Kramer's preachy but hard-hitting The Defiant Ones (1959), which brought him an Oscar nomination as a convict on the run chained to racist redneck Tony Curtis.

His best roles of the 60s were the sardonic journalist sussing out cold warrior Richard Widmark aboard a US warship in The Bedford Incident (1965), and Virgil Tibbs, the supercool homicide detective tangling with dim-witted Southern sheriff Rod Steiger in Norman Jewison's In The Heat of the Night (1967). But the movie that brought him an Oscar was Ralph Nelson's Lilies of the Fields (1963), a sentimental tale of a kindly itinerant labourer helping a party of East German nuns in Arizona.

Self-parody continued with Kramer's Guess Who's Coming to Dinner, a reductio ad absurdum of the earnest liberal movie in which Spencer Tracy has trouble deciding whether he'll allow his daughter to marry Poitier, a doctor of international renown with impeccable manners, on the point of winning a Nobel Prize. This smug movie appeared during the most contentious days of the civil rights movement and strident Black Power leaders called Poitier an 'Uncle Tom'.

But in 1957 he had become the nation's third biggest box-office star, and as he said: 'I'm the only Negro actor who works with any degree of regularity. I represent 10 million people in this country and millions more in Africa. Wait till there are six of us, then one of us can play villains all the time.'

Poitier had no memorable roles in the 70s and by the end of the decade had switched entirely to directing lightweight comedies of no particular distinction. But in 1988 he returned to the screen giving weight to Roger Spottiswoode's Deadly Pursuit as an FBI chief, and he followed this up with another pair of authority figures - a former senior CIA man in Sneakers (1992) and the deputy director of the FBI in The Jackal (1997).

But he figured most strikingly during the 90s in a movie in which he doesn't appear - the screen version of John Guare's Six Degrees of Separation, a dramatisation of the true story of a trickster who entered Manhattan society by posing as Poitier's son. This is a more potent tribute to his fame than his star on the Hollywood Boulevard.

Five classic movie moments

No Way Out
(1950)
In the final scene, Dr Luther Brooks (Poitier) is tending the gunshot wounds of snivelling racist gangster Ray Biddle (Richard Widmark), who's been baiting him mercilessly and stirring up a riot. He says: 'Don't cry, white boy. You're gonna live'

The Blackboard Jungle
(1955)
Gregory Miller (Poitier), angry black student, defies and provokes frustrated liberal teacher Glenn Ford: 'Come on! Go ahead! Hit me!'

Edge of the City
(1957)
Unintimidated black longshoreman Tom Tyler (Poitier) stands up to aggressive racist foreman Charlie (Jack Warden) on the New York docks.

Charlie: I can remember when they didn't let guys like you work around here. You know that hot shot?
Tyler: What kind of guy am I exactly, Charlie?
Charlie: A wise guy.
Tyler: Well, we sneak through now and again.

The Defiant Ones
(1958)
Black convict Noah Cullen (Poitier) foregoes his final chance of escape on a northbound freight train to help the redneck prisoner John Jackson (Tony Curtis) he'd formerly been chained to. He lights a cigarette for the crippled Jackson, cradles him in his arms, and sings a WC Handy blues song, 'Long Gone' as the sheriff and his posse approach.

In The Heat of the Night
(1967)
Virgil Tibbs (Poitier) is arrested for murder in Mississippi, brought before police chief Gillespie (Rod Steiger) and questioned about the money in his wallet.

Gillespie: A coloured can't earn that kind of money, boy. Hell, it's more than I earn in a month. Now where did you earn it?
Tibbs: Philadelphia.
Gillespie: Mississippi?
Tibbs: Pennsylvania.
Gillespie: Now what do you do up there in little old Pennsylvania to earn that kind of money?
Tibbs: I'm a police officer.

To sir, with love: Hollywood on Poitier

Morgan Freeman 'Every man has his one heaven and for me heaven has always been being in the movies. And always in my heaven, since I first started thinking about it, I've had one bright light, Sidney Poitier.'

Denzel Washington 'He's a pioneer. He's like the point man, he's the card that's out-front, and we've all sort of been riding in his draught. A great actor, a wonderful human being.'

Adrian Lester 'I suppose we should judge the measure of a man by his ability to deal with adversity. Sidney Poitier taught himself to speak English. He then went on to become America's number-one box office star at a time when black people were not allowed to go to the same schools or drink from the same fountains as whites. Poitier's achievements are beyond measure. He is the most inspiring actor I have ever seen.'

Robert Townsend 'For me I know Sidney Poitier represented hope because if this one man could have dignity, others could have dignity. He told me once that going into the studio it would be him and only the shoe-shine guy. What Jackie Robinson was to baseball, Sidney was to acting. If there was one person that represented, on a whole, a new image of African-Americans it was Sidney.'

Rod Steiger 'In spite of prejudice and the problems of trying to stay alive, Sidney Poitier moulded himself into an extremely important actor and citizen. One can only gladly respect him.'

William Greaves 'He redefined the way in which we perceived ourselves and the way in which others perceived us. Sidney was a tactician, he was a diplomat. He was someone who understood you couldn't always have everything the way you want it and that you have to sometimes horse-trade Whatever negative roles he may have played, the people have defined as negative, you will see a laundry list of roles in which he projected this positive, interesting, formidable persona which causes people of colour to feel good about themselves. If you look at the whole body of his work in Hollywood you've got to come away with the fact that he was a major contributor to the redefining of who the African-American is as a human being.'

Read Burhan Wazir's interview with Sidney Poitier here

fields.headline: Go see...
fields.standfirst: 100% design
fields.trailText: 100% design
fields.body:
This week, London has been the centre of attention for the design world. Designers from the UK and across Europe have been displaying their work at showrooms across the capital. The main focus of attention, however, is 100% Design, the massive contemporary furniture and product trade show at Earls Court. This is the place where the professionals go to shop, and where the design companies show off their newest, brightest ideas.

But unlike most trade shows, 100% Design gives the public a chance to get in on the secret, too.

Today, the doors are open to anyone who wants to know how their homes might look if they had a limitless budget and access to some of the more obscure prototypes soon to be on the market. You can drool over new furniture by Gijs Papavoine, Ron Arad and Matthew Hilton, fabrics by Christopher Farr, upholstery by the Azumis, and a brand new range of children's furniture by a collective of designers including Michael Marriott. One-off piecescan also be commissioned direct from many of the exhibiting designers.

If you don't have the stamina to trawl around the whole show, however, make a beeline for the 100% Design/Blueprint Awards stand. The winner of a £2,000 prize was announced on Friday, having been judged stringently by a team of experts, including the Italian architect, Mario Bellini. The innovations include a reversible Flip Table by Michael Sodeau for Isokon; a series of elegant vases by Sebastian Bergne for Driade, and an ingenious Scoop stool designed by Hugo Eccles for Pallucco.

It's the ultimate one-stop shop, everything you need for the thoroughly modern home. If you miss the show, you can catch up with the Blueprint finalists at a special display at the V&A Museum until 10 October.

The 100% Design Public Day runs today from 10am-6pm at Earls Court 2, London. Observer readers can enter for £8 (usual price £12) by presenting a copy of this magazine at the registration desk. To catch up on the latest news, go to www.100percentdesign.co.uk.

fields.headline: Barefoot Doctor
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: how to grow old gracefully, digest with ease and look after your crowning glory
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: how to grow old gracefully, digest with ease and look after your crowning glory.
fields.body:
Anyone over the age of 29 must be familiar with those days when the sighting of a new grey or facial line triggers an 'ageing crisis'. We all know, intellectually, that we're getting older with every breath and that eventually we will die, but are perhaps thankfully able to ignore the process most of the time and get on with the ramshackle business of living. But on those days when no matter how much you squint into the mirror you can't dispel the proof of ageing, the process becomes suddenly urgent.

Of course, vanity is not the only trigger. Residual aches, pains, or worse, flare up due to unbalanced diet or overindulgence and, instead of feeling at one with your inner child, you feel at one instead with your inner old wrinkly. Naturally, this gives rise to anxiety. Anxiety gives rise to increased spending on hair colour, emotionally soothing face creams, vitamins and even, occasionally, to the making of resolutions to change dietary habits, take up yoga, join the gym or start cycling to work.

But why wait until you're quaking in your boots with mortal fear to make the change? That's like being in a long-term, worsening financial position and ignoring it until the bank shuts off your credit line. Just as with a healthy bank account, it's not so much about always being in credit as it is about keeping a steady flow of cash in and out, and trying to remain in credit most of the time. Bank managers love an account with high activity.

And so it is with your person which, if it isn't to degenerate, stagnate or run out of funds altogether, needs consistent high-level input-output - physically, mentally, emotionally and spiritually.

To prevent atrophy, stimulate your mind daily by studying - as informally as you like - something that makes your brain hum with intellectual excitement. Prevent yourself from becoming bored and boring. Keep an active eye on cultural trends and spend regular time interacting with younger people. Discipline your thought patterns to run on positive choices. Whether or not you believe the mind controls the body's self-regenerative powers, you may as well hedge your bets by suggesting to yourself, 'I choose health. I choose longevity. I choose my mind to reprogramme all my cells for health and longevity now.'

Stimulate your body and all its sub-systems by treating it to a daily session of intelligent exercise, meaning exercise performed in such a way as to allow your natural intelligence to travel to all parts and sub-systems of the body simultaneously, as in t'ai chi or yoga, for example, but no less so in running or using free weights if performed correctly. Any Olympic champion will tell you it's not the muscles that win the medal, it's the mind that informs those muscles. This involves breathing efficiently and relaxing the muscles to allow the joints to open and the blood and 'chi' (energy) to flow. In Oriental thought, to leave your daily exercise undone, is tantamount to not washing, so do at least 20 minutes intelligent exercise everyday.

Try to have a steady seven hours' sleep a night, preferably embarked upon before midnight or soon after and do more to consciously forbid yourself to succumb to stressing yourself about anything - ever.

To prevent your emotions from curdling or becoming stultified with age, avoid smothering your feelings with the errant belief that you know all the answers. Be open, be vulnerable. Love those around you as you would have done before kindergarten. Love everyone more, even and especially yourself. Let yourself feel the pain of love - the exercise keeps your heart young. Take up some form of daily meditation, if only for a few minutes a day, to provide instant access to the more peaceful inner realms and give the spirit a bath, so to speak.

None of the above, nor indeed any intervention by healer, doctor, geneticist, nutritionist, pharmacist or life-assurance company can guarantee you freedom from infirmity and eventual death. But you stand to gain immeasurable long-term benefits by taking the game into your own hands.

In the meantime, a most closely guarded Taoist (Chinese) secret of longevity is to ensure a profuse daily intake of thyme which, as well as being a powerful anti-oxidant, is considered by some to be the mystic 'elixir of youth' itself - live long and prosper.

Your questions

Dear Barefoot Doctor, having just been diagnosed with diverticular disease 'along the whole length' of the bowel, I have been instructed to eat fibre, fibre and more fibre. I have always eaten sensibly, but wonder if there is a diet I could follow, as I'm sure there are things I should not eat as well as things I should. For instance, is it best to not eat cakes, biscuits or things with refined sugar? I'd be grateful for suggestions.

 First, you have a condition, not a disease. Nearly half the population over 50 suffer from problems caused by inflammation of the diverticula. The condition can be contained by reducing stress levels in general, avoiding refined foods, sugar, dairy products and alcohol. Avoid mixing protein and carbohydrates. Soak a bowl of oats overnight in water or fruit juice and have them for breakfast each day, and consider a course of Chinese herbal medicine, which can be amazingly efficacious for this. Take slippery elm and perhaps golden seal and aloe-vera juice, and drink peppermint tea often.

Dear Doc, I am a 30-year-old woman and have been suffering from slow but steady hair loss for about 18 months. My doctor is not interested - I have not suffered dramatic weight loss or been pregnant. The hair is not falling out in clumps, nor do I have bald spots, but it is more than just natural moulting. Is there anything I can do to hang on to my hair?

 The hair is controlled by your kidney energy. Although it's a slow process, you need to strengthen the kidneys and increase circulation in the head. Use your fists to massage your kidneys in a circular motion for a few minutes every hour or so. Use your fingertips to percuss and gently massage your scalp. Use peppermint in your shampoo. Visit a Chinese herbalist to tonify your kidneys and an Indian head-massage practitioner to stimulate circulation. Also do headstands, handstands or other inverted yoga postures to encourage circulation. Consider cropping the hair to encourage growth while the kidneys are growing stronger. You should start to see results within 90 days.

Barefoot Doctor is author of Handbook for the Urban Warrior and teaches Taoism, meditation, Chinese medicine and t'ai chi. He has been in practice for more than 20 years, specialising in personal-crisis management.

 If you have any problems you'd like answers to, please write to Barefoot Doctor at Life magazine, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER or email him on barefoot.doctor@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Do you come here often?
fields.standfirst: Some have their own seat at the bar. Others always opt for the same table in   the same restaurant, day after day. Andrew Martin investigates the unchanging   world of the regulars and asks what keeps them coming back for more
fields.trailText:
Some have their own seat at the bar. Others always opt for the same table in 
the same restaurant, day after day. Andrew Martin investigates the unchanging 
world of the regulars and asks what keeps them coming back for more.
fields.body:
What follows was triggered by an encounter with a man in a London pub. I'll call him Jacko. I was sitting on a high seat at the bar when the barman came up to me and said: 'I'm sorry, but you're going to have to move, you're sitting in Jacko's seat.' I turned around and saw a small-ish, old-ish man holding a paperback book. This was Jacko, looking - to do him credit - quite embarrassed. I climbed down from the chair, and he got on to it. As he did so, I noticed a metal plaque on the back: 'Jacko's Chair', it said, 'Keep Off'.

No disrespect to Jacko, but as he settled down at his place, I was reminded of those road signs you see warning of frogs crossing the road. The point is: the frogs aren't going to change their ways, so you'd better change yours. It was the same with Jacko.

I later found out that Jacko - who declined to be interviewed - claims his chair every night at 8pm and reads until the pub closes. He is what you might call an extremely regular person, like Admiral Boom in Mary Poppins, who fires a cannon from the roof of his house every night at 6pm, or Sherlock Holmes's brother, Mycroft, of whom it is said, in the Bruce-Partington Plans, that 'he has his rails and he runs on them', and who went to the Diogenes Club every night between quarter to five and twenty to eight.

Sherlock Holmes, by contrast, was exasperatingly irregular. In The Mazarin Stone, Mrs Hudson asks him what time he'd like dinner, and he says 'Seven thirty, the day after tomorrow'.

This waywardness of Holmes was probably more startling then than it would be today. He 'existed' at a time when many people ate fish on Friday and half the population of England went to church on Sundays. It's true that a century of industrialisation meant that the rhythms of nature were being left behind, but by the late-19th century they'd been replaced by the rhythms of industrial work and commuting - compared by Dickens to the act of breathing, which makes metronomes of us all.

Today, despite the fact that the vast majority of people still travel to their place of work, we like to think we're not so orthodox in our behaviour. Our culture celebrates spontaneity in the form of 'flexible friends', Pay As You Go, Just Do It, lastminute.com, etc. A stigma is attached to regularity, which has overtones of All-Bran and prunes, and it attaches especially to pub regularity. You can't be a mover and shaker - according to current theory - if you have a tankard behind the bar with your name engraved on it.

David Kyffin, landlord of the King's Arms in Oxford, however, sees new regulars all the time. After about four weeks, he makes his move, introducing himself. 'And some of them,' he says, 'just won't have it. They back off. They'd thought no one had noticed them coming in every day, and don't want to be marked down as regulars.'

Mike Smith doesn't mind. He's a former stockbroker, now an amiable postgraduate student at Linacre College. In the mornings, he usually works in the Cecil Rhodes library, around the corner from the King's Arms, always using the same seat in a window bay.

Then, at 12.30pm, five times a week, he comes into the King's Arms. He sits in the back bar, adjacent to the picture of Guy Fawkes. Mindful of Jacko, I asked Mike whether he'd mind if anyone was sitting in the seat when he arrived. 'Nah,' he said, at which David Kyffin interrupted, 'You don't say anything,' he said, 'but I've watched you, and your bottom lip goes out.'

Mike has two pints per lunchtime, and the second is automatically poured for him when the first's finished. Ninety per cent of the time he drinks Guinness, but sometimes he'll opt for a lager 'to keep the staff on their toes'. He comes into the pub not for the booze, but for the conversation. 'We'll talk about what Blair's done Prescott. Occasionally somebody might introduce a literary aspect.' He's been using the pub for four years, and although he's not yet been photographed by David for the gallery of regulars around the walls, it's only a matter of time.

The back bar is the epicentre of regularity at the King's Arms. Basically, there are no tourists there. There used to be no women either, and there was a hierarchy of regulars. 'A newcomer would start in that chair there,' says Dave, 'then he'd work his way around to that one there.' When David started working at the King's Arms 30 years ago, the number-one regular, occupying the top chair (actually a stool at the bar) was Harry Turner, a 'cantankerous old bastard' whom David liked enormously. He not only had a personalised tankard, but also custom-made shelves built into the wall next to his stool to accommodate his snuff-taking gear. You were not allowed to sit on his stool, which was the only one in the pub with a padded top.

Tradition dictated that Harry and most of the regulars of the King's Arms in those days drank halves (they drank a lot of them, mind you), and when Harry turned 80, another King's Arms regular, a brilliant low- temperature physicist called Dr Laurie Mole, carved him a 'beerometer' - a wooden stick with notches representing 80 halves of bitter that Mole had bought upfront for Harry. But the tragedy is that Harry had only worked his way through 40 of these before he died.

David Kyffin is full of such stories about the legendary regulars of the King's Arms. He lists some of their names - Alan Turner, Fabian Barker, Cecil Skinner, Bill Quartermain, Ted East - and I enjoy hearing them. They just have a certain regularity about them. He's the sort of landlord who attracts regulars - a good one, in other words. Another of the breed is Norman Balon of the Coach and Horses in Greek Street, Soho - this despite the fact that he is proudly billed on the pub's match boxes as 'London's rudest landlord'. (Once, I was drinking in the Coach and Horses and one of the regulars, the actor Tom Baker, accidentally stood on my foot and apologised fulsomely for doing so. Overhearing this, Norman barked: 'Oi, stop being so bloody polite!')

Norman is actually a very charming man, but if he doesn't like you, he bars you from his pub, so it's quite an exclusive place. One of the people he did not bar, despite pressure from third parties, was the late Jeffrey Bernard, doyen of regulars, who actually inspired a cartoon strip of that name in Private Eye. The catchphrase was 'Jeff bin in?', and the implicit answer was always yes. 'Jeffrey Bernard,' Balon told me, 'came in at 11 o'clock, and always sat on the same stool. In the early days, he was a Scotch drinker, then it was vodka, then gin. His drinks changed as his tolerance for alcohol decreased.'

But he was very loyal to each of those drinks for many years, seldom wavering in his order, for Bernard, although regarded as a wild man, was actually very steady in certain areas.

Norman thinks regularity is fading, but only slowly - 'because there are more other things you can do now'. He believes that '50 to 60 per cent' of the people in his pub at any one time will be regulars.

The ability to be a magnet for regulars is important in the restaurant trade, as well. Elena Salvoni has it. She is probably London's most celebrated maître d'. She started as a waitress at the Café Bleu in Old Compton Street, moved on to manage Bianchi's in Frith Street, and now she's at L'Etoile in Charlotte Street. Many customers have followed her through all three. 'You've got to remember where people like to sit, what they like to eat,' she says. 'Although sometimes they get stuck on the same thing, and if they do keep saying, "I don't want to see the menu, I'll have the liver," I might say, "Look come on, the lamb's very good."' She tries to stretch them a bit, in other words - it's for their own good. Not that she's against regularity. She's got this little thing she whispers to anyone who comes in three times in a week: 'You've done the hat trick!' Andrew Lloyd Webber and Cameron Mackintosh are two people who've done the hat trick at L'Etoile.

Regulars at the Ivy restaurant in Covent Garden can show you the Michael Parkinson table, the Lloyd Webber table (he gets around, that Lloyd Webber), the table of the agent Anita Land, and so on. Another regular is Lee Menzies, currently producing Jeffrey Archer's play The Accused. He 'more or less always' has the hummus and Lebanese flat bread, then fish and chips, washed down with a glass of champagne and half a bottle of wine.

He is a regular at the Piccadilly in Great Windmill Street, Soho, too. He's been going there every week for 30 years and having the tagliatelle bolognaise and a bottle of house red. I asked him to name another regular at the Piccadilly and he said, somewhat inevitably, 'Andrew Lloyd Webber'. Lee Menzies absolutely never eats pudding, never has coffee, but then again this is a man who's holidayed in room 23 of the Pine de Plage hotel in St Tropez for the past nine years. He's just a regular kind of guy, you might say. 'It's pretty boring,' he admits, 'but you know what you're getting.'

Restaurant-going is increasing dramatically in this country, so there are presumably more restaurant regulars than ever. Perhaps their number compensates for what is surely, despite the anecdotal evidence of Kyffin and Balon, a steep overall decline in pub regularity as a result of the declining number of pubs. (According to the Campaign for Real Ale, they're closing at a rate of 20 a month.) My own suspicion would be that any new activity generates its own regulars. Before long, there'll probably be a large number of people who have virtual-reality sex so habitually that you will be able to set your watch by them.

And according to consultant psychologist Dr Sidney Crown, they'll probably be men. Dr Crown believes that women tend to be less predictable, because they have 'deeper priorities' than sustaining habits - and certainly there are more men than women in this article. Dr Crown thinks that regularity across the board has remained pretty constant. On the one hand, he maintains, we had fewer choices in the past, but the current pressure on us all to work so hard forces us back towards regularity. To some extent, this is fine: 'Using the same beer mug every day helps us establish something about our identity; it's when it gets in the way of our overall effectiveness that it becomes a worry.'

Dr Crown believes that more people are being treated for regularity, partly because obsessive-compulsive disorder, as extreme predictability is now called, is so widely popularised. 'The amount of people who come to see me, sit down and straightaway say, 'I'm OCD' It's terrible.' He thinks they think it's glamorous, whereas nobody ever wanted to be labelled with the old-fashioned term 'neurotic'.

One kind of regularity that undoubtedly is declining, however, is church going. Figures published by Christian Research show that, in 1979, 11.7 per cent of the population of England went to a Christian church on Sundays. The figure today is 7.5 per cent, and of those fewer than half go once a week. Statistics aside, the situation was summed up by the telephonist of the diocese of Durham who, when I called saying I was looking for a regular churchgoer in her area, laughed quite derisively for about 30 seconds.

I did find one, though: Connie Hinds, who's been going to St Mary's church in Cockerton Green, Darlington, for about 50 years. If you go into the choir vestry, you'll see her name recurring many times - on the cleaning rota, the linen rota, the intercessions rota. You don't often find her on the flower rota, funnily enough, but she was joining in the flower arrangements for a forthcoming wedding when I met her. Connie comes to the 9am service on Sunday mornings, and also to evensong on Sunday, although I had to press hard to get the second piece of information, because Connie - a self-effacing, humorous woman - has 'a terrible fear of sounding pi'.

For the past 12 years, she's sat at the back of the church, but, between 1951 and 1988, when she accompanied her mother to church, she sat further forward, underneath the war memorial, because that was her mother's favourite spot. 'For me,' she says, 'the week starts on a Sunday. I need to say thanks, I need to be forgiven.' In her time at St Mary's, Connie has seen 'sidesmen' become 'sidespeople', the growing necessity of locking the church to prevent vandalism, and the following vicars: Mr Porteus, Mr Walker, Mr Sexty, Mr Hall, Mr Kent, Mr Conway and now Mr Wallace. She describes the services as 'always the same and always different'. Some of the sermons connect more with her than others, but the point, really, is the ritual and regularity. I asked Connie whether people today had too many distractions on Sundays to be able to go regularly to church. 'That's what they think,' she said, with uncharacteristic severity.

To Connie Hinds, the essentially prosaic performance of a routine leads to something transcendental - namely 'communion with all Christian souls living or dead'. Writers also create their own routines as a way of reaching some wider realm. My own, for example, is this: wake up, pretend to be still asleep until I hear the sound of my wife taking the kids off to school, get out of bed, have a coffee, have a slice of toast with jam on it, have another coffee, go to the lavatory, have a bath, have another coffee, light a small cigar, start work. Enid Blyton, by contrast, would give instructions concerning dinner to her cook, and then sit silently with her eyes closed in front of her typewriter for a few minutes before starting to write.

The Scottish writer Nigel Tranter, who died earlier this year, and was best known for his historical novels, wrote as he walked. He set off every morning for a long tramp around Aberlady Bay in East Lothian, always starting by walking over a wooden structure he called the 'footbridge to enchantment', because it symbolised the point at which routine launched him into creativity. A parallel case from America involves the film director, David Lynch who, every day for seven years, located his muse by going to a Bob's Big Boy diner in LA and having a chocolate shake and seven cups of very sugary coffee.

Then there's the poet and critic Al Alvarez, whose autobiography, Where Did It All Go Right? is just out. He swims every morning on Hampstead Heath. For most of the year, he uses the men's bathing pond but in summer he goes to the mixed bathing pond, a short walk from his Hampstead home. He's been swimming on the Heath more or less all his life, and never really fallen below three times a week. He now does it every day, because a crocked leg means he can no longer go rock climbing, which he used to do every weekend. He thinks it is crucial for a writer to do something that is not writing; and to do it regularly. He was strongly approving when I told him that I believed Martin Amis played tennis literally every day after a morning's work.

As I swam with Alvarez one morning, I observed his routine. He leaves his clothes on a particular bench and dives in from the jetty. He swims front crawl away from the jetty and comes back doing backstroke. This is absolutely unvarying. As he swims, he waves to the composer Albert Alan Owen, a mixed-pool regular, who calls out the traditional, mixed-pool regulars' greeting: 'Not drowning but waving!' Another regular is the radio producer Piers Plowright, and the bench on which Alvarez leaves his clothes commemorates a fourth regular, Alan Franks (1910-94), who was well known to Alvarez.

The pond regulars are a rather tight clique and Alvarez finds himself 'slightly resentful' when, on sunny days, flighty, fairweather swimmers turn up, possibly forcing small detours in his routine. (There are women regulars at the mixed pool, by the way - it is mixed after all; there just weren't any around on the day I turned up.)

After swimming with Alvarez, at about ten past ten, I watch a bearded man enter the open-air male changing room, get dried and then, without removing his trunks, sit down, peel an orange and start reading The Times, beginning with the back page. 'Yes,' Alvarez told me later, 'you'll probably find he does that every day.' Although I myself live close to the mixed-bathing pond, I haven't yet been back to confirm this, precisely because I - like Al Alvarez, and Mycroft Holmes, and most men and many women - do run on rails, and I'm afraid they take me elsewhere at that particular time of day.

 Andrew Martin's next novel, The Bobby-Dazzlers, will be published by Faber and Faber in March 2001
