Statistics aside, the situation was summed up by the telephonist of the diocese of Durham who, when I called saying I was looking for a regular churchgoer in her area, laughed quite derisively for about 30 seconds. I did find one, though: Connie Hinds, who's been going to St Mary's church in Cockerton Green, Darlington, for about 50 years. If you go into the choir vestry, you'll see her name recurring many times - on the cleaning rota, the linen rota, the intercessions rota. You don't often find her on the flower rota, funnily enough, but she was joining in the flower arrangements for a forthcoming wedding when I met her. Connie comes to the 9am service on Sunday mornings, and also to evensong on Sunday, although I had to press hard to get the second piece of information, because Connie - a self-effacing, humorous woman - has 'a terrible fear of sounding pi'. For the past 12 years, she's sat at the back of the church, but, between 1951 and 1988, when she accompanied her mother to church, she sat further forward, underneath the war memorial, because that was her mother's favourite spot. 'For me,' she says, 'the week starts on a Sunday. I need to say thanks, I need to be forgiven.' In her time at St Mary's, Connie has seen 'sidesmen' become 'sidespeople', the growing necessity of locking the church to prevent vandalism, and the following vicars: Mr Porteus, Mr Walker, Mr Sexty, Mr Hall, Mr Kent, Mr Conway and now Mr Wallace. She describes the services as 'always the same and always different'. Some of the sermons connect more with her than others, but the point, really, is the ritual and regularity. I asked Connie whether people today had too many distractions on Sundays to be able to go regularly to church. 'That's what they think,' she said, with uncharacteristic severity. To Connie Hinds, the essentially prosaic performance of a routine leads to something transcendental - namely 'communion with all Christian souls living or dead'. Writers also create their own routines as a way of reaching some wider realm. My own, for example, is this: wake up, pretend to be still asleep until I hear the sound of my wife taking the kids off to school, get out of bed, have a coffee, have a slice of toast with jam on it, have another coffee, go to the lavatory, have a bath, have another coffee, light a small cigar, start work. Enid Blyton, by contrast, would give instructions concerning dinner to her cook, and then sit silently with her eyes closed in front of her typewriter for a few minutes before starting to write. The Scottish writer Nigel Tranter, who died earlier this year, and was best known for his historical novels, wrote as he walked. He set off every morning for a long tramp around Aberlady Bay in East Lothian, always starting by walking over a wooden structure he called the 'footbridge to enchantment', because it symbolised the point at which routine launched him into creativity. A parallel case from America involves the film director, David Lynch who, every day for seven years, located his muse by going to a Bob's Big Boy diner in LA and having a chocolate shake and seven cups of very sugary coffee. Then there's the poet and critic Al Alvarez, whose autobiography, Where Did It All Go Right? is just out. He swims every morning on Hampstead Heath. For most of the year, he uses the men's bathing pond but in summer he goes to the mixed bathing pond, a short walk from his Hampstead home. He's been swimming on the Heath more or less all his life, and never really fallen below three times a week. He now does it every day, because a crocked leg means he can no longer go rock climbing, which he used to do every weekend. He thinks it is crucial for a writer to do something that is not writing; and to do it regularly. He was strongly approving when I told him that I believed Martin Amis played tennis literally every day after a morning's work. As I swam with Alvarez one morning, I observed his routine. He leaves his clothes on a particular bench and dives in from the jetty. He swims front crawl away from the jetty and comes back doing backstroke. This is absolutely unvarying. As he swims, he waves to the composer Albert Alan Owen, a mixed-pool regular, who calls out the traditional, mixed-pool regulars' greeting: 'Not drowning but waving!' Another regular is the radio producer Piers Plowright, and the bench on which Alvarez leaves his clothes commemorates a fourth regular, Alan Franks (1910-94), who was well known to Alvarez. The pond regulars are a rather tight clique and Alvarez finds himself 'slightly resentful' when, on sunny days, flighty, fairweather swimmers turn up, possibly forcing small detours in his routine. (There are women regulars at the mixed pool, by the way - it is mixed after all; there just weren't any around on the day I turned up.) After swimming with Alvarez, at about ten past ten, I watch a bearded man enter the open-air male changing room, get dried and then, without removing his trunks, sit down, peel an orange and start reading The Times, beginning with the back page. 'Yes,' Alvarez told me later, 'you'll probably find he does that every day.' Although I myself live close to the mixed-bathing pond, I haven't yet been back to confirm this, precisely because I - like Al Alvarez, and Mycroft Holmes, and most men and many women - do run on rails, and I'm afraid they take me elsewhere at that particular time of day.  Andrew Martin's next novel, The Bobby-Dazzlers, will be published by Faber and Faber in March 2001

fields.headline: America's most wanted
fields.standfirst: When Eric Rudolph bombed Centennial Park at the Atlanta Olympics in 1996, he triggered the country's biggest ever manhunt. But despite sightings and the $1m on his head, he's so far managed to elude capture. Nick Paton Walsh travels to the Cherokee forest of Nantahala and joins the bounty hunters
fields.trailText: When Eric Rudolph bombed Centennial Park at the Atlanta Olympics in 1996, he triggered the country's biggest ever manhunt. But despite sightings and the $1m on his head, he's so far managed to elude capture. Nick Paton Walsh travels to the Cherokee forest of Nantahala and joins the bounty hunters.
fields.body:
Under the triple canopy of the Nantahala forest of North Carolina it is impossible to see a man 10ft away. In Cherokee the word Nantahala means the 'land of the midday sun'. It is a place that rarely cools below 30°C in summer, that generates a cacophony of sounds - the screech of bobcats and the maddening static of the insects that begin their assault at dusk and continue until first light. The undergrowth throws out tangled roots to trip the unwary, and rattlesnakes lurk in bracken sharp enough to razor through trousers.

Through this landscape, unchanged since the Cherokee were driven from their hunting lands a century and a half ago, the agents of the FBI are now stalking the thickets in search of Eric Rudolph, America's most wanted fugitive. The forest hides other dangers. There are more than a thousand mines within its half million acres - dangerous, half-hidden workings which date back to the Gold Rush. Then there are the natural caves and caverns, some poisoned by underground gases so lethal that a single breath renders a victim unconscious before their body hits the ground.

Lurking among these hazards is Rudolph - bombmaker, backwoodsman and expert marksman. A right-wing extremist so dangerous the US has ranked him in its cosmology of evil alongside the Islamic fundamentalist Osama Bin Laden, who ordered the bombing of the American embassies in Tanzania and Kenya, and in which 200 people died.

In truth, Rudolph - for all the $1 million price put on his head - is a different scale of operator. He has caused minimal disruption when compared with his fellow traveller on the lethal fringes of the far right, America's most prolific domestic terrorist Timothy McVeigh, who killed 168 and injured 500 more when he bombed the Federal building in Oklahoma City.

Charged, however, with six counts of bombing and attempted bombing, Rudolph committed one particular crime that needs to be read as much for its symbolic context as for its body count. The crime that made Rudolph infamous was seen as a humiliation for the US in front of the eyes of world. He bombed the Centennial Olympic Park in Atlanta in 1996, killing one and injuring hundreds, including children who were hit by flying nails packed into the crude device.

His next two bombs targeted a clinic which performed abortions, the Sandy Springs Professional Building, north of Atlanta, in January 1997. Then Rudolph switched his attention to another group loathed by the American far right. He detonated two bombs a month later in the Otherside Lounge, a lesbian bar in Atlanta, and injured five people.

Rudolph is also charged with the 29 January 1998 bombing of another abortion clinic, the New Woman All Women Health Care Clinic in Birmingham, Alabama, during which an off-duty policeman was killed and a nurse permanently disfigured. Rudolph carried each unstable bomb to the site in an army surplus backpack and placed it where it should have killed many more.

Eric Rudolph's significance lies not so much in the number of people he has killed or maimed but in what he represents. Like McVeigh and the Unabomber Ted Kaczynski (who killed three and injured 23 in a 17-year spate of mail bombings), he forms part of the 'leaderless resistance', the lone operators that the chief of the FBI's domestic terrorism unit Robert Burnham, describes as 'the biggest threat right now' to national security. Burnham embodies a contest between all the vast resources of the federal government, against which Rudolph and his colleagues on the 'militia' right have pitted themselves.

This ruthlessness is encapsulated in a single image - the surveillance video that unmasked him and began the long manhunt. It comes from the Alabama bombing. In the grainy CCTV footage, Rudolph sits patiently in his pick-up truck, watching a policemen, Robert Sanderson, bend over to examine the bomb just before it detonates.

Emily Lyons can remember very little about the morning of 29 January 1998. There was little amiss when she arrived early at the New Woman All Women Health Centre in Birmingham, Alabama to cover for a fellow nurse on maternity leave. She does not recall seeing Rudolph's grey pick-up truck parked outside the clinic, or the blast that followed.

The shrapnel from the device has left her disfigured and has permanently damaged her left eye. Since that morning, a series of operations to reconstruct her face have required that she take the powerful painkillers Bersed and Fetnayl. These two drugs have impeded her memory of events between December 1997 and February 1998. But since the bombing, she has learned of witness, forensic, and material evidence amassed by the FBI, and its sister organisations involved in the investigation, that has convinced her beyond doubt that Rudolph is responsible. 'I feel no pity or anger towards him,' she says. 'He didn't know me. He just did it to me. I could feel anger if I knew him, but I have no connection with him. I hate what he has taken away from me: my job, my socialisation. I fear he'll strike again; he has no conscience.'

What links Rudolph with McVeigh and the Unabomber is a warped version of the backwoods self-sufficiency preached by Henry David Thoreau. It is racist, anti-semitic, attached to the rights to bear arms and speak one's mind without interference, but rejecting the balancing duties in the American constitution of paying taxes and respecting the lives and opinions of others. It is Christian fundamentalist and pro-life (anti-abortion) to the extent of being prepared to murder doctors and abortion clinic staff. At its most bizarre, it believes that the United Nations is trying to take over the world.

Andrews is a tiny one-road town on Interstate Highway 74 on the edge of the Nantahala forest, home to 1,699 people, 16 churches and no bars. When an Andrews hotel suggested last year that it might want to serve beer to accompany food, one of the town's First Baptist ministers wrote a furious letter to the local paper suggesting that this was the next step to the hotel declaring itself a bordello.

It was into this deeply God-fearing area in 1981, that the 12-year-old Rudolph moved with his family from Florida. They moved into a small house on Partridge Creek, in the midst of the Nantahala. His father had just died, and it was a new beginning for the family. He enrolled at the local K12 Nantahala High School, a tiny cluster of classrooms along a single dusty corridor - each year group rarely exceeding 15 in number. Randy Cochran was one of Rudolph's better school friends. He and Eric would go camping, play war games in the woods and meet girls with the other boys from their area. 'In this part of the world, people who live near you are your friends,' he says. 'It's how life is here.' But Rudolph, who came from outside and whose family were not regular church goers, began to feel that he was an outsider - a conviction that would deepen with his years in the forest.

With hindsight it appears these early influences on Rudolph are crucial. For Patricia Rudolph, his mother, did little to aid her son's easy assimilation into the community that was his new home. Instead, Patricia shared with the far-right militia movement a paranoid distrust of the Federal government. She refused to give her children's social security numbers to the school as she felt it allowed the government to track individuals.

Significantly, she also introduced her sons to a neighbour, Thomas Wayne Branham, whose bail she paid in 1986 when he was charged with federal firearms violations. At his trial, Branham had denied the authority of the court and declared himself a 'freeman', an opponent of the federal government, before receiving a three-year suspended sentence.

Patricia Rudolph had first met Branham when they lived in Florida before they moved to Nantahala; the Rudolph children would often stay with him in the forest for the summer. When the fatherless family moved to the area, their bond was strengthened. The views of Branham and Patricia Rudolph are not unusual in the forest.

Two locals tell me about a rumour that has been going around. Someone has seen some tanks with United Nations markings, and non-English speaking troops have been seen on exercises in the forest. A popular theory, they assure me, is that the FBI are not solely here to try and catch Rudolph, but that they are acting as a cover for a UN takeover of the United States.

In the deeper recesses of the Nantahala, lives Jay Peircle and her two daughters. They have a National Rifle Association bumper sticker on their car which declares 'Charlton Heston is my President', two large Confederate flags waving in their driveway, and no love for the FBI. Peircle readily tells me she'd rather have a beer with Rudolph than the Feds, and wouldn't tell the authorities if she found traces of him in the forest.

The first sign of Eric Rudolph's growing disaffection and alienation came at 16. Rudolph dropped out of school - Randy Cochran says he doesn't know why - and stayed at home, in the woods. He returned to education, earning sufficient qualifications to enroll in Western Carolina University for two terms, but he was becomingly increasingly erratic.

By the summer of 1986, he had left University to enlist in the army. In August 1987, he was posted to Fort Benning, Georgia, where he served 18 months before being discharged as a private, allegedly after being found smoking cannabis.

Pot-growing is a thriving black economy in Nantahala. Agents working on the case have disclosed that Rudolph grew one of the strongest breeds of the drug in the hills near his home and sold it on to a dealer in Nash-ville, Tennessee.

It was after Rudolph returned to Nantahala that the Olympic bombing took place, as did the two other Atlanta bombings to which the FBI have now linked him. During this time, Rudolph began to betray a few signs that something was amiss: he started using several pseudonyms - Bob Randolph, Robert Randolph and Bob Rudolph - and became ever more reclusive.

The change in Rudolph during this period was noticed by Robin Key, a waitress at a local restaurant whom he first met in 1994. Key had been captivated by Rudolph's intense eyes, but otherwise says she found him dull and didn't chase him up.

They met again by chance at a video store in 1997. They had dinner soon afterwards and went to a barbecue a few weeks later. They watched a few movies together and were alone once. Key recalls Rudolph was always good with her daughter, Selina, despite the fact that Selina found his quiet demeanour 'a little weird'. The last time they met was in an Andrews store in December 1997, and Rudolph 'blanked' her. She describes him as 'cold and nonchalant', as if a change had come over him.

Two months later, Rudolph was charged with the January 1998 bombing of the Birmingham abortion clinic. But by the time the FBI turned up at the trailer he was living in, Rudolph had already fled, triggering the biggest man hunt in American history.

Jack Thompson, county sheriff at the time, had been asked to look out for Rudolph by the FBI and had found him through post office and electricity company records at a place called Caney Creek, near Murphy (the next big town to Andrews).

'My feeling', says the now-retired Thompson, who tipped off the FBI, 'is that he turned on the television at 6pm and must have seen news footage that his truck had been spotted near the Alabama blast.' Rudolph had been gone no more than 30 minutes, when seven federal agent cars arrived to find his trailer door open, the TV blaring and the lights still on. His truck was later dis-covered abandoned at St Martin's Creek, near Murphy.

Rudolph's forest trackers go by the name of the Southeast Bomb Task Force - a collection of officers from the FBI, the Alcohol Tobacco and Firearms Unit, and the Department of Justice. For 30 months they have been scouring the thickets, caves and disused mineworkings of the Nantahala forest. The search teams are led by trackers from the US Forestry Service and include marksmen and local guides. It is tense and exhausting work.

While Rudolph remains their main quarry, the forest itself has also become an enemy, its vastness seeming to collude with the fugitive bomber. Recently, one agent had a heart attack while searching its depths.

It is little surprise that it took 20 minutes for the search party to hack out a clearing big enough for a helicopter to land.

Much of the effort of the search is focused on the forest's caves and mines. The caves provide perfect shelter, remaining at a constant temperature during the extremes of both summer and winter. Many also contain drinkable spring water all year round.

Darren Free has been employed by the SBTF to aid the search over the past 18 months. A caving expert and accomplished woodsman, he has an extensive knowledge of the area's caves which he accumulated while playing in them as a child. Free has proven invaluable to the SBTF. A light-hearted man with native American roots who makes a living cutting glass in nearby Hendersonville, he can theorise for hours about where he thinks Rudolph may be hiding. The $1m reward for his capture has almost lost its appeal for Free; for him it is now a personal hunt into which he pours his energy and ideas.

Free and the SBTF remain convinced that Rudolph is not only alive but still sheltering in the forest. A source close to the search team says they believe they have come near to Rudolph on several occasions. Once they heard someone talking to themselves in the bushes; they then saw a ponytailed man fleeing the scene. Another time, two agents came across a pair of boots on a rock. They went for back-up, but on their return they found that the boots were gone.

Rudolph's bootprints are themselves a problem: he has one of the most common makes of hiking boot in the country, boots in which legitimate hikers trample all over the Nantahala's trails. Regardless of the insurmountable task ahead of them, the task force has continued the search. So far it has cost at least $14m. At its peak, the force was 600 strong, now there remains a hard core of 12 dedicated hunters who scour the forest at the first sign of a fugitive.

The last officially confirmed sighting of someone matching Rudolph's description occurred last February, but unofficially there have been sightings of a man matching Rudolph's description in the area within the past month, and on two of these occasions he was seen with an unidentified female. In February, the SBTF found food parcels and boot prints consistent with Rudolph. More recently, investigators came across an observation post that Rudolph may have been using to survey the area.

A resident of the remote northern Nantahala area has also reported seeing a man matching Rudolph's description at regular intervals. A later search of the caves of that region brought to light what was described by a source close to the search as 'the strongest lead in two years'. In addition, the detailed profiles of Rudolph constructed by the FBI and all the evidence collated thus far, point to one conclusion: that Rudolph is still in these mountains, because this, if anywhere, is where he calls 'home'.

More and more, however, the FBI is becoming convinced that, if Rudolph is surviving, it is because there are those out in the forest who are helping him. There was a steady pattern of break-ins around the Nantahala area in 1998 in which the items stolen - food, supplies and men's boots and shirts - were consistent with Rudolph. These break-ins stopped in 1999, suggesting that Rudolph had left the area, met his death in the forest, or is receiving a regular drop of supplies.

George Nordmann is the last man that the authorities believe has seen Rudolph alive. The taciturn owner of an Andrews health-food store, Nordmann got close enough to be able to provide a description of the haggard Rudolph. On 9 July 1998, Rudolph, then sporting a beard and ponytail, took six months' worth of food and supplies and a truck from Nordmann's house. In Nordmann's absence, he left $500 in payment for the items and a note in the truck which apologised for the inconvenience. The truck was found abandoned near Nantahala and the search picked up pace again. The FBI erected a village of tents on the Appletree Campground outside Andrews and helicopters and agents poured into the forest.

Today, Nordmann still runs a small health-food store - The Better Way - on the main road in Andrews. He has little to say about the events of that day, bar confirming that he knew Rudolph's family and Eric himself as a child, and that Rudolph went to school with some of Nordmann's 11 children. He is tired of the association made between him and Rudolph and yet more fatigued by constant calls from reporters. 'There's so much other crime in the world; I could wring his neck now, having to put up with this baloney,' he says wearily, adding that the $500 he left 'shows he had some decency. He was not robbing me.'

Nordmann's sympathy is political, too. On the wall is a poster picturing two little girls in martial arts poses with the advice 'our children are going to need more than nursery rhymes to get through the next millennium'. Below is a number to call for classes. On one sideboard is an audio tape with the conspiratorial label 'The Real United Nations'. If Rudolph is still in the forest, he is not without friends.

For more information on America's most-wanted fugitives, see www.fbi.gov/mostwanted-htm

Jack Thompson, county sheriff at the time, had been asked to look out for Rudolph by the FBI and had found him through post office and electricity company records at a place called Caney Creek, near Murphy (the next big town to Andrews). 'My feeling', says the now-retired Thompson, who tipped off the FBI, 'is that he turned on the television at 6pm and must have seen news footage that his truck had been spotted near the Alabama blast.' Rudolph had been gone no more than 30 minutes, when seven federal agent cars arrived to find his trailer door open, the TV blaring and the lights still on. His truck was later dis-covered abandoned at St Martin's Creek, near Murphy. Rudolph's forest trackers go by the name of the Southeast Bomb Task Force - a collection of officers from the FBI, the Alcohol Tobacco and Firearms Unit, and the Department of Justice. For 30 months they have been scouring the thickets, caves and disused mineworkings of the Nantahala forest. The search teams are led by trackers from the US Forestry Service and include marksmen and local guides. It is tense and exhausting work. While Rudolph remains their main quarry, the forest itself has also become an enemy, its vastness seeming to collude with the fugitive bomber. Recently, one agent had a heart attack while searching its depths. It is little surprise that it took 20 minutes for the search party to hack out a clearing big enough for a helicopter to land. Much of the effort of the search is focused on the forest's caves and mines. The caves provide perfect shelter, remaining at a constant temperature during the extremes of both summer and winter. Many also contain drinkable spring water all year round. Darren Free has been employed by the SBTF to aid the search over the past 18 months. A caving expert and accomplished woodsman, he has an extensive knowledge of the area's caves which he accumulated while playing in them as a child. Free has proven invaluable to the SBTF. A light-hearted man with native American roots who makes a living cutting glass in nearby Hendersonville, he can theorise for hours about where he thinks Rudolph may be hiding. The $1m reward for his capture has almost lost its appeal for Free; for him it is now a personal hunt into which he pours his energy and ideas. Free and the SBTF remain convinced that Rudolph is not only alive but still sheltering in the forest. A source close to the search team says they believe they have come near to Rudolph on several occasions. Once they heard someone talking to themselves in the bushes; they then saw a ponytailed man fleeing the scene. Another time, two agents came across a pair of boots on a rock. They went for back-up, but on their return they found that the boots were gone. Rudolph's bootprints are themselves a problem: he has one of the most common makes of hiking boot in the country, boots in which legitimate hikers trample all over the Nantahala's trails. Regardless of the insurmountable task ahead of them, the task force has continued the search. So far it has cost at least $14m. At its peak, the force was 600 strong, now there remains a hard core of 12 dedicated hunters who scour the forest at the first sign of a fugitive. The last officially confirmed sighting of someone matching Rudolph's description occurred last February, but unofficially there have been sightings of a man matching Rudolph's description in the area within the past month, and on two of these occasions he was seen with an unidentified female. In February, the SBTF found food parcels and boot prints consistent with Rudolph. More recently, investigators came across an observation post that Rudolph may have been using to survey the area. A resident of the remote northern Nantahala area has also reported seeing a man matching Rudolph's description at regular intervals. A later search of the caves of that region brought to light what was described by a source close to the search as 'the strongest lead in two years'. In addition, the detailed profiles of Rudolph constructed by the FBI and all the evidence collated thus far, point to one conclusion: that Rudolph is still in these mountains, because this, if anywhere, is where he calls 'home'. More and more, however, the FBI is becoming convinced that, if Rudolph is surviving, it is because there are those out in the forest who are helping him. There was a steady pattern of break-ins around the Nantahala area in 1998 in which the items stolen - food, supplies and men's boots and shirts - were consistent with Rudolph. These break-ins stopped in 1999, suggesting that Rudolph had left the area, met his death in the forest, or is receiving a regular drop of supplies. George Nordmann is the last man that the authorities believe has seen Rudolph alive. The taciturn owner of an Andrews health-food store, Nordmann got close enough to be able to provide a description of the haggard Rudolph. On 9 July 1998, Rudolph, then sporting a beard and ponytail, took six months' worth of food and supplies and a truck from Nordmann's house. In Nordmann's absence, he left $500 in payment for the items and a note in the truck which apologised for the inconvenience. The truck was found abandoned near Nantahala and the search picked up pace again. The FBI erected a village of tents on the Appletree Campground outside Andrews and helicopters and agents poured into the forest. Today, Nordmann still runs a small health-food store - The Better Way - on the main road in Andrews. He has little to say about the events of that day, bar confirming that he knew Rudolph's family and Eric himself as a child, and that Rudolph went to school with some of Nordmann's 11 children. He is tired of the association made between him and Rudolph and yet more fatigued by constant calls from reporters. 'There's so much other crime in the world; I could wring his neck now, having to put up with this baloney,' he says wearily, adding that the $500 he left 'shows he had some decency. He was not robbing me.' Nordmann's sympathy is political, too. On the wall is a poster picturing two little girls in martial arts poses with the advice 'our children are going to need more than nursery rhymes to get through the next millennium'. Below is a number to call for classes. On one sideboard is an audio tape with the conspiratorial label 'The Real United Nations'. If Rudolph is still in the forest, he is not without friends. For more information on America's most-wanted fugitives, see www.fbi.gov/mostwanted-htm

fields.headline: The perfect love song
fields.standfirst: Barry White
fields.trailText: Barry White
fields.body:
There are all kinds of people in the world and there is a perfect love song for each one of them. All of them need help to communicate. It's important that a man can explain how he feels to a woman, but most men are bashful. Love songs can help them get over that shyness. They might need songs to say, 'I love you' or 'I miss you', it's up to the individual and what works for one person might not for another.

The important thing is to be able to relate to the song. For me, 'When a Man Loves a Woman' is a perfect love song. You know how he feels, how he loves, how he reacts. It makes a great statement: 'he can't keep his mind on nothing else' and everyone can relate to that. Anyone who understands English understands that song. It has a great lyric, a great melody and it's a great ballad.

Love songs have to be slow. When you listen to a slow song you tend to sway back and forth real easy, if you move at all. It makes the song easier to digest and gives you some time to take it all in.

Writing the perfect love song is all up to the individual, as well. Smokey Robinson's got a style, Stevie Wonder's got a style and I have a style. The inspiration just comes and you never know quite where from although I get in the mood to write a love song, no different from sex.

I want people to communicate with each other and it's one of the most powerful and beautiful things I've ever known in my life.

 Barry White, The Collection is currently on re-release

fields.headline: ... running a nightclub
fields.trailText: ... running a nightclub
fields.body:
Times have changed since the Krays managed 30 of London's nightclubs. Today's superclubs (Gatecrasher, Cream, Home, et al) are more likely to employ armies of accountants than the likes of 'Mad' Frankie Fraser. The best way to get going in the nightclub business is by starting at the bottom: promote your own night.

For any sort of return you should think big. Look for a venue with a capacity of 1,500 or more, which can be about £750 to hire per night. To fill this space, offer a couple of styles of music (something popular like trance or one of the flavours of house - this will not work if you insist on jazz-fusion or folk music).

Now book the appropriate DJs. Aim to spend about £2,000 for a headline DJ (plus an agency fee of about 15 per cent), a second DJ (£800) and a resident DJ (£600, unless you have a friend who is a bit of a dab hand on the Technics). Guaranteed floor-fillers (there are fewer than 10) are not cheap: Paul Oakenfold charges up to £10,000 for a two-hour set, while hotel bills (£300), phone bills and possible flights are hidden extras.

Punters will also expect a sound system (£3,000 hire), vaguely exciting lighting and visuals (£2,000) and to be manhandled by irritable bouncers (£3,000 plus agency fee). And nobody will even turn up if you don't advertise in magazines (£1,000) and print up a few flyers and distribute them (£700).

So far you have spent £14,500 and you have not even paid your staff, the insurance or the VAT yet. Outgoings will total up to £16,000, which means charging clubbers over £10 to just break even. However, if you establish yourself you can look forward to making some serious money: the Ministry of Sound shift an estimated £20m worth of compilation albums each year.

And if you are tempted to hold free parties, don't be misled by the 'free' bit: original sound systems like Spiral Tribe tour the Continent mainland rather than face confiscation of their equipment and paying bail in Britain.

DJs £3,400
Hotel bills £300
Venue hire £750
Sound costs £3,000
Lighting and visuals £2,000
Promotion £1,700
Security £3,000
Outgoings (exc agency fees) £14,150
Income £10-£12 per clubber

fields.headline: The loafer's guide...
fields.standfirst: Spinal Tap
fields.trailText: Spinal Tap
fields.body:
A film for eternal students and failed musicians?
Not at all. The release in 1984 of This Is Spinal Tap - a fake 'rockumentary' of the band on its comeback tour of America - was a huge critical success, and a combination of word-of-mouth recommendation and constant referencing by the music business itself has made it something of a 'cult classic'. So much so that as from next Friday, the film is to get another big screen outing. The band has simultaneously released its first single in eight years (available exclusively on the internet at www.tapster.com).

So who are they?
Fictional rock band Spinal Tap is basically a metaphor for everything that is vacuous and vain in the music business. Featuring five 'musicians' from the East End of London, founding members Nigel Tufnel and David St Hubbins (played by American actors, Christopher Guest and Michael McLean) formed the band in 1964, and after going through obligatory mop-top and flower-power stages (as well as 35 band members) they discovered hard rock and released singles such as 'Sex Farm' and 'Big Bottoms'. Their album reviews have been terrible ('On what day did God create Spinal Tap and couldn't he have rested on that day as well'), and if the film shows anything, it's that they are survivors, even when all the odds are stacked against them. Unaware of being sexist ('What's wrong with being sexy?' says Tufnel), they reach rock bottom when the only gig they can get is as support for a puppet show. But an unexpected top 10 in Japan sees them rise from the ashes and 16 years later they are still going strong.

Any basis in reality?
Director Rob Reiner, better known for his romantic comedy Sleepless in Seattle and who also stars as documentary-maker Marti Di Bergi, is said to have based much of the film on touring stories about Led Zeppelin and Deep Purple.

Any other cameos?
There are a number of blink-or-you-miss-them moments. Look out for Billy Crystal (as a miming waiter), Angelica Huston (as a flaky set designer) and Patrick Macnee (as the head of the Tap's record label).

webTitle: The way we live now: The new dress codes

fields.headline: The new dress codes
fields.standfirst: Does my job look big in this?
fields.trailText: The new dress codes
fields.body:
Earlier this year, a momentous - but under-reported - menswear moment occurred. At the press conference announcing the merger of dotcom upstart America Online and crusty conglomerate Time Warner, AOL chairman Steven Case bucked the internet entrepreneur dress-down trend by donning a suit and tie, while TW's Gerald Levin appeared, rather uneasily, in a look-I'm-down-with-the-kids open-neck shirt.

It was a watershed in the ongoing Casual vs Formal workwear debate. 'Levin blew it,' reckoned Gerald Anderson, of the Neckwear Association of America. 'Because there was Case looking like a million bucks. More than that, I guess.'

Case's embrace of tailoring was the most visible example of a backlash to dress-down that has gathered momentum even as Casual Fridays have rolled out to become Casual Weeks, Summers, and, in extreme cases, Forevers. What was meant to be a liberation from stuffed shirts has become a more insidious form of bondage, as office drones grapple with the complexities of what we might call Third Way Dressing, somewhere between weekend flop-wear and traditional formality, a sartorial limbo of halfway-up, which, as the Grand Old Duke of York's legions knew, is neither up nor down.

'It's a huge grey area,' says Scott Williams, vice chairman of the British Menswear Guild, who is launching an initiative to help navigate men through the workwear maze, 'How to Get Ahead in Style', later this month, with an evening to find the Best-Dressed-Up and Dressed-Down Man in that temple of Mammon, Canary Wharf.

'Dress-down is no longer a fad. It's here to stay. But a lot of men are finding it hard to adjust.' Numerous fashion disasters, from surfer shorts to the full-on Alan Partridge blazer-and-slacks-at-the-Moat-House-Inn look, have inspired the accountancy firm Arthur Andersen, which was put on a permanent dress-down footing at the start of the year, to issue guidelines to perplexed staff as to what is and isn't acceptable - no logos, no Velcro, socks are necessary, steer clear of drawstring trousers, simple colours that kind of thing. As the wife of a harassed captain of industry recently wrote to The Times, 'Now men know what women have known for years: "dress-down" and "smart casual" just mean "what on earth do I wear?"'

Some have solved the dilemma by simply adopting an alternative uniform - polo-shirts-and-chinos or button-downs-and-khakis. Others are buying wholesale from the new 'business casual' ranges launched by the likes of the ailing Austin Reed, who've sent fashion Swat teams into offices to lecture on the intricacies of matching, say, turtlenecks and corduroys. A spokesman at Arthur Andersen insists that they're now a bunch of blissed-out flexecutives: 'People feel more comfortable with dress-down. But suits are still worn for meetings with blue-chip clients.'

Meanwhile in the States, birthplace of dress-down, things are getting a little too relaxed. A recent survey found that half of New York employers reported absenteeism and tardiness rates rising correspondingly with dress-down days. One company issued a diktat that workers don 'foundation garments'. Last year, the number of companies in the US adopting dress-down policies fell for the first time.

All of which helps to explain why we've entered a looking-glass world where the suit is seen as a desirable, and even subversive, way of standing out from the open-necked hordes. A survey from office supplies group OfficeSMART found that a third of those questioned from the New Media worlds claimed they dressed more smartly than their guidelines required, because they felt that 'smart dressing commands greater respect.'

Meanwhile, the transformation of staid old brands like Burberry, DAKS and Kilgour, French & Stanbury - who suited and booted all the mockneys in Guy Ritchie's Snatch - into groovy lifestyle labels, plus Gucci, Prada and Dolce & Gabbana's re-embracing of tailoring for the autumn/winter season are vindicating the efforts of Timothy Everest and Richard James. Young tailors who introduced a new generation to the unique joys of bespoke, and proved that 'wearing a suit' and 'being cool' need not be mutually exclusive.

'The suit will never disappear, because it's one of the things the British do best,' insists GQ editor Dylan Jones, whose attachment to the garment is so devout that he went on Newsnight to defend it. 'The only thing dress-down has achieved is that it's validated sloppy dressing. The reason that dotcommers are getting into suits is that they're making more money and getting more serious, and clothes are a very noticeable way of announcing that.'

And there's a final reason why the suit is far from dead. Put crudely, says Simon Cummins at Timothy Everest, the best-cut suits are designed to accentuate your best bits and camouflage your worst bits. 'One client, a portly captain of industry, always looked elegant in bespoke but reluctantly agreed to go casual when his company went dress-down. Within a few weeks, his wife marched him down here in his crumpled button-down and saggy chinos, and said, 'He needs four new suits. And he needs them as quickly as possible.'

webTitle: Going's tough at ICI - a punt for risk-takers only fancy a punt

fields.headline: Going's tough at ICI - a punt for risk-takers only fancy a punt
fields.trailText: It is now just over three years since Imperial Chemical Industries made its $8 billion (£5.3bn) purchase of a collection of fragrances, flavours and other speciality chemicals from Unilever.
fields.body:
It is now just over three years since Imperial Chemical Industries made its $8 billion (£5.3bn) purchase of a collection of fragrances, flavours and other speciality chemicals from Unilever.

That marked the start of what it promised was a three-year programme of reshaping the group from a bulk producer of commodity chemicals to a highly focused, much less cyclical, business.

At the time of the acquisition, the then chairman, Sir Ronnie Hampel, promised £3bn of disposals to both cut its debt, which stood at £6bn just after the deal, and complete the reshaping of the group.

In fact, it has sold business worth more than twice that - and a further £300 million or so has still to go - as it rapidly became clear that businesses such as materials and titanium dioxide were not resilient enough to merit a place in the new-look group.

Despite that level of sales, however, debt still stands at £2.9bn; analysts expect profits this year to be just over twice its £180m interest bill; and a dividend cut is all but certain; albeit in 2001 rather than 2000. The shares have collapsed from 917p in July 1997 - and a high of 1244p early in 1999 - to just 379p last week.

So has the transformation been a failure? The answer at the moment is a qualified no, if only because its position without Unilever would have been so much worse - just look at the performance of rivals such as Dow, which has stayed in the commodity industry.

It has, however, been harder than ICI expected.

At the time, few would have predicted that the materials business and the added- value parts of industrial chemicals would have declined so rapidly - indeed, ICI had been investing heavily to develop these very areas.

The deterioration in trading undermined the impact of disposals on its borrowings, and made finding buyers willing to pay acceptable prices that much harder.

Some analysts also say it paid too much for the Unilever businesses and then moved too quickly to add bits to them when it should have waited until it had raised the funds.

On the plus side, however, the businesses acquired are performing well.

In the first six months of the year, sales and profits of these new core businesses rose by 6 per cent and 13 per cent respectively. Margins at most of them also rose, despite increases in their costs - not least because of the rise in the oil price.

Fear that the high oil price will start to hit profits prompted another sharp fall in ICI's shares last month - indeed, they have fallen by about a quarter, relative to the rest of the market, in the past three months.

The group is far less exposed to the price of oil than it was; now, oil accounts for only about 30 per cent of its £2bn raw material bill, compared with around 90 per cent as recently as five years ago.

But, as ICI itself admits, that makes it harder to pass on cost increases than it was, so there is the risk that margins will be under pressure in the second half of the year.

The threat of a dividend cut will also hang over the shares until chief executive Brendan O'Neill makes his intentions clear. The betting in the City is that he will hold the payment at 32p for this year, but will warn of a cut, possibly to 20p, the following year.

It would, therefore, be unwise to rely too much on the 8.2 per cent yield currently available on the shares.

But if the forecasts of a 20p dividend are right, the yield would still be a generous 5.1 per cent.

That will of course, look less attractive if the shares continue their inexorable slide - and this column has recommended buying them at higher prices in the past. But the valuation is now so low that sentiment could easily be swayed by any bit of good news, from a lower oil price to a strengthening euro. Those who have the stomach for a risk should buy now.

Time to be radical

Those who have been clamouring for British Land to do something to reverse the poor performance of its shares got a little bit of extra ammunition last week.

The property group has put four of its prime London properties into a joint venture with the German bank WestLB.

The properties were sold to the joint-venture company at a small premium to their value on the balance sheet.

Surely, then, it should simply sell off the rest of its assets and give the money back to shareholders.

Of course, life is not so simple - not least because of the huge tax bill which would be incurred if it should decide to do that.

But the past 10 years demonstrate that the big property companies are not delivering value to shareholders. Ritblat needs to do something a bit more radical than set up yet another joint venture if he is to reverse that trend.

The fact that Vodafone, the mobile phone company, has paid $2.5bn (£1.7bn) for a stake of just 2 per cent in China Mobile shows just how high the stakes are in the battle for international cellular domination.

Vodafone, with its Mannesman and Airtouch deals and its growing international network of shareholdings and alliances, is up there among the leaders of the pack.

The China deal, which gives it a link to the biggest mobile operator in one of the fastest-growing markets, is yet another astute move.

But the risks of the strategy are high. No one really knows what shape our telecoms businesses will take in the future, but the size of the bets required is increasing.

The cost of acquiring stakes is matched by the high price of third-generation licences.

The nervousness of bank regulators means that debt, too, will become more expensive to finance.

Vodafone is well placed to be one of the winners. But those who buy the shares should be aware of the risks.

webTitle: Voyaging around her father, the hi-tech Maxwell

fields.headline: Voyaging around her father, the hi-tech Maxwell
fields.standfirst: Captain Bob's daughter is in Britain, facing down her family's past and delivering a bright message about her internet firm's future
fields.trailText: Captain Bob's daughter is in Britain, facing down her family's past and delivering a bright message about her internet firm's future
fields.body:
Isabel Maxwell is decapitating a boiled egg. It is her second of the morning. The first was too hard. Unfortunately, the second is no better. 'I guess that's England for you, hard boiled,' she shrugs.

It is a funny aside, one of many she will doubtless make throughout the course of the day. But it has an edge. She might have an Oxford education, but the daughter of Robert Maxwell doesn't spend too much time here any more. Too much history. Too much baggage. A hard-nosed, hard-boiled country that will always remember the sins of the father.

Instead, these days Maxwell prefers to swim in a different pond, one where people are not too interested in your past, just your future. She is a major player in that US home of perpetual reinvention, Silicon Valley.

Each day when she's not travelling overseas, Maxwell, one of the late newspaper tycoon's five surviving children, makes the 80-minute 'killer commute' to her company, Commtouch.

She doesn't need to do it. Maxwell calls herself a working mum, but this is a woman who, with her twin sister Christine, saw the internet's potential in 1992 and helped build Magellan, a search engine, which they sold to Excite for nearly £4.5 million.

However, Maxwell is almost messianic about the company over which she presides. At first glance her enthusiasm is hard to fathom. The Nasdaq-listed company claims to be the world's 'leading provider of outsourced email and messaging solutions'. But this doesn't seem enough to generate the fervour that Maxwell obviously feels for it, and it has yet to deliver the sort of stellar future she is predicting.

Commtouch was formed in 1991 to sort out problems that new communications technology would create for companies and consumers: they would spend so much time and money developing new ways of communicating with staff, customers and suppliers that they would lose sight of their core businesses.

Commtouch takes over and builds messaging systems not just for blue-chip clients but even for small and medium-sized enterprises. Its versatile services are available in 26 languages. Want to attract visitors to your website? Offer them free email services so they visit regularly. Want to turn the web into a direct marketing tool without being labelled a junk mailer? Commtouch will offer solutions. Almost 20 million mail boxes now depend on its technology.

Maxwell clearly believes the firm, which is not due to make a profit until next year, is set for exponential growth.

'The need for outsourcing email messaging is incredible,' she says. 'By 2003 it's going to be a $24 billion market, compared with $1bn last year.'

The explosion in different communication devices means Commtouch can position itself in the middle of the competing technologies by offering 'unified messaging solutions', shorthand for getting all your equipment - from PCs to Palm Pilots to mobile phones - talking coherently to one another.

Maxwell will emphasise these points again and again in the coming weeks. Last Monday she gave a lecture at Durham University, the following day she flew to Paris to spread the company's gospel. By the end of last week she was in Tunisia, addressing the World Congress of Women Entrepreneurs.

The congress gave her a chance to talk about one of her favourite themes, the way new technology breaks down old socio-economic barriers.

'The wonderful thing about email is it's not sexist,' she says. 'It crosses all boundaries: age, race, religion, geography and gender. In America it's almost 50/50 men and women on the internet, and in Europe women are catching up. It's democratising.'

It is a hectic schedule. Does she regret travelling so much? 'I regret...' She pulls herself up, perhaps conscious that some Maxwells are not famous for their regrets. 'I miss my son,' she says after a pause.

At first glance the prosaic world of outsourced messaging seems a world away from Maxwell's first job as a television journalist. But then it seems all of Maxwell's life she has been focusing on communication. She started off at Oxford doing a law and history degree but switched to modern languages. After working for a couple of UK regional TV stations she worked in California as an independent filmmaker. And Magellan, too, was an attempt to simplify communication.

Perhaps it comes from her father. 'He'd love it [the internet] if he was still here. He was very prescient. He was doing online stuff back in the late Sixties. He'd be in his element, he'd be having a blast, I'm sure he'd be thrilled to know what I'm doing now,' Maxwell says, throwing back her head and laughing loudly.

Does she tire of people asking about her father, the Mirror pension plunderer who died mysteriously in 1992? The laughter reaches a crescendo. Maxwell shakes her head: 'I am who I am. It's a legacy.'

Even outside her professional life Maxwell seems keen to promote communication in the widest sense. She is a governor of the Peres Centre for Peace, in Tel Aviv.

'I'm optimistic about being able to help. I don't have starry eyes about making some mega-change. War seems to be sexy. Peace is not. But get the economic process going, and the bombs stop.'

She takes succour from the fact that the likes of Wal-Mart are moving into the Middle East. 'Too much good living has started for it to go back to another war. Yes, there'll be more terrorism, but there definitely won't be another war.'

Commtouch, an Israeli company, was attracted to Maxwell's optimism when it head-hunted her in 1997. Maxwell says it is the embodiment of the Israeli business culture. 'It's cohesive, innovative, disciplined' - and she is having the best 'corporate work experience' of her life.

Admittedly, it has been hit by the slump in hi-tech stocks, but Maxwell is san guine about it. 'If you look on the bottom of the market floor now it's just debris. Everyone's been battered.' The fact that big names such as Microsoft have bought into the company suggests Commtouch is better positioned to take the pain than many.

Maxwell jokes about persuading Bill Gates to make a personal investment in the business. In a faux southern belle accent, she purrs: 'He's got to spend $375m a year to keep his tax free status, why not allow me to help him.' She explodes with laughter.

Several times after the interview she rings to reiter ate facts and stress points. Given what the Maxwell name stands for in Britain, her desire to get her story across is understandable.

And she wants it to be her own story. If Commtouch soars, Maxwell will be able to step out of her father's shadow for good.

Job: President, Commtouch

Age: 'How old do you think I am? I'm 50'

Other directorships: Governor of Peres Peace Centre, Tel Aviv

Hobbies: Climbing, mountain biking, skiing

webTitle: Crippled in a war of whispers

fields.headline: Crippled in a war of whispers
fields.standfirst: Complaints about chief executives should be made in the open, writes  Heather Connon
fields.trailText: Complaints about chief executives should be made in the open, writes Heather Connon
fields.body:
Sir Iain Vallance of BT, Ian Harley from Abbey National, Greg Hutchings of Tomkins and Peter Salsbury of Marks & Spencer. Can you spot the odd one out?

It is, of course, Salsbury. He has just lost his job as chief executive after a long whispering campaign against him. The other three are still in their posts fighting those who criticise their performance and question their managerial skills.

It is a difficult battle to fight because none of them really knows who the enemy is. War is being waged not in the boardrooms or even at meetings with significant shareholders, where questions of stewardship should be decided. These are guerrilla wars, waged through unattributable briefings and stories quoting 'insiders' or 'major shareholders'. The very essence of a whispering campaign is that no one will ever admit to being behind it.

They can be extremely destabilising. One company which was at the heart of a long-running campaign said it undermined the ability of the executives to manage the business.

It is no coincidence that the number of whispering campaigns has been rising recently. The stock market has been drifting downwards for much of the year and some sectors - banks, engineers and retailers among them - have been performing badly for much longer. That is bad news for major shareholders and not just because the value of their portfolio is falling. If the poor performance goes on, it can affect their own bonuses and salaries, even the security of their jobs.

'The people who have made the decision to buy into these companies are under obvious pressure when the share price underperforms,' said Peter Butler of Hermes, who has publicly criticised whispering campaigns. 'Regrettably, instead of talking directly to the board or sharing their concerns with other shareholders, they often speak off the record to the press.'

If whispering campaigns are aimed at ending underperformance, then they do not seem to work. The campaign against Hutchings started more than a year ago, and the company has done many of the things that the unattributable investors were asking for, including appointing an external chairman and selling its food business. But the shares are now a third below their high for the year. Marks & Spencer's shares dipped to a 10-year low last week, despite Salsbury's departure. Abbey National has underperformed the banking sector in the six months since the campaign really kicked off; and BT's shares have less than half the rating of telecom rivals such as Vodafone, although they received a fillip on Friday from the resignation of finance director Robert Brace.

Indeed, some say that such campaigns could be counterproductive. Tomkins was trying to sell Ranks Hovis McDougall, its food business, while the whispering campaign was at its height. 'Each time a critical article appeared, the venture capitalists cut the price they were offering for it,' said Butler.

Others say that, far from making Hutchings think about standing down and handing over to someone more able to improve performance, the campaign made him even more determined to stay.

Everyone would agree that institutions should be critical of companies which fail to perform - they are, after all, the owners. Hundreds of pages of corporate governance guidance is aimed at ensuring they do just that. What is questionable, however, is voicing that criticism through whispering campaigns.

'If shareholders are unhappy and they want to go public with that, it is up to them. But it must be attributable; whispering campaigns often destroy shareholder value,' said Butler. Most fund managers seem, however, to be overcome with shyness when threatened with the limelight. While they will be blunt in private with journalists and fellow investors, in meetings with the company, they will give no indication that anything is wrong.

'Sometimes their knowledge of a company will be superficial,' said one institution. They may also be understandably reluctant to tell a chief executive that their performance is inadequate.

That is why Sir Ronnie Hampel recommended that a senior non-executive director, usually the chairman, should always be nominated. He or she would be the person whom shareholders could contact to discuss the performance of the executive team. Such meetings rarely happen, however - perhaps for the simple reason that investors do not know where to find him.

But what happens if the campaign is being orchestrated not by shareholders but by company insiders? While institutional shareholders have complained about all the companies mentioned above, there are signs of internal dissent in three of them. At BT, there are hints that one or more of Vallance's board colleagues told journalists that he planned to leave early, a story that was promptly flatly denied by BT, although Brace's resignation supported the conspiracy theorists. At Abbey National, there are suggestions that the campaign against Harley is being led by one of the directors who failed to get his job when Peter Birch retired. Some executives within M&S were as frustrated by the slow speed of Salsbury's reforms as investors were.

In such cases, it is surely time for the non-executive directors to do something. It should be noted that the most successful boardroom putsch in recent years was at BP, when Bob Horton was ousted in favour of David Simons. That was orchestrated by the non-executive directors, who were concerned at the atmosphere within the company. The shares have been rising almost continuously since.

webTitle: Cards deal blow to M&S financial arm

fields.headline: Cards deal blow to M&S financial arm
fields.trailText: Profits from Marks & Spencer's financial-services division are expected to fall by more than 20 per cent both this year and next as a result of it accepting credit cards in its stores.
fields.body:
Profits from Marks & Spencer's financial-services division are expected to fall by more than 20 per cent both this year and next as a result of it accepting credit cards in its stores.

That fall is despite a change in policy to allow the division to charge stores fees for card usage. Adjusting for the impact of that, the profits fall this year would be almost 40 per cent.

The decline at what was M&S's most successful division is a further blow to the group, which is already suffering a slump in profits at high-street stores here and overseas businesses. It had hoped that taking cards would help stem those falls but this seems to have had little impact. Sales in Britain fell 1.2 per cent in the 24 weeks to September, excluding the benefit of store openings.

M&S says that 11 per cent of sales are now on credit card, although it expects that to rise in the run-up to Christmas. It does not disclose the penetration of its own Chargecard, but Tony Shiret, retail analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston, estimates it has fallen to 21.5 per cent of sales, from 27 per cent. That is despite the fact that M&S cut the interest rate on its card from 25 per cent to 18.7 per cent to be more competitive.

Shiret estimates that the rate cut combined with merchanting fees will cut financial-services profits from £116 million to £90m in the year to next March. He is predicting a further fall, to just £70m the following year.

He estimates that charging stores fees will boost the financial-services profits by £20m this year, but at the expense of an equal cut in profits from retail business.

M&S had warned that financial-services growth would be checked by the decision to accept credit cards, but the scale of the decline has surprised the City. The group has been launching new products - such as home insurance - to try to make up the shortfall.

Meanwhile, there is speculation that M&S will announce plans to cut space at some of its larger sites following a property review. That could involve unwinding the effect of the acquisition of 19 Littlewoods stores, which resulted in M&S having two shops in some cities. It said it had always been anticipated that these would have lower sales per sq ft than others in the portfolio.

That fall is despite a change in policy to allow the division to charge stores fees for card usage. Adjusting for the impact of that, the profits fall this year would be almost 40 per cent. The decline at what was M&S's most successful division is a further blow to the group, which is already suffering a slump in profits at high-street stores here and overseas businesses. It had hoped that taking cards would help stem those falls but this seems to have had little impact. Sales in Britain fell 1.2 per cent in the 24 weeks to September, excluding the benefit of store openings. M&S says that 11 per cent of sales are now on credit card, although it expects that to rise in the run-up to Christmas. It does not disclose the penetration of its own Chargecard, but Tony Shiret, retail analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston, estimates it has fallen to 21.5 per cent of sales, from 27 per cent. That is despite the fact that M&S cut the interest rate on its card from 25 per cent to 18.7 per cent to be more competitive. Shiret estimates that the rate cut combined with merchanting fees will cut financial-services profits from £116 million to £90m in the year to next March. He is predicting a further fall, to just £70m the following year. He estimates that charging stores fees will boost the financial-services profits by £20m this year, but at the expense of an equal cut in profits from retail business. M&S had warned that financial-services growth would be checked by the decision to accept credit cards, but the scale of the decline has surprised the City. The group has been launching new products - such as home insurance - to try to make up the shortfall. Meanwhile, there is speculation that M&S will announce plans to cut space at some of its larger sites following a property review. That could involve unwinding the effect of the acquisition of 19 Littlewoods stores, which resulted in M&S having two shops in some cities. It said it had always been anticipated that these would have lower sales per sq ft than others in the portfolio.

webTitle: BA plans to axe 10,000 jobs over next 12 months

fields.headline: BA plans to axe 10,000 jobs over next 12 months
fields.trailText: British Airways is poised to cut up to 10,000 jobs and abandon loss-making routes in a year-long programme to cut costs and return to profit.
fields.byline: by Joanna Walters, Transport Business Editor
fields.body:
British Airways is poised to cut up to 10,000 jobs and abandon loss-making routes in a year-long programme to cut costs and return to profit.

Rod Eddington, chief executive of the struggling airline, is expected to announce early next month a 'root and branch' review of operations.

Senior airline industry sources said he was not planning a 'big bang' announcement of job losses because final figures have not been decided and he wants to avoid industrial unrest. But the entire route network is being evaluated and, as certain services are phased out and others switch to smaller aircraft, fewer crew, management, administration and engineering staff will be required.

One source confirmed that at least 8,000 and perhaps as many as 10,000 jobs would be shed over the coming 12 months as the airline plans its flying timetable for 2001.

Since BA called off its proposed merger with Dutch national airline KLM last month, Eddington has decided to use the internal financial review carried out during negotiations as a framework for cost-cutting.

He signalled his intentions to BA's 60,000 staff in the company newspaper last week, saying: 'If that means taking some difficult decisions for the sake of our business, then that is what we will have to do. In doing so we will have a better chance of ensuring... our future success.'

Eddington has not ruled out compulsory redundancies but hopes to make all the proposed changes with voluntary job losses. BA axed 1,000 managers last year and drew up plans for a further 7,000 job losses, but the plans were not implemented before Bob Ayling lost his job as chief executive to Eddington.

The City awaits a report from Eddington on 6 November of half-year results after his first six months in office. Now that he has no new partnership to unveil, radical plans for a return to strong profits will be the least shareholders expect. BA lost £115 million last year.

webTitle: Car price war slams the brake on profits

fields.headline: Car price war slams the brake on profits
fields.standfirst: A bloodbath is likely now that Ford has slashed its list prices, writes  Joanna Walters
fields.trailText: A bloodbath is likely now that Ford has slashed its list prices, writes Joanna Walters
fields.body:
Car wars are set to break out on the forecourts of Britain this week as rival manufacturers follow Ford in slashing prices - heralding a bonanza for consumers but further losses for the struggling UK motor industry.

Vauxhall, Peugeot and Nissan are expected to undercut Ford by slashing the 'list' or recommended retail price (RRP) of cars by up to 20 per cent. Renault and Volkswagen are considering similar tactics. On Friday, MG Rover Group announced discounts of between 10 and 19 per cent on all models and Toyota, cuts of up to 15 per cent.

Ford is likely to respond further after its opening salvo last Monday when it cut list prices by up to £2,500, or 13 per cent.

But although faltering sales volumes may recover if reluctant motorists and company car buyers are lured back into the showrooms, a full-blown price war will mean a bloodbath in profitability for some companies.

Alan Pulham, of the National Franchised Dealers Association, said: 'Next to move has got to be Peugeot or Vauxhall. If Ford move they have to, and they have intimated as much to their dealers. It has got to happen in the next few days: you only bring people into the showrooms at the moment with price cuts.'

He said the industry feared that without dramatic action on prices, motorists and fleet buyers may wait until January, so that the car is registered in 2001, giving a higher residual value.

Only 350,000 new X-registration cars were sold last month, a drop of 8.7 per cent compared with September 1999, against the 400,000 sales that the industry was hoping for. 'Those sales will not be recovered in what is traditionally a poor final quarter for the industry,' Pulham said.

Carmakers with factories in this country will be hardest hit because of the strength of sterling against the euro.

Continental manufacturers have a bigger cushion against UK price cuts because they sell their cars here in sterling but bank the revenues and pay their costs in their local currencies, which are linked to the euro. And UK prices are typically between 10 and 30 per cent higher than on the continent.

Ford of Britain lost £119 million last year. Rover, now under British ownership and renamed MG Rover Group, almost collapsed this spring.

Even the ultra-lean Japanese manufacturers are struggling to make profits on their UK activities.

In addition to competing against continental importers, exports from British factories to the eurozone largely fail to translate into sterling profits.

A record 72 per cent of UK sales were imports last month. MG Rover's sales fell by 44 per cent and its market share sank to 3.7 per cent. Vauxhall's sales fell 11 per cent, Nissan's 33 per cent and Ford's 3.6 per cent.

Niche players such as Mitsubishi, BMW, Mercedes and Alfa Romeo have already cut prices, and most of the mass manufacturers have had a host of special offers.

Ford's cutting of its list prices barely impacts on the 'on-the-road' transaction price for many of its models. Consumers could end up paying substantially more because the company has discontinued its earlier 'cashback' offers. But industry observers said the fact that the market leader has slashed the RRP gave a clear signal that UK car prices are moving closer to continental levels.

The Government has ordered car prices to come down by at least 10 per cent as part of its campaign against 'rip-off Britain'.

Aside from Rover's crisis, Ford intends to end car production at Dagenham, Nissan has warned that its Sunderland plant is under threat and Vauxhall and the Japanese plan to increase the proportion of components they buy from the eurozone. They and Peugeot have criticised the Government's stance over joining the euro and said failure to commit threatens investment.

Christopher Macgowan, chief executive of the Society of Motor Manufacturers, said that the profitability of UK carmakers was 'fragile'.

'I fear it [a price war] will be unhelpful and will not give out the right messages to those in Detroit and Tokyo who make the investment decisions,' he said.

fields.headline: Down on the farms
fields.standfirst: Suppliers are suffering as the big supermarkets resort to sharp practices, reports  Paul Farrelly
fields.trailText: Suppliers are suffering as the big supermarkets resort to sharp practices, reports Paul Farrelly
fields.body:
Martin Evans is a potato farmer in Pembroke. For 26 years, this 48-year-old fourth-generation Welsh farmer has sown up to 100 acres, producing 1,500 tonnes of the crop each spring. But next year he will cut back sharply, and in 2002 pack it in altogether.

The reason is straightforward: like thousands of small farmers around Britain, Evans simply cannot make a living. Nor, dependent on the whims of the big supermarkets, can he afford to take the risk of the chains wriggling out of contracts when the next cheap boatload docks from Jersey or Cyprus.

This June, Evans received just 3.4p for every pound of spuds, compared with the 28p Tesco is charging at its new superstore down the road at Pembroke Dock. And, like every lamb and beef farmer in the land, he is furious that the long-awaited Competition Commission report has cleared the big chains of not passing derisory farmgate prices on to the consumer.

'It's absolute rubbish. Tesco haven't dropped their prices,' he says. 'I'm not making any money now. I used to. And supermarkets, because they now control so much of the market, are a big part of the reason why.'

Protests, three years ago, by Evans and his West Wales brethren were instrumental in starting an Office of Fair Trading inquiry into supermarket power in 1998 and then the Competition Commission investigation 16 months ago. As revealed in The Observer last week, the commission's still unpublished report finds the biggest chains guilty of acting against the public interest by overcharging in areas where they face little competition and by drawing customers in with loss-leading prices on staples like bread and milk. But, to widespread anger last week, it concludes that nothing can be done to stop them.

We can also reveal the report finds that the big supermarkets abuse their buying power by screwing down suppliers, who include small farmers like Evans right at the bottom of the food chain. 'There appeared to us to be a "climate of fear" among many suppliers in their relationship with the supermarkets,' the commission concludes. 'Suppliers commonly alleged they were expected to comply with requests for payments, discounts and other concessions if they were to retain their business, or their current level of business, with a multiple. We believe them.'

The commission finds that out of the 42 allegedly bullying practices investigated in detail, 31 adversely affected suppliers and distorted competition. Moreover, 23 of Britain's 24 biggest chains are guilty of using one or more of the tactics. And, the report concludes, the biggest five buyers - Tesco, Sainsbury, Asda, Safeway and Somerfield - form a 'complex monopoly', many of whose buying activities operate against the public interest.

Vulnerable consumers, who use the corner shop, also suffer. Together, the five chains control more than 75 per cent of supermarket grocery purchases. And, screwed by the big chains, suppliers are forced to charge higher prices to small grocers, the report finds.

'We also take the view that the cumulative effect of the practices is likely to be particularly adverse for the competitiveness of suppliers,' the report says. 'It will increase the risk that suppliers may not only reduce their product development but actually exit from the market.'

Jane Howells, another Pembrokeshire farmer, has vowed never to deal with a supermarket again. A former official of the Farmers Union of Wales, she is now converting her 170-acre farm to produce organic Aberdeen Angus beef for sale in farm shops, door-to-door or over the internet. Three years ago, she bred dairy calves, but got out when the milk price collapsed. Now it will be another two years before her 112 head of Angus are ready and the family makes a living again.

'Our biggest problem is that supermarkets know our milk, beef and produce have a limited shelf life. They know they don't have to pay a reasonable price. They're laughing,' she says. 'But they may not just drop their price. They may decide your cauliflowers are the wrong colour or your potatoes the wrong shape. They're clever. The goalposts move all the time. Anything to get round a contract.'

On several complaints alleging sharp practice, the report makes no findings. There's the Tredegar baker asked by her bread supplier, under pressure from Tesco whom she was undercutting, to raise her prices. The manager concerned, Tesco told the commission, 'had acted against company policy'. There's the Cornish cauliflower grower who alleged Tesco pressured other suppliers not to handle its produce. Like several other cases, that was one firm's word against another or a 'one-off', the commission concludes.

But the bullying which the report does pin down puts the industry firmly in the dock. Some of the more eyebrow-raising tactics include: demanding money for stocking items at all or for new store openings and refurbishment; requiring contributions to charities when the chain gets all the kudos; chipping away at contracts by insisting on all sorts of retrospective discounts; and forcing suppliers to use particular transport or packaging firms, which then pay commission to some of the supermarkets.

The report also paints a picture of very grudging co-operation with the commission by the market leader, Tesco, in particular. While rivals Sainsbury, Safeway and Asda freely admit to some of the practices, in the main Tesco fired off the same blanket response: 'It is not company practice nor policy to engage in them.' Yet some of the practices were found to be widespread at the chain.

'Tesco said we could not find it to be a member of a complex monopoly group on the basis of activities that it had carried out which were not the company's policy or practice,' the report says. 'We are not convinced by this argument. Moreover, we do not find it acceptable for a multiple to shield behind the actions of its buyers on the grounds that what may have occurred is not company policy. It is the responsibility of the company to see that its employees follow that policy.'

In response, the commission recommends a code of practice banning many of the most blatant bullying tactics, including payment of shelf fees, retrospective discounts and contract changes, and interference in suppliers' other business. The provisions, to be approved by the Director General of Fair Trading, go further than most supermarkets would like. But, as a voluntary system, the commission's proposals still fail to meet many suppliers' demands for the law to be used to enforce fairer play.

'I don't think any of us thought the commission was going to change anything, given the power of the supermarkets,' said Jane Howells. 'I'd have sleepless nights if I thought I'd have to deal with a supermarket again.'

After years of complaining, farmers are also amazed at one glaring hole in the report. Namely, while focusing on the effects of 'persistent below-cost selling' of the likes of milk and bread on grocers and consumers, the toll on farmers and growers is largely ignored.

After 21 years, in 1996, Martin Evans also quit dairy farming just before the bottom fell out of the market. 'I'm so pleased. Dairy was doing all right. Then you got 22p a litre, but now they're actually selling the stuff for 16p. The business is really struggling. The calves are worth nothing and the dairy boys are really suffering.'
