webTitle: New policy - but not for long

fields.headline: New policy - but not for long
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is the best Prime Minister we have, and the Conservative Party is running out of feet in which to shoot itself.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is the best Prime Minister we have, and the Conservative Party is running out of feet in which to shoot itself.

This seems to be the message of the recent seaside conference season, which has also seen the Chancellor, Gordon Brown, go from strength to strength, during intervals between his trips to the Group of Seven and International Monetary Fund meetings in Prague.

Whatever else they have done, the revolts on the petrol and pensions front have shaken New Labour out of its complacency and forced it to listen. If it does not go on doing so, the Government faces not so much a threat from enthusiasts shouting, 'Don't be vague, vote for Hague' as the kind of mass abstention that has afflicted Labour in most local and European elections since 1 May 1997.

The Conservatives' principal problem continues to be that New Labour has stolen most of its clothes. Labour's problem is that, unless it shows some respect for these embarrassing elderly relations who constitute its core vote, it could yet screw up its best mandate since 1945.

Labour needed a shock, and it has received several. This is no bad thing. Provided the Government shows that it has learnt something from recent grass-roots revolts, it - and we - should be all the better for the experience. The position of the parties is reversed, but there are parallels with 1982-1983, when, for various reasons, Labour was deemed unelectable and Margaret Thatcher, however unpopular her domestic policies (as opposed to her Falklands policies), was given another chance.

The main difference is that whereas Thatcher Mark One had made an unholy mess of the economy, Labour under Brown's chancellorship is generally credited with remarkably good economic stewardship.

While admiring much of what he has achieved, some of us have had reservations about two principal areas: one is the way the combination of Gordonian economy and Treasury parsimony have produced a number of mean-minded decisions - on single mothers; on pensions in general and war widows in particular; and on student grants or the lack of them. All these are unworthy of a left-wing government with a budget surplus that would have embarrassed even Gladstone.

The Conservatives have been too stupid by half in trying to trump Labour on public expenditure. What their claims really boil down to is that they will spend more than Labour does now on this or that public service, simply because in the natural way of things public expenditure is likely to grow year by year anyway. Its growth would be less than under Labour's current plans, that's all.

And anyone who puts his or her faith in the insurance companies as a way of augmenting the good work of the beleaguered health service is referred to the article that a lifelong believer in private insurance, the late Jock Bruce-Gardyne, wrote in the Spectator when the time came for him to collect from Bupa and it was found wanting in his hour of need.

The Government is certainly spending on the public services from now on, but one continues to wonder whether it was really necessary to have that two-year freeze at the beginning.

The second reservation about Brown's stewardship has been the 'hands-off' attitude towards a pound which has been so high that it has been damaging two vital sectors, manufacturing industry and agriculture. An exchange rate regime in which Nissan's European showpiece factory in Sunderland struggles to make money is one that is seriously out of kilter.

There are always time lags in these matters, and the full force of the regime has not yet been felt in an economy that has profited from a combination of a global economic boom and the relative absence of inflationary pressure - an absence not uncon nected with the fierce international competition associated with the phenomenon known as 'globalisation'.

The impressive collection of economic experts who produced the Liberal Democrats' recent pamphlet Britain's Adoption of the Euro concluded that the range of 'possible sustainable entry rates' was between DM2.45 to DM2.84, against around DM3.25 now.

In Prague, the Chancellor told a press conference, against the background of the G7 intervention to stabilise the euro, that the current sterling/euro rate was 'not justified by fundamentals' and, again 'not justified by any look at long-term fundamentals'. Admittedly Brown had made the same point earlier in the summer in his James Meade lecture at the London School of Economics; but, taken in the context of Britain's participation in the G7 operation, this began to sound like a major change of policy and an attempt, at last, to encourage the pound down to more realistic and sustainable levels.

Alas, when the details of the G7 intervention were duly published last week, it turned out that Britain's participation in the multi-billion dollar support for the euro was a mere $70 million or so, and that it sold the euros the same day. This makes Britain sound not so much like a member of the G7 as half a member. It was the first time the British establishment had intervened in the market for sterling against European currencies since Black Wednesday (16 September 1992), although there may have been some intervention later in that decade vis-a-vis the yen.

So, it was a major change of policy - and it lasted several hours. The Treasury is now busily briefing that its intention was to strengthen the euro, not weaken the pound for domestic reasons.

The Bank of England can, within its restricted balance sheet, intervene to lower the pound but only, as I understand it, as part and parcel of its remit to achieve the inflation target. Some members of the Monetary Policy Committee have favoured intervention, but they have been outnumbered.

Still, we have it on record that Brown thinks the pound is overvalued, even if he is reluctant to draw the obvious operational conclusion. At least the implication is that he thinks it's overvalued. For all we know he may believe it is fundamentally undervalued.

So there we have it. The Treasury has dipped a toe in the intervention waters - but only a contorted little toe.
fields.bodyText: Tony Blair is the best Prime Minister we have, and the Conservative Party is running out of feet in which to shoot itself. This seems to be the message of the recent seaside conference season, which has also seen the Chancellor, Gordon Brown, go from strength to strength, during intervals between his trips to the Group of Seven and International Monetary Fund meetings in Prague. Whatever else they have done, the revolts on the petrol and pensions front have shaken New Labour out of its complacency and forced it to listen. If it does not go on doing so, the Government faces not so much a threat from enthusiasts shouting, 'Don't be vague, vote for Hague' as the kind of mass abstention that has afflicted Labour in most local and European elections since 1 May 1997. The Conservatives' principal problem continues to be that New Labour has stolen most of its clothes. Labour's problem is that, unless it shows some respect for these embarrassing elderly relations who constitute its core vote, it could yet screw up its best mandate since 1945. Labour needed a shock, and it has received several. This is no bad thing. Provided the Government shows that it has learnt something from recent grass-roots revolts, it - and we - should be all the better for the experience. The position of the parties is reversed, but there are parallels with 1982-1983, when, for various reasons, Labour was deemed unelectable and Margaret Thatcher, however unpopular her domestic policies (as opposed to her Falklands policies), was given another chance. The main difference is that whereas Thatcher Mark One had made an unholy mess of the economy, Labour under Brown's chancellorship is generally credited with remarkably good economic stewardship. While admiring much of what he has achieved, some of us have had reservations about two principal areas: one is the way the combination of Gordonian economy and Treasury parsimony have produced a number of mean-minded decisions - on single mothers; on pensions in general and war widows in particular; and on student grants or the lack of them. All these are unworthy of a left-wing government with a budget surplus that would have embarrassed even Gladstone. The Conservatives have been too stupid by half in trying to trump Labour on public expenditure. What their claims really boil down to is that they will spend more than Labour does now on this or that public service, simply because in the natural way of things public expenditure is likely to grow year by year anyway. Its growth would be less than under Labour's current plans, that's all. And anyone who puts his or her faith in the insurance companies as a way of augmenting the good work of the beleaguered health service is referred to the article that a lifelong believer in private insurance, the late Jock Bruce-Gardyne, wrote in the Spectator when the time came for him to collect from Bupa and it was found wanting in his hour of need. The Government is certainly spending on the public services from now on, but one continues to wonder whether it was really necessary to have that two-year freeze at the beginning. The second reservation about Brown's stewardship has been the 'hands-off' attitude towards a pound which has been so high that it has been damaging two vital sectors, manufacturing industry and agriculture. An exchange rate regime in which Nissan's European showpiece factory in Sunderland struggles to make money is one that is seriously out of kilter. There are always time lags in these matters, and the full force of the regime has not yet been felt in an economy that has profited from a combination of a global economic boom and the relative absence of inflationary pressure - an absence not uncon nected with the fierce international competition associated with the phenomenon known as 'globalisation'. The impressive collection of economic experts who produced the Liberal Democrats' recent pamphlet Britain's Adoption of the Euro concluded that the range of 'possible sustainable entry rates' was between DM2.45 to DM2.84, against around DM3.25 now. In Prague, the Chancellor told a press conference, against the background of the G7 intervention to stabilise the euro, that the current sterling/euro rate was 'not justified by fundamentals' and, again 'not justified by any look at long-term fundamentals'. Admittedly Brown had made the same point earlier in the summer in his James Meade lecture at the London School of Economics; but, taken in the context of Britain's participation in the G7 operation, this began to sound like a major change of policy and an attempt, at last, to encourage the pound down to more realistic and sustainable levels. Alas, when the details of the G7 intervention were duly published last week, it turned out that Britain's participation in the multi-billion dollar support for the euro was a mere $70 million or so, and that it sold the euros the same day. This makes Britain sound not so much like a member of the G7 as half a member. It was the first time the British establishment had intervened in the market for sterling against European currencies since Black Wednesday (16 September 1992), although there may have been some intervention later in that decade vis-a-vis the yen. So, it was a major change of policy - and it lasted several hours. The Treasury is now busily briefing that its intention was to strengthen the euro, not weaken the pound for domestic reasons. The Bank of England can, within its restricted balance sheet, intervene to lower the pound but only, as I understand it, as part and parcel of its remit to achieve the inflation target. Some members of the Monetary Policy Committee have favoured intervention, but they have been outnumbered. Still, we have it on record that Brown thinks the pound is overvalued, even if he is reluctant to draw the obvious operational conclusion. At least the implication is that he thinks it's overvalued. For all we know he may believe it is fundamentally undervalued. So there we have it. The Treasury has dipped a toe in the intervention waters - but only a contorted little toe.

fields.headline: Nomura sets sights on Sydney
fields.standfirst: Olympic venue replaces Dome as launchpad for City golden boy's global leisure park empire
fields.trailText: Olympic venue replaces Dome as launchpad for City golden boy's global leisure park empire
fields.body:
Guy Hands, the City 'golden boy' who last month withdrew his £105 million offer for the Millennium Dome, is eyeing Sydney's Olympic Park as the jewel in the crown of his new global operations.

Hands, head of the principal finance group at Japanese Investment Bank Nomura, is sending a team to Australia in the next two weeks to open discussions with the New South Wales government over the site of the 2000 Olympics. He wants to turn it into a leisure and retail theme park.

With the success of last month's games, Olympic Park - which includes the Olympic Village and sports facilities - is now seen as one the world's premier leisure sites. The contrast with London's Dome could not be starker.

The Sydney site is one of a range being considered for leisure and retail development by the 40-strong team originally assembled at Nomura to roll out its proposals for the Millennium Dome.

Since the failure of negotiations over the Greenwich attraction with the New Millennium Experience Company last month, the team - whose original title 'Dome Europe' has been dropped as a result - has been looking for other high-profile opportunities.

There have been recent rumours that the Japanese bank is considering re-entering negotiations for the Dome, but Nomura sources said there was no possibility of it rebidding. Suspicion as to the origin of these rumours centres on the New Millennium Experience Company, which is currently trying to close a deal with Legacy, the group headed by millionaire Labour donor Robert Bourne - which was originally outbid by Nomura.

The Japanese bank's favoured targets now include a £100m expansion and modernisation project at the UK's biggest conference venue, the National Exhibition centre in Birmingham; Germany's Expo site in Hanover; and a greenfield development outside Amsterdam.

A successful bid for Sydney's Olympic Park would be a coup for Nomura, which views it as a 'very exciting opportunity' despite being further afield than was envisaged in the original Dome Europe plans.

Details provided by the New South Wales government indicate that it backs a theme park option for the Olympic site, which would fit well with Nomura's leisure model.

'It is a wonderful opportunity, although it is still early days,' said a Nomura source, who confirmed that the team would be visiting within two weeks.

Nomura's plans involve a combination of entertainment and retail facilities, with leisure acting as the main draw for visitors, and retail providing the main revenue stream.

Each development will focus around a show - with other entertainment, educational, retail and restaurant facilities.

It is looking for sites that fulfil key criteria - urban location with a high residential population, potential for entertainment, retail and restaurants, high-quality transport links and the possibility of redeveloping brownfield areas.

Hands will have to negotiate to secure capital from Nomura's board in Japan.

webTitle: Brown poised to offer diesel discounts

fields.headline: Brown poised to offer diesel discounts
fields.trailText: Cuts in fuel duty targeted at road hauliers and other vulnerable groups are emerging as the favoured response to the crisis prompted by last month's refinery blockades.
fields.body:
Cuts in fuel duty targeted at road hauliers and other vulnerable groups are emerging as the favoured response to the crisis prompted by last month's refinery blockades.

Senior government sources indicate that an extension of the 'red diesel' scheme, which gives farmers and construction workers discounted fuel, is the most acceptable and practical measure.

The move is expected to be outlined in Chancellor Gordon Brown's pre-Budget statement, brought forward to the end of this month to beat the 13 November deadline for renewed protests.

Ministers are concerned that any package should not be seen as caving in to the fuel protesters and are also determined not to undermine government environmental policy by adding to carbon dioxide emissions through fuel duty cuts.

However, they concede that some concessions must be made, and the more tightly targeted they are, the better. Some motoring groups want changes to North Sea taxation rules to make oil companies contribute to stabilising pump prices.

One senior government source told The Observer: 'Targeting [the red diesel scheme] at hauliers seems like a sensible way forward. It is certainly more sensible than just letting anybody have a reduction.'

In addition to hauliers, the Government is known to be concerned about vulnerable groups such as pensioners and people living in rural areas who are dependent on cars.

It is unlikely that the full red diesel discount of 42p off the standard duty per litre, would be passed on to hauliers. But any extension of the scheme - the fuel is dyed red to stop illegal use in non-eligible vehicles - would be welcome. Hauliers point to European schemes where 'blue' diesel is available to hauliers at a discount of about 15p. Geoff Dossetter of the Freight Transport Association said the UK's 48p duty level compared with an EU average of 19.3p. The FTA is calling for a 15p reduction.

fields.headline: DTI hits bullying stores
fields.trailText: The government is considering a 'Supermarkets Authority' to police the big food chains as it finally releases the Competition Commission report into the industry this week.
fields.byline: by Paul Farrelly and Oliver Morgan
fields.body:
The government is considering a 'Supermarkets Authority' to police the big food chains as it finally releases the Competition Commission report into the industry this week.

The high-profile body would be charged with resolving disputes under a new code of conduct, obliging supermarkets to cease abusing their buying power.

The proposal, however, falls short of demands, especially from small farmers, for tough, new laws to force supermarkets to play fairer.

'There is still the principle that prices supermarkets charge bear no relation to what farmers get,' said Alan Morris of the Farmers' Union of Wales.

'Supermarkets are making vast profits and farmers don't get their fair share.'

The Department of Trade and Industry has launched an investigation into the leaking of the long-awaited report to The Observer last week. Asda was the first to demand an inquiry in a formal letter from its lawyers to the DTI.

The report, The Observer can reveal, finds the big supermarket chains guilty of damaging suppliers and distorting competition in 31 out of 42 complaints of bullying tactics investigated by the commission.

The top five grocery buyers - Tesco, Sainsbury, Asda, Safeway and Somerfield - are also found to be part of a 'complex monopoly', many of whose buying practices operate against the public interest. The biggest, Tesco, the report finds, squeezes the lowest prices out of suppliers.

This weekend Tesco furiously denied complaints, from sources close to the commission, that it had tried to obstruct the inquiry.

'We have been fully co-operative with the inquiry,' said John Gildersleeve, Tesco's commercial director. 'We have strongly supported the development of a code, and we think it would be a good move for the Government to push this forward.'

The report shows that while Sainsbury and Somerfield also support a voluntary code of practice, Asda and Safeway oppose it.

The code, to be agreed by the Office of Fair Trading, is the second main recommendation of the commission, alongside the need for OFT approval for big, new stores in regions where individual chains are already strong.

According to Whitehall sources, DTI Secretary Stephen Byers is still deciding whether to charge the OFT with policing the code or establishing a new industry body akin to the Advertising Standards Authority.

webTitle: Bertelsmann serenade of EMI out of tune

fields.headline: Bertelsmann serenade of EMI out of tune
fields.trailText: Bertelsmann's attempts to woo EMI, which last week temporarily abandoned plans to merge with the US firm Warner Music in a £13 billion deal, are facing major problems.
fields.body:
Bertelsmann's attempts to woo EMI, which last week temporarily abandoned plans to merge with the US firm Warner Music in a £13 billion deal, are facing major problems.

The German media giant - which has an £8bn war chest - is examining a bid for the British record company in its attempt to become the world's largest music group. But institutional investors in EMI are understood to have given the company's chairman, Eric Nicoli, a pledge that they are not interested in an opportunistic bid based on the company's current deflated share price.

EMI's shares soared to more than 740p last January after it announced the deal. Since then, they have fallen to 530p as the merger plans foundered due to European Commission competition concerns. Bertelsmann would have to answer similar competition worries, and EMI sources say Warner would look to trump any offer made by a rival.

A hostile bid would bring another problem. 'There's a cultural obstacle. You've got to create a business and so you've got to persuade shareholders, artists and management it's a good idea to join you. It would be a crass move to go hostile,' one informed source said.

EMI and Warner plan to have a revamped merger plan back before regulators by next month.

'We will know in a few weeks if it's possible. We're talking single figures,' the source said. The plan is thought to involve a complete reappraisal of the record labels which would be owned by the combined company.

EMI and Warner are looking to see if parts of publishers such as Chappel and chunks of labels like Atlantic and Virgin could be sold off without scuppering the logic behind the merger.

webTitle: FSA considers personal fines for endowments scandal directors

fields.headline: FSA considers personal fines for endowments scandal directors
fields.trailText: Directors of insurance companies who are disciplined for mis-selling endowments may have to pay fines from their own pockets.
fields.byline: by Maria Scott, Personal Finance Editor
fields.body:
Directors of insurance companies who are disciplined for mis-selling endowments may have to pay fines from their own pockets.

The endowments clean-up started by the Financial Services Authority could lead for the first time to personal fines for the heads of insurance companies. Regulators have fined directors of companies in other parts of the financial services industry, such as stockbroking and fund management. But personal fines have not been used before. This has changed with the amalgamation of watchdogs to form the FSA.

The body warned last week that it was investigating a number of firms suspected of mis-selling endowments. More inquiries might be started unless firms improved their sales ethics.

The FSA confirmed it had not ruled out personal fines where firms were found to have mis-sold policies. This could cost errant directors tens of thousands of pounds.

Earlier this year regulators imposed fines of £45,000 and £50,000 on individuals in other areas.

The Consumers' Association welcomed the possibility of fines. Mick McAteer, its senior policy officer, said: 'Unless the board of these big financial services companies realise they have a duty to policyholders, nothing much is going to change.'

Insurers were relieved by the FSA's refusal to launch a full-scale review of past endowment sales. There are 11 million policies, and the regulator said such an exercise would be too expensive.

But the body made it clear there that mis-selling had occurred. Chairman Howard Davies said: 'We want further improvements in practices, and we are determined to identify and correct particular instances of bad practice.'

Insurers could also face legal action from among the 4 million homeowners, who are being told their endowments may not repay their loans.

One action is planned by Joseph Aarons, an Ilford solicitor who has been contacted by 200 people unhappy with their policies.

fields.headline: Billy the kid
fields.standfirst: His debut album went platinum in just 10 weeks. He makes girls scream and grown men cry. Meet US country star Billy Gilman, aged 12
fields.trailText: His debut album went platinum in just 10 weeks. He makes girls scream and grown men cry. Meet US country star Billy Gilman, aged 12
fields.body:
As far as Billy Gilman is concerned, 1991 is, like, ancient history. Not because he was only three at the time, but because those were the days when his family 'didn't even have cable. We only had five or six channels, and Sesame Street was a big deal... LONG time ago!' It was, however, the time when, watching Pam Tillis sing 'Cleopatra, Queen of Denial', Billy Gilman discovered country music, and decided that he wanted to be a star.

Now aged 12, a mere 10 weeks after releasing his debut album, he is the youngest ever person to go platinum (one million copies) in the States, and has just recorded a duet with Charlotte Church in an effort to break Britain. Billy himself does not tell me this; it is his pretty blonde tour manager, Elly, who furnishes me with the precise sales figures. 'Stop it!' yells Billy, 'I'm blushing!' He's not. So how does it feel to be so successful, Billy? 'It's awesome. Platinum in 10 weeks! What else could I accomplish?' He says this in more or less the same tone of voice that Hitler probably used after conquering Poland.

Don't get me wrong: Billy Gilman is cute as a button. Tousled hair, perfect skin, big loud friendly voice, and extensive dental work. The ideal American kid. But when you hear him talking about 'renegotiating with Sony' or his 'densely populated' hometown in Rhode Island, it's easy to think you're listening to some world-weary, hard-nosed fortysomething, rather than a 4ft 7in preteen with take-home pay of $5 a week.

Take the dental work, for instance. It happened on 20 June this year, when Billy was taking a golf lesson. Another kid - 'who had probably never hit a golf ball before in his life' - pitched a ball straight at Billy's mouth, smashing his two front teeth. Billy's first reaction? 'I was crying! I thought, "What are Sony going to say?"' Within a week, a local radio station had produced a billboard of Billy's blown-up face with a hole cut into his mouth, and were challenging golfers to hit a ball through the hole in order to win tickets to see Billy. 'It was real painful,' says Billy, 'but I got good press out of it...'

And while all his adolescent friends spend their evenings in the bathroom, imagining what it would be like to touch a girl's breasts, Billy Gilman is screamed at by thousands upon thousands of girls his own age - or even, gasp, older. 'It's awful. Some times they scream so loud that I can't hear myself sing,' he complains. 'They send lots of letters, too. I laugh, because some of them are so... like, one of them spelt "please" like "p-l-e-e-z-e"!' He snorts with derision. A word of advice to Billy's female admirers: use a dictionary.

It's only when he breaks into song - as he does several times during our interview - that you get a glimpse of the child beneath the pragmatic bluster. Preternaturally mature his voice may be, but its clear, high, haunting quality sounds undeniably innocent. On most of the songs on his debut album, One Voice , it is wasted - doing nonsense rhymes over bland, uptempo country-pop tracks - but on the title track (and first single), Billy sings with an angelic passion which will make men stop pistol-whipping their wives this Christmas, and weep, if only for three and a half minutes.

A subtle anti-gun anthem, it is accompanied by a brilliant black-and-white video in which Billy looks on compassionately at the young thugs beside him on the school bus, smiling enigmatically at the end when one of them tosses his firearm into a river. Released in the wake of the Columbine high school massacre, it had a profound impact on middle America's psyche. Or profound enough at least to cause a million people to buy the album.

I ask Billy whether he's ever seen or even heard about a child with a gun in his hometown. 'Nah,' he smiles, 'It's just kinda general.' Elly interrupts: 'The thing about Billy is that he really likes kids, and he wants little boys and girls to be safe in their houses.' Is that how you feel, Billy? I ask. 'Yeah, sure,' he replies, somewhat less than convincingly. So how did you feel when you heard about the Columbine massacre? 'Well,' he says, brightening, 'we'd just recorded One Voice , and I said to myself, "Hey, that's gotta be the first single!"

The only point during the interview when Billy Gilman shows the slightest sign of vulnerability is when I mention the low career survival rate of child prodigies. Is he worried about his career going belly-up when his voice breaks? 'A little bit,' he replies, in a quiet voice. And what would he do if his singing career was suddenly flushed down the toilet? 'I'd like to be a veterinarian or a pop manager,' he says.

A veterinarian? Oh pleeze! Put it this way: don't ever trust him with your sick puppy, but if your child is a singing star and you want to milk him/her for all they are worth, Billy Gilman would be the perfect manager.

Within a week, a local radio station had produced a billboard of Billy's blown-up face with a hole cut into his mouth, and were challenging golfers to hit a ball through the hole in order to win tickets to see Billy. 'It was real painful,' says Billy, 'but I got good press out of it...' And while all his adolescent friends spend their evenings in the bathroom, imagining what it would be like to touch a girl's breasts, Billy Gilman is screamed at by thousands upon thousands of girls his own age - or even, gasp, older. 'It's awful. Some times they scream so loud that I can't hear myself sing,' he complains. 'They send lots of letters, too. I laugh, because some of them are so... like, one of them spelt "please" like "p-l-e-e-z-e"!' He snorts with derision. A word of advice to Billy's female admirers: use a dictionary. It's only when he breaks into song - as he does several times during our interview - that you get a glimpse of the child beneath the pragmatic bluster. Preternaturally mature his voice may be, but its clear, high, haunting quality sounds undeniably innocent. On most of the songs on his debut album, One Voice , it is wasted - doing nonsense rhymes over bland, uptempo country-pop tracks - but on the title track (and first single), Billy sings with an angelic passion which will make men stop pistol-whipping their wives this Christmas, and weep, if only for three and a half minutes. A subtle anti-gun anthem, it is accompanied by a brilliant black-and-white video in which Billy looks on compassionately at the young thugs beside him on the school bus, smiling enigmatically at the end when one of them tosses his firearm into a river. Released in the wake of the Columbine high school massacre, it had a profound impact on middle America's psyche. Or profound enough at least to cause a million people to buy the album. I ask Billy whether he's ever seen or even heard about a child with a gun in his hometown. 'Nah,' he smiles, 'It's just kinda general.' Elly interrupts: 'The thing about Billy is that he really likes kids, and he wants little boys and girls to be safe in their houses.' Is that how you feel, Billy? I ask. 'Yeah, sure,' he replies, somewhat less than convincingly. So how did you feel when you heard about the Columbine massacre? 'Well,' he says, brightening, 'we'd just recorded One Voice , and I said to myself, "Hey, that's gotta be the first single!" The only point during the interview when Billy Gilman shows the slightest sign of vulnerability is when I mention the low career survival rate of child prodigies. Is he worried about his career going belly-up when his voice breaks? 'A little bit,' he replies, in a quiet voice. And what would he do if his singing career was suddenly flushed down the toilet? 'I'd like to be a veterinarian or a pop manager,' he says. A veterinarian? Oh pleeze! Put it this way: don't ever trust him with your sick puppy, but if your child is a singing star and you want to milk him/her for all they are worth, Billy Gilman would be the perfect manager. One Voice: album 30 Oct, single 20 Nov

fields.headline: Fly away Paul...
fields.standfirst: Paul Newman is a smooth old pro staging his final heist. And so is the character he plays
fields.trailText: Paul Newman is a smooth old pro staging his final heist. And so is the character he plays
fields.body:
Where the Money Is (87 mins, 15) Directed by Marek Kanievska; starring Paul Newman, Linda Fiorentino, Dermot Mulroney

There is a mysterious kind of movie title that is not explained in the film itself and demands some special knowledge. A Clockwork Orange, Straw Dogs and O Brother, Where Art Thou? are examples. The amiable Where the Money Is, directed by Marek Kanievska, a British filmmaker best known for Another Country , from a script by three Americans, belongs in this category.

Nobody uses the phrase in the film and, surprisingly, it is not in any dictionary of quotations I possess. But it is generally attributed to the legendary American criminal Willie Sutton, who spent most of his life in jail and the rest of it planning heists. Asked in old age why he persisted in robbing banks, Willie replied: 'Because that's where the money is', and it is clear that Henry, the elderly thief played by Paul Newman, is modelled on Willie Sutton.

This clever comedy-thriller begins with Henry, a convict well into his seventies, being temporarily installed in a public geriatric hospital in Oregon. He is speechless and paralysed from a stroke two years before, and thus considered harmless by the state and no threat to the largely female inmates. But his notorious career staging ingenious hold-ups coast to coast causes a flutter among his fellow patients and excites the special interest of Carol (the seductive Linda Fiorentino), an attractive nurse whose marriage to her boorish high-school sweetheart, Wayne (Dermot Mulroney), has gone sour.

The frustrated Carol suspects that Henry is feigning his condition, or perhaps unconsciously hopes he is. Anyway, after a leisurely, interestingly detailed opening half-hour, she rumbles Henry.

Having studied autohypnosis, this brilliant, amoral loner has managed to convince doctors, psychiatrists and warders that he has been permanently incapacitated by the stroke.

'It's not enough to play possum,' the sprightly charmer tells his two new pupils. 'You've got to be possum.' That is as good a description of method acting as you can get; Newman and Henry are consummate performers whom you rarely catch acting.

Henry subsequently masterminds from his wheel-chair his last big heist. To assist him, he inducts Carol and Wayne into the art of theft, the way Sean Connery does Catherine Zeta Jones in Jon Amiel's Entrapment and Burt Reynolds does Casey Siemaszko in Bill Forsyth's Breaking In (American movies that also happen to have British directors).

Wayne wants the wages of sin, but lacks the spirit to enjoy transgression. Carol, on the other hand, becomes radiant, is renewed and liberated by embarking on a life of crime, in a manner reminiscent of Peggy Cummins in the subversive classic Gun Crazy and Faye Dunaway in Bonnie and Clyde . However, a violent bout of vomiting before setting out on the final job reveals suppressed qualms and fear.

The chosen target is not a bank but an armoured car, and the scheme is to hijack one and then themselves make the nightly collection at supermarkets, bars, filling stations, an amusement park and a sports stadium. 'You don't rob the route, you rob the crew,' says Henry, explaining why they need to study the behaviour of the armoured-car drivers. His object as always is to carry out the operation without shooting; in fact, almost the film's only act of violence comes in some well-deserved revenge on a crooked male nurse.

There are some holes in the plot and a few improbabilities in Where the Money Is, but generally this beguiling film goes its antisocial way in a stately, magisterial manner befitting the age and stature of its protagonist and its star.

The script is peppered with sharp dialogue that Newman handles impeccably. He tells a cautionary tale about a friend's greyhound on a Florida racetrack that caught up with the hare and was electrocuted - 'He got what he wanted, but not what he expected.'

His best line comes when the police surround them at Fiorentino's house and a sheriff barks through a megaphone: 'Come out with your hands on your heads.' Newman's blue eyes sparkle: 'You haven't lived till you've heard someone say that to you.'

Newman, who is 75, has said that this will be his last movie. One hopes not, as he has done fine work during the past decade. He emerged on the screen 45 years ago under the shadow of his fellow Actors Studio graduates, Marlon Brando and James Dean, and because of Dean's early death and Brando's professional indolence, he has long since outstripped them. He has also been, while living an orderly life and conducting a disciplined career, a greater rebel than either.

Newman has proved himself equally adept at comedy and drama (think of The Sting and Butch Cassidy), though only occasionally has he been an orthodox hero, as in Exodus, one of the few occasions he has played a Jew.

His great strength over the years is the insight he has brought to outsiders, anti-authoritarian rebels as different as the eponymous heroes of Hud, Hombre and Cool Hand Luke .

On the other hand, he gave one of his finest performances in Mr and Mrs Bridge, playing the very embodiment of middle-class, small-town conformity.

Possibly his greatest film is The Hustler (1961), which established him as an actor of stature and, 25 years later, in The Color of Money, Newman was able to revisit the same character, to see how he had changed and grown, and at last win an Oscar.

fields.headline: Here's another fine mezzo
fields.standfirst: Welsh National Opera's new production of Orpheus is hell on earth. And it's heaven
fields.trailText: Welsh National Opera's new production of Orpheus is hell on earth. And it's heaven
fields.body:
Orphée et Eurydice WNO, New Theatre, Cardiff
Mary Seacole Linbury Studio, ROH, London WC2

With its variables of version, edition, voice type, language and even title, Gluck's Orfeo ed Eurydice (or Orphée et Eurydice or Orpheus and Eurydice ) is the kind of cud on which musicologists love to chew. For the rest of us, mere opera- goers, the work emits an air of musty gravitas, like an old book whose importance is known but which is too intimidating to open.

That Welsh National Opera found a way to enjoy the distant rhetoric and make it alive and affecting is a tribute to the production team of Patrice Caurier and Moshe Leiser. Instead of trying to reinvent the piece, which has two hours of enthralling music but almost no action, they exalted in its puzzling qualities and engaged with its spirit.

In simple terms, Gluck's 1762 composition provides a bridge between the grand formalities of baroque opera (Handel, say) and the expressive freedoms of the nineteenth century (almost everyone who followed). Because of its economy, and its new way of integrating chorus and dance with the drama, it has been called a 'reform opera', giving Gluck a particular place in operatic history.

All well and good. The complications start when you learn that Gluck first wrote the piece in Italian, then reworked it in French, adapting the role of Orpheus from castrato to high tenor, changing the orchestration and generally fiddling around with order, keys and detail. Further revisions followed, with the 'English' Bach (J.C.) inserting his own music when the work came to London in 1770 in order to make a longer evening's entertainment (not, apparently, having learnt that short can be beautiful, especially in the opera house).

Bypassing the many other efforts by various hands, we then come to Berlioz, who paid homage to Gluck with an edition of his own in 1859, aided by the great mezzo-soprano, Pauline Viardot (much swooned over by Charles Dickens).

You can read the details in books. The significance here is that WNO chose Berlioz's version for the new staging. This meant that the title role was sung by a mezzo, the Swedish-born Katarina Karneus, winner of the Cardiff Singer of the World Competition in 1995. She follows in a tradition of mezzo interpreters which includes Clara Butt, Kathleen Ferrier and Janet Baker.

Tall and, with her short hair, boyish looking, Karneus fits the part admirably. Her voice has a crisp asperity, which softened as the evening progressed and suited the virtuosic runs and ornaments of Berlioz's version. As yet she keeps a tight rein on emotional power. The music demands restraint, but a notch more expression would develop her already dignified and serious interpretation.

Natalie Christie, always a sympathetic performer, sang Eurydice - who doesn't meet her lover until the third act - with a sharp mix of petulance and fervour. Eurydice, you will recall, was the girl who wouldn't take no for an answer when Orpheus refused to look at her.

He finally weakens not because of his own desires but to quell her unjust accusations. His plans to rescue her from the underworld are thus wrecked, and she dies a second time. Fortunately, this being the eighteenth century, a deus ex machina in the shape of Amour (Jeni Bern) appears and all ends happily, with a Hymn of Love and Cupid floating back up to heaven on clouds of glory.

Not for Gluck the continuation of the story (fully explored by Harrison Birtwistle in his 1986 Mask of Orpheus ) in which, after Bac chic revelling, Orpheus is torn to shreds, his head cast in the River Hades still calling out: 'Eurydice!' Paul McCreesh, renowned for his historically informed performances, conducted a taut account in which the WNO orchestra, after a scrappy start, got in to their stride and played vigorously and accurately, and the chorus sang well, though their French was somewhat vague.

Caurier and Leiser dealt with the work's static nature by creating handsome stage pictures, with the help of Christian Fenouillat's sets and Agostino Cavalca's old-new costumes (with lighting by Christopher Forey) in which colour is used to potent effect.

At the start, after the bright overture which hardly prepares you for the melancholy scene which follows, mourners in black suits and coats, successful-looking even in grief, stand stock still in the dappled light around the tomb of the dead Eurydice. In the Elysian Fields, all are in white with fine chiffon blindfolds, the sylvan scene evoking the fetes galantes of Fragonard or Watteau. Orpheus, in black, touchingly lifts the head or tilts the hat of each in his search for his lost love, who eventually springs from her protective white cot in a cocktail dress of cerulean blue. Amour, a quaint dancing master figure, dazzles in burnt orange frock coat and feathered hat.

The spectres and furies of Hades, echoing images of Fuseli, wriggle and jive in agitation at the sound of Orpheus's lyre. Painted side-wings and cloths rise and fall in the style of an eighteenth- century theatre, changing swiftly and simply. All is thought out in impressive detail. A work that has long been respected was here celebrated and brought to sombre life. It deals out its rewards more gradually than other operas but they are durable.

After Cardiff, next performance is Oxford, 19 October.

The musical severity of Orphée certainly seemed light years from the engaging mix of calypso and gospel, highland piping, Victorian music-hall songs, waltzes and Brittenesque soliloquy which comprised Mary Seacole , a ballad opera by Richard Chew (to a libretto by SuAndi Obe) about the Jamaican healer and nurse who went to the front line of the Crimean War at the same time as Florence Nightingale.

The world premiere was given by Gyenyame, a new company which was founded to 'produce multi-cultural opera and dance in the UK'.

More episodic than dramatic, with many touching moments, it was well performed and easy to listen to.

To be among a celebratory audience in the Royal Opera House (albeit in its subterranean Linbury Studio) as part of a white minority was a novel experience and one to repeat, though perhaps with more taxing fare.

webTitle: Remember when Eddie Murphy was funny? You must be old

fields.headline: Remember when Eddie Murphy was funny? You must be old
fields.trailText:
Nutty Professor II: the Klumps (107 mins, 12) Directed by Peter Segal; starring Eddie Murphy, Janet Jackson, Larry Miller
Water Drops on Burning Rocks (86 mins, 18) Directed by François Ozon; starring Bernard Giraudeau, Malik Zidi, Ludivine Sagnier, Anna Thomson
Sorted (99 mins, 18) Directed by Alexander Jovy; starring Matthew Rhys, Sienna Guillory, Tim Curry, Jason Donovan
fields.body:
Nutty Professor II: the Klumps (107 mins, 12) Directed by Peter Segal; starring Eddie Murphy, Janet Jackson, Larry Miller
Water Drops on Burning Rocks (86 mins, 18) Directed by François Ozon; starring Bernard Giraudeau, Malik Zidi, Ludivine Sagnier, Anna Thomson
Sorted (99 mins, 18) Directed by Alexander Jovy; starring Matthew Rhys, Sienna Guillory, Tim Curry, Jason Donovan

There was a time in the early Eighties - when he'd followed his debut movie, 48 Hrs with Trading Places - that Eddie Murphy seemed to be among the freshest talents in Hollywood. Since then, he's gone steadily downhill, getting ever richer while making a succession of weak movies, several of them sequels and remakes like the dire Nutty Professor II: the Klumps .

In his 1996 remake of Jerry Lewis's The Nutty Professor, Murphy played both the obese scientific genius, Sherman Klump, and his wicked id, the Mr Hyde figure, Buddy Love. In two scenes in the film, he also played the whole of Klump's grotesque family.

In the sequel, the family have been brought into the foreground and for much of the time Murphy is on screen in eight different guises, two of them highly sexed women. In fact, the Klumps take over the film, brushing aside a wafer-thin plot concerning the outrageous Buddy's attempts to prevent Sherman merchandising his youth serum and marrying his adoring fiancée, fellow scientist, Denise (played by Janet Jackson).

The jokes in Nutty Professor II are about small penises, erections, geriatric lust, fatness, the accidental eating of excrement, oral sex and, endlessly, farting. In a typical scene, a giant, mutated hamster attacks a crowd of spectators with a barrage of cannonball-sized turds before buggering the university's dean, leaving him staggering in pain for the rest of the movie.

Technically, the film is highly accomplished, supporting the theory that the sophistication of a film's humour is in inverse proportion to the brilliance of its special effects.

Rainer Werner Fassbinder wrote the play on which François Ozon's Water Drops On Burning Rocks is based in the mid-Sixties, when he was 19. But though it resembles some of his theatrical movies, most obviously The Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant, he never adapted it for the screen and it was never staged in his lifetime.

A formal, prentice affair in four acts, the sort of thing produced for a playwriting class, it's about a 50-year-old, well-off German gay, Leopold Blum (Bernard Giraudeau), who lures the 19-year-old Franz (Malik Zidi) back to his flat.

The teenager becomes his live-in lover, then six months later, Franz's girlfriend, Anna (Ludivine Sagnier), arrives, as does Leo's one-time partner, Vera (Anna Thomson).

Characteristic Fassbinder games ensue as the characters manipulate and humiliate each other; the first three acts end almost identically, and at one point in each act there's a dialogue between two people looking out of a window.

The film is set back in the Seventies with the men wearing flared trousers and listening to LPs, and Ozon handles it well enough. But it remains a footnote, a curiosity.

Sorted is not, as the title suggests, a sequel to The Postman, but a wholly unconvincing thriller set in the milieu of London's rave clubs.

Carl (Matthew Rhys), a country mouse of breathtaking naiveté, comes from Scunthorpe (described, presumably jokingly, as being in Yorkshire) to the wicked city to investigate the mysterious death of his brother, Justin, a prosperous lawyer.

It seems that Justin spent his time among corrupt ravers and that his chief client was Damian, who owns half of London's clubs, is a number one drug dealer, speaks entirely in Shakespearian quotations and is played by Tim Curry as if reprising his Gilbert and Sullivan Pirate King.

Before you can say Ann Widdecombe, the rural innocent has been fed a succession of illegal substances that drive him around the bend. Fortunately, Jason Donovan, playing a Heathrow customs officer, transvestite and club DJ, is on hand to help - but then that's what good neighbours are for.

Talking of soap operas, I was attracted by a TV programme listed in Thursday's Evening Standard. Intending to watch Lon Chaney in Victor Sjöström's 1924 classic, He Who Gets Slapped on the TCM channel, I noticed that it was preceded by Close-Up - Ken Barlow Talks About Lon Chaney .

I tuned in expecting to hear an account of earnest discussions about the silent cinema down at the Rover's Return. Maybe he'd recall Ena Sharples saying: 'I'll never forgive that Louis B. Mayer for making the nice Swedish gentleman, Mr Sjöström, change his name to Seastrom.' However, the splendid introduction was not in fact by Ken Barlow, but by the film restorer, director and historian, Kevin Brownlow.

This week saw the beginning of Typiquement British: Le Cinéma Britannique at the Centre Pompidou, the biggest season of British movies ever staged in France or anywhere else. The valuable accompanying book by a variety of British and French writers (myself among them) is introduced by France's greatest living director, Bertrand Tavernier, longtime and discerning enthusiast for our cinema.

He begins by quoting François Truffaut's influential dictum about ' l'incompatibilité between the words Cinéma and Angleterre', a sneer that put back the appreciation of British movies for a couple of decades. This season should serve to revoke what Tavernier calls Truffaut's 'excommunicatory bull'.
fields.bodyText: Nutty Professor II: the Klumps (107 mins, 12) Directed by Peter Segal; starring Eddie Murphy, Janet Jackson, Larry Miller Water Drops on Burning Rocks (86 mins, 18) Directed by François Ozon; starring Bernard Giraudeau, Malik Zidi, Ludivine Sagnier, Anna Thomson Sorted (99 mins, 18) Directed by Alexander Jovy; starring Matthew Rhys, Sienna Guillory, Tim Curry, Jason Donovan There was a time in the early Eighties - when he'd followed his debut movie, 48 Hrs with Trading Places - that Eddie Murphy seemed to be among the freshest talents in Hollywood. Since then, he's gone steadily downhill, getting ever richer while making a succession of weak movies, several of them sequels and remakes like the dire Nutty Professor II: the Klumps . In his 1996 remake of Jerry Lewis's The Nutty Professor, Murphy played both the obese scientific genius, Sherman Klump, and his wicked id, the Mr Hyde figure, Buddy Love. In two scenes in the film, he also played the whole of Klump's grotesque family. In the sequel, the family have been brought into the foreground and for much of the time Murphy is on screen in eight different guises, two of them highly sexed women. In fact, the Klumps take over the film, brushing aside a wafer-thin plot concerning the outrageous Buddy's attempts to prevent Sherman merchandising his youth serum and marrying his adoring fiancée, fellow scientist, Denise (played by Janet Jackson). The jokes in Nutty Professor II are about small penises, erections, geriatric lust, fatness, the accidental eating of excrement, oral sex and, endlessly, farting. In a typical scene, a giant, mutated hamster attacks a crowd of spectators with a barrage of cannonball-sized turds before buggering the university's dean, leaving him staggering in pain for the rest of the movie. Technically, the film is highly accomplished, supporting the theory that the sophistication of a film's humour is in inverse proportion to the brilliance of its special effects. Rainer Werner Fassbinder wrote the play on which François Ozon's Water Drops On Burning Rocks is based in the mid-Sixties, when he was 19. But though it resembles some of his theatrical movies, most obviously The Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant, he never adapted it for the screen and it was never staged in his lifetime. A formal, prentice affair in four acts, the sort of thing produced for a playwriting class, it's about a 50-year-old, well-off German gay, Leopold Blum (Bernard Giraudeau), who lures the 19-year-old Franz (Malik Zidi) back to his flat. The teenager becomes his live-in lover, then six months later, Franz's girlfriend, Anna (Ludivine Sagnier), arrives, as does Leo's one-time partner, Vera (Anna Thomson). Characteristic Fassbinder games ensue as the characters manipulate and humiliate each other; the first three acts end almost identically, and at one point in each act there's a dialogue between two people looking out of a window. The film is set back in the Seventies with the men wearing flared trousers and listening to LPs, and Ozon handles it well enough. But it remains a footnote, a curiosity. Sorted is not, as the title suggests, a sequel to The Postman, but a wholly unconvincing thriller set in the milieu of London's rave clubs. Carl (Matthew Rhys), a country mouse of breathtaking naiveté, comes from Scunthorpe (described, presumably jokingly, as being in Yorkshire) to the wicked city to investigate the mysterious death of his brother, Justin, a prosperous lawyer. It seems that Justin spent his time among corrupt ravers and that his chief client was Damian, who owns half of London's clubs, is a number one drug dealer, speaks entirely in Shakespearian quotations and is played by Tim Curry as if reprising his Gilbert and Sullivan Pirate King. Before you can say Ann Widdecombe, the rural innocent has been fed a succession of illegal substances that drive him around the bend. Fortunately, Jason Donovan, playing a Heathrow customs officer, transvestite and club DJ, is on hand to help - but then that's what good neighbours are for. Talking of soap operas, I was attracted by a TV programme listed in Thursday's Evening Standard. Intending to watch Lon Chaney in Victor Sjöström's 1924 classic, He Who Gets Slapped on the TCM channel, I noticed that it was preceded by Close-Up - Ken Barlow Talks About Lon Chaney . I tuned in expecting to hear an account of earnest discussions about the silent cinema down at the Rover's Return. Maybe he'd recall Ena Sharples saying: 'I'll never forgive that Louis B. Mayer for making the nice Swedish gentleman, Mr Sjöström, change his name to Seastrom.' However, the splendid introduction was not in fact by Ken Barlow, but by the film restorer, director and historian, Kevin Brownlow. This week saw the beginning of Typiquement British: Le Cinéma Britannique at the Centre Pompidou, the biggest season of British movies ever staged in France or anywhere else. The valuable accompanying book by a variety of British and French writers (myself among them) is introduced by France's greatest living director, Bertrand Tavernier, longtime and discerning enthusiast for our cinema. He begins by quoting François Truffaut's influential dictum about ' l'incompatibilité between the words Cinéma and Angleterre', a sneer that put back the appreciation of British movies for a couple of decades. This season should serve to revoke what Tavernier calls Truffaut's 'excommunicatory bull'.

fields.headline: Dense forests, drifting snow. Tank heavens for little worlds...
fields.trailText: Mariele Neudecker doesn't just create a theatre of the unconscious, she fills it with spells and symbols, fragments of fiction and poetry, souvenirs from a voyage through painting.
fields.body:
Mariele Neudecker: Until Now Ikon Gallery, Birmingham until 12 Nov

Shirazeh Houshiary Lisson Gallery, London NW1, until 21 Oct

Jim Shaw: Thrift Store Paintings ICA, London SW1, until 5 Nov

Scene one: A dense glade in the forest, tall trees obscuring the sky. A few motes twinkle in the angled rays, but nothing stirs among the hollows. The further you look into the thickening light, the more the perspective vanishes. A twig cracking would shatter the unearthly hush. There is no trace of a path.

Scene Two takes place in another part of the mind - an expanse of snow-capped mountains you have somehow scaled. It might be the view from a Boeing - those Alps you imagine treading like a giant - or that painting by Caspar David Friedrich in which you have become the traveller looking out over the white mists of the Romantic sublime.

To say Mariele Neudecker has realised these visions in three dimensions would be true but insufficient. She doesn't just create a theatre of the unconscious, she fills it with spells and symbols, fragments of fiction and poetry, souvenirs from a voyage through painting. She also does in it miniature - the tanks in which she installs her model dioramas are roughly proportioned to a Friedrich. When you notice that these tanks are filled with liquid - mysteriously resolving into low-lying vapours and even viscous light in the forest - there is the additional thrill of a submerged world, of landscapes at the bottom of the ocean.

Neudecker's models are so superb that you can press your face against the glass and the illusion of reality won't be dispelled. This is a breathtaking accomplishment, to make a sealed scene no bigger than a fishtank stand in for an actual realm. But it is also crucial to Neudecker's aim that you should be able to look directly into your own imagination without wondering why those clouds don't disperse in water. She puts you above the clouds, nose-deep in the forest: just where the mind's eye would take you.

That, of course, was a Romantic ideal, the mind wandering through the infinite landscape of art. Neudecker is from Düsseldorf and many of her models are a kind of Paradise Regained - German Romanticism before it was annexed by the Nazis. But although they may dream of painting, her works aren't bounded by two, or even three dimensions.

In It was always like this , Neudecker has filmed a soaring range, its shadows cobalt-blue in the distance. Another film has been superimposed on these immovable mountains, so snow seems to drift across them, obliterating all but the peaks, before blowing away again in a fantastical time-lapse sequence. Friedrich's mountains have been remade as a model; the work of ancient seasons is animated through digital paintbox. It is an illusion within an illusion, making imagined time and place suddenly, spectacularly visible.

Neudecker can seem too attached to painting. At the Ikon, two films are projected on panels hung back to back like the double sides of a canvas. If you saw them next to each other, you would witness the simultaneous rising and setting of the sun in Australia and the Azores - just the kind of dream she likes to realise. But then you encounter her amazing anamorphic skull, created in glowing amber. What seems to be an impossible object - surely these perceptual distortions only work in 2D - resolves into a perfect head from a certain vantage. It is more skilful, more wondrous even than the flat image from which it leaps - the skull in Holbein's Ambassadors .

This is a stunning exhibition. Neudecker is one of those rare artists whose intelligence is matched by skill and who knows how to liberate the imagination in others. When she wants to envisage infinite light, she does it with fluorescent fishing wires and a litre of sol vent. The effect is a play on painted rays, but it's also a hi-tech vision for the mind's eye - a work of postmodern sublime.

Iranian-born Shirazeh Houshiary was shortlisted for the Turner Prize in 1994, vanished soon afterwards and has barely been seen in this country since. Self-effacement was always something of a theme in her work - labyrinthine sculptures based on the geometry of Islam, veils of tiny marks pencilled across canvases, which turn out to be Sufi mantras. Now she has retreated from sculpture and eliminated the words from her abstract paintings.

What's left at the Lisson is pretty well nothing, or little more than monochrone panels. A few shadows are faintly discernible, a deepening void at the centre of a brilliant white rectangle, a grey mist settling over a patch of light. These indistinct blurs have titles to match - Deep , Unknowing , Memory - and seem to materialise like ghosts from the canvas. Minuscule graphite marks congregate between glazes of diaphanous aquacryl so you can't tell which came first: drawing or painting.

Clearly, these are intended as contemplative objects. But the minute you get up close, a civil war breaks out. The brain tries to read the craquelure of marks as some sort of calligraphy, while the eyes are dazzled by the glare. Instead of experiencing the light and abstraction as metaphors of mystical immanence, you feel thwarted by the discomfort and illegibility. The work comes over as repetitive, laborious and, for all its subtle delicacy, like a long-winded postscript to Minimalism.

The loudest counterblast to Minimalism ever marshalled in a gallery is surely Jim Shaw's Thrift Store Paintings at the ICA. This is a show of content and nothing but: smiling pets, flying saucers, tearful crucifixions, lavish dollybirds, Hollywood dreams and private nightmares. Shaw has collected 400 examples of this hideous American schlock at a dollar a throw - not so much found art as discarded artefact.

Hideous, but also weirdly absorbing. Nothing comes between you and the subjects these people wanted to paint - not skill, style, reputation or value. There is absolute sincerity in the religious scenes, palpable psychosis in some of the fantasies. What you get is the message, never lost no matter how ineptly transcribed. There's also the pleasure of spotting a work that looks just like some of the knowing cack-handedness touted in London galleries last year, only with more innocence and spark.

Shaw hangs the work as a narrative, flowing seamlessly from surrealism to religion, still life to domestic fantasy. The idea is that you view it as an alternative tradition, something like Harry Smith's folk music archive. That comparison may be wildly over-flattering to the abysmal skill on show, but it makes the all-American point that this junked stuff also constitutes the content of the culture.

fields.headline: Design by committee doesn't have to be bad
fields.trailText: Tony Blair invited the great and good to drinks in Downing Street last Wednesday for the launch of a policy that set out to demonstrate how to improve the quality of government-sponsored architecture.
fields.body:
When Tony Blair invited the great and good to drinks in Downing Street last Wednesday, he managed with jolting suddenness to transform an arcane subject, previously of interest only to design anoraks, into a serious political issue. Every big-spending department from the Treasury to the Foreign Office was dragged in to help launch a policy that purported to show not just why architecture matters to a society, but also set out to demonstrate how to improve the quality of government-sponsored architecture - from law courts to hospitals.

Here was the implicit promise of a new generation of social security offices, barracks, embassies and primary schools that would make Britain a byword for great architecture. It would, so Blair and his advisers blithely promised, have the effect not just of producing good buildings, but also of saving money and producing a healthier, happier society. Which is, even with the best will in the world, going a bit far.

Given that the guest list included Lord Falconer, the event ran the risk of turning into an embarrassment. A document which talks about construction best practice and value for money does not sit easily with Labour's angst over the Dome.

But extraordinarily, just at the same moment that Blair was launching the Commission for Architecture and the Built Environment's (CABE) report on government architecture, William Hague, in Rambo mood, promised the Conservative Party conference he would demolish every tower block in sight and address the future of Britain's towns from a new, design-conscious perspective.

Hague was missing the point about high-rise living, focusing on an architectural fad of strictly peripheral significance rather than the hard slog of housing policy, just at the moment that high-rise living is again rising to the top of the housing agenda. But what could have become another stick with which to beat the Government's back turned into a safely bipartisan approach.

It is safe to assume that both parties had a raft of ulterior motives driving them on to embrace architecture. Not the least of which for New Labour was ridding its embarrassment at the lordly disdain with which Norman St John Stevas presided over the Royal Fine Art Commission. When confronted with the Millennium wheel, he stamped his foot and declared that it was horrid. The Queen Mother's gates in Hyde Park on the other hand were, as far as this constitutional expert was concerned, just lovely.

The whole idea of an official arbiter of taste had turned into a laughing stock, apparently driven by arbitrary prejudice more than any objective standard. Not surprisingly the commission was rapidly replaced by CABE when Blair came to power, under the leadership of the well-connected and respected property developer Sir Stuart Lipton. He was responsible for Broadgate, one of the most impressive developments in London for 40 years.

The move could be presented as part of Labour's modernising agenda. Lipton was charged not so much with the task of stopping bad buildings from happening, as making it possible for good new buildings to be realised. Instead of vulgar prejudice, CABE's job would be to give Britain's best architects their head.

Lipton now has to live up to the rhetoric that accompanied his appointment. Given the context, it is perhaps not surprising that most of CABE's report is full of platitudes about value for money rather than concrete examples. Turning the pages of the report, you find Will Alsop's library in Peckham and Benson and Forsyth's Museum of Scotland cited as examples of great official architecture. Which of course they are. But neither - nor any of the other illustrations - had anything to do with Lipton's initiatives; they all predate CABE.

But Lipton does attempt to deal with the most crucial issue, how to create a climate in which Britain opts for the best architectural solution, rather than the most expedient. And on this issue it is still far from clear if the answer is the kind of bureaucratic procedures CABE's document suggests or the headstrong wilfulness of individual clients determined to make their mark.
