fields.headline: May the farce be with you
fields.standfirst: Noises Off is still hilarious after 18 years. But it's even better when treated as a ballet
fields.trailText: Noises Off is still hilarious after 18 years. But it's even better when treated as a ballet
fields.body:
Noises Off Lyttelton, London SE1
Romeo and Juliet Olivier, SE1
The Woman Who Swallowed a Pin Southwark Playhouse, SE1
Shoot Me In The Heart Gate, W11

Even before the curtain went up on the first night of Noises Off , it was obvious that Michael Frayn had provided the National with another of his hits. As soon as the usual request to silence phones and pagers had been issued - 'noises off', as it were - a mighty peal from a mobile rang defiantly through the auditorium. A plant, presumably, rather than an eerie coincidence? Either way, two of Frayn's points were neatly made. Here's a farce about a farce which shows that timing can make the difference between annoyance and amusement, and a play in which real life unexpectedly takes the stage.

Eighteen years after its first performance, the central device of Noises Off is still hilariously effective. The first act shows a repertory company rehearsing a farce, whose title, Nothing On , neatly echoes Frayn's own. Its cast is a gruesome parade of stereotypes: a comic char in a pinny, a dizzy blonde in cami-knickers, a burly robber. Its actors slip in and out of character: a brilliant piece of casting allows Patricia Hodge to slide in a second from gorblimey to cut-glass.

For the second act, the stage spins round, and you watch Nothing On being performed as if you were backstage. You see the reverse side of Robert Jones's cleverly tacky design - with its sticky doors, plastic Tudor beams and earwig-size antlers. You see the liaisons between the actors beginning to interfere with their onstage relationships. You see their world-weary control beginning to slip: this, one of them remarks, 'is becoming farcical'.

This is wonderfully entertaining. But the really original stroke is the final tweak. There's a third act - so startling that at least one member of the audience was already on his feet thinking it was all over - in which everything unravels, and the satire about farce is engulfed by farce. Here some of Frayn's slow-burning jokes burst into flame. He builds up his gags pyramid-style: in the first scene, every joke has a lot of triggers; in the last, one word - 'Sardinia' comes to mind - is enough to cause a collapse.

And here the skill of director Jeremy Sams, who persuaded Frayn to make some elisions in the play, is fully shown. His musical skills - he directed the London production of Spend, Spend, Spend - are valuable here. He choreographs the piece like a ballet, which is what is needed: whole sequences hinge on tripping, leaping, passing, miming. Everything happens at speed; everything happens at the same time. It's a whizz.

The National needs this success. No one doubts that Trevor Nunn is a fine director of plays. But there are doubts about his direction of a theatre. The National is looking lopsided at the moment, with Nunn's own productions strong, but too many gaps elsewhere. Where is the new writing? And where are the new directors?

What, for example, is the point of subsidising a Royal National Theatre and a Royal Shakespeare Company to do within six months of each other two poor productions of the same Shakespeare play? Twelve weeks ago Stratford hosted a leaden Romeo and Juliet ; now Tim Supple has followed suit in the Olivier.

Supple's production (to the extent that it is his, as Nunn was called in to help out) is slurrily spoken and moves at a snail's pace. Confusingly set in modern dress but with sword fights, it seems to be propelled by the notion that youthful passion can be evoked by clamour and irritation.

When Charlotte Randle's Juliet isn't on the brink of inappropriate jokiness (she nearly falls off the balcony, and almost giggles at 'God knows when we shall meet again') she is racing around the stage, flinging her arms about (she does this at the mention of wings) and stomping. Patrick O'Kane's short-breathed Mercutio spends the whole play in a lather of indignation, which makes sense when he's just been stabbed but means he delivers the Queen Mab speech as if it were an extended insult. Both are gifted actors: something has gone badly wrong with their direction.

Blasts of music by Adrian Lee underline points that the verse should make, sometimes in an attempt to give an illusion of exciting movement as men toil round the stage, pushing into place the gargantuan biscuit-coloured screens that make up Robert Innes Hopkins's design. Beverley Klein is a delightfully dirty-minded nurse; Chiwetel Ejiofor's Romeo is graceful. But they are left floundering without support.

To glimpse the theatre of the future you have to look elsewhere. At, for example, the Southwark Playhouse, where an investigation of family history - The Woman Who Swallowed a Pin - is being enacted. Clare Bayley's promenade play begins as the audience wait in a lane to go into the theatre. Illuminated behind a heavy plastic curtain which gives things the blurred milky look of old film, you see an early twentieth-century scene: a young girl applying for a below-stairs job. You step through the curtain into the actors world, and find yourself outside an old tea warehouse where scenes from past and present are plaited together.

A young, pregnant wo man moves into an old building and begins to uncover its history. She is set on recovering her family's past, seeing her history of miscarriages as linked to the story of an ancestor who lost eight children. Recovering the past may mean securing the future.

A guide, so tactful as to seem ghostly, prompts the audience to move through the tiny space which, in an origami-style feat, is made to contain long views into the past, a multitude of different characters and generations, and a host ofinteriors and outside views. A large central space is a typing-pool in which 1920s flappers use tea-chests as desks, and an Edwardian kitchen where a maid pummels something in an enamel bowl, while a workman peeks in through a skylight. Double doors open to show a courtship conducted on a bench, framed as by a proscenium arch; another romance is followed through a game of chess. Here's a piece which imitates the flicker of film and of memory.

The artistic director of Southwark, Erica Whyman, is to move in the New Year to the Gate, treading in the footsteps of Stephen Daldry. The theatre is currently full of animation under the sorcerer's touch of Hayley Carmichael, who makes her directorial debut with an adaptation of a South American fairy tale. Anyone who has ever felt even faintly stirred by the idea of magic realism should see Shoot Me In The Heart .

You don't go for the plot, which is tousled by whimsicality: you go to see a carnival. Its story - of a young woman who, never growing beyond the size of a small girl, is surrounded by harpy malice but rescued by romance - is a lava flow of red-hot images.

Unexpected perspectives, both physical and emotional, are apparent from the opening moments. Naomi Wilkinson's beautiful design - a scarlet box made up of louvred doors - springs apart to display the heroine, radiantly played by Lisa Hammond, at a child's party surrounded by adults dressed as children. Parents mutter that their children's companion is not 'usual', but would be hard put to claim their own bulky offspring as being an appropriate size. Moments later the girl's mother stands in front of a book made out enormous red and white sheets, ripping out the pages on which are inscribed the tale of 'Thumbelina'. The mad dance induced by the bite of the tarantula is often mentioned: the play ends with lace curtains closing around the stage: they are striped with shadows like the huge jointed legs of a giant spider.

The author of To the Green Fields Beyond , which I reviewed last week, was wrongly named as Nicholas Wright, instead of Nick Whitby.
fields.bodyText: Noises Off Lyttelton, London SE1 Romeo and Juliet Olivier, SE1 The Woman Who Swallowed a Pin Southwark Playhouse, SE1 Shoot Me In The Heart Gate, W11 Even before the curtain went up on the first night of Noises Off , it was obvious that Michael Frayn had provided the National with another of his hits. As soon as the usual request to silence phones and pagers had been issued - 'noises off', as it were - a mighty peal from a mobile rang defiantly through the auditorium. A plant, presumably, rather than an eerie coincidence? Either way, two of Frayn's points were neatly made. Here's a farce about a farce which shows that timing can make the difference between annoyance and amusement, and a play in which real life unexpectedly takes the stage. Eighteen years after its first performance, the central device of Noises Off is still hilariously effective. The first act shows a repertory company rehearsing a farce, whose title, Nothing On , neatly echoes Frayn's own. Its cast is a gruesome parade of stereotypes: a comic char in a pinny, a dizzy blonde in cami-knickers, a burly robber. Its actors slip in and out of character: a brilliant piece of casting allows Patricia Hodge to slide in a second from gorblimey to cut-glass. For the second act, the stage spins round, and you watch Nothing On being performed as if you were backstage. You see the reverse side of Robert Jones's cleverly tacky design - with its sticky doors, plastic Tudor beams and earwig-size antlers. You see the liaisons between the actors beginning to interfere with their onstage relationships. You see their world-weary control beginning to slip: this, one of them remarks, 'is becoming farcical'. This is wonderfully entertaining. But the really original stroke is the final tweak. There's a third act - so startling that at least one member of the audience was already on his feet thinking it was all over - in which everything unravels, and the satire about farce is engulfed by farce. Here some of Frayn's slow-burning jokes burst into flame. He builds up his gags pyramid-style: in the first scene, every joke has a lot of triggers; in the last, one word - 'Sardinia' comes to mind - is enough to cause a collapse. And here the skill of director Jeremy Sams, who persuaded Frayn to make some elisions in the play, is fully shown. His musical skills - he directed the London production of Spend, Spend, Spend - are valuable here. He choreographs the piece like a ballet, which is what is needed: whole sequences hinge on tripping, leaping, passing, miming. Everything happens at speed; everything happens at the same time. It's a whizz. The National needs this success. No one doubts that Trevor Nunn is a fine director of plays. But there are doubts about his direction of a theatre. The National is looking lopsided at the moment, with Nunn's own productions strong, but too many gaps elsewhere. Where is the new writing? And where are the new directors? What, for example, is the point of subsidising a Royal National Theatre and a Royal Shakespeare Company to do within six months of each other two poor productions of the same Shakespeare play? Twelve weeks ago Stratford hosted a leaden Romeo and Juliet ; now Tim Supple has followed suit in the Olivier. Supple's production (to the extent that it is his, as Nunn was called in to help out) is slurrily spoken and moves at a snail's pace. Confusingly set in modern dress but with sword fights, it seems to be propelled by the notion that youthful passion can be evoked by clamour and irritation. When Charlotte Randle's Juliet isn't on the brink of inappropriate jokiness (she nearly falls off the balcony, and almost giggles at 'God knows when we shall meet again') she is racing around the stage, flinging her arms about (she does this at the mention of wings) and stomping. Patrick O'Kane's short-breathed Mercutio spends the whole play in a lather of indignation, which makes sense when he's just been stabbed but means he delivers the Queen Mab speech as if it were an extended insult. Both are gifted actors: something has gone badly wrong with their direction. Blasts of music by Adrian Lee underline points that the verse should make, sometimes in an attempt to give an illusion of exciting movement as men toil round the stage, pushing into place the gargantuan biscuit-coloured screens that make up Robert Innes Hopkins's design. Beverley Klein is a delightfully dirty-minded nurse; Chiwetel Ejiofor's Romeo is graceful. But they are left floundering without support. To glimpse the theatre of the future you have to look elsewhere. At, for example, the Southwark Playhouse, where an investigation of family history - The Woman Who Swallowed a Pin - is being enacted. Clare Bayley's promenade play begins as the audience wait in a lane to go into the theatre. Illuminated behind a heavy plastic curtain which gives things the blurred milky look of old film, you see an early twentieth-century scene: a young girl applying for a below-stairs job. You step through the curtain into the actors world, and find yourself outside an old tea warehouse where scenes from past and present are plaited together. A young, pregnant wo man moves into an old building and begins to uncover its history. She is set on recovering her family's past, seeing her history of miscarriages as linked to the story of an ancestor who lost eight children. Recovering the past may mean securing the future. A guide, so tactful as to seem ghostly, prompts the audience to move through the tiny space which, in an origami-style feat, is made to contain long views into the past, a multitude of different characters and generations, and a host ofinteriors and outside views. A large central space is a typing-pool in which 1920s flappers use tea-chests as desks, and an Edwardian kitchen where a maid pummels something in an enamel bowl, while a workman peeks in through a skylight. Double doors open to show a courtship conducted on a bench, framed as by a proscenium arch; another romance is followed through a game of chess. Here's a piece which imitates the flicker of film and of memory. The artistic director of Southwark, Erica Whyman, is to move in the New Year to the Gate, treading in the footsteps of Stephen Daldry. webTitle: 'I went to Hollywood to see how far I could ride the royal ticket'

fields.headline: 'I went to Hollywood to see how far I could ride the royal ticket'
fields.standfirst: Charlie Skelton  became the 'Earl of Newmarket', - and found that doors opened
fields.trailText: Charlie Skelton  became the 'Earl of Newmarket', - and found that doors opened
fields.body:
I am a monarchist. There - I've said it. We need the royals. Whatever people might say about them being an inbred bunch of freeloading, self-promoting pillocks, one thing cannot be denied. They possess a combination of unmerited social standing and grotesque personal inadequacy without which our country would be a poorer place.

Their goonishness is raised above the ordinary by their highness, their budding insanity blooms untroubled under the mysterious protection of their royalness. In short, they live their mad, mad lives without anyone ever saying to their face: 'Shut up and go away, you arse.' This is their power.

I speak as one who has tasted this power, who has worn the amulet of royalty - albeit briefly - and enjoyed the blessed freedom to twerp that Fergie, Edward, William and the rest take for granted. I became, for two short weeks, Charles, the fourteenth Earl of Newmarket. With double-breasted suit, weak chin and equerry in tow, I went to Hollywood to see how far I could ride the royal ticket. One hell of a long way, as it turned out.

The Channel 4 lawyers had given us strict instructions before we left: don't break anything, don't kill anything, and don't tell anyone that you're Prince Harry's real father. Typical bloody lawyers. Trying to take the fun out of everything. Bang went our plans to go whale-watching off the Californian coast and for me to whip out a shotgun and have a pop at a humpback. Still, we did manage to get a sword through customs. More of that later.

As a programme, The Earl is a tribute to one particular and perhaps the finest of all the royal family's foibles: the shameless attempts of some of them to cash in on their status to forge media careers. In this arena, two names stand head and shoulders above the rest: Sarah Ferguson and Prince Edward.

At heart, the Earl's character is the unholy amalgam of frenetic self-promotion and breathtaking talentlessness that makes Eddie and Fergie such extraordinary individuals. To this we added a smattering of other royal traits: rudeness, bigotry and an unshakeable absence of self-consciousness.

Lord Newmarket shares as well Prince Edward's charming belief that Britain resents success. Edward's thesis, like the man himself, is simple: 'I am so successful in Britain that I'm not allowed to be successful.' So he hotfooted it to LA, where his success wouldn't be stifled.

Like Edward before him, Newmarket found a willingness among Americans to give him the respect and deference owing to him. In an address to the assembled masses at a charity baseball game in Orange County - where he had the honour of throwing the first pitch (by far, incidentally, the most embarrassing moment of my already embarrassment-rich life) - he set out his stall: 'America is a wonderful place to be. America applauds success. America is a success. Not morally or economically, but spiritually...'

Having so spoken, I turned to the pitcher's mound, wound up my weak left arm, and delivered the weediest throw in baseball history, which landed a good yard short of the catcher's feet. I acknowledged the bemused cheers of the crowd and hurried off to the lavatory where I clutched my head in shame.

With my public profile growing, I set out to conquer Hollywood. 'Conquer' in the sense of behaving like a nut. A succession of studio bosses, producers, agents and publishers were subjected to a merciless barrage of thunderingly bad ideas. Like Buckingham 3000 - a sci-fi historical romance with a Windsor twist - or, as I put it in one meeting: ' Judge Dredd meets Crocodile Dundee .'

There was no depth to which I wouldn't sink. The pitch for If Diana Had Lived was pretty low on the scale: 'We're looking currently at a script for a biopic about what would have happened if Diana hadn't died in that terrible tunnel. Would, for example, Prince William have turned out to be something other than an Austro-Hungarian goon?'

Sadly, my subsequent speculations about the character of Prince Harry were banished, after some urgent words from the lawyers, to the cutting-room floor.

Interest in If Diana Had Lived was heightened when I revealed that Princess Margaret was being lined up for a cameo role. 'I happen to know she's rather short of cash at the moment.' In lowered tones, I explained the reason: 'It's her feet...'

My inside knowledge of Palace goings-on (and my Fergian willingness to share every last bit of it for financial gain) was one of the keynotes of the meetings. And the Hollywood players lapped it up. In fact, they lapped up almost everything I said. When I proposed a soft-core fictionalisation of the sex life of the Duchess of York, I had people reaching for the chequebook.

It's appalling but it's true: if you're a royal, you can get away with anything in America. Never more did I know this to be the case than when I had David Waller, the associate dean of the National University, kneeling before me on a purple Marks & Spencer cushion, with his assembled faculty members looking on - me tapping him on his head with a sword, he swearing eternal fealty to the throne. I smiled down at him: 'Arise, Sir Waller.' Never have I seen such awe in another human being's eyes.

Such is the power of the royal family. God knows, I'm going to miss it.

The Earl is on Channel 4, on 11 October at 11.30pm

fields.headline: We asked...
fields.trailText:
What is your favourite No 1 single of all time?
What No 1 single do you love to hate?
What single do you feel should have made No 1 but never did?
fields.body:
What is your favourite No 1 single of all time?
What No 1 single do you love to hate?
What single do you feel should have made No 1 but never did?

Zadie Smith novelist

Favourite: 'Vogue' Madonna

Hate: If the Lighthouse Family have ever been No 1 with that song 'Lifted' then it's that [no, it only reached No 4]. If not, Elton John's pap for the princess of pap.

Should have been: 'The Real Slim Shady', Eminem (if it wasn't - can't remember), 'No Surprises', Radiohead, and 'Around the World', Daft Punk.

Tony Blackburn DJ

Favourite: 'I'm Still Waiting' by Diana Ross. I heard it once on an album and suggested to Diana's record company that they released it and it got to No 1. She never thanked me for my suggestion, which bugged me.

Hate: I couldn't stand 'Albatross' by Fleetwood Mac.

Should have been: A great record from the Sixties by the Cascades called 'Rhythm From The Rain'.

Andrew Motion poet

Favourite: ' I Heard It Through The Grapevine' Marvin Gaye.

Hate: ' Merry Xmas Everybody' Slade.

Should have been: Almost anything by Dylan - but No 1s aren't like that, are they? They're like 'Merry Xmas Everybody'.

Michael Winner film director

Favourite: 'Rock Around The Clock' Bill Haley.

Hate: 'Merry Xmas Everybody'.

Should have been: 'How Much Is That Doggy In The Window?'

Amy Jenkins writer

Favourite: ' Careless Whisper' George Michael.

Hate: ' Red Red Wine' UB40.

Should have been: anything by Bob Marley.

Jon Snow C4 newsreader

Favourite: ' I Believe I Can Fly' R. Kelly.

Hate: ' I'm a Barbie Girl' Aqua.

Should have been: 'Still Life Talking' by Pat Metheny.

Fay Weldon novelist

Favourite: ' Wichita Lineman' Glen Campbell or 'Urban Spaceman' The Bonzo Dog Doodah Band. [Neither was a No 1]

Hate: ' Grandad' Clive Dunn.

Should have been: ' Little Wheel Spin and Spin' Buffy Sainte-Marie.

Oona King MP

Favourite: ' Ready or Not' Fugees.

Hate: ' I Should Be So Lucky' Kylie Minogue.

Should have been: ' Harvest For The World' The Isley Brothers.

Courtney Pine musician

Favourite: 'Back To Life' Caron Wheeler and Soul II Soul

Hate: 'You're The One That I Want' John Travolta and Olivia Newton-John.

Should have been: 'Love And Affection' Joan Armatrading.

Dylan Jones editor GQ

Favourite: 'Hey Jude' by the Beatles, because it has all the ingredients, it is an anthem, an epic and the kind of song people remember now.

Hate: ' Bohemian Rhapsody'.

Should have been: 'God Save the Queen' The Sex Pistols.

Tim Rice lyricist

Favourite: 'Runaway' Del Shannon. That was one that I really loved.

Hate: ' The Chicken Song' Spitting Image.

Should have been: Probably 'Like A Rolling Stone'. Also 'Winter's Tale' David Essex. I wrote it and am still hoping it will reach No 1.

Simon Frith Mercury Prize chairman

Favourite: ' UpTown Top Ranking' Althia and Donna.

Hate: 'American Pie' Madonna.

Should have been: 'Blue Monday' New Order.

Matt Black producer and co-owner of Ninja Tune

Favourite: 'Double Barrel' Dave and Ansell Collins.

Hate: anything by Steps.

Should have been: 'Up for the Downstroke' Parliament.

Jon More producer and co-owner of Ninja Tune

Favourite: ' Voodoo Chile' Jimi Hendrix.

Hate: ' You're The One That I Want' John Travolting and Olivia Nutron-Bomb.

Should have been: 'Ride a White Swan' T. Rex.

John Barnes former footballer

Favourite: ' Stand By Me' Ben E. King.

Hate: ' I Should Be So Lucky' Kylie Minogue.

Should have been: ' How Do You Want It' 2Pac & Jodeci.

Interviews by Chloë Diski

The single can be any No 1 from the past 50 years, not necessarily one from the panel's choice. If you need inspiration, visit www.rockmine.music.co.uk/lists. Then simply cast your vote by phone, post or online at www.channel4.com where you will find the panel's full list of No 1s. The results will be on Channel 4 in January when you can find out which are the 100 Greatest No 1 singles.

webTitle: Being No 1 - How was it for you?

fields.headline: Being No 1 - How was it for you?
fields.trailText:
Bryan Ferry
Roxy Music were at No 1 for two weeks in February 1981 with their cover of John Lennon's 'Jealous Guy'.
fields.body:
Bryan Ferry
Roxy Music were at No 1 for two weeks in February 1981 with their cover of John Lennon's 'Jealous Guy'.

We were playing a big concert in Germany a couple of weeks after John Lennon had died, so I just said: 'Let's do "Jealous Guy" live as a tribute.' The response was so overwhelming that we got back, recorded it and put it out as a single.

We'd had No 1 albums - we always thought of ourselves as an albums rather than a singles band - and we did have singles in the top five, but it was our first No 1 single.

Having a No 1 didn't really change anything. It was great but it really had more to do with the British obsession with lists than a life-enhancing experience. Plus, of course, it means I get rung up every three years or so for a list like this.

Lulu
Lulu was at No 1 for two weeks in October 1993 with 'Relight My Fire', which she recorded with Take That.

Take That were fabulous. The boys were on a roll. I wouldn't say it changed my life. I'd had had hits before. And I was having so much fun working with them that I don't recall how I heard it was No 1. It was my first here although I had a No 1 in America with 'To Sir With Love' when I was 17.

There's such an emphasis these days on getting to No 1. If you only get to No 2, it's considered a failure. For me, to have an album in the charts for, say, 52 weeks would be a greater goal today. No 1 records don't sell in the quantities they used to. Not that I would shy away from having a hit. You do get a lot of attention for that brief period. It's very heady, you're on a high and it's marvellous, but then you do get back to reality.

We'd had No 1 albums - we always thought of ourselves as an albums rather than a singles band - and we did have singles in the top five, but it was our first No 1 single. Plus, of course, it means I get rung up every three years or so for a list like this. Lulu Lulu was at No 1 for two weeks in October 1993 with 'Relight My Fire', which she recorded with Take That. Take That were fabulous. The boys were on a roll. I wouldn't say it changed my life. I'd had had hits before. webTitle: Rising stars of the Royal Ballet

fields.headline: Slaves to the rhythm
fields.standfirst: Billy Elliot is breaking records at the box office. But who are the real rising young stars at the Royal Ballet?
fields.trailText: Billy Elliot is breaking records at the box office. But who are the real rising young stars at the Royal Ballet?
fields.body:
This is Anthony Dowell's last season as head of the Royal Ballet. After 15 years in the hot seat, Dowell has come through the agonies of the Royal Opera House's closure, only to hand over to Ross Stretton, already nicknamed Stressed Rotten, the Australian who succeeds him next summer. It is a challenging period for new dancers trying to make their mark in the company. But they are getting their chances in a rich season - a programme of ballets dear to Dowell's heart which include Romeo and Juliet , Ondine , Shadowplay , The Dream , Triad and Song of the Earth .

All these dancers have taken risks, made sacrifices, to join the Royal Ballet. Unlike the five men who left in a blaze of publicity two years ago to join Tetsuya Kumakawa's K-Ballet in Japan, these dancers believe that Covent Garden is the place to dance. Their enthusiasm is infectious, as is their optimism.

TAMARA ROJO (Spanish, age 26)

'The repercussion in Spain of my joining the Royal Ballet was amazing. When I went home to Madrid in the summer, I was in the news - everybody wanted to have an interview.' Rojo, already a principal with the English National Ballet, had approached Dowell last year after dancing the Chosen One in ENB's production of MacMillan's Rite of Spring . 'It was a role that really had an effect on me, as a person, not only as a dancer. It showed me a new world of possibilities and I thought, "I want more of this".'

Rojo's interpretation received rave reviews. She was a thing possessed, brave and vulnerable, her dark eyes burning like coals. She has always been remarkable. She joined Victor Ullate's ballet company in Madrid at the age of 16, dancing leading roles. She joined ENB in 1997, introduced by Derek Deane as a star in the making. In spite of a range of roles, she was beginning to feel restive by 1999 as the same ballets came round again. Then came the Rite of Spring revelation and the lure of dancing more MacMillan works if she moved to the Royal Ballet. 'I was on hold for a contract, then they called and asked if I could do Giselle at three weeks' notice. Yes, definitely I could.'

Rojo made her unscheduled debut on the last night of the Royal Ballet's July season, replacing an injured Darcey Bussell. Rojo gave a compelling performance. 'This season is to discover each other,' she says diplomatically. 'I have no career plan. I just want to make each performance as near-perfect as possible.'

She will be dancing Giselle again in April next year, as well as Romeo and Juliet . But first she follows Bussell in Swan Lake at the start of the new season, appearing in Shadowplay and Ondine before Christmas.

JOHAN PERSSON (Swedish, age 29)

After four years as a principal with the National Ballet of Canada, Persson decided to follow his Canadian girlfriend, Jamie Tapper, to the Royal Ballet. They had won the Erik Bruhn Prize together in 1995: 'But we don't insist on dancing with each other. We're not a package deal. Jamie came first, a year ago, and she loves it - so I was prepared to come even as a first soloist.'

Bruce Sansom's departure from the Royal Ballet in July created a principal's vacancy, so Persson comes in at the top. He dances Swan Lake with Tamara Rojo on 25 October and will be doing leading roles in The Nutcracker , La Fille Mal Gardée and Giselle. He's being tried out with a range of partners. 'I'm not quite tall enough for Darcey. But I'm considered tall for some of the roles I do, like Puck in The Dream and Alain in Fille .' He hopes to be coached by Dowell in roles that Dowell created. 'He's one of those people you look up to - that's why I want to be here.'

EDWARD WATSON (English, age 25)

Watson's most conspicuous role on the Opera House stage so far has been as the geeky redhead who blipped Sylvie Guillem over the head in The Concert . His next big chance comes in Shadowplay , the work that first brought the young Dowell to public attention. Watson, who started dancing because his twin sister did, has featured mostly in new works by his contemporaries - Cathy Marston, William Tuckett, Wayne McGregor. They have exploited his strange intensity and his hyper-suppleness. 'Yeah, I did hear a few gasps when I did Wayne's piece. It was a big challenge because it was so fast, with such extreme positions.' He partnered Deborah Bull in McGregor's Symbiont , another big challenge for him. 'I've learnt a lot about partnering in the last year, both with Debbie and rehearsing Serenade with Darcey. You don't drop somebody like that'.

ALINA COJOCARU (Romanian, age 19)

Very small and very young, she startled audiences last year by taking on one of Margot Fonteyn's iconic roles at five days' notice. Cojocaru had never seen Symphonic Variations when she stepped in for an injured dancer and won everyone's admiration. 'I didn't have time to realise... I just did it and I loved it,' she says shyly.

Cojocaru wasn't quite plucked, unknown, from the corps de ballet . She trained in Kiev and was then at the Royal Ballet School, after winning a Prix de Lausanne scholarship in 1998. The Kiev Ballet invited her to join straight from school as a principal. 'I admired the Royal Ballet but I just had to dance big roles, given the chance.' She did, in Don Quixote , The Sleeping Beauty , The Nutcracker , Cinderella . Then she left after a year, to start again at the Royal Ballet. It was a hard decision to go from principal to low-ranking artist, but she was never going to get stuck in the corps . After her lucky break with Symphonic Variations , which she will dance again in December, she has been understudying Manon and Ondine ; she will make her debut as Giselle , with Johan Kobborg as Albrecht, in April. And she is longing to have a go at Juliet. All being well, Cojocaru is the Royal Ballet's next ballerina.

IVAN PUTROV (Ukrainian, age 20)

Putrov trained in Kiev and joined the Royal Ballet School after winning the gold medal in the 1996 Prix de Lausanne. He was offered a principal's contract with the Kiev Ballet, but turned it down to join the Royal Ballet as an artist. 'I decided I would respect myself more if I did it the hard way. I knew I would need more and more, which I might not get in Ukraine. I want contemporary as well as classical.' He's been frustrated, cast only as the young male lead in The Nutcracker last Christmas and this. But now he is sharing the role of the Shadowplay Boy with the Matted Hair with Edward Watson, and he is getting Benvolio in Romeo and Juliet . However, he may return to guest with the Kiev Ballet next year as the Royal Ballet is not yet offering him fully grown up roles.

Putrov looks at the meteoric career of his friend from Kiev, Svetlana Zakharova, already a principal at 21 with the Kirov. 'Yes, I would like to dance with the Kirov. Yes, it could be possible. But I am happy here. You want Nirvana, like the boy in Shadowplay , but you'll never find perfection.'

MARIANELA NUñEZ (Argentinian, age 18)

Nuñez joined Maximiliano Guerra's Argentine ballet company as a baby ballerina but was told she was too young to join the Royal Ballet at 15. 'They had a contract for me but I had to wait until I graduated from the Royal Ballet School at 16. So I went from leading roles to being back in school and then into the corps de ballet . But I knew it was the right thing for me. Even when things went slow in the company, I knew I had to be patient.'

Nuñez was promoted to first artist at the end of last season, after dancing in the White Nights Gala for the Kirov. 'It was the best night of my life. Dancing with Carlos Acosta was one of my dreams and I was surrounded by these Russian dancers I so admire. And then I was promoted as well!'

Nuñez is friends with Cojocaru and Putrov, as well as with the large number of Spanish speakers in the company. 'I bet all the girls say the same thing - we all want to do Juliet, Manon, Odette/Odile. We'll have to see what the new director wants. I have to pinch myself sometimes and say, "You are here, in the same studio as Sylvie and Darcey". It means so much to me.'

Royal Ballet season starts 20 October. Programme details: 0207 240 1200; www.royalballet.org.uk

webTitle: Are these the best songs of all time? No says Barbara Ellen

fields.headline: Are these the best songs of all time? No says Barbara Ellen
fields.trailText: All due respect to the panel assigned to pick out a short list of all-time great No 1s for the public to choose from. Whatever happened, they were never likely to get thanked for their endeavours. It was never going to be a vigorous pump of the hand, and a 'Jolly well done.' More a metaphorical rotten tomato splattering gently against their suits, a riot of raspberries, a groundswell of happy bickering. I mean, how could they? They left  this out. They put  that in. Had these poncey industry boffins ever spent a solitary evening yelling in front of  Top of the Pops in their lives? The thing is, they probably did, they were probably yelling the loudest. Ultimately, it makes no difference.
fields.body:
All due respect to the panel assigned to pick out a short list of all-time great No 1s for the public to choose from. Whatever happened, they were never likely to get thanked for their endeavours. It was never going to be a vigorous pump of the hand, and a 'Jolly well done.' More a metaphorical rotten tomato splattering gently against their suits, a riot of raspberries, a groundswell of happy bickering. I mean, how could they? They left this out. They put that in. Had these poncey industry boffins ever spent a solitary evening yelling in front of Top of the Pops in their lives? The thing is, they probably did, they were probably yelling the loudest. Ultimately, it makes no difference.

The point is, lists like these are terribly difficult to decide by committee. Everyone who is the least bit interested in music has their own agenda about what is 'best'. Everyone has their own sacred relationship with their turntable/CD player/radio/whatever, and wishes to see it honoured, or dishonoured, as the case may be. In the very special case of No 1 singles, it is arguable whether 'good taste', personal or collective, should come into it at all. While albums are, have always been, the true litmus test of an act's longevity and influence in the music business, No 1s are traditionally where the great taste-free British public gets to sneak up out of nowhere, and gleefully ruin everything.

Like a musical version of Animal Farm , this list sends out the message - all No 1s are equal, but some are more equal than others. However, on a day-to-day basis, that's not how the public view it. To them, a No1 is a No1, the top spot is the top spot. And when a single gets to No1, it's because - to hell with the muso bores - the public felt like putting it there. A case of 'What are you rebelling against?' 'What has Greil Marcus got?' That's how, for short slightly macabre periods, the likes of Mr Blobby get to breathe the same rarefied air as John Lennon. 'Shaddap You Face'? We did that. Celine Dion? Well, something's got to get the dancing started at weddings. Jennifer Rush for a thousand weeks? Wet Wet Wet for a zillion more? We did all that, we committed all these crimes against taste and cultural decency, and there wasn't a damn thing John Peel could do about it.

Hard as it may be to accept, there just seem to have been times in our nation's history when we all felt like sitting around, sobbing lustily along to 'Bright Eyes' ('burning like fire!'), waiting for Adam Ant to snag his nylons on a chandelier, or observing Little Jimmy Osmond plumply sweating through 'Long Haired Lover From Liverpool'. True, in the latter instance, we may only have been marvelling about how one precocious American could encompass everything that is unattractive in a human being. Nevertheless, we were there, we suffered all this and more - glam, folk-on-purpose, boy band replicants - so that future generations could have a good laugh about our dog-rough taste. Is this sweat and valour, this dogged, very British loyalty to vacuous tripe and mawkish balladeering, adequately reflected in this short list? I fear not, though the inclusion of 'Lady In Red' makes up for a lot.

So it is that my first gripe against 'The List' is that it's not nearly silly enough. My second gripe, naturally, is that it's not quite serious enough. 10cc's plodding 'I'm Not In Love' instead of something by the Bay City Rollers, David Cassidy or Hot Chocolate? 'Je T'Aime ... Moi Non Plus' instead of Dusty Springfield or Sandie Shaw? If John Lennon and Paul McCartney can appear as separate entities from The Beatles (counting Wings, Macca appears three times), then why can't The Jackson 5 feature as well as Michael? There are no Walker Brothers, Jerry Lee Lewis, or Carpenters. Instead we get the most boring and obvious Elvis, Beatles, Rolling Stones, Bowie, Abba, Slade and Sinatra tracks, Elsewhere, black music is slightly under-represented, while punk, hip hop, house, hard rock, country and Britpop are treated as if they never happened. Are the panel having what is commonly known as a 'laugh'?

Going off on a tangent, as a self-confessed 'old punk', surely Paul Morley could have put a stiff word in for greatest 'lost' No 1 of all time - 'God Save The Queen' by The Sex Pistols, which was famously bumped from the top spot in Jubilee year. There are other great 'lost' No 1s too, though in fairness to the panel, they were only ever No 1 in my mind. Reading through the short list, I lost count of the number of times I'd sit carping childishly about the non-inclusion of such and such, only to discover, to my amazement, that these records never actually hit the top spot.

That's the trouble with a lot of seminal 'No 1s' - they tend to stall at No 2, 3 or 137. Which is close, but not quite close enough. Where No 1s are concerned, a miss is as good as a mile. So, goodbye to the esteemed likes of 'Rapper's Delight', 'Heroes', 'Don't Stop Til You Get Enough', and 'Common People'. Farewell and thank you to Ultravox's Midge Ure, selflessly amusing the entire nation with his overcoat-clad turn in ('Ooooh!') 'Vienna'. Life just isn't fair chaps. And neither is this list. But then, I would say that, wouldn't I? If I was honest, I'd grudgingly admit that, considering the mammoth task facing the panel, they've done a pretty good job pick-and-mixing the 'best' No 1s down the ages. Sadly for them, the only list that would completely satisfy you and I would be the one we would make ourselves.

webTitle: The A-Z of Getting to No 1

fields.headline: The A-Z of Getting to No 1
fields.standfirst: Want to make it to the top? Take a leaf out of Ken Dodd's book, says Neil Spencer
fields.trailText: 'Anyone can get to No 1 these days,' claimed Chris Tarrant on his Capital Radio breakfast show last week. 'You only have to go into the studios, make a record and you're there.'
fields.body:
'Anyone can get to No 1 these days,' claimed Chris Tarrant on his Capital Radio breakfast show last week. 'You only have to go into the studios, make a record and you're there.'

Tarrant's hyperbole contains a seed of truth. The whirligig of names occupying the coveted No 1 spot continues to accelerate, its pace reflecting both the sophistication of marketing techniques and the proliferation of ways in which people access music.

Chart-topping singles sell a fraction of what they did in the vinyl and transistor era, when Radio 1 and Top of the Pops loomed monolithically over the nation's listening habits. Hits now arrive via MTV, or surface from the frenzied dance scene, while the first internet-spawned chart-topper is just a matter of time.

Though there are more ways to get to No1, the rules of ascent haven't changed that much. Being a megastar is still the surest route to the top; acts like Elvis, the Beatles, Madonna and Robbie Williams build up a momentum that carries every release to the peak.

These days, the majority of No 1s are generated by playground power. Boy and girl groups must work their nubile butts off by touring schools, making record shop personal appearances, where you might just lip-synch your song, endlessly donning fresh togs to serve up photo exclusives for the pubescents' pin-up mags, and showing up properly scrubbed on Saturday morning kids' TV - a crucial promo spot.

You can cut some of these corners by being famous from the soaps, which helped EastEnders' Martine McCutcheon to her No 1 and Robson and Jerome to theirs with 'Unchained Melody'.

Whether you're big cheese, small fry or soap bubble, you will need a formidable marketing machine behind you. In the bad old days, before big-hitting record shops were obliged to have secure computers to make their chart returns, record companies simply sent out minions to buy their own product (a practice which helped Brian Epstein get the Beatles off the ground). Alternatively, they would make chart-return shops offers they couldn't refuse - massive discounts on large orders, special edition singles in coloured vinyl, picture sleeves or with pull-out posters. Eventually, the shady deals became so visible that the British Phonographic Institute was embarrassed into action.

That hasn't stopped companies pursuing a variety of legal hypes. Well-paid 'pluggers' still enjoy privileged entry into the portals of Radio 1 and other major radio stations for the purposes of bending the ears of producers to the latest product of the major labels. There is even an industry-nominated 'Plugger of the Year', though unlike in the US, he or she is unlikely to come with a sack of cocaine to refresh the ENT department of radio producers.

Labels may also pour their money into massaging the media via advertising and the gentle blandishments of exclusives - little different, in short, to any other branch of industry or politics.

Some genres are more favoured than others to reach No 1. The Novelty Song - Benny Hill's 'Ernie', the Simpsons' 'Do The Bartman' - is always with us. The Christmas single used to be a staple of Onedom (Slade, Cliff Richard etc) but has faded. The perennial route to the top is the Big Sloppy Ballad, which unites Oners as disparate as Whitney Houston ('I Will Always Love You'), Oasis ('Don't Look Back In Anger') and Ken Dodd ('Tears').

The only two songs to occupy the No 1 spot three times over have both been BSBs. 'Unchained Melody' made a Oner of Jimmy Young (1955), of the Righteous Brothers (in 1990, a reissue from 1965) and of Robson and Jerome (1995). 'You'll Never Walk Alone' elevated Gerry and the Pacemakers (1963), The Crowd (1985) and, er, Robson and Jerome (1996).

webTitle: Are these the best songs of  all time? Yes says Paul Morley

fields.headline: Are these the best songs of  all time? Yes says Paul Morley
fields.trailText: In voting for your favourite No 1 records of all time, the rules stipulate that you can only vote for one record by a group or artist. This ensures that the list is not overrun by a plague of Beatles, or a camp of Queens, or a fishnet of Madonnas. Or indeed a drip of Westlifes. Westlife have had six number ones inside a couple of years, and so you might imagine that the carefully chosen experts on Channel 4's selection panel, including angry middle aged ex-punk me, might have spent many hours deciding which Westlife to include.
fields.body:
In voting for your favourite No 1 records of all time, the rules stipulate that you can only vote for one record by a group or artist. This ensures that the list is not overrun by a plague of Beatles, or a camp of Queens, or a fishnet of Madonnas. Or indeed a drip of Westlifes. Westlife have had six number ones inside a couple of years, and so you might imagine that the carefully chosen experts on Channel 4's selection panel, including angry middle aged ex-punk me, might have spent many hours deciding which Westlife to include.

If you're over nine, you'll be pleased to hear that there is no Westlife song in the selection. It's as difficult to think of the name of a Westlife song as it is to think of the name of a Westlife boy. Perhaps they're all called Boy - the songs and the members. Thanks to Westlife's best and worst efforts, a No 1 single isn't quite as rare a thing as it was up until a few years ago. In the Sixties, Seventies and Eighties, the veritable pits of current pop nostalgia, the list decades of the moment, there were usually about 12 to 15 No 1s a year. This year, there will probably be about 30. Next year, possibly 52. In the good and bad old days, records took time to reach No 1. Sometimes there was a kind of struggle that made the No 1 somehow richer. Now record companies like to demonstrate their greased marketing muscle and the instant impact their acts are having on a spoilt youth consciousness by heaving their singles straight in at No 1, where mostly they shine anonymously for a week or so before drifting off.

But even now that No 1 singles are as common as muck, and you can have half a dozen and make minimal impact on the mass popular imagination, the No 1 pop single remains a special thing. The aura of magic, tragedy, novelty and glamour that has accumulated over 40 years has not been rubbed away, not even by the fact that a single isn't quite what it was but a multi-formatted marketing echo of the idea of a single. The marvellousness of the No 1 pop single hasn't yet been undermined by all the business interference that goes on as to what a single is about or for. It's still all about the potential madness of the moment collected in a commercial song that you love or hate and that reminds you of who you are, and who you were.

The enduring specialness of the No 1 and how it relates to the individual and collective memory, the way that No 1s over the years somehow communicate the strange extremes of pop, and tell a story about the history of fashion, means that I was happy to do something I normally don't like doing, which is to become part of a panel choosing a list. I'm reluctant to do this kind of thing because I get anxious, I take it far too seriously, and panic when things don't go my way. As soon as I accepted the task of helping Channel 4 come up with a selection of No 1s for people to base their votes on, I became a zealot, determined to rid the list of the 'Lady In Reds' and 'Mull Of Kintyres'. The thought of Berlin's 'You Take My Breath Away' making the list upset me dearly, and I knew that I was quite capable of making such exceptional points about why 'Sugar Sugar' by The Archies or Buck Fizz's ' 'Making Your Mind Up' were to be included that it might lead to me being led away by men in white jackets. I could write a book on why Sonny and Cher's 'I Got You Babe' is more of a No 1 than, say, The Eurythmics' 'There Must Be An Angel'.

My kind of No 1 is a great thinking blast of non epic non-soppy, non-pretty-pretty pop that at the very moment of being No 1 seems to celebrate that it is No 1. My kind of No 1 is a dramatic blend of obviousness and surprise that takes all pop forward a little bit, or at least sidewards. I prefer the silly No 1, whether 'In The Year 2525' or Cher's 'I Believe', to the drawn out thickly sentimental trips of triteness of Whitney Houston, Wet Wet Wet and Bryan Adams. The length these songs stay at No 1 suggest that a nation doesn't so much fall in love with their grace and insight as get hypnotised by their creepy-crawly insistence.

Other panellists had their quirks too. The venerable Paul Gambaccini, appalled at my frivolous and rather desperately trendy determination to have the Chemical Brothers 'Setting Sun' included over Spandau Ballet's gluey 'True', was adamant that no song from the past five years should be included. He figured, taking it all even more seriously than me, that it takes time for greatness, or iconic badness, to form, for the essential temporariness of pop to become inessentially permanent. Other panellists were alarmed that it would look foolish to ignore the obvious pop classicism of Britney, The Prodigy and Fatboy. And even though Norman Cook added a seaside fish and chip beat to the aromatic delicacy of Cornershop's 'Brimful Of Asha' to help it to No 1, it's one of the deftest songs to ever get there, along with The Pretenders' 'Brass In Pocket,' and it had to be included. Gambaccini was overruled. (It should be said that, this being the civilised twenty-first century, we didn't meet in a smoke filled room. We deliberated via email. The storming outs were done at the touch of a button. The sulking was all cyber.) Personally, I would have gone up to last year, and would have preferred to have seen Mud's 'Tiger Feet' in the list rather than Spiller's 'Groovejet' (written by Mud's guitarist.)

The compromises forced upon you are what makes doing such a thing so painful. It becomes a matter of personal taste versus cultural inevitability. I knew that against all my principles something by Take That was going to be included, and however sensitive I felt about it there was just no room for Creedence Clearwater Revival, ABC or KLF. But there is pleasure in winning a few battles. A list without Kraftwerk is to me as absurd as a list without The Beatles or Presley. The fact that someone as intense and dangerous as Hendrix had a No 1 demonstrates some of the changing wonders of the No 1, and he just had to be included. I felt I was being very professional at suggesting 'If You Tolerate This' by the Manic Street Preachers despite feeling the song is more Bryan Adams than Sex Pistols, and that I was being acceptably emotional in using virtual tears to force in New Order's 'World in Motion' and maturely nostalgic in pointing out the absolute necessity of including the love of my early teens, T.Rex. (It was immaturely nostalgic of me to expect McGuinness Flint's 'When I'm Dead And Gone' to be included over above, say, 'Bridge Over Troubled Water', and probably verging on the hysterical for me to demand Adamski's 'Killer' over say Oasis. It was also stupid of me to try and marshall support for Edwyn Collins's 'Never Met A Girl Like You Before' as it never actually got to No 1, one of those that got away, like Pulp's 'Common People, and Robbie's sobby, psychosickly 'Angels'.') And then there is, as there always is at a time like this, Queen's 'Bohemian Rhapsody,' to me the infantile novelty song of all infantile novelty songs, the ultimate No 1 nasty. I spent sleepless nights worrying about its inclusion in the list, feeling that if it was included it would no doubt come top of the list, as it is another song that seems to hypnotise people. I gave in, as if I had much of a choice, only because I hope that as well as topping the favourites it might well top the least favourites. Not that I want to influence your voting or anything, but I did pledge to the panel that if it tops the favourites but not the least favourites then I will sing the song live on Richard and Judy's This Morning wearing nothing but a revolving bow tie and a stick-on Freddie Mercury moustache.

And if you're looking for your favourite in this list, for The Who, or Meatloaf, or All Saints, or indeed Westlife, all I can say is, don't blame the panel. Blame 'Bohemian Rhapsody'.

Paul Morley was one of the panel who chose the list of No 1s above

fields.headline: Real smoothies? We were more like real amateurs
fields.standfirst: Richard Reed was a total innocent when he began his fruit drink business, he tells Natalie Sutton
fields.trailText: Richard Reed was a total innocent when he began his fruit drink business, he tells Natalie Sutton.
fields.body:
Richard Reed, 27, a graduate working in a 'regular advertising job', said goodbye to a salary of about £35,000 because he wanted to 'do something different' and work with his two friends, Adam Balon and Jon Wright.

'It was something we'd always talked about. We loved our jobs, but we were at the stage in our careers when people wanted us to step up the ladder. We all thought: nobody's married, nobody's got children and nobody's got a mortgage. Now is the time to do it.

'We decided that a good product is anything that makes life a little bit easier and a bit better for people.'

They dabbled with a system allowing baths to fill themselves to a designated temperature and depth, before deciding that the combination of electricity and water could not so much better people's lives as shorten them.

'We wanted to make it easy to do yourself some good without being health Nazis. Convenience food is usually unhealthy - but if the healthy option is there, people will buy it.'

Following the idea of health in a bottle, they created 'smoothies' at home, using only fresh fruit. They then did a consumer test at a London music festival, asking the public to vote on whether they should give up their day jobs and produce the drinks professionally.

The result was a resounding 'yes'. And so Innocent fresh fruit 'smoothies' were born, to be joined this year by their yogurt-blended alternatives, 'thickies'. Two years on, the boys have clearer complexions and are running their own show, but are their bank balances as healthy as their fruit juices?

'Friends, family, everyone was incredibly supportive. My old firm gave us an office to work from for free and they said that if it didn't work out I could go back.'

Total innocents that they were, the boys made few provisions financially. 'We were very naive. We thought we could start making the juices in a month and then the money would start coming in. We thought we'd done the difficult bit - the recipes, labels and everything. We were totally wrong. It takes so much longer than you think.'

The biggest hold-up was not accepting any compromise. 'Our product is all about 100 per cent fruit - no water, no sugar, no concentrated juices, no preservatives. We had to be singleminded and not let people water it down for us. They kept saying, you don't understand. So we'd say no, you don't understand.

'We had nine months of not earning a penny. We survived through huge debts (more than £10,000 each), outstanding credit card bills (the highest was about £10,000) and understanding girlfriends who were always buying the drinks and picking up the bills. Every meal was breakfast cereal or soup. It was pretty bleak.'

And now? 'We're not working any harder but we feel a lot healthier. I have to drink about eight of these juices a day to make sure they pass quality control. Before, we were eating burgers, chips and lager because that was all that was available. Now we have burgers, chips, lager and fruit juices, which provide daily vitamins.'

'None of us has the salary we had, but we've only just started. I've paid off my credit card and can look at my bank account without fainting.'

The future now looks even rosier for the boys, with 'veggies' joining Innocent's list of products, and possible forays into the beauty industry.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Endowment compensation
fields.body:
Endowment compensation

If you were sold a 10-year endowment savings plan by City Financial Partners, you may be entitled to compensation.

CFP's owner, Lincoln Assurance, is writing to the 5,000 people who have been sold the endowments since 1998. They will be offered compensation if they were mis-sold the plan, including a refund plus interest, or a transfer to an Isa. Lincoln now considers the plan 'inappropriate' for people who were young and single when they bought them because their money is locked in for the life of the plan. CFP no longer sells the plans.

The move follows an investigation by consumer magazine Which? which led to CFP being reported to the Financial Services Authority. Which? found some CFP salespeople had just two weeks' training.

Lincoln spokesman Ian Crowder says: 'We are taking these allegations extremely seriously.'

Help the tax-slow

Help the Aged will assist people who have missed the September deadline for submitting tax returns in calculating their tax bill for a £75 fee. Although the offer is targeted at the over-50s, the charity says there is no lower age limit set for those wanting to use the service.

If taxpayers file their returns before 30 September each year, the Inland Revenue will work out their tax liability for them. Subsequently they, not the Inland Revenue, are responsible for calculating the amount of tax due.

Call 020 7474 3310 for further information.

Paying for debt

People overwhelmed by domestic debt are being offered a one-stop way to repay their creditors.

The debtor makes one regular payment a month at a PayPoint (an automated payment service found in garages and newsagents around the country), which is then used to pay creditors a pre-agreed amount.

The service has been set up jointly by PayPoint, the automated bill payment company, and the Money Advice Trust, the umbrella organisation for all money advice groups, and will be offered to people seeking help with their debts at centres such as citizens' advice bureaux.

Healthy policy

The problem for many people thinking about buying private medical insurance is that pre-existing conditions are excluded from the policies on offer. This means that the very cover they need for an ongoing medical problem is not available.

Bupa is introducing a new care plan called Heartbeat which will cover 90 per cent of pre-existing conditions after judging them on a case by case basis. It will not cover immediate operations, chronic heart disease and uncontrolled diabetes. The policies, which will typically be more expensive than traditional private medical policies, will be priced on an individual basis.

Pensions at stake

Many personal pensions are not compatible with the new stakeholder pensions starting in April, according to a survey by magazine Money Management.

Regulations demand that people taking out a personal pension in the meantime should not be financially penalised if they subsequently transfer to a stakeholder pension. But the Money Management survey shows 19 personal pensions do not meet this requirement as defined by the Association of British Insurers. Money Management has interpreted the ABI guidelines as meaning that at least 93 per cent of gross premi ums paid after one year should be available for transfer, after all charges, into the new stakeholder plan. Providers who fall short of the mark include Axa, Eagle Star, NPI, Scottish Equitable and Scottish Widows. The worst offender is Forester Life whose personal pension has a zero transfer value.

Best advice

Tim Robson, of London-based Marsh Financial Services, has been named 'financial adviser of the year' by the Society of Financial Advisers. The planning for retirement award went to Paul Duckworth from the Grimsby firm of the same name, while the best mortgage adviser was judged to be Steve Smith of London-based Sedgwick IFC.

For a list of Sofa members, contact the organisation on www.sofa.org.

An Isa insider

Want to know more about Isas? A free guide is available with this month's issue of our sister publication Money Observer . The guide is also available separately through the post.

Cheques or postal orders for £1.75 should go to Money Observer Isa Guide, 75 Farringdon Road, London EC1M 3JY.

webTitle: ISAs: Seoul traders gamble on a big win

fields.headline: Seoul traders gamble on a big win
fields.standfirst: Invest in markets such as India and Korea - but only if you can afford to take a loss, reports  David Hunt
fields.trailText: Invest in markets such as India and Korea - but only if you can afford to take a loss, reports David Hunt.
fields.body:
So you have decided on an equity Isa and you want a managed fund, but you also quite fancy chancing your arm.

You've got some spare money to play with that you are prepared to tie up for five years or more and, if you lose it all, it won't be the end of the world.

You reckon that tracker funds and diversified global funds are for wimps; you are bored with waiting for Japan to recover; and even technology funds are yesterday's news.

So where do you look to invest? If you are really prepared for a white-knuckle roller coaster ride, single-country funds could be the asnwer.

Single-country funds in this context are not invested in the mainstream markets of the UK, the US or Japan, but more typically in places such as Russia, Korea and Chile.

These are the markets which can provide returns of more than 100 per cent plus returns one year, and then lose fistfuls of cash in the next.They are the markets for which the phrase 'high risk/high return' was invented

But while a wide range of single country funds are available to offshore investors, opportunities are more limited onshore. Even where they exist, they are not always available through an Isa.

Schroder, for example, has a Korean fund (Schroder Seoul) which is not available through the group's ISA.

Philip Middleton, head of investor services at Schroder, explains: 'We don't have a lot of demand from retail investors; it's very speculative. An Isa is usually someone's first equity investment, and Korea is not really the sort of market they should be in.'

Korean fans will have no better luck at Save & Prosper or Barings, where the groups' Korean funds are also off limits to ISA investors. As the Korean market was down by more than 40 per cent at 20 September from the start of the year, this is may be just as well.

Old Mutual, however, is offering its Thai fund in an Isa format.

Graham Kane, Old Mutual Fund Manager's chief executive, admits: 'It is always going to be a roller-coaster ride. We believe people should start with the basic building blocks - UK, Europe, America, global. They have to work their way down quite a long list before they come to Thailand.' The Thai market fell by 48.3 per cent between January this year and 20 September.

'This is a very specialist product,' says Kane. 'Investors have to come in with their eyes wide open. It was Thailand's banking crisis which led Asia into the crisis, and the rest of Asia has recovered faster.'

Chase Fleming Asset Management offers two sin gle-country investment trusts which are Isable - Fleming Chinese and Fleming Indian.

The group's Mike Connors says that it offers all of its funds through an Isa, although he admits that these two are probably 'the least suitable for the private investor'.

Shares in Fleming Indian, for example, are currently selling for 79p, down from a high of 127p in February.

Worse still, anyone investing about four years ago could have bought shares at a 9 per cent premium to their net asset value. They have now slumped to a 24 per cent discount.

Both trusts currently have quite a large retail shareholder base, partly because of the number of investors with an ethnic affinity to the regions.

However it is not all gloom and doom. Single- country funds investing in more established markets - especially European ones - have turned in some fairly respectable performances this year.

Invesco's French Growth fund, managed by the same team than runs Invesco's table-topping European Growth fund, has grown by 88 per cent, while Baring German Growth has increased by 43 per cent.

Old Mutual also offers a Swiss fund (not quite in the same risk category as the Thailand offering, says Kane) which has grown by 12 per cent in the past year, and a Hong Kong and China fund, which has grown by 31 per cent.

'Increasingly Hong Kong and China are becoming a single market,' he says. At the moment the fund is invested 75 per cent in Hong Kong and 23 per cent in China.

But aside from people who hold definite views about the regions - those who believe that China is an economy of the future for example - Chase Fleming's Connors advises caution.

'They should definitely not form a core part of anyone's portfolio,' he says. 'They are very volatile, but then again, if you time it right, volatility can sometimes be your friend.'

webTitle: ISAs: The DIY route to tax-free dealing

fields.headline: The DIY route to tax-free dealing
fields.standfirst: Try to beat the experts with a self-select Isa, writes  Alistair McArthur
fields.trailText: Try to beat the experts with a self-select Isa, writes Alistair McArthur.
fields.body:
Many things in life are often better - and cheaper - if you do them yourself. Investors who want to buy shares in their favourite companies can protect any returns from tax by keeping their holdings in a self-select individual savings account.

Self-select Isas are exactly as their name suggests. Unlike a unit trust Isa, where the fund managers select which stocks are held within the trust, investors in self-select Isas can make their own choice of stocks.

The flexibility of the self-select Isa enables investors to build up their own portfolios, buying and selling their holdings as they see fit. The Isa rules also allow them to hold cash within the tax-free wrapper for up to 42 days.

'The beauty of self-select Isas is that investors can change the combination of their holdings within the Isa,' says Sasha Ewart, director of marketing at stockbroker Killik & Co. 'They can sell stocks, hold the cash and then buy more stocks, without losing the tax-free status.'

The ability to pick and choose your own holdings within an Isa is not suitable for people who have had no experience of stock market investments. 'For novice investors, it may not be the best option to lead off with,' says Nigel Reynolds, a director of stockbroker Charles Schwab. 'These people would be better off starting with unit trusts.'

But for more experienced investors, self-select Isas provide the opportunities for them to build up a portfolio of stocks and shares that mirrors their changing lifestyle. For example, while they are working, they may be more prepared to take chances to maximise the possibility of high capital growth. Once they near retirement they can consolidate their gains, and once they have retired, they will be able to pick investments that will provide them with a tax- free income.

The biggest attraction of self-select Isas, according to Reynolds, is that investors are not charged capital gains tax (CGT) on any increases on their investments. He feels that the types of investors that are attracted to this form of Isa can be split into two categories. The first is those who think they can get better returns than fund managers by making one or two trades a year, and the second is the more active investors, who make two or three transactions a month and want to shelter significant capital gains.

However, there can be disadvantages in using a self- select Isa. First, any losses made on shares within the self-select Isa cannot be offset against any capital gains made elsewhere, thereby reducing a possible CGT liability.

Second, you need to keep an eye on charges. There are two main charges - a management fee that the provider charges for running the Isa, and a deal-ing charge, which is payable when a share is bought or sold. But while self-select charges may seem low compared with those of unit trust Isas, they can eat into your returns if you deal frequently. Killik & Co makes no annual management charge. Ewart says: 'Investors pay when they buy and when they sell. The disadvantage is that, if they buy and sell all the time, it could have an erosive effect on the fund.'

Charles Schwab Europe uses both methods of charging investors. It levies an annual management charge, which relates to about 0.75 per cent of the Isa value, and dealing charges which range from £12 to £75 a deal, depending on the size and the method of dealing.

Increased interest in the internet has given investors increased choice in how they make changes to their portfolios. Several stockbrokers, including Barclays, The Share Centre and Charles Schwab all now provide a route to dealing online.

fields.headline: What's the catch?
fields.standfirst: Scratchcard prizes may look attractive on paper, but are they really such a good bet?
fields.trailText: Scratchcard prizes may look attractive on paper, but are they really such a good bet?
fields.body:
Supermarket Safeway has withdrawn scratchcards inserted in its monthly magazine after customer complaints.

Some 50 shoppers said that they had to claim the prizes they had won through a phone line at a cost of £1 a minute. A typical call cost £4.

Although the charge was stated in the promotional literature and the value of all the prizes was more than the cost of the call, some customers still felt disgruntled when they learnt the precise details of their win.

Safeway received the most complaints about a trip to France which was advertised as a 'high prize' on Aces scratchcards supplied by Iso Matrix. The complainants became unhappy when they discovered the trip was just for the day as a foot passenger on a ferry. They argued it was not worth coming from locations all over Britain to go on the trip from Dover. Safeway withdrew the scratchcards after two months.

Its customer services team wrote to one of the people who complained, John Burls, of Essex, saying: 'We are disappointed that this promotion did not live up to expectations for our customers... However, with hindsight we probably took too much in good faith and were misled by the promoters to a degree over certain issues.

'As a consequence, the team responsible for this type of promotion have been briefed to ensure more rigorous investigations prior to any future promotions.'

The retailer says it was the first time it included this type of promotion in its magazine, and that it will not be running more like it.

 Seen an advertisement or mailshot that looks too good to be true? Write to What's the Catch, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

fields.headline: £1,000 Connex refund on slow track to arrival
fields.standfirst: Has a bank, building society, insurer or other firm treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has a bank, building society, insurer or other firm treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
I took early retirement last June and, as my annual season ticket ran to 5 December, I wanted a refund from Connex South Central. I was due for £979, which they said would be paid to my bank account, through my debit card, on 5 July. Despite innumerable phone calls, this still has not been paid. Other than taking the firm to court, what can I do?
MC, Seaford

This should have been a straightforward case to sort out. But no. First, Connex said its records showed you had been paid on 5 July.

When it was proved that you had not, it claimed the delays were caused by Barclays Merchant Services which runs the electronic plastic-card business. Barclays countered that Connex was at fault for processing your refund on an inactive terminal. Barclays had disabled it because Connex had fewer transactions going through that one outlet than agreed in the contract.

No, not our fault, said Connex: we went on using the terminal because Barclays failed to tell us it had shut it down.

Well yes, we were a bit slow, admitted Barclays, and we had to go through Connex's intermediary company which added to the delay. Nine other refunds have also been held up.

You should by now have £979 in your bank account but I feel you are entitled to compensation for the cost of the delay.

Neither Barclays nor Connex agreed immediately, but said they would discuss it. Write to them both and ask.

Seeing double over TV cover

I bought a television set from Powerhouse on a 12-month 'buy now, pay later' deal that included extended warranty insurance for £244. Between signing and the payment date, I bought insurance for all my electrical equipment, so I contacted the store and the lender, GE Capital Bank, and was told I could cancel my original deal. I paid for the TV in June 1997 and visited the store to confirm what I had done.

A year later, I noticed a direct debit of £77 from my bank. GE Capital Bank took it for the insurance cover under a mandate signed two years earlier. It said that, because I had not paid the £244, I now owed £750, including interest on the sum I had already paid. I did not feel up to making a fight of it then but, after reading a similar case in Money Writes, I wonder if I could now.
PH, Birmingham

GE Capital initially refused to refund the money, saying your situation was not the same as the other reader's. The only difference I could see was that you had already paid up.

When asked for an explanation, GE deliberated for several weeks before agreeing you had done all you could. It now has systems in place that alert staff when borrowers repay all but a small amount of an interest-free deal, and says it will not penalise you for being hit by the old procedure. It is refunding the insurance premium and interest you paid.

Please Minister, give us windfalls

Thousands of NHS staff have subscribed to Equitable Life additional voluntary contributions for their pensions, but apparently the scheme is invested in a single account in the name of the Health Secretary. How can we protect our interests?
AS, Wigan

Exactly what happens depends on Equitable Life's new owner, whoever that turns out to be, and whether the insurer demutualises. But you can be fairly relaxed. Civil Service employees were in the same situation when Lloyds TSB bought their AVC manager, Scottish Widows. There too the Secretary of State held the policy but the windfall was spread among the AVC holders.

The NHS Pensions Agency says the principle of including members in any windfall 'would be respected where practicable'. Equitable Life says it too wants individual policyholders to receive the money.

The National Association of Pension Funds points out that all Equitable Life's AVC holders face the same problem and it has already had meetings with the company to see they are treated fairly.

Who will handle my son's cash?

I am a single parent with a court order for maintenance payments for my 15- year-old son, arranged in 1991. I receive £129 a month, plus £30 recently agreed voluntarily. I understood, when the Child Support Agency was established in 1993, that it would take over all agreements arranged through the courts. Is this still the plan?
JS, Haddington

The original idea was that the courts would cease to have jurisdiction, and all applications to vary court orders would be made to the CSA, although this has not happened in practice.

But under new legislation, from 2002 the CSA alone will have jurisdiction to determine child maintenance. It is believed that, for existing court orders, jurisdiction will remain with the courts for one year after the new law takes effect. Then it, too, will go to the CSA alone.

Leaving on a jet plane, £750 light

I took out Barclaycard travel insurance a couple of days before flying to Canada to visit my elderly father, but did not receive the policy document before I left. I misread my return date. I should have checked in at 10pm on 7 July for a flight at 1am, but I had it fixed in my mind that I was flying back on 8 July and missed the plane.

When I realised my error, I called the emergency number and was advised to find the cheapest flight out. I paid £750, more than twice the cost of my original return ticket. Barclaycard has refused my claim, saying my policy does not cover these circumstances. If I had been told this by the Canadian representative, I would have sought a much cheaper, if more complicated, way home.
UN, Southall

Travel insurance will pay for extra flights only if you had missed the original through circumstances beyond your control. The person you spoke to was probably trying to be helpful and sympathetic, but was not in a position to say your money would be refunded. Sadly, you have no case.
