webTitle: ISAs: Picking out a dream theme

fields.headline: Picking out a dream theme
fields.standfirst: Jill Insley examines the attractions of putting cash into a specific sector
fields.trailText: Jill Insley examines the attractions of putting cash into a specific sector.
fields.body:
Older unit trust investors may remember the Motorways Fund. Then came property funds, commodity funds and funds invested in the financial sector. Theme funds - unit trusts invested in a particular investment theme or sector - have been around for a long time, but they have seldom made a lasting impression.

This time though, it is different, we are told. Aided by the dramatic upsurge in the technology sector, theme funds are back with a vengeance and Isa investors have an increasing number to choose from.

And, while technology leads the way, there are also healthcare, biotech and telecoms funds and funds combining different themes, as well as more general funds pursuing a thematic investment philosophy.

The thematic approach is a different way of investing money. Whereas the traditional investment manager looks at the world, country by country, and then sector by sector, the thematic investor argues that these global boundaries have broken down and are no longer relevant. Communication, they argue, is now so good that what starts as a trend in the US today, rapidly spreads from market to market. Companies and industries now think, and act, globally.

So instead of looking geographically, thematic investors look for emerging trends and then invest in companies which are likely to benefit as a result.

'It's like a food chain,' said one fund manager. 'You find the theme and then track it back to those companies which feed off it.'

Gary Marshall, managing director of Aberdeen Unit Trusts, managers of one of the most successful technology funds, believes theme funds are popular 'because investors can relate to them much more'.

'Technology, communications and healthcare all touch people's lives. They see what is going on around them and want to be a part of the success stories.'

Aberdeen recently extended its theme range with the launch of the Global Champions fund aiming to exploit the themes of globalisation, innovation and communication.

Another fan of thematic investment is Tim Wilson, chief strategist at Newton Fund Managers. 'You have to think laterally,' he suggests. 'Once we have established a theme we put it to the analysts and fund managers who identify companies which will be beneficiaries of these themes and put them in their portfolios.'

Wilson cites mobile phones. 'You don't just invest in the operators like Vodafone, but in the people who make the handsets, the chips that go in them and the companies that build the towers that the operators stick their radio masts on.'

And thematic investment doesn't just work for global, or regional funds. 'Say you believe in Asian recovery and you think the construction industry will benefit as a result.' he says. 'But you don't like any of the Asian construction companies because their balance sheets are poor. Thinking laterally, you may buy Blue Circle for your UK fund because it has strong links with Asia and could well be a beneficiary of the Asian recovery theme.'

Not everyone, however, is convinced by the sudden conversion to theme funds. Alan Beaney, head of investments at Principal Investment Management, believes it may be just the latest fad.

'Theme funds have been around for a long time, but you don't hear much these days about gold funds, commodity funds or European privatisation funds. The "new economy" is a buzzword, but theme funds end up with too many eggs in the one basket; they lead to biased portfolios.

'One man's theme fund is another man's bandwagon,' he reckons.

Nigel Thomas, fund manager of the highly successful ABN Amro UK Growth fund, has operated in a thematic way for many years, but has some sympathy with Beaney's view. 'Trends are like horses,' he says. 'They are easier to ride in the direction they are already going. You have got to avoid the sort of hype we had with the internet bubble. Long term, we seriously believe in software, but we avoided all the dotcoms. You have to see through all the puffery.'

ABN Amro uses a team approach to come up with themes. 'In the main, we find a global theme and then track it back here and find out how you can play it in the London market.'

Thomas lists a number of themes he is currently following such as photonics , remote sensing, fuel cells, online logistics, innovative semiconductor design, organic foods, garage forecourt retailing, outsourcing, mobile telephony with internet, digital imaging, discount retailing, green pharmaceuticals and genomics.

'Theme funds have a place,' argues Amanda Davidson, of IFA Holden Meehan.

'But it depends very much what the theme is. Technology and healthcare make good sense,' she says, but stresses that these are higher risk funds and should occupy no more than between 5and 10 per cent of anyone's portfolio.

fields.headline: Cashback loan in focus
fields.trailText: More than 2,000 borrowers have already come a cropper with a personal loan scheme that claims to allow you to reclaim up to 100 per cent of the interest you have paid after five years.
fields.body:
Readers of our What's the Catch? items are used to fantastic money-spinning schemes proving too good to be true. In May we wrote about loan broker HFS, which has been selling personal loans that allow you to reclaim up to 100 per cent of the interest you have paid after five years.

To qualify you have to follow several precise steps. We warned readers that the insurer backing the guarantee - UK Insurance, a subsidiary of Direct Line - expects few borrowers to claim successfully, meaning they will pay 12.9 per cent APR for their loans.

Unfortunately more than 2,000 borrowers have already come a cropper with a previous version of the scheme, backed by a different guarantor, Intervest Capital. Intervest Capital was involved in several cashback schemes during the mid-Nineties, including deals promoted by HFS and The Sofa Company in Merseyside. But by 1997 Intervest Capital and its Nevada-registered parent were being investigated by the DTI. The DTI was unable to confirm that the US company had enough money to honour its cashback liabilities, and concluded that both companies should be wound up, leaving thousands of customers clutching valueless 'cheques'.

HFS told its customers that while it had no legal liability, it was willing to negotiate with the lenders of the interest-back loans to reduce the interest being charged, and therefore reduce remaining monthly payments.

One reader, Terence Buckley of Stadhampton, near Oxford, took HFS up on its offer, and had the interest rate charged on his £9,000 loan reduced from 17.3 per cent to 14.3 per cent. However, the reduced rate was still high compared with typical charges on equivalent loans available at that time. It is particularly painful when you consider that Buckley expected to pay no interest at all; instead he must pay nearly £4,000. He says: 'The liquidator informs me that over 20,000 people have signed up to cashback offers and look as if they, like myself, stand to lose a great deal of money. I feel aggrieved.'

Paul Naden, managing director of HFS, says his firm has done its best to act as a responsible broker, trying to reduce the damage for customers. Some decided to redeem their loans rather than opt for the interest-rate reduction, in which case HFS contributed towards the repayment due.

Naden adds: 'We are an injured party as well. The amount of discounts that we awarded them [people repaying their loans] was greater than the commission we earned. We were over £1m out of pocket. It was a damage-limitation exercise.'

HFS set up the current interest-back loan just six months after the Intervest scheme collapsed. It is distinct from the previous scheme as it uses a UK-based insurer. 'No UK-based company can issue £1 of insurance without having £1 in assets to back it up,' explains Naden, adding that the DTI, FSA, OFT and other regulatory bodies have scrutinised the new scheme to the 'nth degree, because they don't want the same thing happening again'.

fields.headline: Axa under fire over 'orphan' distribution
fields.standfirst: Insurer is accused of manipulating ballot, writes  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Insurer is accused of manipulating ballot, writes Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
With-profits policyholders in Axa Sun Life could lose out on a cash payment of about £400 unless within the next week they return papers to the insurer supporting Axa's proposals on distributing its 'orphan assets'. Policyholders who don't show their support in this way, whatever they truly think of the proposals, will get nothing - at least in the short-term.

Axa's proposals are highly controversial, bringing accu sations of unfairness and manipulation from the Consumers' Association (CA) and from lawyers. The association believes policyholders are being shortchanged in order to pass on a large chunk of the £1.7 billion orphan assets to shareholders.

In the past, orphan assets - unclaimed policy funds - have traditionally been split on a 90:10 basis between policyholders and shareholders. But CA calcula tions, produced by accountant KPMG, suggest that policyholders stand to get as little as 35 per cent in the Axa scheme.

Policyholders must return their paperwork to Axa by 16 October to be included in the ballot. But there is a sting in the tail: the paperwork only allows policyholders to support the proposal. Anyone who wants to show their dissent only has the option of not sending back the form.

As of last week, about 350,000 policyholders - out of a total of 750,000 - had yet to send in the forms. The February payments will aver age £400 per policyholder, and some will be as much as £1,000. The CA will hope to see its concerns aired in a High Court hearing on 20 November. Arrangements of this kind - occurring as the result of the merger of Axa and Sun Life's with-profits funds - always need court approval.

The CA is also concerned that the balloting procedure has been unfair. Its spokesman Ashley Holmes is unhappy with the way that Axa has announced that more than 51 per cent of policyholders have already sent in their papers. He says: 'This is rotten. It will clearly influence people who haven't already voted.'

Electoral Reform Services, a subsidiary of the Electoral Reform Society, which is overseeing the ballot, says it is happy with Axa's plan to stop payments to those who do not send in their forms.

£2 billion opportunity goes begging

Pensions lawyer Robin Ellison of Eversheds is calling on insurers, the Government and other bodies who sometimes end up with orphan funds to ask people building up their pensions or life assurance to sign a form donating all such funds to charity.

Many people pay into their funds - whether through National Insurance or through contributions into actual pensions and life policies - and then never claim on the money they have built up.

Ellison estimates orphan funds worth £2 billion a year would be given to charities if a new charitable scheme of this kind happened. It would also avoid the type of row that is engulfing the Axa scheme.

webTitle: ISAs: Yielding to pressure on redemption day

fields.headline: Yielding to pressure on redemption day
fields.standfirst: Fund managers must now provide investors with all the information about the true returns from corporate bond Isas, writes Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Fund managers must now provide investors with all the information about the true returns from corporate bond Isas, writes Helen Pridham.
fields.body:
If you need an income from your savings, you cannot afford to ignore corporate bond Isas.

They invest, usually through a unit trust, in fixed- interest securities issued by companies which need to raise extra capital. Although yields on some funds have come down recently, it is still possible to find those offering 8 per cent or more and - thanks to the Isa wrapper - all this income is tax free.

When income is important to you, it is natural that you should compare yields on different Isas to find out where you can get the best return. However, until recently, you could not be sure you were comparing like with like. There was no uniform formula for calculating yields. Some companies would quote the 'running yield', which simply reflected the level of income paid out, others a 'redemp tion yield' which took account of any charges against capital and potential capital loss if the bonds in the fund had been purchased above their redemption price.

Since the beginning of September, new guidance from Autif, the investment funds' trade association, means that all fund managers must now give equal prominence in their advertising literature to the redemption yield. Jason Hollands, deputy managing director of independent financial advisers Best Investment, welcomes the move. He said: 'We have been calling for this change for some while. We always felt running yields were misleading and did not reflect the true return.'

However, investors still have to be careful when making comparisons of corporate bond Isa yields because funds may be investing in different types of bonds. Those with the highest yields will be holding the highest risk bonds.

Warren Perry, investment adviser at independent financial advisers Whitechurch Securities, explains: 'Yields on corporate bonds reflect the credit ratings of the companies that issue them. The greater the risk of default perceived by the market, the higher the yield the company must pay in compensation.

'Big blue chip companies, on the other hand, can borrow money at lower interest rates because the risk of them not being able to pay back their debts is seen as very low.'

This means that when you invest in a higher-yielding Isa you are taking a greater risk with your capital, but as Perry points out: 'In a corporate bond fund which will have between 80 and 100 holdings, if one company defaults it won't have a massive effect on your investment.'

Nevertheless, even if there are no defaults, the capital values of the funds are likely to fluctuate more than those which invest in higher quality, lower-yielding bonds because, like shares, prices of high-yielding bonds will be affected by stock market sentiment. But this can also work to your advantage.

Steven Price, technical manager at independent financial adviser Towry Law, says: 'It is always dangerous to sell bond funds on the basis of potential capital growth but there is no doubt that there is a greater likelihood of appreciation with a higher-yielding fund than a lower-yielding one.'

One possible source of gain is when a company is taken over by another, more creditworthy company. This has the effect of increasing the value of its bonds.

Perry believes different fund management skills are needed to run a high-yielding bond fund than a high-quality one. He says: 'You need a manager with experience and a good equity team behind him so he can avoid the companies most likely to default.'

The two funds he recommends are Newton European High Yield and Scottish Widows High Income Bond fun. Both yield more than 9 per cent.

He says: 'Helena Morrissey of Newton has an extremely good record running the company's other bond funds, and the group has a very strong European Equity team.

'Similarly, the Scottish Widows fund which invests in American high-yielding bonds is managed in New York by bond experts at Mackay Shields and is already one of the best performers in its category.'

Among other advisers, Jason Hollands, of Best Investment, also recommends the Newton European High Yield Fund, while Aberdeen Fixed Interest, managed by Paul Reed, gets Price's vote.

Meanwhile Amanda Davidson, of financial adviser Holden Meehan, is a fan of Perpetual's Monthly Income Fund. She says: 'Not only does this fund invest in high-yielding bonds, it also has a small exposure to shares which automatically makes it more risky, but this should help to maintain its capital value in the longer run. Its performance so far has been very good.' However, Davidson points out: 'Many people seeking income only want to take the minimum riskwith their capital. For these investors we would recommend Legal & General's Fixed Interest fund which invests only in the high-quality bonds.'

Hollands agrees: 'Legal & General's fund has the lowest management charges and with this type of fund where scope for differences in performance is limited, charges are the most important consideration.'

Perry and Price, on the other hand, favour Perpetual's Corporate Bond fund for those who prefer a less risky choice.

fields.headline: Seven-month internet itch
fields.standfirst: We asked three experts how to invest £50,000. Seven months later,  Rachel Fixsen reports on how their efforts have been hit by shocks to the stock market
fields.trailText: We asked three experts how to invest £50,000. Seven months later, Rachel Fixsen reports on how their efforts have been hit by shocks to the stock market.
fields.byline: Rachel Fixsen reports on how their efforts have been hit by shocks to the stock market
fields.body:
In February, we asked three independent financial advisers to create two investment portfolios for us - one which aimed for capital growth and the other to provide an income.

Seven months on, we are taking another look at the investments to see how they have done, and whether any should be changed.

A lot can happen in seven months - particularly in the financial markets. Our fledgling portfolios had barely poked their beaks out of the nest when trouble pushed them back. In March, internet stocks, which had seen stunning growth for months, were caught in a frantic sell-off. And over the summer, the swelling price of oil kept a lid on stock prices.

Each of our three IFAs had their own idea about what to do with the £50,000 portfolios.

In the growth portfolio, Kim North, of Calkin Pattinson, opted for a high exposure to technology and internet stocks, while Jason Hollands, of discount bro kers Best Investment, worked across a wider range of funds. Some of these took in specific geographical regions, such as South East Asia and Japan.

Stephen Dight, of Grosvenor Financial Services, resisted picking out individual funds, choosing instead to leave the market-guessing to the experts.

He split all but £7,000 between three different strategies operated by Rothschild Asset Management - where the asset manager picks from a range of funds at their own discretion.

Even the £7,000 was invested in a Rothschild Five Arrows Isa. The IFAs also displayed individual styles picking income portfolios. Hollands chose to spread the portfolio between a range of seven corporate bond and other income-producing funds, North chose three income funds, incorporating some capital growth in the form of HSBC's UK Growth & Income fund. Dight kept to his fund of funds method.

'The fund of funds approach really does work,' he says. 'Less paperwork, easy to understand and much lower charges on switching which is effected without any client involvement.'

North said she was fairly pleased with the figures for her income portfolio. 'The yields are excellent, driven by the ABN Amro Equity Income fund - it's been outstanding,' she says.

But the picture is not quite as rosy for her growth portfolio. The rout in internet stock prices hit North's funds quite hard.

Hollands said all the funds he had chosen remained strong contenders in their sectors.

So would the IFAs make any changes to their portfolios now?

Dight says not at this point - and this was the whole idea of choosing the Rothschild funds. Rothschilds can make switches between trusts within its strategies at substantially less cost than those incurred by investors choosing their own funds due to the discounts they can achieve, he points out.

For her income portfolio, North says she would make no changes because none of the funds included have suffered any management changes.

However, even though the growth portfolio's performance was hit by the slump in technology stocks earlier this year, she says she would not rush to change the portfolio's composition just yet.

'We expect that by the end of the year the new economy will have bounced back, so the recommendation on all funds is a hold,' she says.

But she will keep an eye on the Henderson Global Technology Trust, she says, since the staff and managers there have just announced they are leaving to set up a private investment 'boutique'.

The Johnson Fry Slater Growth fund was hit hard by the fall in internet stocks, but North says she is still confident in fund manager Mark Slater's ability to turn performance around.

Hollands says there are a number of elements he would now change in the portfolios, because there have been management various changes.

The money in Gartmore's UK Smaller Companies fund should be switched to Gartmore's UK & Irish Smaller Companies fund, which is smaller and more nimble. The UK-only fund went further up the market capitalisation scale at the wrong time, he says.

Since the manager of the M&G European Smaller Companies fund has left, that investment should be switched to Invesco's European Smaller Companies fund. 'It was very much a one-man bet,' he says.

Management has changed at the Credit Suisse Transatlantic fund too, and Hollands advises jumping ship to the Framlington American Growth fund.

In the income portfolio, Hollands says he would switch the M&G High Yield Corporate Bond Isa for an investment in the Newton European High Yield fund. And he would now sell the stake in the M&G Corporate Bond fund, using the proceeds to buy into the Legal & General Fixed Interest fund. 'The head of the retail team at M&G has gone on a sabbatical,' he says.

This exercise shows how different portfolios can change over just a few months. But the advisers pointed out that the performance is not representative of the growth stocks and shares can achieve - the period was simply too short.

'Nobody should ever go into stocks and shares for a six-month period,' says North. Anyone who might need to use their money in the short-term should choose to keep it in cash.

webTitle: ISAs: Unwary savers break tax rules

fields.headline: Unwary savers break tax rules
fields.standfirst: A lot of us don't know our minis from our maxis when it comes to investing, says  Helen Pridham. And the muddle is putting people on the wrong side of the Revenue
fields.trailText: A lot of us don't know our minis from our maxis when it comes to investing, says Helen Pridham. And the muddle is putting people on the wrong side of the Revenue.
fields.body:
Thousands of people have been unknowingly breaking Isa investment rules and evading tax for the last 18 months.

Individual Savings Accounts have been very successful since their introduction in April 1999, attracting investments worth £28bn in their first year alone, around a third more than the sum put into Peps and Tessas in their last and most popular year on sale .

Richard Wastcoat, managing director of Fidelity Investment Services, one of the largest Isa providers, attributes the Isa's success to the fact that it is a uniform scheme. He says: 'With Isas there is just one message to get across to savers, rather than two as with Peps and Tessas. This helps create greater awareness and it makes it easier to educate people.'

But while the concept of Isas may be easier to grasp, the complexity of the investment rules has proved more difficult for many people. In particular, confusion has arisen from the fact that savers have had to decide between spreading their £7,000 investment allowance between up to three so-called 'mini' Isas or keeping it within one 'maxi'. Soon after Isas were intro duced, the PEP & Isa Managers Association (PIMA) warned that there was growing anecdotal evidence that savers did not appreciate the difference between mini and maxi accounts and were inadvertently taking out multiple Isas without realising they had broken the rules.

Peter Shipp, PIMA technical director, says: 'It was not always the public's fault. During the first six months of Isas, there were plenty of reports of savers being given the wrong information, particularly on the high street.'

However, the Government was reluctant to admit there was a problem until it had hard evidence from the examination of managers' first-year records. These are now in the Inland Revenue's hands, but, according to a spokeswoman, a significant number of managers did not meet the deadline of 1 June, so the process of checking for multiple Isas has been delayed.

'If a problem is discovered, the matter will have to go to a Minister for comment,' she says.

In theory, if it is discovered that someone has taken out both a mini and maxi in the same tax year, they will have the second one they opened voided and any tax relief they have received will be clawed back. However, PIMA believes savers who have made a genuine mistake and have not exceeded the £7,000 Isa limit should not be penalised. Whether the Government will scrap the distinction for the future remains to be seen.

PIMA's Shipp says: 'We have always questioned the need for minis and maxis.' However, Fidelity's Wastcoat does not want to see a single limit. He thinks his company's business might suffer. He argues: 'It would hand the Isa market to the banks. They would encourage savers to put the whole £7,000 into cash instead of investing in shares for the long term.'

Whatever their other complications, the Government clearly felt it could help make Isas more understandable through the introduction of Cat standards. These were a different set of terms and conditions for each Isa component which focused on three aspects - fair Charges, easy Access and decent Terms. Cat standard cash Isas, for example, have to allow withdrawals within seven days and pay interest no lower than 2 per cent below base rate. Cat standard unit trust Isas must have an annual charge of no more than 1 per cent.

However, Cat standards were voluntary and there was no rush among Isa providers to take them up. Currently only 53 out of 136 mini cash Isas listed by the Moneyfacts research organisation are Cat standard, only 20 out of 95 unit trust Isa managers offer them and just one out of 32 investment trust Isa providers.

At one of the refuseniks Aberdeen Asset Managers, sales and marketing manager Richard Wilson explains: 'We are not in favour of Cat standards because we feel investors may see them as a quality endorsement when all they are really doing is flagging up that a fund is cheap.'

However, not everyone is dismissive of Cat standards. At the Halifax, which offers a Cat standard mini-cash Isa and claims to have a 30 per cent share of the cash account market, Nigel Payne, head of savings, believes it has helped to give savers confidence.

'It's difficult to quantify the effect it has had on our business but I'm sure that it has been a reassuring feature for some of our savers,' says Payne.

'It's a bit like the kitemark you get on furniture and so on. Even if you don't know what it means, you feel better about buying it because you know the product conforms to a minimum standard.'

webTitle: You too can wed a tycoon

fields.headline: You too can wed a tycoon
fields.standfirst: Wear natural fabrics, go to Alcoholics Anonymous... Hot tips from  Jill Insley
fields.trailText: Wear natural fabrics, go to Alcoholics Anonymous... Hot tips from Jill Insley.
fields.body:
The American court ruling that valued a former Playboy playmate's marriage to a 90-year-old oil tycoon at $1 million a day is a clear example of the inextricable link between sex and money.

Photographs of the happy couple during their 14 months of marriage would appear to indicate that the late James Howard Marshal was more than content with his side of the deal. And his wife, model Anna Nicole Smith, has consistently said she loved her geriatric husband. How much warmer her feelings towards him must be since she was awarded $449m from his estate last month, even though he inadvertently forgot to include her in his will.

While the more puritanical and idealistic have probably already dismissed Anna Nicole as a gold-digger, albeit a beautiful one, many women may secretly have been wishing they, too, were in the position to attract a billionaire. Even a multi-millionaire would do!

With the advent of the Lottery and dotcom firms, there are far more millionaires in Britain than ever before - about 2,500, according to the Inland Revenue. This covers only those permanently based in this country, not people just passing through.

So, if women were to put their feminist scruples aside, how would they go about marrying one? As with all projects, it's a good idea to read around the subject first. Although British authors are a bit squeamish, American writers have been much more forthcoming. In How to Marry the Rich ($6.29, Berkley Publishing Group, available from www.barnesnoble.com), former stockbroker Ginie Polo Sayles reveals how she snared a Texan oil baron.

Tips include wearing natural fabrics (on the grounds that they are richer-looking), getting a job in the private jet lounge at an airport, attending Alcoholics Anonymous meetings in affluent areas, having a tidy bathroom with just a box of facial tissues on the counter (so that's where I've been going wrong...), and reading obituaries to target rich widowers. Cleavage is also very important.

You may be sceptical, but remember that Polo Sayles' tactics landed her a rich husband who has not yet learnt to say no to shopping sprees.

Slightly more practical is Susan Wright's How to Marry Money - The Rich have to Marry Someone, Why not You?' ($8.05, also from www.barnesnoble.com), which claims that a wealthy spouse is within the grasp of nearly anyone who knows how to go about it. She details where to go to meet a rich spouse, how to dress, how to find out about his finances, what the rich are really looking for, and - crucially - how to get around prenuptial agreements.

But if you really want to understand how to capture the heart of a wealthy man, you are probably best off consulting one. Marry me - Three Professional Men Reveal how to get Mr Right to Pop the Question ($18.36 from www.barnesnoble.com, although the book will be available in the UK from next spring) has been written by a married lawyer, an engaged doctor and a single accountant.

They 'explain the weird alchemy that prevents men from committing, and tell readers how Mr Right can be persuaded to trot down the aisle'. Their advice is based on the belief that one of the most overlooked issues influencing a man's decision to commit is his career. Fit in with that and, apparently, you've cracked it.

But if you feel you have no hope of nailing that millionaire - and let's face it, with just 2,500 to go around some of us are inevitably going to miss out - you'll just have to work on becoming a millionaire in your own right.

Diane Harris, a financial expert on US website ka-ching recommends saving 10 per cent of your salary and half of every pay rise, and putting as much of your long-term savings into shares as your nerves can stand.

She reckons a 30-year-old woman earning $40,000 a year, who gets a 5 per cent pay rise every year and earns an average of 12 per cent on her savings (the average for the US stock market over the past 50 years), will have amassed $250,000 by the age of 45, $500,000 when she hits 50 and the magic $1m at around 55. To check when you will become a millionaire, visit the Ka-ching 'millionaire calculator'. There's no guarantee the news will be good, though - I won't be one until I'm over 100!

Wanted: A bride as rich as I am

You don't even have to leave the comfort of your home to find a suitable bride.

Tobacco heir Patrick Reynolds has been advertising on the internet for a partner. It seems strange that a blue-eyed 51-year-old multi-millionaire living in the fashionable suburb of Brentwood, Los Angeles, has had to resort to blind dating via a website (www.love4two.com), but Reynolds claims that meeting the right woman is not easy.

'I guess I got tired of finding myself in teeming bars, and knowing little or nothing about the women there,' he says. 'I decided it makes more sense to be introduced by someone who knows me - but very privately. So I thought I'd quietly approach friends and acquaintances who might be able to introduce me.'

Reynolds set up his website - which includes a photo album (see above), a section on his work as head of a non-profit organisation campaigning against cigarette smoking, and personal details about himself and what he is looking for in a mate. Then he asked friends to pass on the details to women who matched his criteria. His ideal woman must be aged 28-34, no children but keen to have them, Caucasian, athletic or slender, 5'5" or taller, some education and a non-smoker. But before you get too excited, the future Mrs Reynolds must also come from a wealthy family - the sticking point, no doubt, for many thousands of hopefuls who have visited his site.

Reynolds explains: 'I feel it's important that we have this common ground, this shared experience. There's a whole set of problems that goes with being from a wealthy family, and I'd like someone who shares in and fully understands that.' Ahhhhhh.

As with all projects, it's a good idea to read around the subject first. Although British authors are a bit squeamish, American writers have been much more forthcoming. In How to Marry the Rich ($6.29, Berkley Publishing Group, available from www.barnesnoble.com), former stockbroker Ginie Polo Sayles reveals how she snared a Texan oil baron. Tips include wearing natural fabrics (on the grounds that they are richer-looking), getting a job in the private jet lounge at an airport, attending Alcoholics Anonymous meetings in affluent areas, having a tidy bathroom with just a box of facial tissues on the counter (so that's where I've been going wrong...), and reading obituaries to target rich widowers. Cleavage is also very important. You may be sceptical, but remember that Polo Sayles' tactics landed her a rich husband who has not yet learnt to say no to shopping sprees. Slightly more practical is Susan Wright's How to Marry Money - The Rich have to Marry Someone, Why not You?' ($8.05, also from www.barnesnoble.com), which claims that a wealthy spouse is within the grasp of nearly anyone who knows how to go about it. She details where to go to meet a rich spouse, how to dress, how to find out about his finances, what the rich are really looking for, and - crucially - how to get around prenuptial agreements. But if you really want to understand how to capture the heart of a wealthy man, you are probably best off consulting one. Marry me - Three Professional Men Reveal how to get Mr Right to Pop the Question ($18.36 from www.barnesnoble.com, although the book will be available in the UK from next spring) has been written by a married lawyer, an engaged doctor and a single accountant. They 'explain the weird alchemy that prevents men from committing, and tell readers how Mr Right can be persuaded to trot down the aisle'. Their advice is based on the belief that one of the most overlooked issues influencing a man's decision to commit is his career. Fit in with that and, apparently, you've cracked it. But if you feel you have no hope of nailing that millionaire - and let's face it, with just 2,500 to go around some of us are inevitably going to miss out - you'll just have to work on becoming a millionaire in your own right. Diane Harris, a financial expert on US website ka-ching recommends saving 10 per cent of your salary and half of every pay rise, and putting as much of your long-term savings into shares as your nerves can stand. She reckons a 30-year-old woman earning $40,000 a year, who gets a 5 per cent pay rise every year and earns an average of 12 per cent on her savings (the average for the US stock market over the past 50 years), will have amassed $250,000 by the age of 45, $500,000 when she hits 50 and the magic $1m at around 55. To check when you will become a millionaire, visit the Ka-ching 'millionaire calculator'. There's no guarantee the news will be good, though - I won't be one until I'm over 100! Wanted: A bride as rich as I am You don't even have to leave the comfort of your home to find a suitable bride. Tobacco heir Patrick Reynolds has been advertising on the internet for a partner. It seems strange that a blue-eyed 51-year-old multi-millionaire living in the fashionable suburb of Brentwood, Los Angeles, has had to resort to blind dating via a website (www.love4two.com), but Reynolds claims that meeting the right woman is not easy. 'I guess I got tired of finding myself in teeming bars, and knowing little or nothing about the women there,' he says. 'I decided it makes more sense to be introduced by someone who knows me - but very privately. So I thought I'd quietly approach friends and acquaintances who might be able to introduce me.' Reynolds set up his website - which includes a photo album (see above), a section on his work as head of a non-profit organisation campaigning against cigarette smoking, and personal details about himself and what he is looking for in a mate. Then he asked friends to pass on the details to women who matched his criteria. His ideal woman must be aged 28-34, no children but keen to have them, Caucasian, athletic or slender, 5'5" or taller, some education and a non-smoker. But before you get too excited, the future Mrs Reynolds must also come from a wealthy family - the sticking point, no doubt, for many thousands of hopefuls who have visited his site. Reynolds explains: 'I feel it's important that we have this common ground, this shared experience. There's a whole set of problems that goes with being from a wealthy family, and I'd like someone who shares in and fully understands that.' Ahhhhhh.

fields.standfirst: NPI Socially Responsible Bond
fields.trailText: NPI Socially Responsible Bond
fields.body:
Contact: 01892 596098

Aim: To provide a lower risk way to achieve growth through socially responsible investment.

Bells & whistles: NPI says its new socially responsible with- profits fund, offered as part of the package, is unique in enabling ethical investment without direct stock market exposure.

How it works: The bond offers a choice of funds in any combination: the with profits fund, and NPI's unit linked Global Care (average annual return 12.6%) and Global Care Managed (average annual return 13.1%) funds. The with profits fund will invest in Global Care Managed fund. The funds are all managed by Henderson, NPI's sister company. The with profits fund will award an initial annual bonus of 5 per cent. Up to 10 per cent can be withdrawn each year without penalty.

Minimum: £10,000

Charges: No initial charge. Allocation rates range from 100% to 103.5%. Annual charges 1.25 % for unit linked funds, and built in to with profits fund.Withdrawals over 10 % in the first five years incurr penalties - 9 % of the withdrawl in the first year,decreasing by 2 % each year to 1% in the fifth. Withdrawals from the with profits fund after a market fall may result in an investment devaluation by NPI.

Tax: Returns are taxed within the funds, so basic rate tax payers have no further tax to pay. Higher rate payers can withdraw up to 5 per cent of the original investment each year, deferring payment of extra tax until the entire investment is withdrawn. Non tax payers cannot reclaim tax already paid.

Risk: Medium

Should you buy it? Ian Beestin of The With Profits Bond Shop in Nottingham says this is not the best with-profits bond, but it is an excellent development for ethical investors. He recommends ethical investors stick to the with profits fund, and use an ISA for investing in other funds.

John Turton of Best Investment in London rates Henderson but doubts if people over 60 will be interested in ethical investment.

Points out of 10: Beestin - 7, Turton - 6.

webTitle: Property: Cut down the stress - hire an e-solicitor

fields.headline: Cut down the stress - hire an e-solicitor
fields.trailText: Half of the people who say they had problems in house buying or selling say the cause was due to 'delays by solicitors', according to research conducted by law firm HammondsDirect.
fields.body:
If you have ever felt that you would like to murder a solicitor, you are not alone. Half of the people who say they had problems in house buying or selling say the cause was due to 'delays by solicitors', according to research conducted by law firm HammondsDirect.

But help is at hand. Hammonds recently launched an e-conveyancing service which, it says, will deliver a much quicker and more efficient service.

The firm, which has been involved in e-conveyancing for the Halifax and other lenders for nearly three years, estimates that it cuts the length of the process from 12 to eight weeks.

Other firms are likely to follow suit. The Society for Licensed Conveyancers has agreed to provide e-conveyancing for the homebuying site www.easier.com.

E-loan, the online mortgage quotation and arrangement site, also wants to set up an e-conveyancing capability. 'In theory, searches could be done instantly,' says product development director Frank Eve. 'Buying a house is very stressful - but it becomes less stressful if you know what is happening. Under the current system, what tends to happen is that people ring their solicitors to find out, but have difficulty getting a reply. Solicitors tend to be busy people. And if you don't know what is happening on the transaction, you tend to fill the vacuum with negative thoughts.'

On the Hammonds Direct site, legalmove.com, clients can access their case file 24 hours a day on a secure part of the site. They can read all the relevant documents as they are created or as they arrive - the contract agreement, the leasehold or the fixtures and fittings list, for example. They can also see whether the searches have been applied for and what responses were received.

Hammonds Direct has not, however, set out to be the cheapest player in the business. Its fees for most properties will be between £299 and £499, depending on the purchase price.

Lucci Dammone, who has masterminded legalmove.com, says the emphasis is more on providing an efficient, transparent service than on shaving the fees to the minimum. 'The conveyancing service is ideally suited to using the internet,' he says.

If local authorities also went online, searches could be done in a matter of seconds, rather than the fortnight that it often takes now. But progress of this order will take a few years yet: only a quarter of local authorities are thought to have converted to an electronic system.

And solicitors have been slow to embrace the new world of the web in this field. Many are worried that they could lose some of their profit margin if they switch from a labour-intensive service to one that makes more use of computers. But now that the first firms have started offering their services, however, other firms are more likely to feel the heat of competition.

The service being developed by the Society for Licensed Conveyancers will also focus on service delivery rather than marketing itself on price. About 24 firms are planning to take part in the scheme. Each will be able to set its own charges. 'The web brings about a very high degree of transparency,' says society chief executive Nigel Ewert Evans.

Conveyancing charges now average £397 on an £80,000 sale, according to the Woolwich, and £415 on an £80,000 purchase. Fees are only slightly lower on a £60,000 transaction - £372 and £390 respectively.

webTitle: Property: Going parking mad? Make space to relax

fields.headline: Going parking mad? Make space to relax
fields.standfirst: A driveway or garage is guaranteed to boost your home's value, writes  Graham Norwood
fields.trailText: A driveway or garage is guaranteed to boost your home's value, writes Graham Norwood.
fields.body:
Which one piece of work adds the most value to your house? A swimming pool for post-Olympics fitness fanatics? Or a conservatory to take advantage of an occasional sunny afternoon?

Neither, but convert some of your garden into hard- standing for a car, or build a garage, and you could add £20,000 or more to the value of your home - and cut your motor insurance premiums, too.

Across the UK there are more than a million vehicle crimes recorded annually, at a cost of £3 billion in terms of personal loss, rising insurance premiums and use of police time. They range from scratched paintwork, through stolen radios to theft of the vehicle itself . There were 400,000 cars stolen in 1999, according to Home Office figures.

Little wonder that off-street parking is such a bonus in a property, according to estate agents. The benefits are greatest in cities, where controlled parking zones mean demand exceeds supply. Streets are often narrow, and large houses have been converted into flats, creating four or five car-owners where there used to be one or two.

'In central or north Oxford, it is only the larger four- to five-bedroom semi-detached or detached houses that have off-street parking or a garage,' says William Kirkland of estate agency Cluttons. 'Parking in Oxford is very limited. People who live in the area realise this and tend to use bikes as their main means of transport.

'It's very rare for someone not to consider a property in Oxford simply because it doesn't have off-street parking - but those which do have it are definitely in demand and command a premium of £10,000 or £20,000.'

In central London the added value of a parking space is much, much higher. 'Properties with parking in areas such as Chelsea and South Kensington can command up to an additional £100,000,' claims estate agent Nicholas Pearce.

Harlequin Court, which is being built in part of the Strand Palace Hotel in London's Covent Garden, will include only six parking spaces for 42 apartments, Each space is selling for £40,000, so it is likely that owners will let out their spaces - spaces nearby are being rented at up to £12,000 per year.

'Charging extra for parking makes people think about whether or not they really want a space for their car,' says central London estate agent Linda Beaney. 'Not everyone does, so this frees up additional spaces for, say, the larger units or the penthouses, where the buyer may require more than one parking lot.'

In more sensibly priced areas the cost is still high if parking is at a premium. Garages in St Albans, home to thousands of London commuters, have changed hands for £15,000. In the south Devon farming village of Blackawton, where there is next to no car crime, a breeze-block garage was recently on sale for £11,000.

Ironically, two new envi ronment-friendly measures may make a parking space even more valuable.

First, Ken Livingstone's proposals for congestion charges in the centre of London may force commuters to go by train or bus, but this will force them to leave their cars in the suburbs, exacerbating parking problems in residential streets.

Second, residential developers are coming to terms with the Government's advice to planning authorities in March 1999 that densities in new developments should be increased, and that this could be achieved partly by reducing the recommended number of parking spaces. A new Planning Policy Guideline encourages councils to cut car spaces for new developments to a maximum of two per dwelling, making it difficult for builders to match customers' expectations with planning regulations.

'In many cases purchasers will not buy a property if parking is not included,' warns Ian Plumley of new-build specialist Berkeley Homes. All of which means that converting all or part of a front garden into a parking space could increase your house's value - even if it does little for the view from the front room. Note that if you put in an access ramp you will probably need planning permission.

Of course the extra space will do nothing at all to ease parking in your street because the need for free access to the ramp will effectively remove one kerb parking space.

But if you do succeed in getting your car off the street, there is an extra bonus in the form of lower insurance premiums.

'Most insurers will offer a discount if your car is in a secure area off the street, especially if it's a garage rather than a driveway,' says a spokesman for the Association of British Insurers.

'That will vary across the country and from urban to rural locations. In exceptional circumstances, it's possible the insurer might even insist the vehicle is parked in a garage to get insurance at all,' he says.

Incidentally, if you want to get that swimming pool installed, think again. Estate agents say an indoor pool is the most consistent cause of houses losing value - no matter how good the parking may be.

webTitle: Wealthcheck: Teacher who needs tuition in pensions

fields.headline: Teacher who needs tuition in pensions
fields.standfirst: With a lacklustre retirement fund and fixed mortgage, room for manoeuvre is slight, writes  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: With a lacklustre retirement fund and fixed mortgage, room for manoeuvre is slight, writes Helen Pridham.
fields.body:
Lynne Wright
Age 42
Lives in West London
Occupation Teacher
Earns £15,156 per annum
Mortgage £52,000
Debts None
Investments £3,000 in Egg account
Pension £70 a month into Windsor Life plan
Aims Sort out pension, reinvest savings for better return, remortgage

Lynne Wright teaches English as a second language in a private language school in west London. For her students, getting to grips with all the exceptions that make up our mother tongue cannot be easy. For Lynne, it is pensions and investments that cause a headache.

She is worried about the personal pension she took out with insurer Gan when she opted out of the State Earnings Related Pension Scheme (Serps) in 1992. Gan was taken over by Windsor Life and recent bad press about the company's investment performance has made Lynne unhappy.

'I wrote to the company expressing my concerns and got a letter back which admitted to the underperformance of some funds but assured me things would be OK in the long run,' says an unconvinced Lynne. 'I don't feel confident in the firm,' she says.

Yet she finds herself in a dilemma because she feels she would lose out if she tried to transfer her pension fund elsewhere.

Lynne would like to increase her contributions but does not want to do so if she is not going to get a good deal. She now puts aside just under £70 a month, although she has saved more in the past. Her last statement from Windsor Life put the value of her voluntary contributions to her Personal Wealth Plan at £16,448 and her Serps con tribution rebates at £6,373. The plan's transfer value - the amount she would get if she switched - was only £17,023.

Her employer does not provide a scheme, although the school employs seven full-time staff and six or seven more working casually. Lynne knows 'stakeholder pensions are a possibility' but the school principal has not yet told staff his intentions about the new Government-backed scheme, which starts next April.

She has recently been saving £50 a month in an Egg account, and could afford to put aside around £20 a month more.

Is there anything better she could be doing with this money, she asks. So far she has £3,000 in the Egg account and would like a better return. She has been considering switching to another high interest bank or building society account.

Her mortgage concerns her too. Like many borrowers who feared a return to higher interest rates a few years ago, in 1997 she took out a five-year fixed-rate loan at 7.89 per cent. Ordinary mortgage rates declined, and she is still paying more than the current variable rate of 7.74 per cent charged by most large lenders.

She has thought about remortgaging, but her bank, NatWest, said early redemption would cost her more than £900 in penalties, which appears to cancel out any advantage.

Adviser 1: Amanda Davidson

Lynne has an old-style pension that locks you in and penalises you heavily for moving. There is unlikely to be anything that she can do about this.

She is right that stakeholder pensions will be with us in about six months' time. Her firm will have to provide one of these pensions as there are more than five staff. It could be advantageous for Lynne to participate, particularly if her employer decides to contribute. She should keep up with any plans it may have before deciding what to do.

Meanwhile, she could put the money into an individual savings account (Isa). This, while not giving her tax relief on contributions as a pension would, would enable her to benefit in future from a tax-free fund, from which she could draw a tax-free income. This has become a good alternative to pensions for basic-rate taxpayers such because annuity rates are so low.

The savings in the Egg account could be transferred into a mini-cash Isa. Up to £3,000 can be placed in these without any tax on the interest.

Lynne could ask her lender, to waive the penalties, giving her a fresh deal. If that only locked her further into her current scheme or she fails to improve it, she should wait until 2002 and renegotiate.

Finally, she should make sure that if she or her husband fell ill they could repay their mortgage. They need either health or critical-illness insurance.

Amanda Davidson works for financial adviser Holden Meehan.

Adviser 2: Steven Price

The £3,000 Lynne has saved for emergencies should go into a tax-free mini- cash Isa.

Remortgaging would bring exit and entry costs if a further fixed-rate loan was taken out. Lynne already puts the fees for leaving her current loan at more than £900. Arranging another five-year fixed loan would cost between £350 and £600, though this could be added to the new loan.

There are some very competitive deals available, and she could benefit from remortgaging in the short to medium term. The Britannia and the Leeds & Holbeck offer five-year fixed rates of 6.39 per cent and 6.44 per cent respectively. Yet it would take Lynne between 16 and 24 months to break even on the exit and entry costs. She should first ask NatWest to put the loan on more favourable terms for little or no penalty.

Lynne could go on with her present pension until she knows what her employer will offer. She could check the costs of reinstating her contributions to the original level of £140 with Windsor Life. The initial charges may have been largely taken out, so the ongoing fees could be relatively cheap.

Lynne should ask Windsor Life and a rival firm - of her own choice or her employer's in a year's time - how much she could expect at retirement if she did raise her contributions to the old level. Then she can consider her options in more detail.

Steven Price works for financial adviser Towry Law.

Advice is for guidance only.

 Do you want to appear in Wealthcheck? Write, including daytime and evening telephone numbers, a brief list of circumstances and any investments, to: Wealthcheck, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail: cash@observer.co.uk. You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

Her last statement from Windsor Life put the value of her voluntary contributions to her Personal Wealth Plan at £16,448 and her Serps con tribution rebates at £6,373. The plan's transfer value - the amount she would get if she switched - was only £17,023. Her employer does not provide a scheme, although the school employs seven full-time staff and six or seven more working casually. Lynne knows 'stakeholder pensions are a possibility' but the school principal has not yet told staff his intentions about the new Government-backed scheme, which starts next April. She has recently been saving £50 a month in an Egg account, and could afford to put aside around £20 a month more. Is there anything better she could be doing with this money, she asks. So far she has £3,000 in the Egg account and would like a better return. She has been considering switching to another high interest bank or building society account. Her mortgage concerns her too. Like many borrowers who feared a return to higher interest rates a few years ago, in 1997 she took out a five-year fixed-rate loan at 7.89 per cent. Ordinary mortgage rates declined, and she is still paying more than the current variable rate of 7.74 per cent charged by most large lenders. She has thought about remortgaging, but her bank, NatWest, said early redemption would cost her more than £900 in penalties, which appears to cancel out any advantage. Adviser 1: Amanda Davidson Lynne has an old-style pension that locks you in and penalises you heavily for moving. There is unlikely to be anything that she can do about this. She is right that stakeholder pensions will be with us in about six months' time. Her firm will have to provide one of these pensions as there are more than five staff. It could be advantageous for Lynne to participate, particularly if her employer decides to contribute. She should keep up with any plans it may have before deciding what to do. Meanwhile, she could put the money into an individual savings account (Isa). This, while not giving her tax relief on contributions as a pension would, would enable her to benefit in future from a tax-free fund, from which she could draw a tax-free income. This has become a good alternative to pensions for basic-rate taxpayers such because annuity rates are so low. The savings in the Egg account could be transferred into a mini-cash Isa. Up to £3,000 can be placed in these without any tax on the interest. Lynne could ask her lender, to waive the penalties, giving her a fresh deal. If that only locked her further into her current scheme or she fails to improve it, she should wait until 2002 and renegotiate. Finally, she should make sure that if she or her husband fell ill they could repay their mortgage. They need either health or critical-illness insurance. Amanda Davidson works for financial adviser Holden Meehan. Adviser 2: Steven Price The £3,000 Lynne has saved for emergencies should go into a tax-free mini- cash Isa. Remortgaging would bring exit and entry costs if a further fixed-rate loan was taken out. Lynne already puts the fees for leaving her current loan at more than £900. Arranging another five-year fixed loan would cost between £350 and £600, though this could be added to the new loan. There are some very competitive deals available, and she could benefit from remortgaging in the short to medium term. The Britannia and the Leeds & Holbeck offer five-year fixed rates of 6.39 per cent and 6.44 per cent respectively. Yet it would take Lynne between 16 and 24 months to break even on the exit and entry costs. She should first ask NatWest to put the loan on more favourable terms for little or no penalty. Lynne could go on with her present pension until she knows what her employer will offer. She could check the costs of reinstating her contributions to the original level of £140 with Windsor Life. The initial charges may have been largely taken out, so the ongoing fees could be relatively cheap. Lynne should ask Windsor Life and a rival firm - of her own choice or her employer's in a year's time - how much she could expect at retirement if she did raise her contributions to the old level. Then she can consider her options in more detail. Steven Price works for financial adviser Towry Law. Advice is for guidance only.  Do you want to appear in Wealthcheck? Write, including daytime and evening telephone numbers, a brief list of circumstances and any investments, to: Wealthcheck, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail: cash@observer.co.uk. You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

fields.headline: Help!
fields.standfirst: I have an income drawdown pension. When should I buy an annuity?
fields.trailText: I have an income drawdown pension. When should I buy an annuity?
fields.body:
Income drawdown gets round today's problem of low annuity rates. It is suitable for people with pension funds above £250,000 who do not need to squeeze the maximum income from this money and can afford the risk that their income might reduce.

On retirement, you can take the tax-free cash sum from your pension fund and then draw an income from the balance, which would otherwise buy the annuity. As well as avoiding low annuity rates, you may choose income drawdown because:

a) Your pension fund continues to grow, so you have more with which to buy an annuity eventually;

b) You want to decide how your money is invested;

c) The older you are when you buy an annuity, the better rate you get;

d) You do not need all the income an annuity provides;

e) You want your beneficiaries to inherit your fund.(Once you buy an annuity, the insurer keeps your capital.)

You can continue income drawdown until you are 75, when you must buy an annuity by law. The only reasons to buy an annuity sooner are if your health changes; you can no longer afford investment risk; you need more income; or annuity rates have risen so high they are worth buying (which is not happening). Re-evaluate every year.

If you contract an illness that shortens your life expectancy, you can buy an impaired life annuity, which pays more from the outset, making them better value.

Once started, stay with income drawdown as long as possible, so your investments have time to grow to counterbalance the outgoings. The Government restricts how much you can take under income drawdown, and this is less than annuities pay. Ensure you are not withdrawing so much that it eats into your capital, otherwise you will end up with less for the eventual annuity.

Peter Quinton, managing director of The Annuity Bureau, advises: 'What is regarded as a conservative amount varies according to your age. Around 6 per cent is a sensible level.'

 Income Drawdown Advisory Bureau: 020 7401 2040

fields.headline: Endowed with sense of loss
fields.standfirst: Victims of mis-selling must continue to fight for a fair deal, writes  Maria Scott
fields.trailText: Victims of mis-selling must continue to fight for a fair deal, writes Maria Scott.
fields.body:
You have an endowment mortgage and have been told that the insurance policy may not pay off the loan. It's come as a shock because you don't remember any warning from the salesman. In fact, you remember lots of talk about how you'd end up with more than you'd need. You feel cheated and misled. But you have no paperwork to prove what was said by the salesman, and he's probably long since left the building society that sold you the endowment.

This set of circumstances will be familiar to millions of homeowners. Last week these people were told by the watchdog set up to protect their interests that they may have no reason to complain, even though they face unexpected financial outlay to ensure their homeloans are repaid. Bafflingly, they are probably even better off with an endowment, argues the watchdog, than if they had taken out an old-fashioned capital repayment loan.

Announcing plans for a clean-up of the endowment industry, the Financial Services Authority said that potential shortfalls on an endowment were not grounds for compensation and, even where homeowners were not warned that the product may not repay their loans, compensation still may not be payable. The view is spelt out starkly in a leaflet published by the FSA last week: 'Just because you have a valid complaint doesn't mean you have lost out financially. If you haven't lost out financially, you won't be due compensation, even if you were not given suitable advice.'

Six million households are relying on one or more endowment policies to repay their mortgages - there are 11 million policies in total - and around 6 million of these, affecting about 4 million households, are expected to fall short of their mortgage targets.

The reason for this is that returns on the endowment policies are expected to fall. News that 4 million homeowners may not have enough money set aside to repay their loans is shocking in itself. Many will feel that they were not given adequate warning that their endowments were a bomb waiting to explode.

But the FSA has rejected the idea that all past endowment sales should be reviewed by the insurers who sold the plans, on the grounds that such an exercise would be too costly and policyholders would end up paying, through even lower returns than those now forecast. To back its view it has compared the performance of endowments so far, with that of repayments. It gives the example of a 25-year £50,000 mortgage, taken out on 1 August 1990. A unit-linked endowment policy for such a mortgage could be expected to be worth £11,465. If the homeowner had taken out a repayment loan they would have repaid £9,674, so the endowment borrower is £1,791 better off.

Because there has been no loss, says the FSA, no com pensation would be due, even if the homeowner had been given unsuitable advice. The FSA acknowledges that homeowners may need to 'boost their savings' to repay their loans but brushes aside any disappointment with the statement that 'most of those concerned will have benefited from the general reduction in mortgage interest rates'.

However, homeowners unhappy with their endowments should not be deterred from complaining by the FSA's figures. If the Ombudsman were to look at their claims, he would measure the value of their endowment now by looking at the surrender value that the insurer would pay if it were cashed in. This is not the same figure as that used by the FSA to measure the investment growth; this assumes charges are spread across the life of the policy whereas, in reality, they are deducted early in the term.

The FSA's strategy for dealing with endowments was widely criticised.

The consumer panel set up to monitor the FSA said it was 'particularly concerned that companies' inadequate records may have helped some sales people to get away with giving poor advice'.

Sheila McKechnie, director of the Consumers' Association, said the FSA's view was 'simply incomplete'.

McKechnie also points out that the FSA's approach 'places the burden on consumers'. The FSA does acknowledge that mis-selling has gone on, and still goes on, and is investigating certain firms. These firms will be named and possibly fined, and will be asked to contact policyholders who received poor advice.

Customers of other firms are on their own.

Got a shortfall?

If you have no case for redress, the first options to consider are:

Taking out a repayment loan to pay off the shortfall

Save in an Isa

Surrendering a policy should be a last resort. Remember that you may need the life insurance in the endowment.

webTitle: Praise the north: Making do in London

fields.headline: Making do in London
fields.standfirst: Jill Insley  on how to survive life in the capital's property jungle
fields.trailText: Jill Insley on how to survive life in the capital's property jungle.
fields.body:
The cost of putting a roof over your head in London is daunting, but there are a few ways to reduce the burden.

Move to a cheaper part of town

Although properties are much more expensive in London than anywhere else in the country, there is a wide variation in prices throughout the capital. Generally, the further from the centre you live the more you will get for your money. While £150,000 might buy you a dog kennel in Chelsea or South Kensington (if you are lucky), the same amount could buy you a two-bedroom house in Tooting. If you have to live in an expensive area because of work, ask local estate agents if there are pockets of housing that represent better value for money compared to their fashionable neighbours. Cash-strapped buyers usually look in the area immediately next to the one that they really want to live in, but can't afford.

However, Yolande Barnes, head of research at agent FPD Savills, says that in a housing market that is on the turn (as London seems to be), this can be a dangerous ploy. She warns that property prices in the 'poor man's alternative' areas are much more volatile than those in consistently popular areas, and that people buying at the top of the market could soon find themselves sitting on a loss.

However, if you are buying on a budget, you will have little choice. Instead of looking in:

 Islington, former home of the Blairs, consider Stoke Newington, where £150,000 will buy you a two-bedroom flat in a mansion block;

 Chiswick consider Brentford where £155,000 will buy you a two-bedroom house;

 Clapham consider Tooting or Streatham, where £138,000 buys you a two-bedroom house;

 Fulham, consider Putney, where £149,950 will buy you a three-bedroom split-level maisonette;

 Blackheath, consider Catford, where £158,000 will buy a three-bedroom terraced house on the Corbett Estate.

Take in a lodger

Take advantage of the fact that some people cannot afford to buy in London by renting out a room in your house. Under the Rent-a-Room scheme, you can take in a lodger and charge up to £4,250 during the current tax year (or £81 a week) without paying any income tax (any rent over this amount will be liable for tax at your highest rate). You cannot, however, claim any expenses or capital allowances. The Inland Revenue publishes a leaflet IR87 Letting And Your Home, available free via internet, www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk or by calling the Orderline on 08459 000404.

Check mortgage and insurance

If you have lived in your home for a few years and have had the same mortgage and house and contents insurance since you moved in, you can probably save money by switching.

Ray Boulger of London independent financial advisers John Charcol says someone paying the typical variable rate of 7.74 per cent on a £150,000 repayment mortgage would be paying £1,145 a month. But if they remortgaged to a Coventry Building Society mortgage discounted by 2.46 per cent (to a rate of 5.24 per cent) until 31 December 2002 (with free legal fees and valuation but an arrangement fee of £195), they would pay just £908 a month - a saving of £237.

Likewise there is little benefit to be gained in staying with the same house and contents insurer. Ask an insurance broker such as People's Choice (0800 112233) to check out quotes on your behalf, and shop around some of the direct insurers yourself, such as Churchill (0800200345) or Eagle Star (0800 868686).

Do holiday swaps

Just because you find London a strain, it doesn't stop other people wanting to visit for a holiday. Save money while seeing the world by swapping your home for another in a more exotic location. Several organisations publish directories of home swaps, and you can get your home listed for as little as US$30 (£20). Check out home swap websites:

 www.homelink.org - annual subscription £95, lists 2,000 properties in 50 countries;

 www.wwhec.com - £40 fee to have your home listed, plus £10 if you want a photo included, 330 homes on books;

 www.homebase-hols.com - membership starts from £38, 3,000 listing worldwide, with 33 per cent in the US, and the bulk of the rest in Europe.

 www.homeexchange.com - joining fee of $30, site based in Santa Barbara, California, with 1,500 listings on its database.

If all else fails, move out of London

Milton Keynes is the most popular destination for evacuees, according to the Regional Trends survey. But if concrete cows don't take your fancy, you could swap your £350,000 Balham terrace with 50ft garden for a £345,000 four-bedroom house with stables and four acres on the south side of Harrogate, leaving you£5,000 for a horse - or a six-bedroom farmhouse with four acres for £300,000 in Westhoughton, near Manchester (both properties on www.easier.co.uk)

The internet is a good place to start if you have no firm location ideas. Try www.rightmove.co.uk, www.assertahome.com and www.home.co.uk to get an idea of what you can buy nationwide. If you want to check out schools, try www.dfee.gov.uk for state school performance tables and www.whichschool.co.uk for private schools.

New town, new life in Milton Keynes

If you are looking for an alternative to London but still need to be within commuting distance, what about Milton Keynes? The new town is the most popular destination in the UK for people moving home, according to the Regional Trends survey. Its population grew by 60 per cent between 1981 and 1998.

Liz Clarke, a 29-year old project administrator, has experienced both places. 'I was born and grew up in Milton Keynes, moved to London when I was 19, and came back to Milton Keynes after travelling. I found it really dull as a teenager, but the town has changed out of all recognition since then,' she says.

The town used to lack an infrastructure, she says, with no real high street and no community feel. But now Milton Keynes has developed a thriving shopping centre over the years, with a John Lewis, Marks & Spencer, Top Shop, Hennes and a recently opened Debenhams. A piazza has built up around the town's theatre, encour aging a cafe-society feel to evenings out.

And although Milton Keynes is just 35 minutes from London by train, with Oxford and Cambridge just 35 miles away in opposite directions, property prices are relatively low. You can buy a two-bedroom flat for £50,000 and a four-bedroom house with double garage for £140,000. But a disadvantage is that you really need a car to get around from one section of town to another.

Nor is there any shortage in employment, with companies such as Abbey National, Minolta, Mercedes, IBM and BT having bases there. 'I've never been out of work for more than three days,' says Liz.

But although there are attractive villages in the vicinity such as Newport Pagnell and Stoney Stratford, she admits the town itself still lacks character.

Now she is on the move again. Last week Liz swapped a one-bedroom flat in Newport Pagnell, which she had been renting for £385 a month, for a smaller one-bedroom flat off Clapham Common in South London for £800 a month. She hopes the move will enable her to move into media-related work and add spice to her leisure time. 'Milton Keynes is fantastic for families. It's got everything you need then. Maybe in 10 years I'll settle down here.'
