fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Wembley special: Towers exclusive
fields.body:
Wembley special: Towers exclusive

Plans to move the famous twin towers to the new national rugby league museum in Widnes have been threatened by an ambitious proposal to ship out and reconstruct them at the base of the Annapurna mountains in Nepal, according to a document passed to Observer Sport. The plan, a rival to the £3m bid backed by Halton Borough Council, is the brainchild of a Nepalese multi-millionaire who made his money from selling Indian food in Britain. An artist's impression of the scheme shows only half the story: The idea is to incorporate the towers into a new syncretic centre of unified Hindu, Buddhist and Tantric worship. The millionaire is said to have visited Wembley in 1989 for the Sherpa Van Trophy final between Bolton and Torquay, since when he has wanted to recreate the binding 'venue of legends' spirit in rural Nepal. 'He's a big fan of the beautiful towers,' says a bid insider. 'He believes they will bring great peace and happiness to our people, as they have done in Brent for 77 years.' An FA spokesman denied knowledge of the scheme and said the artist's impression looked 'remarkably like the new menu cover from the Wembley Tandoori'.

Win: top tickets, top night

Just hours before demolition begins, Wembley will host a massive New Year's Eve-style farewell bash: tickets are on sale now (020 8947 1881), but we've a top-of-the-range pair to give away. The 'AXA Final Ball' event on 2 November will see 2,000 celebrities celebrating the personal achievements of sportsmen and women at the stadium, and raising £1m for the NSPCC'S Full Stop campaign. To win our exclusive pair of seats for the night, priced at £3,000, answer this:

What was the name of the white horse in the 1923 White Horse final? a) Billie b) Alf c) Trevor?

Send your answer and details to AXA Final Ball, Observer Sport, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1M 5RS.

Other news: Jesus, panties and bras

Atletico Madrid president Jesus Gil - who, as predicted here two weeks ago sacked his twenty-third manager on Monday and appointed his 24th - has been answering charges of frittering $800,000 of club money on women's underwear and photos of Franco. Gil was challenged over the expenses last week by administrators investigating Atletico's debts. They found 150 million pesetas had been spent on dubious items - with baby clothes, perfume and kitchen accessories among the other items on Gil's list of essentials. Gil, though, says they were gifts for visiting officials. 'No one told me there was a prohibition on panties and bras,' Gil told the court. He also justified the redecoration of one of his houses with club funds, denied alleged illegal financing of his political party GIL, and refuted allegations of misuse of funds in his role as flamboyant mayor of Marbella. The entertaining hearing goes on.

The longest ball: part two

Jamie Clapham to Mark Venus - 25 million miles: was it the longest ball ever played? Not according to a strangely large volume of responses to last week's item. Although Tim Stevens of London missed the point by offering Sheffield United's Curtis Woodhouse (Cumbria) to Bruno Ribiero (north Brazil) at 4,689 miles - falling 24.99 million miles short - Gavin Huggett's 26.5m light years from Tottenham's Justin Edinburgh to Ramon Vega (the brightest star in the Lyra constellation) looks unbeatable. (Baz Sheridan's theological bender from Socrates to Jesus was disqualified.)

Win: Sportal trip to San Siro

British web company Sportal - producers of last summer's Euro 2000 website - have launched their Champions League shirt sponsorship of Juventus and juventus.com by offering S&D readers a chance to see Juve play AC Milan later this month. The trip to the San Siro for the 21 October game includes flights and a four-star hotel. To enter, answer this: euro2000.org received 1.41 billion hits, making the site officially the most popular football website in internet history. But how many punters mistyped and made euro200.org - a blank purple page - almost as popular? a) 9,816, b) 21,281, c) 54,075. All entries to reach us by Friday - write to Sportal Competition, Observer Sport, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1M 5RS, or email sport@observer.co.uk.

Tales from the Tabs

RANIERI'S £7M SWOOPNew Chelsea boss Claudio Ranieri last night lodged a £3m bid for Deportivo La Coruna's Savisa Jokanovic and made a £4m salary offer to AC Milan reject Zvonimir Boban. Ranieri is said to be 'desperate' to build up his midfield in the wake of Roberto Di Matteo's injury - Real Madrid's Savio remains a target.

TOON CLOSE ON ACUNANewcastle have had a £1m bid for controversial Chilean midfielder Clarence Acuna accepted. Acuna spent two weeks on trial from Universidad de Chile last month - Bobby Robson followed up with a bid yesterday after Man City expressed their interest. Personal terms and a work permit, though, could be a problem.

SAINTS SPLASH CASHSouthampton boss Glenn Hoddle has made a club record £2m bid to land Dundee's Scotland B keeper Robert Douglas. Hoddle wants to replace struggling Paul Jones, and placed the bid after Celtic showed an interest. Hoddle could finance the deal by selling club icon Matt Le Tissier to Crystal Palace.

Jens Nowotny's £15m move from Bayer Leverkusen to Arsenal could go through this week after the defender spoke of his admiration for Arsenal's pitches. 'They have 10 pitches which is very interesting,' says Nowotny. A deal for B93 Copenhagen's young right-back Per Kroldrup is also close, as is the arrival of Feyenoord keeper Jerzy Dudek.

 Aston Villa will reopen talks for Sheffield Wednesday's wantaway Belgian Gilles De Bilde tomorrow.

 Bradford have been knocked back by Everton in their attempt to sign Richard Dunne - Sunderland and Middlesbrough are also keen.

 Charlton have denied making a £2m bid for Leicester's Frank Sinclair.

 Christian Panucci has told Chelsea he'd like to play for Real Madrid instead: 'Whenever I hear of Real, it raises the hairs on the back of my neck.' A £10m deal for Portuguese star Rui Costa is still under discussion.

 Colin Hendry has slammed Coventry for running a hate campaign against him: 'I am a big boy but being booed and jeered is not on.'

 Jim Smith says he'll be sacked soon unless Derby start winning.

 Everton are battling Aston Villa in the race to sign Liverpool reject Steve Staunton.

 Gert Verheyen says he still hopes to join Ipswich despite Bruges rejecting two bids: 'I've set my mind on playing for Ipswich'.

 Leeds youngster Alan Maybury could make his loan move to Crewe permanent.

 Peter Taylor says Leicester won't be spending again until the EU secure the transfer market.

 Liverpool have offered Michael Owen a new 10-year deal.

 Man City want Chilean star Clarence Acuna on trial.

 Hamburg winger Mehdi Mahdavikia has refused to join Manchester United.

 Middlesbrough are battling Leeds to land Australian Simon Colosimo.

 Newcastle are keen on Wrexham midfielder Carlos Edwards.

 Southampton are favourites to land Sheffield Wednesday's Andy Hinchcliffe.

 Milton Nunez says life in Sunderland isn't as bleak as he expected: 'I'm enjoying it. Now I just hope to get a chance in the first team.'

 Celtic have made a new £1m enquiry for Tottenham's Ian Walker - George Graham wants £1.5m.

 West Ham have sent scouts to check on Wigan keeper Roy Carroll - Leicester, Newcastle and Liverpool will rival any bid.

fields.headline: Welsh gloat is too early
fields.standfirst: Wales (Blake 60) 1 - 1 Norway (Helstad 80)
fields.trailText: For twenty minutes yesterday, life was just perfect in the Principality. Wales were leading 1-0 and seemingly on the verge of a memorable victory, while events across the border were raising more than a titter. 'Are you watching, Eng-er-land,' they chanted mischievously, but it was too good to last. Within three minutes of coming off the bench, Thorstein Helstad deflated the home crowd with a scrambled equaliser. It was, ultimately, harsh on Wales, who recovered from a hesitant start to dominate the second half and who could have added to the lead given to them in spectacular style by Nathan Blake on the hour. Paul Jones, the goalkeeper, produced his fifth excellent save to deny Erik Mykland, but the rebound was converted at the second attempt by Helstad.
fields.byline: Diana Dargie at the Millennium Stadium
fields.body:
For twenty minutes yesterday, life was just perfect in the Principality. Wales were leading 1-0 and seemingly on the verge of a memorable victory, while events across the border were raising more than a titter. 'Are you watching, Eng-er-land,' they chanted mischievously, but it was too good to last. Within three minutes of coming off the bench, Thorstein Helstad deflated the home crowd with a scrambled equaliser. It was, ultimately, harsh on Wales, who recovered from a hesitant start to dominate the second half and who could have added to the lead given to them in spectacular style by Nathan Blake on the hour. Paul Jones, the goalkeeper, produced his fifth excellent save to deny Erik Mykland, but the rebound was converted at the second attempt by Helstad.

For the manager, Mark Hughes, there was the customary reflection of what might have been but also the more reassuring feeling of knowing that some pride had been restored following the disappointing 2-1 defeat in Belarus a month ago. 'The players have had a lot of stick from many quarters since the Belarus game - some of it was justified but a lot of the things that have been said haven't been fair,' he said.

'You can't kid the Welsh public. We knew we had to show some passion out there and that's what they got in abundance. I said before we left the hotel that it was time for the players to show that they are good players who can compete at this level, and I think they proved that. I'm delighted for them.'

The improvement was marked, but not for a long time. Hughes was honest enough to admit that Norway could have been out of sight long before his team got their act together.

Although their tactical approach has been refined since the days when they were coached by Egil Olsen, validating their complaints about the state of the pitch at the otherwise majestic Millennium Stadium, Norway caused most of their problems from set pieces.

Paul Jones was troubled by an inswinging corner on 14 minutes, from which Henning Berg would have scored had his far-post header not been blocked inadvertently by Mark Delaney, but the Southampton goalkeeper soon recovered to mount a single-handed resistance effort for the remainder of the first half. He saved well from Ronny Johnsen, one of seven England-based players in the Norway team, and Oyvind Leonhardsen.

Christer Basma threatened from another set piece, but Wales appeared to be over the worst of it by the time of their first notable attack midway through the first half. webTitle: Uefa must not ignore small clubs

fields.headline: Uefa must not ignore small clubs
fields.trailText: It seems that all the major leagues in Europe are being devalued by the formation of a full-blown international club Super-League.
fields.body:
For as long as I can remember, people in football have talked about the likelihood of all the major leagues in Europe being devalued by the formation of a full-blown international club Super-League.

Much as I hate to have to admit it, all the evidence suggests that this step to an elitist environment inhabited only by the clubs with the greatest financial potential and box-office appeal is inevitable, and that we are quite close to it occurring.

One major step towards the concept, of course, has been the change in the European Cup format - the development of the competition from a straight knock-out tournament to a league contest - which has created something of a safeguard against the big clubs being knocked out by those at the other end of the scale before they have had the chance to make the money they need to justify their massive expenditure.

The latest sign of where the game is heading concerns the Uefa's plans to introduce a licensing scheme for the top clubs throughout its 51 member countries.

Under that system, which was outlined in these pages last month, it would not be enough for clubs to qualify for the Champions League or the Uefa Cup through their achievements on the field. Entry would also depend on factors such as their financial position (the extent to which they were in debt); the size of their pitches and the capacities and facilities at their stadia.

In the latter respect, Uefa apparently want the stadium criteria for participation in their competitions to include a 150-seat press box, three TV studios and a 300-seat media working room.

For me, David Bowen, the general secretary of the Northern Ireland Football Association, really did hit the nail on the head when he said: 'There is a general feeling among the smaller FAs in Uefa that the big boys do not want our teams playing in the European cup competitions. The squeeze is on.'

When it comes to having an upmarket football home - a place that will not lower the tone of the game at the highest level and that even the likes of Manchester United and Real Madrid might enjoy visiting - I do not think Uefa will turn their noses up at the new 45,000-capacity stadium being built for Coventry. Among its numerous state-of-the-art features are a retractable roof and a retractable pitch.

However, as Coventry are among the group of clubs who cannot hope to be as big as the traditional giants, my feelings about what is happening at the latter's level to give them a bigger advantage than ever should be obvious.

One of the problems for Uefa is that because of the greater number of countries and teams following the break-up of the old Soviet bloc, the overall standard of their competitions has probably declined.

The standard has certainly been dissipated in the qualifying competitions for the World Cup and European Championship. At the preliminary stages, there are too many one-sided matches or matches in which the good teams find it difficult to lift themselves.

However, while I would be in favour of some form of preliminary qualifying competition for the smaller countries, there is no way that I would want to see them out of the World Cup or European Championship picture altogether.

It's the same for clubs striving to take part in the Champions League or Uefa Cup.

The Uefa plan represents just one more step towards ensuring that clubs with dreams of bettering themselves - clubs like Coventry - have the door closed on them.

In general, I agree that the higher the level of the competition, the more important it becomes for there to be certain standards. However, if a club cannot satisfy these, there is an alternative to stopping them from competing - surely, it is merely a matter of allowing them to play home matches somewhere else.

For me, the only things that really matter - outside the actual standard of foot ball the teams are capable of producing - are that the stadiums are safe for spectators and that the pitches are in good condition.

Anything over and above that criteria is immaterial as far as I am concerned. When people talk about poor playing surfaces causing matches to become contests of power and luck as opposed to skill - and thus hampering teams with the greatest technical ability - I am immediately reminded of some of the mud-heaps I experienced during the early part of my career in Scotland.

Playing at Morton could be a particular nightmare. The pitch was such a quagmire in one match there that, when my boot flew off, it took me ages to find it.

Generally, though, the standard of pitches is excellent nowadays. It has to be - if one is going to charge high admission prices to the top matches, it is only right that the conditions are conducive to good football.

Whether the Uefa moves towards that European Super League could also be deemed conducive to good football is another matter. The Champions League is nothing like as appealing to the fans as the old European Cup. It often strikes me that the only people who like it are the competing clubs' bank managers.

Call me an idealistic fool if you like, but I cling to the view that football should be about more than money - and that every team must feel that they have a chance of success.

webTitle: Public told not to give to beggars

fields.headline: It's official: Thou shalt not give money to beggars
fields.trailText: A high-profile campaign instructing people not to give money to beggars is to be launched by the Government, The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
A high-profile campaign instructing people not to give money to beggars is to be launched by the Government, The Observer can reveal.

Funded by the taxpayer, the £240,000 advertising blitz is to be unveiled four weeks before Christmas. The move will reignite claims that Ministers and the Government's 'homelessness tsar' are unsympathetic to the street homeless.

Rory Gillert, deputy chief executive of the Big Issue , said: 'Telling people what to do in this way is ridiculous. Often people who are begging are not actually homeless. Not giving to them doesn't help get people off the streets at all.'

A government official last night defended the adverts, which will appear in national newspapers and magazines at the end of November.

'We want to encourage people to volunteer or give gifts in kind [to beggars] or to charities rather than stopping to give cash,' the official said.

The campaign has been awarded to Leith, the advertising agency which has just won a new £10 million contract to promote Carling beer and whose other clients include Tennent's, Grolsch and Standard Life. An agency spokesman said yesterday: 'The Government has forbidden us from discussing this.'

The Rough Sleepers' Unit (RSU), set up two years ago by the Cabinet Office, was embroiled in controversy last year when Louise Casey, appointed as homelessness tsar by Tony Blair, criticised soup runs and handouts as 'misplaced goodwill'.

Officials claim that the RSU has reduced the number of people sleeping outside from 1,800 to 1,200 since 1998. It has pledged to cut that figure to 600 by 2002. Five years ago as Shadow Home Secretary, Jack Straw pledged that a Labour Government would clear the 'squeegee merchants, beggars and winos' from the streets. The promise was greeted with horror from homelessness campaigners and civil liberties organisations.

The Big Issue's Gillert added: 'If the public are told not to give money to beggars at Christmas, many are likely to do exactly the opposite.'

fields.headline: Shearer, Crozier stunned by exit
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan has stunned his England team and his FA bosses by quitting just minutes after German's 1-0 victory at Wembley's farewell international.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan has stunned his England team and his FA bosses by quitting just minutes after German's 1-0 victory at Wembley's farewell international.

Keegan said: 'I have got to be judged by my results and my results have not been good. I fell short of what's required for the job.

'The effort has been there - I could not have asked more from the lads - but I have not been able to find that little bit extra that you need to win important matches at this level.

'The crowd at the end gave their opinion and made me realise that they can give you this job - and they can also take it away. And that is where the power should be.

'Now I want to spend some more time with my family.'

Keegan's old skipper Alan Shearer was stunned at hearing Kevin Keegan deliver his resignation speech on TV after the World Cup qualifying defeat.

'I'm shocked,' said Shearer. 'But on the other hand you have to give him credit for being so honest and coming out and saying this at the end of what has been a difficult two weeks for him.

'One of Kevin's strong points is that when he feels something he does it. I'm similar in that way, but I'm amazed because it would have been right to go on to Wednesday and get the right result in Finland.

'It must have been very, very tough for him . He must be hurt and he is obviously very, very disappointed. He took us into a tournament in the summer and he had players, and I include myself in that, who let him down.

Former skipper Terry Butcher said: 'It was a very difficult game but that's your job as England manager, to overcome hurdles. He didn't pick a team to win the match. There was not that belief among the players.'

Keegan's boss, Crozier, emerged from talks with the departing coach to say: 'Kevin came in at a very hard time and has built a very close group of players.

'I respect him as a person, as a man and he has given it 100 per cent and I understand his reasons. Kevin just felt during the course of the game that things were not going right for him and that he could not get as much out of the players as he wanted - and that someone else might. The reaction of the crowd might also have persuaded him.

'It is now absolutely vital that we get a result in Finland. The timing of this is not ideal but our players are top-class professionals. Kevin gave it everything he had and it has not worked out. Now we must focus on Finland and Howard Wilkinson will help us through that. As for the new England coach, we'll pick that up from Thursday.'

fields.headline: Wilkinson's worries
fields.standfirst: Can England's caretaker coach halt the slide against Finland on Wednesday?
fields.trailText: Can England's caretaker coach halt the slide against Finland on Wednesday?
fields.body:
Japan and South Korea in the summer of 2002 looks a very, very long way away. In the short term it is destination Helsinki, and if England want any chance to revive a qualification campaign that began in the worst possible taste victory is essential.

As Gareth Southgate points out, 'We've got to regroup quickly and make sure we win on Wednesday to rectify things immediately. In qualification for Euro 2000 we lost our opening game in Sweden and we drew the next game at home to Bulgaria. We have to make sure we lift ourselves. Players will be stung into action.'

And how they need to be, to prevent the possibility of another competition faltering against Scandinavian opposition. The 1984 European Championship was scuppered by a goal from Denmark's Alan Simonsen. Norway's turn came when a 2-0 triumph began the rot that accounted for Graham Taylor and the 1984 World Cup. Sweden took up the baton in the turbulent approach to Euro 2000. Is it time for Finland?

England are unbeaten in seven matches in Helsinki but they fly to Finland next week in a state of turmoil. The man responsible for picking up England's shattered morale, and selecting a team to claim much-needed points is Howard Wilkinson.

In temporary charge for the second time, he faces a far more critical task than previously, when his charges went down 2-0 in a friendly against France at Wembley after being thoroughly outclassed as the World Champions taught England a lesson.

As did Germany yesterday. For two nations wallowing in the international doldrums during last summer's European Championship, there couldn't have been a greater contrast in the way they have responded. Rudi Voller's men were well drilled, moved fluently, and each player looked comfortable with their roles to make them an individually and collectively efficient outfit.

Southgate admitted England did not do themselves justice: 'Everybody will have their opinions on formations but we have to take responsibility as players. I don't think we played well enough in the first half. We didn't perform.

'We didn't look like creating enough chances and we've given away a sloppy goal. It's bitterly disappointing to be beaten by them. The first game of the group, against Germany, the last game at Wembley, we all wanted to go out on a high.'

A sense of shock shuddered through the old stadium as the last hurrah turned into a wake. Following the debacle of Euro 2000, a creditable draw in Paris last month was supposed to herald a new dawn for England. It turned out to be yet another false one. Why did they fail to carry that confidence through? Why did players in key positions struggle to spark? Paul Scholes and Nick Barmby, in particular, were poor imitations of creative attacking players.

David Seaman is also under fierce scrutiny for the blunder so ruthlessly capitalised on by Dietmar Hamann. Southgate tried to exonerate the 37-year-old keeper, suggesting they were all culpable.

'We didn't get a wall organised in time. Dave wanted two men in front of it and I think we were all looking at each other waiting for each other to get in the wall. He couldn't see it until very late and it skidded up off the surface. We'll probably watch the game again and see things we could have done differently.'

Perhaps Finland will choose a different video to psyche themselves up by borrowing the legendary Norwegian commentary from the moment England's Scandinavian's troubles began: 'We beat the best in the world! We beat England! Lord Nelson, Lord Beaverbrook, Sir Winston Churchill, Sir Anthony Eden, Clement Attlee, Henry Cooper, Lady Diana... Maggie Thatcher can you hear me? Maggie Thatcher your boys took one hell of a beating!'

Keegan said that if he left one legacy he at least left a team with good spirit. That was hard to detect as they made their final journey down the Wembley tunnel, a grey-faced set of silent, sorry, shameful players.

fields.headline: Wednesday's smell of decay
fields.trailText: Sheffield Wednesday's season-ticket holders received renewal forms in the summer emblazoned with the slogan: Get your Premier League return ticket. Oh dear. Nine games into the campaign some fans are questioning in which year they intend to return. Or even which century. At the moment it's looking more like a super saver direct to Division Two.
fields.body:
Sheffield Wednesday's season-ticket holders received renewal forms in the summer emblazoned with the slogan: Get your Premier League return ticket. Oh dear. Nine games into the campaign some fans are questioning in which year they intend to return. Or even which century. At the moment it's looking more like a super saver direct to Division Two.

Wednesday are bottom of the pile, picking from the remains of a squad the manager confesses is a considerable distance short of ideal, and crippled by debt. After a fans' forum last week, the faithful called for the board to quit. Celebrity supporter Martyn Ware, of new romantic pop fame, mused: 'I came out of the meeting with the smell of decay and death in my nostrils.' From Heaven 17 to the undertakers via Hillsborough.

The club are ailing, with symptoms that supporters fear are serious. The cause is a desperate lack of funds. Despite being spinelessly relegated last spring, the team had the seventh highest wage bill in the Premiership and the board immediately set about whittling it down. Eleven players have been offloaded, nine on free transfers. The gallows humorists reckon that if anybody comes in with a decent offer for the goalposts, Wednesday will gladly flog them.

What is left of the squad comprises moderate buys, loan signings and kids. If Aaron Lescott, a £100,000 arrival from Aston Villa's reserves, makes his first appearance today against West Brom he will be the thirteenth player to make his Wednesday debut this season. The fans don't recognise their team. 'Ideally, some of these players wouldn't be anywhere near the first team,' admits their manager, Paul Jewell. 'Some would barely get in the reserves if the club were strong. For the game at Tranmere it was so bad that if you were fit and over 16 you were in the squad. I've got to put 11 on the pitch somehow. My hands are tied.'

When Robbie Fowler was due to make his comeback against Wednesday's reserves, the game was cancelled as they couldn't raise a side.

The future doesn't bear thinking about. The past is simply tormenting, the good old days making the fall from grace even more unfathomable. A week ago, Hillsborough ambled down memory lane for David Hirst's testimonial, and nostalgia flooded back. In the early Nineties, Wednesday played in Europe, in Wembley Cup finals, swooned to the skills of Chris Waddle and Trevor Francis, and average gates approached 30,000.

Hirst was once one of the most coveted strikers in the land, subject of a £3.5 million bid from Alex Ferguson at Old Trafford (which would have smashed the transfer record). It was faxed directly back with a 'Not for sale' sign attached.

How attitudes have changed. Today, any hands proffering a few bob for the likes of internationals Gilles de Bilde and Wim Jonk would be snapped off. But as chairman Howard Culley laments: 'There is no magic solution that makes people come in and bid for your players.' The seeds of financial despair were sown when Wednesday's demise wiped the value off a clutch of talented, handsomely paid foreigners. Their pair of rebellious Italian artists, Paolo Di Canio and Benito Carbone, abandoned ship for a fraction of their true worth. Brazilian defender Emerson Thome, sold to Chelsea for £2.5 million, left the Bridge six months later for £4.5 million. Lively Swede Niclas Alexandersson was transferred to Everton for a bargain £2.5 million.

How quickly does Jewell want to complete the purge of unaffordable staff? Today. Painful process though it is, at least it would give the team a clean slate to start again, without the dissenting vibes of big shots with bad attitudes. 'The whole club needs a change of thought process,' explains the former Bradford manager. 'I've come from a team where every player gave their best every day in training and were desperate to get in that team. Here, people lack a little bit of discipline, good basics. I've got to re-educate people and that takes time.

'When I first walked in the door, you could hear a pin drop. It was really negative, there was so much apathy. Now there is more noise, more character, more fun if you like. I think people actually enjoy coming to training. They don't enjoy being bottom of the league. But as bad as we have been we are capable of performing 10 times better than we have shown. We shouldn't lose sight of the fact we've still got some good players here.'

Jewell is remarkably chipper all things considered. Joe Kinnear, a previous target of the Wednesday board, had turned the job down after his pleas to delay selling experienced players until some points were in the bank were ignored. It sounded a sensible enough plan, and as it is Wednesday are left with a minuscule squad and minimum points. Jewell accepts the situation and hopes endeavour and positive spirit will turn things around.

There is pathos in this sorry tale. Both Jewell and Culley are decent men trying to do their best in unenviable jobs. But the supporters worry that this may not be enough. Dan Gordon, vice chairman of the Wednesday Independent Supporters Club, fears a noose is tightening round the club's neck. 'Nobody can see where the next win is coming from. At Hirsty's testimonial, the team of the early Nineties were better than the one now, which shows how far we've sunk. Accountants who have examined the financial statements say the club is insolvent. I feel Howard Culley is in over his head. What the club need is some vision and imagination. Whether anyone is capable of that I don't know.'

Culley responds: 'The job is difficult enough to do without having to fight our own supporters. I think we're doing the right things and it's very early to judge us or our management team. We can see the light at the end of the tunnel and it's an old football saying that nobody gets relegated in October. We've got to climb out of the danger zone and I don't blame people for saying we can't wait too long.'

Jewell believes he is a third of the way down the road to manipulating his players around to his methods. By that thinking they should have turned the corner by Christmas. 'I don't know what year Christmas,' he laughs, keeping that chin up while those around him feel like singing the blues.

Maybe someone pointed out the circus was setting up over the road at Hillsborough Park.

fields.headline: Familiar faces in Helsinki
fields.standfirst: Finns in the English leagues
fields.trailText: Finns in the English leagues.
fields.body:
SAMI HYYPIA (Liverpool)

For Liverpool centre-half Hyypia the real home game is not on Wednesday but next March, when the return fixture will be played at Anfield. Hyypia, Finland's player of the year, said; 'That will be a great occasion and I will tell my team-mates all about Anfield. Perhaps I'll have some support from the crowd, as well as the England players. By then my Liverpool team-mates, Emile Heskey and Michael Owen, could be together in England's attack. But they will not be team-mates then, they will be my enemies. We have nothing to lose against England and Germany and we are certainly good enough to make things very difficult for them.'

MIKAEL FORSSELL (Crystal Palace)

Forssell, just 19, joined Palace from Chelsea on a season-long loan and he is the first division club's leading scorer. Having steadily proved his fitness, he should start against England. 'People here in England tend to underestimate Finland, but we will give you a difficult game,' he says. 'We made a good start to our qualifying campaign and it's good for us that the first match against England is in Finland. We'll probably play with three strikers - myself, Jonatan Johansson and Jari Litmanen, who is a fantastic footballer. Our front-line will be a threat; we have pace and skill. We'll be a handful so don't start writing us off.'

JUSSI JAASKELAINEN (Bolton)

A towering 25-year-old, competing with Hearts' Antti Niemi for the national number one spot. He has established himself as Bolton's undisputed first choice and says: 'The whole of Finland is looking forward to the game - it has been sold out for weeks and there will be around 37,000 at the Olympic Stadium. Before that we're in Greece and we'd ideally like at least four points from those two games. We are still quite a young team but most of the players are abroad and gaining important experience. We know Germany and England are two of the strongest teams in the world and have to be favourites. We'll see where we stand next week.'

SIMO VALAKARI (Derby County)

Derby's midfielder has been in and out of Jim Smith's side. He says: 'England are favourites, but their followers seem to expect their team to beat everybody without realising how much the competition has improved. This is a good Finland team and if we have a good day and England are not right, we could win. That would surprise those who think we are there to make up the group. Finland owes a great deal to Jari Litmanen. His career lit a flame because he showed that a footballer from Finland could make it through to big clubs like Ajax and Barcelona.'

JARKO WISS (Stockport County)

Wiss will not fear the prospect of taking on David Beckham and Co, having already shackled Zinedine Zidane. The former captain of HJK Helsinki kept Zidane quiet in a friendly international. He said: 'I was really happy with my performance even though we lost 1-0. I was disappointed that he would not shake my hand afterwards. I wanted to exchange shirts but Zidane refused and I didn't think he was very sporting. I expect the same kind of battle against the likes of Beckham. I'm not worried about that.'

JONATAN JOHANSSON (Charlton Athletic)

When Johansson joined Charlton from Rangers over the summer, the biggest surprise was that more clubs weren't interested. He has scored seven times in the last eight games. 'Naturally England should win,' he says. 'They have a more professional set-up while we have hardly any league structure. But it's a small stadium and it will be packed.' As for England, Johansson is wary of being too critical but says,'Their defenders are good but they're getting old.'

fields.headline: Brown slips with Leighton offer
fields.trailText: The Jim Leighton affair has threatened to introduce some dreaded discord to Craig Brown's well-established Scotland squad serenity - and perhaps even create a morale-damaging schism. It was the last thing Brown needed as his squad prepared for what he considers to be their most demanding World Cup qualifier, against Croatia in Zagreb on Wednesday.
fields.body:
The Jim Leighton affair has threatened to introduce some dreaded discord to Craig Brown's well-established Scotland squad serenity - and perhaps even create a morale-damaging schism. It was the last thing Brown needed as his squad prepared for what he considers to be their most demanding World Cup qualifier, against Croatia in Zagreb on Wednesday.

Yet, from the available evidence, it is impossible to escape the conclusion that Brown carried the trouble over his own threshold. By inviting Leighton, Scotland's most-capped goalkeeper with 91 appearances, to join the group as a goalkeeping coach to the under-21 side, Brown virtually guaranteed that the previously happy camp would be riven by controversy and acrimony.

The manager was aware of the bad blood that has existed between Leighton and the senior goalkeeping coach, Alan Hodgkinson. Leighton has held Hodgkinson culpable for influencing the manager to choose Andy Goram ahead of him in Euro 96 and in subsequent matches.

Leighton has always found it difficult to reconcile himself to the fact that he was regarded as second best, apparently failing to consider the reality that it was, in all cases, ultimately Brown's decision.

It has also been public knowledge for some time that Leighton had commissioned the 'ghosting' of his autobiography, in which he would publish retaliatory criticism of several figures he believed had wronged him - including Hodgkinson and Brown himself. The serialisation of the book begins today in the Sunday Mail, who recognised that maximum publicity would be generated by starting with the chapter on Hodgkinson.

In defending his decision to ask Leighton to join the party, Brown insisted that the notion had occurred to him after Leighton led a 'session' with the under-21 team in Latvia last month, where he was covering the Scots' opening World Cup qualifier as a summariser for BBC Radio 5 Live.

Brown also said that he had been assured by Leighton that nothing in the Mail serialisation would embarrass the SFA while they were on the expedition to San Marino and Croatia.

These were unconvincing claims and what seemed much more plausible was the whisper that circulated later - and hinted at the real reason for Leighton's startling appearance at Glasgow Airport on Thursday afternoon kitted out in the uniform of the official party.

It is said that Ebbe Skovdahl, the Aberdeen manager for whom Leighton works as a goalkeeping coach, had turned down the latter's request to make the trip to San Marino and Croatia as a radio commentator. Skovdahl was then allegedly persuaded by Brown to relent for an official one-off arrangement that would allow Leighton to continue his normal work with Ryan Esson, the young Aberdeen goalkeeper.

Brown himself admitted to phoning Skovdahl and to the fact that the Dane was initially reluctant to allow Leighton to make the trip, but he stopped short of confessing that he had recruited Leighton merely as a favour. And Brown took pains to scotch a darker rumour - emphasising that he had categorically assured the Yorkshireman that there was no threat to his position as senior goalkeeping coach.

Hodgkinson was so upset by the presence of Leighton that he eschewed the usual first-night banter on a trip in favour of an early night. By Friday morning, Hodgkinson was quite animated in his anger. It was decided then, by Brown and the association's chief executive, David Taylor, that it would be appropriate if Leighton were relieved of his duties and moved out of the team's hotel to take up his job in the media.

As Brown had known since last weekend's blurb in the Sunday Mail that serialisation of the autobiography was to start today, it would have been a simple matter to call Leighton and postpone his appointment. Now comes the crunch.

Having seen Croatia, including talented midfielder Robert Prosinecki, draw 0-0 with Belgium in Brussels, Brown has no doubt they are the keenest rivals in Group 6. 'They are better than Belgium and this is indisputably the toughest match we'll face,' he said.

In defending his decision to ask Leighton to join the party, Brown insisted that the notion had occurred to him after Leighton led a 'session' with the under-21 team in Latvia last month, where he was covering the Scots' opening World Cup qualifier as a summariser for BBC Radio 5 Live. Brown also said that he had been assured by Leighton that nothing in the Mail serialisation would embarrass the SFA while they were on the expedition to San Marino and Croatia. These were unconvincing claims and what seemed much more plausible was the whisper that circulated later - and hinted at the real reason for Leighton's startling appearance at Glasgow Airport on Thursday afternoon kitted out in the uniform of the official party. It is said that Ebbe Skovdahl, the Aberdeen manager for whom Leighton works as a goalkeeping coach, had turned down the latter's request to make the trip to San Marino and Croatia as a radio commentator. Skovdahl was then allegedly persuaded by Brown to relent for an official one-off arrangement that would allow Leighton to continue his normal work with Ryan Esson, the young Aberdeen goalkeeper. Brown himself admitted to phoning Skovdahl and to the fact that the Dane was initially reluctant to allow Leighton to make the trip, but he stopped short of confessing that he had recruited Leighton merely as a favour. And Brown took pains to scotch a darker rumour - emphasising that he had categorically assured the Yorkshireman that there was no threat to his position as senior goalkeeping coach. Hodgkinson was so upset by the presence of Leighton that he eschewed the usual first-night banter on a trip in favour of an early night. By Friday morning, Hodgkinson was quite animated in his anger. It was decided then, by Brown and the association's chief executive, David Taylor, that it would be appropriate if Leighton were relieved of his duties and moved out of the team's hotel to take up his job in the media. As Brown had known since last weekend's blurb in the Sunday Mail that serialisation of the autobiography was to start today, it would have been a simple matter to call Leighton and postpone his appointment. Now comes the crunch. Having seen Croatia, including talented midfielder Robert Prosinecki, draw 0-0 with Belgium in Brussels, Brown has no doubt they are the keenest rivals in Group 6. 'They are better than Belgium and this is indisputably the toughest match we'll face,' he said.

fields.headline: Albion tactics key to success
fields.trailText: Nationwide League preview.
fields.body:
One note of encouragement for Paul Jewell today can be found in the change of fortunes of his opposite number, Gary Megson.

His West Bromwich Albion side have also been at the bottom this season, after losing their opening three matches. However, they have been unbeaten in their subsequent seven - of which five have been won - and conceded just two goals.

Megson believes his side's change of fortune is purely down to a change in tactics. 'We have tried to tighten-up more on set-pieces against us, and have played with three centre-halves,' he said.

But the men who have garnered the most praise from him are midfielder Derek McInnes and striker Lee Hughes. 'Their work means that we are winning a lot of the ball before we even get to a situation where we have to defend,' Megson said. 'Lee's closing down at the front is better than anybody's outside the Premiership and a lot better than most in it. Our defending starts from there.'

Today's match will bring back memories for Megson, who had two spells as a Wednesday player and made more than 250 appearances for the club. His father, Don, was also a Wednesday player. 'Wednesday's result is the first one I look for every Saturday,' he said. How does he feel about their present plight? 'You do have a certain amount of sympathy - but you have to focus on your own job.'

Elsewhere, after just two months of the season, the managers whose jobs are already in jeopardy - according to one 'grapevine' report - include Graeme Souness at Blackburn. However, a more obvious candidate for the boot is Portsmouth's Tony Pulis, who preceded today's match at Stockport with a plea to the club chairman, Milan Mandaric, to be more patient with him.

With Portsmouth languishing in 18th position, Pulis, who has recently come under fire from Mandaric, said: 'He is a chairman who has put his money in and pays for everything so he has a right to criticise.

'But when I was at Gillingham I took over a club that was rock bottom of the Third Division and nearly out of existence and it took us time to get things right - it does not happen overnight.

'Unfortunately Milan feels as though it should be moving a bit quicker - sometimes it does, and sometimes it doesn't. The important thing is that you build on a solid base.'

fields.headline: Keegan quits
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan has surprisingly quit as England coach after little more than 18 months with the sad reflection: 'I just haven't been quite good enough.'
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan has surprisingly quit as England coach after little more than 18 months with the sad reflection: 'I just haven't been quite good enough.'

As for his side, he added: 'The effort has been there - I could not have asked more from the lads - but I have not been able to find that little bit extra that you need to find to win important matches at this level.

'The crowd at the end gave their opinion and made me realise that they can give you this job - and they can also take it away. And that is where the power should lie. Now I want to spend some more time with my family.'

German match-winner Dietmar Hamann, whose goal nailed Keegan's hold on his job, said: 'This goal was no different for me than any of the others.

'It is always a good feeling to score for your national team and in this instance I am happy that it has put us in such a strong position in our qualifying group. We now have six points from our first two matches, which is ideal.

'I was sure that I could score from the free-kick because the conditions we played in today are always tough for a goalkeeper. David Seaman was not exactly in the middle of his goal and I knew I had a good chance.

'The conditions were difficult for both teams, but this was particularly the case for England because they had to chase the game.'

Alan Shearer, the former England captain, was disappointed that when the free-kick was awarded, an England player did not stand on the ball to stop it being taken quickly.

You see it happening week in, week out in England, but for some reason our lads were caught napping.

'I played with Dietmar at Newcastle, and know what a great striker of the ball he is. But in this instance, the goal could have been avoided.

'It all goes to show that if you want a celebration (to mark the end of Wembley} don't invite the Germans. They are real party poopers.

'You have to give them credit. They looked very professional and were never really in danger in my view.

'I thought we suffered in the first ahalf by not playing with enough width - but the Germans deserved their win.'

fields.headline: Doctors prescribe themselves £1m salaries
fields.standfirst: Top doctors  income from private work soars
fields.trailText: The day of the million-pound-a-year doctor has dawned. Top private doctors commanding more than £3,000 for one operation have followed rapidly in the footsteps of barristers and city financiers, to join the small élite earning seven-figure salaries.
fields.byline: Anthony Browne, health editor, The Observer
fields.body:
The day of the million-pound-a-year doctor has dawned. Top private doctors commanding more than £3,000 for one operation have followed rapidly in the footsteps of barristers and city financiers, to join the small élite earning seven-figure salaries.

An Observer investigation suggests as many as 20 British doctors now earn more than a million pounds a year, with a greater number earning more than £500,000.

The huge salaries have alarmed private clinics and insurance companies, who fear the fees could drive patients into the state sector.

Incomes of private doctors have been boosted by the growth in the number of private operations, and by the fact they now tend to charge extra for services that used to be included in the overall price, such as outpatients services. The highest-earning specialities include heart surgery, plastic surgery and gynaecology. William Laing, chairman of the private medicine analysts Laing & Buisson, said: 'I know there are some, but they are few in number. There are a far larger number earning over £500,000 a year'.

Jerry Gilmore, a top consultant surgeon in Harley Street, is thought to be one of the highest earners. Gilmore, who specialises in breast cancer, is reputed in private medical circles to earn more than £1 million a year. The Observer was unable to contact him for comment.

Last year, around 600,000 operations were carried out in private hospitals. The number has risen in recent years as disillusionment with NHS waiting times has grown.

Standard fees for surgeons are £2,170 for a heart bypass operation, £2,140 to remove a brain tumour, £1,045 for a mastectomy, £825 for a hip replacement, and £645 for a hysterectomy. Doctors in high demand in London can push up their fees further.

Laing said that, with these kinds of fees, earning a million a year was perfectly feasible. 'Suppose they earn £2,000 an operation and have 200 working days a year, they'd have to average two-and-a-half operations a day to make a million pounds. That's certainly possible.'

Private hospitals and health insurers, who have to pay the bills, have become increasingly dismayed by the growing incomes of private doctors. David Ashdown, director of communications at private insurer WPA, said: 'The trouble is you get expensive doctors, and the hospitals and people can't afford it. People then give up private health.'

Until recently the rates for private operations were set by the British Medical Association, but insurers have now succeeded in implementing their own standard rates. However, doctors have resisted by boosting their salaries in other ways.

Dr Adrian Bull, medical director of PPP Healthcare, said: 'Some doctors have started to add things on. Before they would just charge for a hernia, whereas now they might also charge for 'dividing adhesions' when they are operating - that's an extra charge sometimes made to inflate the overall bill. We need more clarity in what patients are paying for.'

Another increasingly common practice is that doctors charge separately for the outpatient follow-up for an operation, which used to be included in the whole bill.

Consultants who work exclusively in the NHS earn about £60,000 a year. However, many boost their earnings with private work, doubling their salary on average. The private earnings of doctors who work in the NHS has always been a source of controversy, and the Government is trying to clamp down. One consultant at Guy's and St Thomas's hospital in London admitted the consultants' car park used to be full of Rolls Royces, but they had learnt to be more discreet.

The highest earning doctors - those on more than a £250,000 a year - tend to work exclusively in private practice. The rise in their incomes means consultants have kept up with top barristers. However, doctors are far more guarded about their incomes than barristers. One medical source said: 'It's a dark and well-kept secret what they earn. No one will speak about it because they don't want to alienate them. Money and medicine are a sensitive area.'

fields.headline: How I passed my diving test
fields.standfirst: Minty Clinch  nearly drowned,  but eventually emerged triumphant from the deep
fields.trailText: Minty Clinch nearly drowned, but eventually emerged triumphant from the deep.
fields.body:
'Do you think you're too old to learn to dive?' This was a delicate question from The Observer. Certainly too old to wear a bikini, probably too old to take up free fall parachuting, but no way too old to scuba dive. Moments later, I was committed to a course in the Cayman Islands. Friends expressed envy but I knew the learning curve would be difficult. I am naturally more terrestrial than aquatic and diving, unlike most adventure sports, is potentially life-threatening from the start.

With 5,000 centres around the world, Padi is the most widely recognised of several dive training organisations. Passing the basic open water diver course is the key to the deep, allowing you to rent scuba equipment and go diving without an instructor. Padi stands for Professional Association of Diving Instructors or, less reverentially, Put Another Dollar In, a reference to the extensive list of more advanced courses pressed on successful students. Candidates for the basic qualification must pass an exam based on the Padi Diver Manual and complete five confined and four open water dives. If all goes well, this takes four days, rather too large a chunk of holiday to spend in school. A better option is the referral system, which allows you to do the classwork and the confined dives at home, then finish the course in the resort.

So we gathered in Wembley for a long, hot Saturday of Americanised video tuition, followed by a water-logged Sunday in a swimming pool in Essex. Our teacher, Mike Harrison, was patience personified as he coaxed us into the unwieldy equipment and positioned us on the bottom of the pool to practise our skills. It was possible, he insisted, to remove and replace the regulator (breathing mouthpiece) without choking. Ditto the mask. Or even to take off the kit altogether and replace it underwater. The Padi course is geared to worst-case scenarios. What if your tank got jammed in a wreck? Or your mask flipped off by a passing shark?

Under water, forewarned is forearmed, but there are extreme penalties for failure. What of nitrogen narcosis, which can result in 'foolish' behaviour at depth, or decompression sickness, which can numb, paralyse or even kill? The answers lie in calculating safe depths and appropriate surface intervals between dives. By the time we flew to Grand Cayman, we knew the score.

After a night in the Hyatt Hotel patronised by Tom Cruise and Gene Hackman in the film The Firm, we ate a nervous breakfast and gathered on the jetty for our inaugural open water dive with Red Sails Sports. Our instructor was Renee, an ebullient Canadian who inspired confidence from the start, and we were soon geared up and stumbling awkwardly towards the brink. The moment for the 'giant stride', the flippered step into the sea, had come. Masks and regulators held firmly with one hand, weight belts with the other, we launched ourselves and discovered the equipment, so unwieldy on shore, is weightless in the water.

That was the first miracle. The second was the reef. Inquisitive sergeant majors, disdainful spotlight parrotfish and iridescent queen trigger fish milled around us as we tried to maintain proper buoyancy above the vibrant plant life embedded in the gnarly coral. Don't touch, we'd been warned, not only because damaged coral regenerates at an infinitesimally slow speed, but also because it is slightly poisonous. Within 30 minutes, we were back on the surface, triumphant and ready for a second attempt, longer and deeper, with sightings of bulky grouper fish, a golden eel, briefly tempted out of a rock crevice by Renee, and a million or so tiny yellowtail snapper. Two dives down, two to go.

Had the next day not been Renee's day off, things might have worked out differently. As it was, we were passed to Mark, also Canadian, but aggressively macho. He launched into the things he would require of us if we were to qualify. We were on rough seas on a dive boat that resembled a factory ship. We were in the presence of experienced divers. Insensitively, Mark took us down to 60ft, as deep as unqualified divers are allowed to go, and put us through the skill tests required for open water dive three.

On the final dive, which requires a full mask removal and replacement, I swallowed half the ocean and was choking so badly that Mark had no alternative but to abort my dive. I had to rely on him to assess the speed that would get me to the surface without either drowning or decompression sickness. As I coughed and struggled, he yelled for help to remove the equipment and eventually I was heaved back on board in total disarray. Mark's note to the clinic cited 'frothy yellowish/pinkish foam' coming from my lungs in a 'near drowning', but luckily the ascent had been slow enough for the doctor to pass me fit to try again.

The next day, we visited Stingray City with Ashton Ebanks, an amenable Cayman Islander who was persuaded I wouldn't drown in 10ft of water. The rays are so well geared up for tourists they throw themselves into your arms as they target Ashton's bait. Harmless nurse sharks were eager to share the bonanza.

The question of the diving qualification was still hanging over me when I arrived in Rarotonga two weeks later. Owned by New Zealander Greg Wilson, Cook Island Divers is an endearingly yesteryear operation, a group of people hanging out cheerfully for the love of the sport. Nick, my instructor, went out with me beyond the reef into the deep blue waters of the Pacific and in a couple of hours, the dives were done. No factory ship, no fuss, no fear of failure. For wannabe divers, this is the way to go.

In at the deep end

Diving Leisure London (020 7924 4106) offers a two-day referral PADI Open Water Course (theory and pool work) for £179.

Red Sails Sports: 001 345 949 8732; fax 001 345 949 8570; email redsail@candw.ky). Padi certification courses in the Cayman Islands: $440 (£280)

Cook Island Divers (00 682 22 483; fax 00 682 22 484; email gwilson@ci-divers.co.ck). Padi certification courses in Rarotonga: NZ$475 (£162)

Getting there

British Airways (0990 444000): From Gatwick on Mondays and Wednesdays to Grand Cayman, from £400.

Air New Zealand (020 8741 2299): Heathrow via LA (with optional stop over) to Rarotonga, economy return from £844.

fields.headline: How they rated...
fields.standfirst: England's players marked out of 10
fields.trailText: England's players marked out of 10.
fields.body:
DAVID SEAMAN 4

The end is nigh after a farewell to forget. Struck by the curse of Gazza 1991 all over again. Same distance, same concentration lapse, same result as Seaman found himself easily, horribly, decisively beaten from a 30-yard dead ball. The cursed ponytail's worst Wembley nightmare returned in a haunting flashback. Redeemed himself a little to fingertip away a replica effort from Marco Bode and deny Mehmet Scholl.

GARY NEVILLE 6

webTitle: A top hotel manager reveals all

fields.headline: A top hotel manager reveals all
fields.standfirst: Richard Baker, Manager at The DeVere Grand Hotel, Brighton
fields.trailText: Richard Baker, Manager at The DeVere Grand Hotel, Brighton.
fields.body:
You must have been busy last week?
Yes, political conferences are a security challenge but the police take over - even I have to wear my ID badge.This year we provided 4,000 delegates with food and drink each night of the Labour conference and they've already made their booking for next year. We delivered a dozen newspapers each morning to one third of the rooms. The senior politicians don't stay here but we are full of exhibitors and journalists all gossiping among themselves. They might have large G&Ts in their hands but they are working!

Who else comes to Brighton?
Brighton is very popular as a short break destination. We get everyone here from those staying in B&Bs to those paying £300 a night. Tourism in Brighton has changed enormously since the Eighties: a huge number of restaurants have opened, the Royal Pavilion has been renovated and £5m has been spent on the Palace Pier. All age groups enjoy it here although some don't like the cosmopolitan atmosphere. They're better off in Frinton.

Your most memorable moment?
Margaret Thatcher reopened the hotel two years after the IRA bombing - it's an old façade but brand new inside. Concorde flew over and it seemed low enough to touch the masts. It was absolute euphoria.

What about a night out?
We don't really have London prices here. The trendiest restaurant might be The Ginger Man on Weston Street, which is owned by a charming couple. They just have one sitting per night and are always full. A good Italian restaurant is Latin In The Lanes, while English's specialises in fantastic fish dishes. People come from all around to go to Brighton's nightclubs.

And a day out?
Devil's Dyke, behind Brighton, is a great place for a walk. The marina is becoming more popular as it develops into an entertainment centre with shops and cinemas. Lancing, along the coast, is worth a visit, but Madeira Drive in Brighton usually has some sort of activity at the weekend, such as a classic car rally.

Rooms from £210 per night

The Ginger Man 01273 326 688

fields.headline: Hunger pang
fields.standfirst: With Mr Pang on hand, a menu is superfluous at Pimlico's Hunan. But don't make the mistake of filling up on rice
fields.trailText: With Mr Pang on hand, a menu is superfluous at Pimlico's Hunan. But don't make the mistake of filling up on rice.
fields.body:
The new 10th edition of the Harden's guide lists the best restaurants in London by category. The top Chinese for under £35 (a massive category encompassing every polished dim sum joint in Chinatown as well as the massed legions of China Gardens and Jade Palaces out in the suburbs) is a restaurant called Hunan on the Pimlico Road. This was startling news. The Pimlico Road is generally known for the grossly over-priced antiques shops flogging pointlessly gilded nick-nacks to the inbred, snorting Chelsea girls with too much money and not enough taste who live nearby. It is where you go for an emergency rococo mirror. It is not where you go for great Chinese food.

Except, of course, that according to the punters who contribute to Harden's, it is. And they are right, though God knows how they found it in the first place. Hunan is not a glossy establishment and you could quite easily miss it. Which I and my companion Robert almost did.

Once, Robert was a banker, but, as he puts it, greed forced a career change upon him - during incessant business lunches he began to find the food more interesting than the business under discussion. And so he became a restaurateur instead. Certainly he is a man who knows his Chinese food. He even claims to possess a recipe for bear's paw 'in the Hunanese style'. 'Though it says you can substitute beef for bear' - helpful given that Robert lives in east London, which is a bit light on wild bears these days.

There may or may not be bear's paw on the menu at Hunan. To be honest, we gave it very little attention save to note that, for a Chinese restaurant, it is exceptionally short. We had been advised, both by Harden's and the waiters, to place ourselves in the hands of the owner, Mr Pang. He would see us right, we were told. And he did.

Mr Pang is probably the only acquired taste at Hunan. He tends to hover a little, looking for your approval and grinning like an indulgent nanny as each dish arrives. But then, when the food is this good, who can blame him? We gave him few directions, save that we didn't mind a bit of chilli - useful as its a key flavour in Hunanese food - and that a bit of seafood wouldn't go amiss. Mr Pang grinned some more.

We began with little bamboo mugs of a steaming, aromatic broth heavy with pigeon breast that had been steamed and then minced. (We know this because we asked; a friend of mine, who is a non-meat eater and a regular at Hunan, only discovered that he has been eating pigeon for years when he and I compared notes.) Next came minced chicken in a sweet chilli sauce to be wrapped in crisp lettuce leaf. That was followed by the best, sweetest prawn toast I have ever tasted.

It should be said that none of these dishes were huge; each was little more than a forkful, so that there was space for the next. When we asked for a bowl of rice with which to soak up the sauces, Mr Pang almost refused. 'It will fill you up,' he said with disdain. He didn't want that. The kitchen was only just getting into it's stride.

There were green beans in a light batter with chilli and salt. Four gorgeous dinky mushrooms came stuffed with minced pork and topped with a sesame crust. There were slices of pork fillet in a sweet unctuous sauce that remained crisp despite being served en papillote. Then came two perfectly formed dumplings stuffed with spinach, water chestnut and sweet basil. We know this because Mr Pang insisted that we identify them. Robert got them all; I trailed in behind with just the spinach.

The next dish, shredded duck with plum sauce and pancakes, was the only slightly duff note. The perfectly rendered crispy dusk had been swamped in a sweet chilli sauce. No matter. As a palate cleanser there was a dish of fresh spring vegetables and one of chicken, stir fried in a very different and chilli sauce. (A warning: don't go to Hunan if you're not keen on chillies; it would be like someone with a fear of heights going up the Eiffel Tower.)

For pudding we shared a light and delightfully bland almond jelly - exactly what was needed after such a massive assault of flavour. There is no doubt that, with Mr Pang's help, we pushed the boat out and the bill for £72, which included service and a few beers, reflects that. But give Mr Pang a budget and I'm sure he'd keep to it. Just don't ask him for the menu. Mr Pang does not hold with menus.

Hunan, 51 Pimlico Road, London SW1 (020 7730 5712). Dinner for two, including wine and service, £70. Harden's guide to the best restaurants in your area will be free exclusively with The Observer on 12 November. Contact Jay Rayner at jayrayner@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Last chance saloon for a district in despair

fields.headline: Last chance saloon for a district in despair
fields.standfirst: After the demise of steel and mining, South Yorkshire's future depends on Euro cash, says  Nick Mathiason
fields.trailText: After the demise of steel and mining, South Yorkshire's future depends on Euro cash, says Nick Mathiason
fields.body:
The Temple pub nestles between two redundant steel factories on Rotherham's Sheffield Road. Licensing laws notwithstanding, it used to be heaving with steel workers 24 hours a day. Last Monday at 5.30pm, there were just three drinkers in the Temple. On the juke box, Elton John was singing 'Don't let the sun go down on me'. It already has.

Next door to the Temple in a cavernous former British Steel factory, frantic workers are rushing to create a £37 million theme park based on the steel and coal industry in time for its Easter opening next year. The factory once employed 1,500 people. When Magna opens next year, 150 will run it.

Senior staff at Magna know that if this Lottery-funded project is to work and win the respect of sceptical locals, new companies, in particular multi-media firms, will have to locate to the fringes of this huge site. Visitor attractions, after all, have a limited shelf-life. As catalysts of regeneration, they don't always work.

But as things stand few businesses would dream of coming to Rotherham or South Yorkshire. This is because skills levels here are among the worst in the country. A workforce whose members for generations were guaranteed a job didn't need to pay any attention at school. Their children, seeing how their dads were thrown on the scrapheap with no alternative offered, gave up. The result? A deep socio-economic crisis.

In Grimethorpe, home to the famous colliery brass band, heroin and crack pose serious problems for this small, resilient community. Residents in sink estates outside Doncaster literally air their dirty washing for all to see as whey-faced kids roam the streets with nothing to do. And the last time Rotherham hit the front pages? The discovery last year that a 12-year-old girl was expecting a baby fathered by a 14-year-old boy.

During the past 15 years there have been various attempts to regenerate South Yorkshire after an estimated 160,000 workers lost jobs in the coal, steel and engineering industries. The Tories, having destroyed 'the enemy within', set up City Challenge funds to rebuild communities. The trouble was, these initiatives placed the emphasis on bricks and mortar regeneration assuming that businesses would flock to the area to take up the slack once foundations were in place. They didn't.

After Tory Minister Michael Heseltine rang the death knell of the coal industry in 1992, an emergency package of aid was set up. This included Single Regeneration Budget funds. The trouble is that rival regions compete for funds and more than half the applicants fail. The failures are normally from communities that do not have the resources to plough into a coherent bid - the very communities which SRB funds are there to help.

Swept to power on a wave of optimism in 1997, the Labour Party pledged to revitalise depressed coal mining communities. Its response to the Coalfields Taskforce was considered to be the most important step forward for England's mining communities for decades.

Three years later, progress has been made. The Government has set up the Coalfield Regeneration Trust with £55m to plough into community-led initiatives over three years. One year down the line, grants worth £20m have been committed. It is now crucial that the CRT extends its funding for another three years. Negotiations are ongoing.

The Government has allowed English Partnerships, the regeneration quango, to assume control of most of the coalfields to fast-track redevelopment.

But progress in transferring the coalfields has been held up by lease complications and a recent EU judgment which ruled government intervention on regeneration sites as 'anti-competitive'.

The Government has set a framework by which South Yorkshire can fight back, but what could really make a difference to the region is a £700m EU Objective One grant announced last July which, as it has to be, will be matched by another £700m from the Government.

Objective One grants are given to areas deemed to be poverty stricken, and there are many Yorkshire folk who see the windfall as confirmation of abject failure. Action plans by the local Regional Development Agency, Yorkshire Forward, are being fine-tuned, but most money will be spent on education, training and employment opportunities.

Objective One cash, despite having lost £50m in value since the collapse of the euro, is seen by those in the area as its last chance to get itself on an even keel.

'EU enlargement means that other countries will get it in the future,' explained Mike Bower, acting deputy director of the Yorkshire's Objective One project team. 'We won't get this amount of cash from Europe again.'

If handled correctly, this cash could lever another £400m of public and private money into the area, making a total of £1.8 billion. That it might be wasted is the great fear preoccupying South Yorkshire.

'Inevitably, we'll get duplication on the ground. With so many agencies, local councils, employment organisations, training bodies, it gets very complicated. I don't know the answer,' said Sara Turton, Yorkshire Forward's Learning & Skills manager.

But for those who have been thrown on the scrapheap, egos, corruption and inefficiency cannot be tolerated. This is South Yorkshire's last chance. It must not be blown.

Carving out a new living

It would take a hard man not to be inspired by the Wildwood project next to the former Bentley mine in South Yorkshire. The project was set up last year with £250,000 of grants from the Church Urban Fund, Coalfield Regeneration Trust and the John Paul Getty Junior Trust.

The initiative trains the long-term unemployed in making furniture from recycled wood. Later this month, it is forecast that Wildwood will scoop a Chambers of Trade Investors in People award.

The project is currently driven by the vicar of Bentley and a former deputy managing director of the Scotsman newspaper group.

In this financial year, Wildwood has turned over £9,000 in sales. It has got a long way to go to be self-financing.

But it has just won a contract to supply a local museum with exhibition cabinets, is identifying other niche markets and is talking to retail partners to sell products ranging from mahogany dining tables, toy boxes and garden furniture.

Such is the energy and drive pulsing through Wildwood that you don't think those involved in it will allow it to fail.

Graduates from its courses have either been employed within the company or have found employment outside it. Only two have given up, both through ill-health.

Retraining delivers jobs

With numbers in the coal and steel industries slashed, unions have found it hard to adapt to the post-industrial age.

But ISTC, the principal steel union, has over the last year increased its numbers by 7 per cent to nearly 35,000 thanks to retraining ex-steel workers. It is the first time a British union has taken this approach - using a model which came from the United States.

Staffed largely by redundant steel workers, its new body, the Steel Training Partnership, counsels those put out of work, offers them training and tries to find them new jobs.

The organisation is held back by a lack of IT teachers and the sheer number needing help.

In Rotherham, STP has found people jobs in tree surgery, product auditing and telecommunications, and helped a number of non-union members to study for childcare qualifications.
