webTitle: Observer review: Mary Shelly by Miranda Seymour

fields.headline: Was Frankenstein a fluke?
fields.standfirst: Miranda Seymour risks being buried under a mass of facts in her biography of Mary Shelly
fields.trailText: Miranda Seymour risks being buried under a mass of facts in her biography of Mary Shelly
fields.body:
Mary Shelly
Miranda Seymour
John Murray £25, pp655

Mary Shelly was born Mary Godwin to illustrious parents, the first and only child of philosophers, William Godwin and Mary Wollstonecraft, who died in childbirth. Mary spent her teens looking portentously sly and clever, sufficiently so to dazzle the Oxford atheist Percy Bysshe Shelley when he came to worship at Godwin's republican shrine. Brushing aside the trifling objections of Shelley's wife, the two 'children of light' eloped, with Mary's step-sister, Claire Clairmont, in tow.

Mary was 18 when she wrote Frankenstein, Gothic progeny, so one story goes, of a particularly weird evening in which, after reading Coleridge's Christabel, Shelley became convinced that Mary's nipples were eyes and had to be visited by a doctor. A few years later, Shelley was drowned, his fish-eaten corpse burned on a beach.

Mary Shelley returned to England with the remnants of Shelley's heart lovingly stowed away in a box, and took up a quieter, slower life, producing generally unpopular novels such as The Last Man, and struggling to earn enough to support her father and her only surviving child, Percy.

In this biography, Miranda Seymour aims to unearth a more 'real' Mary than legend has allowed, neither the cerebral heir to Mary Wollstonecraft memorialised by the feminist movement, nor the prudish stiff despised by Katherine Mansfield - exerting a petty force over Shelley's posthumous reputation, censoring his works, scrubbing out unseemly mentions of republicanism. Seymour also proposes to investigate the 'causes' of Frankenstein - the coincidence of emotion, circumstance, and talent which produced the book.

Coiled in the heart of Seymour's biography lies an anxious query about the 'greatness' of Mary. Did she achieve merely fleeting luminescence under the inspiring guidance of Shelley and Byron? Would any excitable 18-year-old, thrilled by such extraordinary company, have produced a fictive 'personal best', impossible to improve upon later in life, when, in a dull-toned afterworld, she struggled to earn a living from practical histories and grubby hack work? Or was Mary truly great, but subsequently oppressed into docile conformity by censorious gossips and acidic reviewers?

In her hunt for the answers, Seymour commits herself to an extensive and impressive trawl through Mary's unpublished journals, and through a multitude of written exchanges with Shelley, Godwin, Byron, Claire Clairmont, as well as assorted acolytes and aspirant lovers. This approach creates a minutely detailed, meticulously cited account of Mary Shelley's day-to-day grit, grind, melancholy and sudden joy.

From this solid base, Seymour allows herself a few imaginative flights, spicing up her sources with speculative embellishments: 'Mary was perhaps feeling a little guilty by the summer of 1821'; 'a brisk and businesslike letter [arrived] for Mary. She must have felt ready to weep when she read it.' At times, Seymour clutches too much of the debris, and eyes it with too sentimental a gaze. Do we, for example, need to know exactly when Mary and Shelley first 'made love'?

While small moments are lingered over, the contemporary backdrop tends to be roughed in in shorthand flicks and dashes. Literature, politics and contemporary thought seem continually in danger of receding under a messy unraveling of small things. Despite the array of evidence, Seymour fails to answer the questions she began with - how is a great work created? Is it mind or intangible inspiration or communion with others? Seymour argues that Frankenstein can 'easily be turned into a biographer's sandpit, but Mary's story of Promethean ambition, of rejection, was intended to carry the weight of a social message'.

Defying her own admonishments, Seymour turns the tale back on to the teller. Frankenstein is read as a psychoanalysable teenage tale of alienation and confusion - more a semi-tutored outpouring of loss (of her mother) and rejection (by her father) than a piece of linguistic and imaginative extremis. In the end, Seymour's account leaves the reader a little flat and maudlin. Perhaps because we hope erroneously for a more exciting Mary, and the biographer's 'facts' - the diaries, the letters - prove her not to have been so.

But there is something rather abject and unconsoling about this cowering Mary - neither a genius nor a future-gazer, but a clever, talented woman we might know and pity; a single parent living quietly in Harrow, frowned upon by her neighbours, enjoying the occasional trip to the shops, worrying about the fortunes of her son.

The creator of Frankenstein is lassoed in a thousand knots of housework and living arrangements; a delicate, nervous woman, whose imagination flared briefly and was ever after doused.

webTitle: Paperback of the week: Adrian Mole

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: Just when you thought it was impossible to satirise the Nineties any further, along comes the inimitable Sue Townsend.
fields.body:
Adrian Mole: the Cappuccino Years
Sue Townsend
Penguin £6.99, pp391
Buy it at BOL

Just when you thought it was impossible to satirise the Nineties any further (hasn't the comic potential of sun-dried tomatoes been exhausted?) and that touchy-feely New Labour had put themselves far beyond parody, along comes the inimitable Sue Townsend with a whole new chapter in the life of Adrian Mole, the comic anti-hero who united generations of readers with his solipsistic musings long before Bridget Jones started pinching her cellulite and counting her units.

Adrian, now 30, begins this latest instalment of his diary on 30 April 1997, the day before Labour's momentous election victory. Between them, the familiar characters epitomise the Zeitgeist; Adrian is head chef at Hoi Polloi, a fashionable Soho eaterie serving up traditional, working-class cuisine, and his Beatrice, the beautiful, chainsmoking Pandora Braithwaite, is about to become one of Blair's Babes. Much to Adrian's despair, his yobbish teenage nemesis, Barry Kent, has become a bestselling urban poet.

Adrian's elevation from Neil Armstrong comprehensive to the fringes of media London allows Townsend to indulge her gift for pastiche and there are some brilliant vignettes: the parliamentary candidate from Slag - Socialist Lesbians Against Globalisation (' "What makes a woman have a hairstyle like that?" I said. "Chemotherapy," said my mother, with a withering look'), A.A. Gill's contemptuous review of Hoi Polloi's sausages ('It looked like a turd, it tasted like a turd, it smelled like a turd, it had the texture of a turd. In fact, thinking about it, it probably was a turd'), or Adrian's poem on the death of Diana ('Oh Diana! was a song, of/ my mother's youth. Sung by/ Paul Anka, who was small/ and white of tooth').

There is also a nice postmodern irony to Mole's acknowledgement of his arriviste rival: 'I have been reading Bridget Jones's diary in the Independent. The woman is obsessed with herself!'

In the future, Adrian Mole: The Cappuccino Years will no doubt prove one of the best satirical treatments of the Cool Britannia age, and will stand alongside the earlier volumes as a comic classic.

fields.headline: Love letter to London
fields.standfirst: Peter Ackroyd anatomises the will of an unruly capital in London: the Biography
fields.trailText: Peter Ackroyd anatomises the will of an unruly capital in London: the Biography
fields.body:
London: the Biography
Peter Ackroyd
Chatto & Windus £25, pp822
Buy it at BOL

What is London? The disaster of the Dome, the grunge of traffic, the cost, the crime, the desolation living rough beneath its arches. Familiar fodder from familiar headlines. Moan, moan, moan (as my Spanish grandson says when he comes to visit). But here, by way of antidote, is something wonderful - 'the London of labyrinth, half of stone and half of flesh', the London Peter Ackroyd was born to write about.

He calls it a 'biography' because there can be no steady march of history to 'this wilderness of alleys and passages': London is simply too various, too impossible to define, unless given half-human character. Yet, in truth, that formulation does not quite fit either. What we really have here are some 800 pages of excavation, anecdote, explanation and observation by a man who has come to cherish every sight and sound of the great metropolis which enfolds him. Variations on a theme called London.

Does it always work? Inevitably not, especially in the earlier reaches when information itself is hard to come by. If you do not know where the very name of London came from - maybe Llyndon, the town by the stream; Laindon, the long hill; londos, the Celtic for 'fierce'? - you're doomed to patrol through the years of the Romans, Danes and Saxons in occasionally lumpen travelogue mode, making much out of little. Persevere, though, for as soon as Ackroyd sets foot in the past four centuries he is instantly at home, the master of diverting detail.

And as for blowzabellas, drabs, mawkes and trugmoldies (all London names for the ubiquitous whore) then off we go to Madame Cresswell's in Clerkenwell - unless, that is, you're gay and fancy a Mollie house like Mother Clap's in Holborn.

Ackroyd is the most effortless guide. You wander by his side through the streets of the old city, savouring its bustle, colours and its smells, the stink of living. Yet he also makes the connections. I, too, remember that dwarf, and people gingerly crossing the road to give him wide berth, caught between amusement and embarrassment; but I could not, for the life of me, recall the time of his vanishing. Yet here he is again, returned as a part of the quintessential London, a memory to stand alongside those of Boswell, Hogarth or Defoe. So past and present conjoin. So this is much more than history; it is a tapestry of inspiration and love.

Could such love letters be written to any city, anywhere in the world? Perhaps, in some measure: wherever there are throngs of humanity there is the richness of city life. But Ackroyd aims to go much further than that, to define London's uniqueness. 'It is not civilised or graceful... but tortuous, inexact and oppressive... It is a city built upon profit and speculation, not upon need, and no mayor or sovereign could withstand its organic will.' There you have it. Not Paris, grandly all of a piece. Not New York, where concrete is king, nor Los Angeles, where the freeways are arteries. The world is full of great cities, but London is different. It possesses that organic will.

Take the South Bank in the past 10 years. Has central authority decreed the Tate Modern, the Globe, the wharfs and walkways of regeneration and reclamation right along the Thames? Hardly. Most of it happened when there was no such authority - just as old London once crossed the bridges from the north and swarmed into Southwark and Peckham and Brixton and Camberwell, creating not suburbs without soul - the Paris model - but villages with their own character and peopling. (Read Ackroyd on the Brixton way of murder and the Camberwell way with poison).

This isn't, for good or ill, a city for city planners. It shuns - even after the disasters of the Great Fire or the Blitz - the grand dream as solution: and where there is a small, mistaken dream, like the tower block, it soon shrugs it off. London believes in muddling through, making up its own destiny as it goes along. That's why, alas, its traffic will never flow smoothly, nor its spread of central areas become a precinct to warm Ken Livingstone's heart. Nobody in their right mind would have invented this London, the London we know. But nobody, I think, can subdue it now.

'The South Bank,' Ackroyd writes, 'has been able triumphantly to re-assert its past. The restored Bankside power station, with its upper storey resembling a box filled with light, is aligned with Cardinal's Wharf and the newly constructed Globe in a triune invocation of territorial spirit... five centuries embraced in a single and simple act of recognition. It is part of London's power. Where the past exists, the future may flourish.'

You will not find a better, more visionary book about a place we take for granted, despising, envying, seeing without eyes properly open. Coming, like so many of its merchant class of long ago, from the East Midlands, I used to resent its power and the way it drained the rest of England. I resent it no longer: not because the influence is in all respects healthy - it isn't - but because the power comes naturally, from the first descriptions of what Julius Caesar found when he touched our shores.

London is what was meant to be, secured across the centuries in a multiplicity of races, ways and tongues. You could not re-create it; you cannot destroy it. This London is our London, and if you want to know it better, to see it with eyes wide open, then Ackroyd is your indispensable companion.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Peter Robb's biography of Caravaggio weaves his controversial art into the story of his mysterious life, plus Ali and Nino, Geisha, Stiffed, Godless in Eden and Letters between a Father and a Son
fields.body:
M
Peter Robb
Bloomsbury £7.99, pp567
Buy it at BOL

M is for Michelangelo Merisi, the painter known by the name of his home town, Caravaggio. His stark, unflinching portrayals of reality were in marked contrast to the Counter-Reformation kitsch of his stunned peers.

Robb's biography seeks to interweave Caravaggio's controversial art with a life full of violence and mystery. Information is scarce, particularly on the murky circumstances of Caravaggio's death, and Robb frequently has recourse to speculations and projections. He is helped in this by a firm grasp both of the political machinations and seedy streetlife of seventeenth-century Italy, by his engaging, conversational tone and, most importantly, by his brilliant readings of the paintings themselves. Despite the affectation of the title, Robb's M emerges as a strong personality, unceasingly determined to be his own man in life as in art.

Ali and Nino
Kurban Said
Vintage,£6.99, pp237
Buy it at BOL

In Baku, just before the outbreak of the First World War, Ali falls in love with Nino; he is a Muslim Azeri, she is a Christian Georgian. The complications and misunderstandings of their romance are also those of their country, since Azerbaijan is where Asia and Europe, Islam and Christianity meet.

Ali seems, like his country, to be facing a choice between identities, before war and then the Russian Revolution intervenes, tragically removing any question of choice. The identity of Kurban Said was for a long time shrouded in mystery, but he is now thought to have been Lev Nussimbaum, a Jew from Azerbaijan who emigrated to Germany in the 1920s and then Italy. With its wealth of details and gentle humour, Ali and Nino speaks of a great love for the anarchic, multicultural country Kurban Said left behind.

Geisha
Liza Dalby
Vintage £7.99, pp357
Buy it at BOL

Dalby is the only non-Japanese to have become a geisha, living in Kyoto's 'floating world' of tea houses, kabuki theatre and three-stringed shamisen in the late 1970s while researching a PhD. Her encyclopaedic knowledge of Japanese culture results in many engrossing insights, but there is a sense that she has romanticised this last bastion of feudal culture, and her contention that geisha are in some way empowered by providing convivial company for old-fashioned Japanese men is less than convincing.

Her argument is not helped by the changes that have occurred in Japan since the book's original publication in 1983. The cursory new preface singularly fails to address any of these issues, and the fact that what follows is simply an unaltered reprint does little to dispel the strong whiff of a shameless cash-in on Arthur Golden's Memoirs of a Geisha.

Stiffed: the Betrayal of Modern Man
Susan Faludi
Vintage, £8.99, 676pp
Buy it at BOL

From shipyards to stadiums to the streets of Los Angeles, American men feel angry, betrayed and emasculated. Faludi sees this not as a kneejerk backlash against feminism, but as caused by several deeper discomforts: with an economic system that deprives men of steady jobs, with a society avid for glamour, and with the absence or silence of their fathers.

Their real problem, Faludi argues, is that the cultural framework which once trapped women now imprisons men. She has interviewed a wide variety of men in a broad range of social circumstances, and the sheer legwork involved in her project must be admired. But her suggestive argument is far more worthy than the men on whose behalf it is made, since some of these wife-beaters and gun-toters are so reprehensible that betraying them begins to sound like a good idea.

Godless in Eden
Fay Weldon
Flamingo, £7.99, 266pp
Buy it at BOL

Godless in Eden gathers together several articles, lectures and essays from the past five years, on topics ranging from New Labour to Lady Di. Unfortunately, Fay Weldon's range is entirely illusory, since she discusses everything at exactly the same superficial level, citing the same random facts and statistics over and over again at the expense of intelligent discussion or genuine insight.

For the first half of the book, not only ideas but entire paragraphs recur. Things pick up when Weldon interviews of stars such as Jamie Lee Curtis and Jean-Paul Gaultier, where her jerky, idiosyncratic style adds a little flavour, and in the mildly entertaining last section of autobiographical fragments. But as comments on contemporary Britain, Weldon's essays aren't even eccentric enough to be of interest.

 Tony Wood

Letters between a Father and a Son
V.S. Naipaul
Abacus £9.99, pp333
Buy it at BOL

The title of this fascinating book, edited and introduced by Naipaul's longstanding literary agent, Gillon Aitken, is slightly misleading, since many of the letters are also between the author and his mother and older sister, Kamla. The core of the book spans only three years, almost exactly the duration of Vidia's years at Oxford. His father, Seepersad, a journalist who published one novel, did not live to see his son's illustrious career as a writer, but the letters he sent to Vidia from Trinidad are full of tenderness, wisdom and sympathy. 'If I didn't know the man,' Vidia writes on receipt of one of them, 'I would have said: what a delightful father to have.'

 Jane Perry

webTitle: Observer review: The New Penguin Book of Scottish Verse

fields.headline: In the beginning was the word. Then they started arguing
fields.standfirst: The New Penguin Book of Scottish Verse charts the evolution of Scots as a literary vehicle
fields.trailText: The New Penguin Book of Scottish Verse charts the evolution of Scots as a literary vehicle
fields.body:
The New Penguin Book of Scottish Verse
edited by Robert Crawford and Mick Imlah
Allen Lane, the Penguin Press £20, pp554
Buy it at BOL

What makes a poet Scottish comes down to voice and identity rather than linguistic choice. Yet more than anything else language is the anvil on which Scottish poetry and its 'flytings' (quarrels) have been forged.

For a long time, the demise of Scots as a literary vehicle appeared to be historically inevitable and the poetry of Burns seemed like the last shower of sparks from a dying star. Scots received three blows from which it surely could never recover. The Church adopted the Authorised Version of the Bible; the union of the Crowns took the court and aristocratic patronage to London; and the union of the Parliaments, a century later in 1707, made English the language of government.

Yet generations of artists have resisted assimilation, sometimes to the disapproval of their countrymen. When he published his anthology, The Northern Muse in 1924, that archetypal Scotsman-on-the-make, John Buchan, primly recommended that Scots poets should add 'only a word here or there' to provide a 'Northern tone'.

The advice was essentially political, reflecting Buchan's unionism and anglophilia. In fact, Robert Louis Stevenson had already shown that using Scots did not inevitably mean sinking into the sentimental sump of the Kailyard and could sound perfectly natural. Later, Hugh MacDiarmid's Scots, filtered by a true ear for the speech of his native Langholm, acquired a higher octane by culling words from Jamieson's etymological dictionary. MacDiarmid reacted against Kailyard sentimentality, Burns idolatry and T. S. Eliot's assertion in 1919 that there was no such thing as Scottish literature. If none existed, it would be necessary to invent one.

Oddly enough, in their mutual detestation of the mawkish school, MacDiarmid, the restless political extremist, and Buchan, the tireless lickspittle of the state, forged an unlikely literary alliance.

Thus, three linguistic strains are instantly apparent. The first is standard English, perhaps with what Douglas Dunn called a 'Scottish intonation'. The second is English with a mild Scots additive according to the Buchan formula. The third is no-holds-barred Scots itself and even though scholars like David Murison, editor of the Scottish National Dictionary, argued that it was a language in its own right, with its own rules of spelling and grammar, it has, in practice, proved itself to be more plastic in the best and worst senses, more regionally fragmented and, occasionally, more dangerous.

Writers like Burns and Robert Fergusson and, afterwards, Charles Murray and Robert Garioch, used a language resonant of the old self-confident Scots tongue. MacDiarmid's constructed poetic instrument in lesser hands degenerated into a language as artfully concocted as the Azed crossword and about as accessible. If the Kailyard was the unwanted consequence of Burns, then obscure verse is the downside of MacDiarmid, a kind of poetic bebop designed to make things difficult for the audience. Then there is the late twentieth-century flowering of the urban demotic, represented in this anthology by the diamond-hard poems of Tom Leonard.

The language question gave rise to the bitterest dispute of the twentieth century, when Edwin Muir rejected MacDiarmid's advocacy of Scots as the instrument of renaissance, although MacDiarmid himself reverted to English when he immersed his poetry in science, politics and philosophy. Indeed, Muir mocked the idea that Scotland in itself was a concept strong enough to inspire a literature, dismissing Scott and Burns and the 'sham bards of a sham nation'.

Then there is Gaelic, the language of the first Scottish kingdom. James Macpherson's spurious translations of Ossian briefly entranced Europe, but discredited the old bardic muse for generations to come. In the twentieth century, Sorley Maclean reasserted its often intensely local traditions, though one of his most powerful poems is about the death of a German soldier in the Desert War, where he himself was wounded.

The anthology opens at the dawn of Scotland, with St Columba's 'Altus Prosator' (Maker on High, in Edwin Morgan's exuberant translation from the Latin). The editors, Robert Crawford, professor of modern Scottish literature at St Andrews, and Aberdeen-born Mick Imlah, poetry editor at the Times Literary Supplement, traverse the dominant peaks - William Dunbar, the Border Ballads, Burns, MacDiarmid and Muir. They even find a place for Byron, who was educated in Aberdeen.

But they also offer some digressions. Douglas Young, when he compiled his own Scottish Verse 1851-1951, found those 100 years produced 'probably no more than six' poets of the higher order - John Davidson, Muir, MacDiarmid, Maclean, Sydney Goodsir Smith and George Campbell Hay.

To the list of superior talents, a contemporary critic would add Edwin Morgan, Norman MacCaig and Douglas Dunn. But the anthology also includes curiosities, such as the Paisley poet Marion Bernstein, and William Topaz MacGonagall's paean to the Beautiful Bridge over the Silvery Tay. Crawford, with whom I exchanged emails, reasons that the 'crazed acoustic' of the self-styled tragedian, much mocked in Dundee when peddling his rhymes there, has achieved its own classic status.

Another large issue in Scottish verse sets rural purity against urban stink. Poets like MacDiarmid and Muir were united, for once, in their detestation of Glasgow. Sorley Maclean also used that great city, melting pot of Highlanders, true-blue Lowland Protestants and Donegal Catholics, as a metaphor for corruption, rot and evil, drowning out Alexander Smith's earlier celebration of its 'noise and smoky breath'.

Only in the last decades of the twentieth century did a literature gather substance, using the language, ungrammatical and profane, of the urban poor, notably in the novels of James Kelman and Irvine Welsh, though the vision remains of a benighted underworld. In this collection, Tom Leonard speaks pungently for the 'scruff' banished from the BBC's polite microphones. 'I remember being ashamed of my father/ when he whispered the words out loud/ reading the newspaper...'

Towards the end, a sense of patchiness develops, perhaps for reasons of space, and we have smorgasbord, not a satisfying meal. There are, of course, omissions - no George Bruce, no Maurice Lindsay, no Alan Bold. To be fair, there is no Robert Crawford or Mick Imlah either, although both appear in Douglas Dunn's 1992 Faber Book of Twentieth Century Scottish Verse. No anthology covering so large a period could be exhaustive but this collection offers a serviceable route map.

But the anthology also includes curiosities, such as the Paisley poet Marion Bernstein, and William Topaz MacGonagall's paean to the Beautiful Bridge over the Silvery Tay. Crawford, with whom I exchanged emails, reasons that the 'crazed acoustic' of the self-styled tragedian, much mocked in Dundee when peddling his rhymes there, has achieved its own classic status. Another large issue in Scottish verse sets rural purity against urban stink. Poets like MacDiarmid and Muir were united, for once, in their detestation of Glasgow. Sorley Maclean also used that great city, melting pot of Highlanders, true-blue Lowland Protestants and Donegal Catholics, as a metaphor for corruption, rot and evil, drowning out Alexander Smith's earlier celebration of its 'noise and smoky breath'. Only in the last decades of the twentieth century did a literature gather substance, using the language, ungrammatical and profane, of the urban poor, notably in the novels of James Kelman and Irvine Welsh, though the vision remains of a benighted underworld. In this collection, Tom Leonard speaks pungently for the 'scruff' banished from the BBC's polite microphones. 'I remember being ashamed of my father/ when he whispered the words out loud/ reading the newspaper...' Towards the end, a sense of patchiness develops, perhaps for reasons of space, and we have smorgasbord, not a satisfying meal. There are, of course, omissions - no George Bruce, no Maurice Lindsay, no Alan Bold. To be fair, there is no Robert Crawford or Mick Imlah either, although both appear in Douglas Dunn's 1992 Faber Book of Twentieth Century Scottish Verse. No anthology covering so large a period could be exhaustive but this collection offers a serviceable route map.

webTitle: Observer review: Hey Yeah Right Get a Life by Helen Simpson

fields.headline: Life is what you had before kids
fields.standfirst: Helen Simpson tells the whole story about having children in Hey Yeah Right Get a Life
fields.trailText: Helen Simpson tells the whole story about having children in Hey Yeah Right Get a Life
fields.body:
Hey Yeah Right Get a Life
Helen Simpson
Jonathan Cape £14.99, pp179
Buy it at BOL

Helen Simpson tackles a subject that has become taboo: the sacrifices involved in having children. She complains of loss of sleep, sense, good looks, conversation. A self-pitying whinge? On the contrary, her stories are shot through with love for children. It is complicated. She is saying: loving your children is not - cannot ever be - the whole story. And the whole story is what she is gallantly trying to tell.

She describes women who have chosen to put themselves second but still have spirit enough to see the cost. She writes about mothers with careers and without. She is not militant but gently judgmental. And her writing mutinies against its subject in a wonderful manner. When she writes about being trapped, it is in a liberating way. (To find words for wordless exhaustion is almost like overcoming it). Her stories are - for those who, like me, recognise the truth in every word - like a reprieve.

This is Simpson's third collection and her best. It is beautifully structured: some names recur in more than one story, suggesting the way our several lives are threaded together. The opening story, 'Lentils and Lilies', is about Jade, a young woman suffused with promise. She is determined never to 'go dead inside'. One moment she is 'moving like a panther into the long jewelled narrative which was her future'; the next, she is castigating her mother for being a career woman.

At the end, Jade bumps into a struggling mother whose child has a lentil stuck up its nose. She is unwillingly drawn into this predicament and observes, with distaste, the mother's poor condition, the way her 'heels stuck out from the backs of her sandals like hunks of Parmesan.'

Jade can afford to be censorious only because she is innocent. In time, she may come to resemble the women in the next story called, with light irony, 'Cafe Society'. It is about two mothers who try but fail to have a conversation. The third person is Ben, a savage toddler with cafe-wrecking potential who does a good line in buoyantly insulting strangers. It is funny and awful. Neither of the women is working full time. One has gone 'freelance' - a euphemism for having given up.

Sally's face is not so much described as diagnosed: 'This woman Sally has a drinker's face but her lustreless grey skin and saurian eye come not from alcohol but from prolonged lack of sleep.' The cafe with its cracked Formica, 'dead ham' and 'tired old tuna' shares their mood. The women's thoughts are conveyed in speechless italics. I felt glad and sorry not to be able to join them at their table. But they left me uneasy: for this is a book as much about what we owe to children as what we deserve ourselves.

If this sounds pious or suggests that these are stories for tormented mothers only, then I have misrepresented them. Nobody who admires good writing should miss them. They are sharp, poetic and marvellously witty. And Simpson is at her funniest when circumstances forbid a smile. In the title story, Dorrie is struggling against the clock to get the children to school on time. She steps round them 'like a slave during a palace orgy'.

As the adults become ever more jaded and unpreposessing, so, as if in direct response, the children thrive. They are resplendent, sensuous - well. Dorrie revels in her son: 'His chest was like a huge warm baroque pearl. She satined the side of her face against it for a moment...' It is Dorrie who fusses over the carrot sticks in her older son's lunchbox and gets told by him: 'Hey yeah right get a life!'

Simpson writes just as well about those who have, officially at least, got 'a life'. She describes Dorrie's husband's feelings with sympathetic acuity and in 'Burns and the Bankers', she leaves home altogether for a dire night out. This is a mercilessly funny account of a corporate function. Simpson's ear for philistine and banal conversation is hilarious. But it is a story that works on many levels - and it is full of arrestingly incongrous moments such as the one in which a high-flying woman lawyer reflects in a way that would not disgrace Virginia Woolf on her failure to 'live inside the minute like a thin-skinned raindrop proud on a nasturtium leaf'. In the atmosphere of sexist jokes, empty banter, swinging kilts and haggis, this image seems to have come from another world. But that is typical Simpson.

webTitle: Observer review: JRR Tolkien by Tom Shippey

fields.headline: A creature of Hobbit
fields.standfirst: Tom Shippey issues a challenge that nobody can ignore with JRR Tolkien: Author of the Century
fields.trailText: Tom Shippey issues a challenge that nobody can ignore with JRR Tolkien: Author of the Century
fields.body:
JRR Tolkien: Author of the Century
Tom Shippey
HarperCollins £16.99, pp362
Buy it at BOL

Tom Shippey emerged as one of Tolkien's most acute critics and convincing apologists with The Road to Middle Earth (1983), a nicely Tolkienian title. The subtitle of his enjoyable new book, characteristically, teases as it asserts. Tolkien, 'author of the century'? Hasty, perhaps, as Treebeard might have said. But the sly echo of Germaine Greer's remark that: 'It has been my nightmare that Tolkien would turn out to be the most influential writer of the century' issues a challenge which nobody can quite ignore.

For when The Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit came out, many saw them as a stupendous irrelevance, a 'flight from reality', ignoring everything worthwhile in the modern novel. But others waited - for years - for (the difficult) The Silmarillion to appear, and all the other texts that emerged from material left when Tolkien died.

For many in the Fifties to Seventies, Tolkien's imaginary world, despite passages of frankly weak writing, provided a diagnostic myth which, as myths do, simplified and intensified, and held contradictions in tension together. He always said he was writing a 'mythology for England'. But this mythology was wider than that, for it confronted what modern orthodoxies were beginning to relativise, the absoluteness of evil, a word one feels still uneasy about using in certain company.

Tolkien created a world with a detailed history and chronology stretching over millennia. He gave it languages, some of them beautiful, with credible philological development. And Lord of the Rings had many imitators, who still thrive. Tolkien's influence on fantasy has been profound, as Shippey underlines - he altered the map.

You can hardly approve of Tolkien's fiction on the basis of orthodoxies that, latterly prevailing in the academy, have become the small change of the conversation of the literati. But there is evidence of many Tolkien readers among that same group, and of a massive following among intelligent people of sensibility who simply read and trouble not their heads with theory or orthodoxy. So perhaps the 'Tolkien phenomenon', in fact, turns the tables: if theory cannot accommodate such works, then, perhaps, theories need revising.

Indeed, Tolkien offered that challenge: the two essays on Beowulf and 'On Fairy Stories', to which Shippey gives proper weight, are arguably among the most important theoretical works of the last 60 years. They summarise his thinking about the nature of imaginative literature and its importance, how it transcends the fashion of the moment. While the academy, quite properly, theorises about what ought to be and has been, the imaginative and emotional needs served by the art of lying that is fiction must still be met.

Shippey's witty, combative book is illuminating, especially on The Silmarillion. He also claims that Tolkien can be seen in the context of major developments in modernist fiction. Shippey argues the twentieth century's need for new myths, new maps of Hell, the world changed with the First World War, in which Tolkien fought, and ancient images of paradise lost provided by literary tradition were no longer viable for a writer marked by losing most of his friends in those terrible four years of industrialised warfare. You have, after that experience, to make and live your own myth and, if you are lucky, you can write about it.

The central chapters demonstrate the ingenious articulation of the trilogy, the profundity of its thought about suffering, and evil, both personal and institutional, cosmic and frankly devilish: no allegory, as some tried reductively to decode it, for the problems of the Second World War, for the issues of nuclear deterrence, but something applicable to both, and to the then unimagined Vietnam, and to all struggles where Mordor so nearly wins.

Tolkien, Shippey argues, was in an interesting dialectic between the Boethian view of evil, where it is, in the end, a privation of good, and the dualist or Manichean, where it is an active principle based on the corrupted will of sentient beings. And if we are not, as we once thought, beyond Good and Evil, if we are, in fact, responsible beings, how do we recognise their unchanging substances beneath the blandishments of accident? Eomer's question - 'How shall a man judge what to do in such times?' - must be our question, indeed. And fictions might help us to an answer.

webTitle: Observer review: Bad Blood by Lorna Sage

fields.headline: Sorry Dad, Grandpa's on the sauce
fields.standfirst: Lorna Sage's childhood memoir, Bad Blood, tells how she was determined to break the rules and get away with it
fields.trailText: Lorna Sage's childhood memoir, Bad Blood, tells how she was determined to break the rules and get away with it
fields.body:
Bad Blood
Lorna Sage
Fourth Estate £15.99, pp287
Buy it at BOL

Lorna Sage is surrounded by adults in her childhood memoir and yet she's the one character who seems to grow up. There's her grandmother who always regrets the day she got married; her mother, the child-wife, who can barely leave the house; her father, the boy-soldier, who relives his glory days in the war by staging mock battles with the cruet set and the sauce bottle.

We follow Lorna from rationing to rock'n'roll, from tide-marked, nit-ridden ragamuffin in Hamner, North Wales, in the early Forties, through to council-house adolescent in the Sixties - 'Any minute now I would be a teenager. My clock would strike 13 almost exactly in time with Bill Haley and his Comets.' By 17, she's already a mother and a wife. Barely an adult herself, she's already more self-assured than the rest of her family. And the one thing she knows more than anything else is that she doesn't want to be like them - 'There are too many children in our house.'

The central inspiration is Sage's theatrical grandfather, a lusty, boozy old boy and the local vicar to boot. He dies when Sage is nine, too early for her to recognise him as the embittered old man he was but not before he's given her an insatiable appetite for reading.

When the new vicar moves in, the family are cast out to a council estate and a house designed for the model family of Fifties adverts: 'Man at work, wife home-making, children [two of each] sporty, lean and extrovert.' Except, of course, this image could be not be further from the truth. Her father still longs for conflict; her brother, is constantly poorly; her mother is a parody of the perfect homemaker and an appalling cook. Grandma comes along too, staying up all night reading the papers and railing against men who she believes have ruined her life.

There's something of Dickens about her characters. Her grandmother's idea of affection when Sage was small is to say: 'You're so sweet, I'm going to eat you all up' and you rather think she might. Sage was often unloved, misunderstood, lonely. Yet despite the horror of some of the passages - the day she gives birth stands out for its cruelty - there's a bravado about her that never allows the book to fall into self-pity.

The bad blood of the title describes the way Sage - and the rest of the family - sees herself as her grandfather's progeny: 'I had acquired from grandpa vanity, ambition and discontent along with literacy. I didn't know my place.'

Sage is the odd one out - the teenager who loves Latin and Elvis; the university student with the husband and baby daughter. She grows up at a time when boys are presumed to be best and girls are for dusting. Yet she is determined to, 'to break the rules and get away with it'.

In a wonderful way, Sage succeeds in spite of and also because of her child-like family. This is an eloquent, brave, funny memoir. In an era when the confessional device has become ubiquitous, Bad Blood stands out.

webTitle: New Lottery lawyers worked for Branson

fields.headline: New Lottery lawyers worked for Branson
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: The bitter battle to run the National Lottery descended into new chaos last night after it was revealed that the company giving legal advice on the bidding process had regularly worked for Richard Branson's Virgin empire.
fields.body:
The bitter battle to run the National Lottery descended into new chaos last night after it was revealed that the company giving legal advice on the bidding process had regularly worked for Richard Branson's Virgin empire.

The Observer can disclose that Freshfields, the leading City law firm hired by the Lottery Commission, has acted for Branson and Virgin companies. Its website reveals a series of cases in which it acted for Virgin. Freshfields was appointed to advise the commission earlier this month after Treasury solicitors were dismissed for giving 'defective and calamitous' advice.

Anthony Salz, Freshfield's senior partner, has also advised Branson, whose People's Lottery consortium is battling against Camelot to win the new licence to run the lottery.

Last week solicitors for Camelot wrote to Freshfields demanding answers about a potential conflict of interest. The letter asked if the firm had considered its position carefully before agreeing to the work. Freshfields has written back, saying the company did consider its position. The commission was fully informed of all previous links between the firm, Branson and Virgin.

A spokesman for Branson said past links between Virgin and Freshfields were 'neither here nor there' and that Freshfields had also advised Camelot in the past. Strong safeguards were in place to ensure there was no conflict of interest, a source said. The spokesman said any relationship between Branson and Salz had ended 'a decade ago'.

'Conflict issues do arise frequently,' a Freshfields spokeswoman said. 'All lawyers have to think very carefully before they accept a new client to see whether it is proper for them to do so.'

Peter Ainsworth, the Shadow Culture Secretary, said that the latest row over the lottery showed how careful all sides needed to be. 'It is a question of perception, and perception is vital,' he said. 'It is absolutely essential that confidence is restored. All relationships must be whiter than white.'

The news comes following disclosures yesterday that Alan Howarth, the Arts Minister in the department overseeing the lottery bidding process, was a paid adviser to Branson between 1992 and 1996.

The Camelot letter is the latest salvo in the battle to win the contract to run the lottery. Camelot successfully challenged in the High Court the commission's decision to negotiate solely with the People's Lottery, a move which has led to chaos and delay in the bidding process.

Branson last night attacked Camelot for not having public interest at heart. In his first public comments since The Observer revealed last week that the bidding process was approaching meltdown, Branson said that Camelot had used 'every tactic in the book' to try to undermine the process.

He said he would hold emergency meetings with suppliers to the People's Lottery this week to see if it was possible to meet the new timetable for introducing the lottery.

'Apart from the delaying tactics and maybe making a little bit of extra money, what are Camelot trying to achieve?' he said. 'The possibility of Camelot winning is something which I just can't see, to be honest.

'To start the whole process again would be an absolute nightmare. There is a suspicion that Camelot would like to see the process started again because they know in a sense what the results are already.

'Anything to destroy this process is in their interests. It is certainly not in the interests of the people in this country.'

A senior government source said that it was becoming increasingly exasperated by the high-profile media battle over the lottery.

Three days after The Observer revealed that Camelot was considering fresh legal action against the commission, Dame Helena Shovelton, the commission's chairwoman, resigned.

'I think it was an extremely brave decision,' Branson said. 'I think it did clear the air. I don't think she did anything wrong, the lawyers just gave her bad advice.'

webTitle: Comment: Axing jury trials for many offences threatens democratic freedom

fields.headline: We are not obliged
fields.standfirst:
Axing jury trials for many offences threatens the democratic freedoms at the core of our country

Special report: trial by jury
fields.trailText: Comment: Axing jury trials for many offences threatens the democratic freedoms at the core of our country
fields.body:
It is essential to present yourself as a working-class hero if you are to prosper in the political, media and business élites. From the Director General's office at the BBC to the Institute of Directors, from the New Labour to the Old Tory conferences, the powerful inherit the Earth by seeming meek.

Tony Blair 'listens' with an attention we haven't witnessed since Di died. Greg Dyke is a victim of toffs who bitch behind their manicured hands about his contempt for public-service journalism. Question the priorities of corporations and you attack the sacred market that is nothing more than the unfettered choice of ordinary people. Do you think they're stupid? Do you dare set yourself above the likes of William 'It's you that I'm in it for' Hague who humbly affirm their wish to obey the vox populi .

Many at the top try a prolier-than-thou style that has the advantage of turning critics into reactionary aristocrats, but there isn't an e-business billionaire or newspaper tycoon who can match the master, Jack Straw. The worst Home Secretary of the twentieth - and, if we're lucky, the twenty-first - century denounces his powerless opponents of his élitist plans to take power from the people as élitists themselves - and gets away with it.

Straw and Lord [Gareth] Williams of Mostyn, the Attorney General, have been fighting for a year to deny citizens the right to elect to be tried by jury for assault, theft, burglary and other middle-ranking offences. All whose work includes handling money know that convictions for dishonesty brings the loss of reputation, whatever punishment the courts inflicts and the probable loss of their jobs. They will no longer have the power to insist that they are innocent until found guilty beyond reasonable doubt by a jury of their peers. By extension, about 80,000 people a year will no longer have the power to sit on juries and decide on the guilt or innocence of their neighbours. Power will flow to the growing number of professional stipendiary magistrates appointed in secret by Lord Irvine, the Lord Chancellor, who is in office because he was the patron of Tony Blair and Cherie Booth when they were young barristers on the make.

Short of abolishing the franchise, it is hard to imagine a more élitist assault on popular rights. Yet Straw poses as the people's tribune whose rough but ready working-man's fists will smash the snobs until they bow to the will of the silent majority. Those who defend trial by jury were pampered 'BMW-driving civil liberties lawyers', he sneered. They lived in Hampstead and subscribed to a 'woolly-minded liberalism', which took 'no account of the situation of those who are less favoured than they'.

He forgot to mention that at the last election he was the most louche limousine liberal in the land. 'Surely cutting down the right to jury trial ... is not only wrong but short-sighted,' he drawled in 1997 when Michael Howard proposed the assault on juries he was destined to ape. Tony Blair was no more in touch with the concerns of plain, decent folk. The poor little rich boy didn't understand that ordinary people love to be patronised but thought that 'fundamental rights to justice cannot be driven by administrative convenience'. Meanwhile Gareth Williams revealed himself to be the most isolated of Hampstead hermits when he said in 1993 that it was 'madness' to abolish juries.

After all we've been through, these gentlemen's apostasy is no longer surprising. What has been remarkable is the speed with which Straw's and Williams's mendacity has been exposed. Straw began by claiming that his enemies were the forces of conservatism who opposed any change. Why when Roy Jenkins had introduced majority verdicts in the Sixties he had been attacked by the very types who were shouting at him today. Jenkins stood up in the House of Lords on 20 January. He had allowed juries to find a criminal guilty by a majority of 10 to two to stop them from being nobbled by gangsters, he said. He had protected juries, Straw was abolishing them. 'I cannot allow the Home Secretary to claim my endorsement for this ill-conceived little bill, so directly contrary to everything that he and his spokesman said in opposition.'

The Scots did not have the right to ask for jury trial for assault and the like, continued Straw, why should the English and Welsh be different? The Scottish barrister and Labour peer Helena Kennedy made the obvious riposte in the Lords last month. Scotland has a separate legal system with its own safeguards. Straw was not proposing to introduce Scottish procurators fiscal and 'not proven' verdicts, rather he was collecting the most repressive features of different jurisdictions and pasting them together in a grim collage. In any case, English readers may say, who cares if the Scots arrange these matters differently? Aren't we meant to take a pride in Englishness and cherish what is best about us in this age of devolution? If there is anything in England better than the democratic right to be tried by your peers I have yet to find it.

Williams opened a new front the other day when he sobbed that he wanted to protect victims from the delays jury trials bring to justice. With the exception of saints and masochists, victims want criminals to pay for their crimes. Yet when suspects opt for a jury trial and lose, Crown Court judges give far stiffer punishments than magistrates. The Home Office admits as much. The sav ings it predicts the nobbling of jurors will bring are based on the assumption that the cost of running our bulging prison system will fall as softer sentences are issued. Not much joy for victims there.

The same objection meets Straw's claim that professional criminals are abusing the system by asking for a jury trial. Why would they court a longer stretch? Citizens who are not Napoleons of crime do. Some take the risk because they have been overcharged by an understaffed and not noticeably competent Crown Prosecution Service and agree to plead guilty when the Crown Court has made prosecutors agree to hit them with a lesser crime. Others are protesting their innocence and believe, as all of us believe, that a jury will give them a fairer trial.

And so it goes on. Straw told the Commons on 7 March that his plan 'enjoys the active endorsement of the Lord Chief Justice, Lord Bingham'. Bingham revealed that a fortnight earlier he had sent a letter to the Home Secretary in which he wrote of his 'unease' about the 'dangers' of the legislation. Straw claimed that Professor Michael Zander, chairman of the Royal Commission on Criminal Justice, supported him. Zander said he did not. Straw said that 95 per cent of cases in Britain are heard by magistrates without a jury so there was no harm in slipping a few more trials in their direction. It was left to others to say that nearly all defendants plead guilty in magistrates courts and don't therefore need to bother a jury. If you're ever in trouble don't call the Home Secretary as a witness. There's not a jury in the country which would believe him.

So disreputable has the Home Office's case become that when the Lords last threw out the measure, peers such as Melvyn Bragg, Clive Hollick, and Waheed Ali, who are usually dismissed as New Labour stooges, refused to support the Government. In the Commons, Straw has been forced to rely on the payroll vote and Scottish MPs to secure a majority.

Everyone who opposes Straw and Williams says they are simply good boys obeying Treasury orders to save money. I'm sure that's true, but beneath the anti-élitist rhetoric lurks another motive - a scarcely concelaed anxiety about decisions being out of the hands of polite society.

Authoritarian governments have always loathed juries. They can put justice before the letter of the law and by refusing, for example, to convict whistleblowers who have broken the Official Secrets Act. Lord Lipsey, a superior journalist turned New Labour peer, revealed establishment fears when he blurted out in February that blacks 'opt for jury trial in the hope that they will get an O.J. Simpson. What they hope is that there will be enough black jurors who are fundamentally hostile to the criminal justice system'.

I suppose the only way to solve this shocking state of affairs is to ban all blacks from juries. Or perhaps the Government wants to go further and ban juries completely. Williams said last month that citizens who asked for juries were imposing an intolerable burden on the authorities. The courts were being bullied by the exercise of the 'defendant's diktat'. It was a revealing choice of words. Suspects facing charges which might ruin their lives were oppressors. The helpless state was the victim.

A Conservative peer leapt up and rebuked him. The noble lord was Norman Tebbit. When a Labour Attorney General can be attacked from the Left by such a man you realise that Blairism has sunk into irredeemable decadence.

The Government will decide in February whether to order the Commons to override the Lords and force Straw's bill into law. In the run up to the election when the élite will pose as the champions of anti-élitism, it will be destroying the democratic liberty. In the name of the people, of course.

webTitle: Gene scientists disable plants' immune system

fields.headline: Gene scientists disable plants' immune system
fields.standfirst:
Special report: antibiotics in food
Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Scientists working for Swiss food giant Novartis have developed and patented a method for 'switching off' the immune systems of plants, to the outrage of environmentalists and Third World charities who believe the new technology to be the most dangerous use so far of gene modification.
fields.body:
Scientists working for Swiss food giant Novartis have developed and patented a method for 'switching off' the immune systems of plants, to the outrage of environmentalists and Third World charities who believe the new technology to be the most dangerous use so far of gene modification.

Patents filed by Novartis, manufacturers of Ovaltine, reveal that its scientists expect to be able to use the radical biotechnology for almost every crop on Earth.

Novartis claims that the new use of genetic modification will give farmers greater control over disease and boost production. But critics insist that it will make Third World farmers dependent on buying the company's chemicals each year to produce healthy harvests.

A spokeswoman for Novartis said: 'We are trying to help farmers, not hinder them. We are looking at ways to improve the way plants fight disease.'

She agreed that the company had discovered a way of genetically modifying crops so that their immune systems were disabled, but stressed that this was for 'research purposes' only.

The process involves transferring a single DNA molecule, described by the firm as the 'NIM gene', to the plant. This gene then reacts with the plant's immune system, allowing it to be switched on selectively by the use of chemicals when disease threatens. But the patent also describes plants where the entire immune system has been switched off, making them highly prone to disease.

Environmentalists fear the new technology could have a disastrous ecological impact if crops with their immune systems suppressed are allowed to cross-pollinate with surrounding plant life. The use of GM technology, which uses chemicals to activate genetic traits, was specifically condemned by the UN earlier this year. It recommended that the technology should not be field-tested and called for a moratorium on its development until the impact had been fully assessed.

The patent documents seen by The Observer suggest that Novartis intends to use the new GM technology on 'barley, cucumber, tobacco, rice, chilli, wheat, banana and tomato'.

The company cites an extensive list of more than 80 crops, including several cereals, dozens of fruit such as apples, pears and strawberries, vegetables like beans and lentils, and cash crops like cotton and tea.

Alex Wijeratna of Action Aid, a development charity that works with farmers in developing countries, said: 'We find it extremely frightening that such a powerful multi-national is working on this type of technology, which seems aimed at protecting their profits by threatening the rights of poor farmers.'

Dr Sue Mayer, director of Gene Watch, said: 'These companies should halt development of these potentially dangerous products until there has been a proper assessment of whether they are good for agriculture.'

On Wednesday, the shareholders of Novartis and biotechnology giant Astra Zeneca will vote on whether to merge and create the world's largest GM company.

fields.headline: Web inventor denounces net censorship
fields.standfirst:
Special report: free speech on the net
Net news
fields.trailText: On the tenth anniversary of the creation of the internet, Tim Berners-Lee, the British scientist who invented the world wide web has called for the abolition of censorship online.
fields.body:
On the tenth anniversary of the creation of the internet, the British scientist who invented the world wide web has called for the abolition of censorship online. As parents' groups and politicians press for new ways to police websites, Tim Berners-Lee rejects censorship as 'horrific'.

In an exclusive interview with The Observer , Berners-Lee dismisses the recent outcry over paedophiles targeting youngsters in web chatrooms, child pornography and fraud, and rejects calls for a 'net regulator'. 'I know there are some very strong feelings but you can not banish technology or regulate content.

'Regulation is censorship - one grown-up telling another what they can and cannot do or see. For me, the idea is horrific. Universality is the key. You must be able to represent anything on the web.'

Illegal material - child pornography, 'video nasties' - should remain illegal, but he insists 'the world is a diverse place and we should trust people, not try to police them... There are many cultures and they are continually changing. What somebody in Tennessee might think of as reasonable when it comes to nudity is very different from what someone in Finland might think.

'Two neighbours next door to each-other might have very different ideas. So any attempt to make a global centralised standard is going to be unbelievably contentious. You can't do that.'

Instead of regulation it is up to parents to 'catch up' with the new e- generation and teach youngsters how to use the web safely. Children are at risk because they are 'technologically ahead of most grown-ups, who have to ask the younger generation how to turn the thing on and get it working. Adults are slower than children. They need to catch up so they can teach their children what to see and what to avoid.'

Ten years ago Berners-Lee wrote the electronic code that enables computers across the world to 'talk' to each-other down a telephone line. The internet was born and has grown from a single website to more than 800,000,000, with e-commerce, chatrooms and email transforming the way we work, shop, do business, socialise and relax.

The Manchester-born scientist has been hailed as 'the man who invented the future'. A decade on he says we are still 'just scratching the surface' of what the internet can do. 'The web is far from done. Just imagine you were back in the Middle Ages and somebody asked "Given the full impact that paper is going to have, where will we be?" That's where we are.'

He describes the future as 'the semantic web... a new, more powerful interactive network that will really enable e-commerce and industry to hum. But I don't want to say more or everyone will jump on the bandwagon and that will wreck it.'

He says his creation is 'progressing remarkably well... it's neat. It is an achievement of a group of people who had a twinkle in their eye about a possible future. We should celebrate the fact that we can change the world by creating a new social tool. It gives a great feeling of hope that we can do it again.'

fields.headline: Embattled Trimble blasts UUP dissidents
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: David Trimble put his political reputation on the line yesterday with an emotional attack on dissident loyalists' 'knee-jerk response' to the Good Friday Agreement.
fields.body:
David Trimble put his political reputation on the line yesterday with an emotional attack on dissident loyalists' 'knee-jerk response' to the Good Friday Agreement.

With the Northern Ireland peace process on a knife edge, Trimble said at his Ulster Unionist Party's annual conference in Belfast that he would not be bullied out of Stormont by those who wanted to see him fail.

'I am not impressed by self-serving calls for us to rush out of the Assembly,' he said. 'Knee-jerk reactions are unwise. Will we sleep any sounder in our beds if we are seen to ditch this agreement? Will there be decommissioning? Will the Union be guaranteed? No, no and no again.'

Trimble's charged speech was one of the most important of his political career and threatens to split his party. Two-thirds of the audience gave him a standing ovation. The rest booed.

Trimble faces a challenge at an emergency meeting of his party's ruling council next month where dissidents will attempt to have him overthrown.

If Trimble is forced out, the UUP will resign from the Assembly, plunging the peace process into chaos.

Tony Blair and the Irish leader Bertie Ahern will meet on Tuesday to discuss the crisis. Trimble said the British Government should stop prevaricating on the decommissioning issue.

'Our people are losing faith in a Government whose response to paramilitary pressure is to look for another set of goodies to give them,' he said.

Disaffection has been growing against Trimble since the party lost its safe South Antrim seat to the Democratic Unionists 10 days ago.

fields.headline: Trimble savages his enemies within
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: David Trimble risked his political reputation yesterday when he launched an emotional attack on dissident elements in his party for a 'knee-jerk response' to the Good Friday Agreement.
fields.body:
David Trimble risked his political reputation yesterday when he launched an emotional attack on dissident elements in his party for a 'knee-jerk response' to the Good Friday Agreement.

With the Northern Ireland peace process on a knife-edge, Trimble told the Ulster Unionist Party conference in Belfast that he would not be bullied out of the Stormont Assembly by those who wanted to see him fail. 'There is no Utopia out there. Politics is a rough business with limited choices,' the leader said, to heckling and booing.

'I am not impressed by the self-serving calls for us to rush out of the Assembly. Knee-jerk reactions are unwise. Will we sleep any sounder in our beds if we are seen to ditch this Agreement? Will there be decommissioning? Will the Union be guaranteed? No, no and no again.

'The choice we have is simple. On the one hand, we can draw nationalism and republicanism into a consensus. On the other, we can be governed by London with Dublin interference, deprived of a voice, deprived of a veto.'

Trimble's highly charged speech threatens to split his party in two. Although two-thirds of the audience gave him a standing ovation, there were cat-calls as he spoke..

Earlier, Ken Maginnis, one of Trimble's closest allies, faced shouts of 'shame, shame' when he said the paramilitary murder rate had fallen by 70 per cent since 1995.

Trimble is threatened with a leadership challenge at an emergency meeting of the UUP's ruling council next month. If that were successful the party would resign from the body, plunging the peace process into chaos.

Tony Blair and the Taoiseach, Bertie Ahern, will meet on Tuesday to discuss the impending crisis.

Trimble told the conference that the Government should stop prevaricating about decommissioning. 'We have had enough,' he said. 'Our people are losing faith in a Government whose response to paramilitary pressure is to look for another set of goodies to give them.'

Opposition to him has been growing since the party lost South Antrim to the Democratic Unionists 10 days ago. Party members opposed to the Agreement say Trimble should agree to a 'no guns, no government' policy, which would mean pulling out of the Assembly until the IRA began decommissioning to the UUP's satisfaction.

Trimble called on colleagues to stop attacking their own party- a reference to fierce critic Jeffrey Donaldson.

'I hear loud calls for a change of policy,' said the party leader. 'I'll give those who have been shouting a change of policy - stop undermining the party. Stop undermining the leadership of the party. Stop undermining democratic decisions made by your party. Stop running to the media and bad-mouthing the Assembly team.'

Trimble also attacked the Patten Report and criticised Sinn Fein, which he said had failed on decommissioning.

fields.headline: Israel faces fresh border crisis
fields.standfirst:
Hizbollah captures troops Gunships raid Lebanon  Jewish shrine left in ruins

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Middle East was on the brink of a violent crisis last night, with the Israeli government threatening 'forceful action' after the capture of Israeli soldiers by Hizbollah guerrillas.
fields.body:
The Middle East was on the brink of a violent crisis last night, with the Israeli government threatening 'forceful action' after the capture of Israeli soldiers by Hizbollah guerrillas.

American diplomats and President Bill Clinton launched a last-ditch effort to prevent the region slipping into the abyss as the unrest seen throughout the week in Israel and the Palestinian terri-tories continued unabated.

Hizbollah claimed to have taken three soldiers prisoner after a massive rocket attack on disputed, Israeli-controlled farms. It was the first such strike since Israel ended its 18-year occupation of southern Lebanon earlier this year. Three Israeli soldiers were injured in the fierce artillery exchange that followed the rocketing.

Ehud Barak, the Israeli Prime Minister, demanded that Beirut rein in Hizbollah, which is based in southern Lebanon. '[Barak] called on [them] to stop hostile activity... immediately and exert its authority on all the organisations active there,' the Prime Minister's office said.

A similar message was sent to Syria, regarded as the main power broker in Lebanon, the spokesman said.

Last night the Americans launched a frantic effort to prevent the situation spiralling out of control. Clinton cancelled a domestic fund-raising trip after talking with the Israeli and Palestinian leaders. A White House spokesman said: 'The President has been working on the Middle East since early this morning [Saturday]. Given the situation, he feels he needs to stay.'

Many are worried that a fierce row over a UN Security Council resolution seeking to condemn the violence between Israelis and Palestinians will lead to countries throughout the region being dragged into the conflict.

The resolution, opposed by Israel, condemns 'excessive use of force against the Palestinian population'. It is feared that an American veto would spark a massive upsurge in the violence of the past 10 days - originally sparked by the visit of the Israeli right- wing politician Ariel Sharon to a site holy to both Jews and Muslims in Jerusalem. So far about 80 people, mostly Palestinians, have been killed.

Yesterday afternoon the Israeli army made plain its determination to meet force with force. Helicopter gunships and artillery pounded Hizbollah-held areas in southern Lebanon, witnesses said. A man and his three children were reported to have been wounded when Israeli helicopters fired on them as they fled their home.

Hizbollah's actions came soon after Israeli soldiers killed two Palestinian demonstrators when they opened fire on a crowd attempting to tear down border fences to reach a Jewish settlement just inside the Lebanese-Israeli frontier. Fourteen demonstrators were also injured in the shooting.

The violence in the north of Israel and Hizbollah's intervention ended any hopes that a dawn withdrawal of Israeli troops from a shrine in the West Bank town of Nablus, one of the key flashpoints in the fighting, would lower tensions.

A squad of Israeli paramilitary policemen who were protecting the Jewish shrine of Joseph's Tomb as well as an attached religious school pulled out of their bunkers at around 5am. One policeman was shot and wounded as they withdrew. Earlier in the week another policeman was shot dead at the site.

Jubilant youths and mask-ed gunmen set the shrine on fire and attacked it with hammers before the Palestinian police moved in.

An Israeli government spokesman expressed 'disappointment'. He said: 'If this is the way they respect their commitment, I don't know what it means for the future.' Though right-wing Israeli politicians called the decision to pull out from Nablus 'an embarrassing capitulation', Yasser Arafat, the chairman of the Palestinian Authority describedit as 'a good step'.

Hanan Ashrawi, a Palestinian Authority spokeswoman, said: 'Pulling out from areas of confrontation and preventing direct provocation would also put an end to clashes and conflict.'

As his domestic position weakens, it becomes harder for Barak to make concessions. Hizbollah's seizure of Israeli soldiers will be a major problem for him, though the attacks on farms in the disputed Chebaa region will help him regain an element of the international sympathy lost in recent days.

A Hizbollah statement said it carried out the operation 'in fulfilling our pledge to liberate every prisoner and all occupied land and in support of the great struggling Palestinian people'.

There are at least a dozen Lebanese held in Israeli prisons, including two guerrilla leaders. Hizbollah has repeatedly pledged to try to secure their release and end Israeli control over the Chebaa farms.

Israel captured the land from Lebanon in the Six-Day War of 1967, when its forces took control of the nearby Golan Heights.

webTitle: Border town waits in fear for its killer sons to be unmasked

fields.headline: Border town waits in fear for its killer sons to be unmasked
fields.standfirst: The names of the Omagh bombers are known in their home town of Dundalk and to police. Now, two years after the atrocity, the world will discover their identities.
fields.trailText: The prosperous Irish town of Dundalk has not been itself in the past few days. True, the shops in the pretty main street have been as busy as usual and the pubs could hardly complain about lack of custom, but a sharp edge has crept in and the town is charged with anticipation.
fields.body:
The prosperous Irish town of Dundalk has not been itself in the past few days. True, the shops in the pretty main street have been as busy as usual and the pubs could hardly complain about lack of custom, but a sharp edge has crept in and the town is charged with anticipation.

This weekend, every citizen is aware their life could be about to change for ever. Families, friends and neighbours watch each other knowing that, tomorrow night, some will see loved ones unmasked as members of the Real IRA, the terrorists responsible for the 1998 Omagh bomb, which killed 29 people and injured 200.

The fear is palpable. 'You don't get a badge when you join the Real IRA,' says one local who prefers to remain anonymous but admits to fear of the imminent revelations. 'Your wife doesn't know, your family doesn't know and your community doesn't know. You don't drink in Republican pubs, you don't support Republican views. For you, the Real IRA doesn't exist, even though once you're a member, you will be a member until the day you die.'

In many ways there is no difference between the border town of Dundalk and any other semi-rural centre. In fact, proud locals are quick to point out, the town is actually better off than most: a plummeting punt has created a windfall for local businesses as canny northerners nip over the border to stretch their sterling, and the imminent relocation of the government's Social Welfare department to the town combined with the arrival of Xerox Europe's headquarters will practically double the population of around 30,000 in under three years.

But Dundalk is a town unlike any other. Behind the pretty window boxes and welcoming smiles, there is a black fact even the most optimistic locals cannot deny.

Mention Dundalk to anyone on either side of the Irish border and their eyes narrow. For Dundalk is home to the Real IRA, the splinter group which, on Saturday 15 August 1998, murdered 29 men, women and children - including a woman heavily pregnant with twins - with a bomb in the unsuspecting town of Omagh.

It was the worst single act of violence in more than 30 years of troubles, committed against the first realistic backdrop of hope the country had ever seen. It was excoriated by Republicans and Unionists alike and even hardened dissidents found its brutality impossible to condone.

When the Real IRA, a shadowy organisation whose members and leaders were shrouded in mystery, admitted to the atrocity, names were bandied around Dundalk and fingers pointed. More than 6,500 people were interviewed; 3,500 houses and premises were visited; 2,700 statements recorded.

Yet no-one has been convicted or held to account. High-ranking RUC officers admit they are almost certain of who is responsible, but even with emergency laws bought in to help them, police have failed to crack the organisation's fiercely loyal wall of silence.

It is this failure that promoted the BBC to launch this year an undercover investigation into the atrocity. Tomorrow night, the BBC says it will name those it believes guilty of the Omagh bombing, challenging them to prove their innocence in the same way the media called to account those it believed responsible for the death of Stephen Lawrence.

But, although most of those living in Dundalk passionately support anything that could lead to a conviction, many feel the BBC has underestimated the passions such an action could unleash.

'It seems entirely probable that this programme will be a catalyst to the tensions simmering under the surface of this town and I find that idea quite terrifying,' said one local businesswoman.

'The IRA could risk the ceasefire by punishing those named, or the gangster element could pick them off to strengthen their position.'

Everyone has ideas about who will be exposed, but no one knows for sure. The imposing homes of two locals, Colm Murphy and Liam Campbell - the only men to have been charged in connection with the crime - are deserted this weekend but it is feared the most dangerous members of the Real IRA have slipped away before the programme is screened.

'I know for a fact that there's one name Panorama doesn't have,' said a well-placed source. 'And yet he's one of the most dangerous men of all in the organisation. Some of the men they've found are the lowest of the low in the Real IRA; they know nothing. Naming them is useless and will only spark intergroup violence.'

The source added: 'Without this man, the Real IRA would seriously falter. With him still in place, the organisation will continue to thrive.'

This man lives in a large housing estate on the edge of town. Like Dundalk itself, the estate appears ordered and relaxed. Along the main road is a church, a sports centre and an employment centre.

Wind further into the maze of roads behind the main street, however, and the character of the area alters radically. Houses here are decaying, their curtains stained and tattered, and their gardens piles of festering rubbish.

However, some houses among the gloom are positively glamorous. They sport conservatories and porches, their paintwork is immaculate and their carefully-tended gardens boast expensive ornaments.

Groups of men gather outside these houses, smoking and talking. Strangers are noted and eyeballed. When The Observer drove through the streets, its car was followed and continued to be so until it had left the area.

This is the side of Dundalk that is unlikely to be cowed by whatever revelations Panorama has to offer. The man in question has no criminal convictions and few locals know what he looks like or recognise his name. He is using lessons learnt from the Provisional IRA to strengthen the Real IRA and his input is bearing fruit.

The cancer in Dundalk is deep-set and intricately twined, ever since thousands of fleeing Nationalists made it their home during the purges of the Seventies. Known as 'El Paso' for sheltering border-hopping dissidents during the Troubles, the town was blackened further in the Eighties by association with the INLA after Mary McGlinchy was shot dead as she bathed her two young sons.

The Omagh bomb was a watershed for Dundalk. Two days after the blast, the town turned out in a spontaneous demonstration of fury. More than 15,000 people - half the population - paraded in candlelit silence. They picketed the house shared by Michael McKevitt, a local man who rose to the rank of IRA quartermaster in charge of arms before orchestrating creation of the Real IRA, and his partner, Bernadette Sands, sister of hunger striker Bobby and a powerful republican force.

In the face of such anger, McKevitt and Sands moved out of their £200,000 house on the outskirts of Dundalk and settled in the less salubrious Knockbridge village, three miles west of the town.

The Real IRA dropped out of sight and the IRA suffered a haemorrhaging of local support in the months after the bombing. But the terrifying reality is that, in the face of a faltering peace process, the Real IRA, the Continuity IRA and the INLA have regained something of their former position in the town.

It is into this seething potion that the BBC will drop its own explosion, a move seen by many as orchestrated by the RUC in a last, desperate attempt to flush out those responsible for the bombing.

It could work, but it is dealing with unknown quantities. Many locals fear it may simply blast the minnows out of the pond and leave the sharks more space. If that happens, neither Dundalk, the families of the murdered, nor any of those desperate for the ceasefire to hold, will thank them.
