webTitle: Maria Scott: Watchdog's feeble bite fails 4m

fields.headline: Watchdog's feeble bite fails 4m
fields.trailText: Homeowners will find it hard to believe that the Financial Services Authority's strategy for cleaning up the endowment scandal has been constructed with them in mind.
fields.body:
Homeowners with the patience to comprehend the finer points of insurance company charging structures and economic forecasting will find it hard to believe that the Financial Services Authority's strategy for cleaning up the endowment scandal has been constructed with them in mind.

It is hard to escape the con clusion that the regulator's starting point was to seek a solution that would let the industry off the hook.

The FSA is trying to reassure the 4 million people with potentially dud endowments that everything is all right really because their policies have grown to be worth at least as much, if not more, than they would have repaid off a repayment loan. But it reaches this conclusion by valuing endowments in the most flattering light possible, using figures that spread charges over the full term.

If a homeowner surrenders an endowment policy the amount they get back from the insurer is likely to be lower - much lower in the early years of the loan - than the figures produced by the FSA. It is true, as the watchdog says, that a forecast shortfall on an endowment is not necessarily a case for claiming mis-selling. But the danger is that the FSA's view will deter many homeowners from reflecting on how adequately they were warned about the risky nature of their policies - and from lodging a complaint.

Homeowners, including those who cancelled policies prematurely, should not be put off. The greater the pressure exerted on companies, the greater the likelihood that the firms will voluntarily underpin clients' policies.

Policyholders who can afford it could seek redress through the courts, and legal opinion suggests that fine print in endowments would not necessarily let insurers off the hook. Action is planned by at least one firm that has been contacted by 200 unhappy homeowners, Joseph Aaron in east London. But what is really needed is fair play by insurers that does not add to policyholders' costs.

Past regulators are not covered in glory over endowments because they set standard assumptions about charges at too low a level.

And while insurers will bear the brunt of compensation bills it seems entirely wrong that lenders who pocketed millions of pounds of commission on endowments should get off unscathed.

 Joseph Aaron: 020 85180333

It is true, as the watchdog says, that a forecast shortfall on an endowment is not necessarily a case for claiming mis-selling. But the danger is that the FSA's view will deter many homeowners from reflecting on how adequately they were warned about the risky nature of their policies - and from lodging a complaint. Homeowners, including those who cancelled policies prematurely, should not be put off. The greater the pressure exerted on companies, the greater the likelihood that the firms will voluntarily underpin clients' policies. Policyholders who can afford it could seek redress through the courts, and legal opinion suggests that fine print in endowments would not necessarily let insurers off the hook. Action is planned by at least one firm that has been contacted by 200 unhappy homeowners, Joseph Aaron in east London. But what is really needed is fair play by insurers that does not add to policyholders' costs. Past regulators are not covered in glory over endowments because they set standard assumptions about charges at too low a level. And while insurers will bear the brunt of compensation bills it seems entirely wrong that lenders who pocketed millions of pounds of commission on endowments should get off unscathed.  Joseph Aaron: 020 85180333

webTitle: Barbara Ellen: Billy, don't be a hero

fields.headline: Billy, don't be a hero
fields.trailText: To be like me, first be destined for a glittering career at the local knicker factory. Leave home in a strop, doss for several years, dressing strangely, experimenting with drink and drugs, and falling in love with madmen
fields.body:
Now and then I receive the most flattering letters from people still at school. Could I tell them how I managed to become a 'successful journalist'? What degree course did I take? At which college? What was my plan and how did I go about executing it? These letters send me into a tailspin of confusion. What is this 'plan' they speak of? And what should I say?

The truth would go something like this: 'To be like me, first be destined for a glittering career at the local knicker factory. Leave home in a strop, doss for several years, dressing strangely, experimenting with drink and drugs, and falling in love with madmen. Apply to a rubbish college a week before term starts, because the dole are hassling you (maaaan!). Write for music press, and earn over £50 a year. Develop infatuation with sound of own voice. Once working for 'proper papers', gain reputation as unreliable lush. Have baby at exactly the wrong time. Wake up one day to find that you've been given column. Spend rest of life sitting at computer, surrounded by dirty coffee cups, crying: 'Ow, ow, brain hurts!'

And the killer punch: 'There are no short cuts, you must follow these instructions to the letter if you are to become a "successful journalist" just like me.'

This sort of advice probably wouldn't be very helpful to media wannabes - it's too messy, frightening, and insane. Nonetheless, this is how things tend to be when you are born into the class that ambition forgot. It's hard enough for middle-class children to carve a niche for themselves these days, but at least they're mindful of the need for a 'plan'. For the working-class child, nothing is signposted, so you tend to bumble about, making it up as you go along.

The way things have turned out for me, I can't complain. But I do. I'm forever banging on about my impeccable council-house credentials, to the general fascination of nobody. It's beyond chippiness, this feeling; more a case of pure fear. I stare at my child, bent over her homework, and think: 'Be anything you want, but please don't be anything like me.'

I was reminded of all this as I watched Stephen Daldry's critically acclaimed film Billy Elliot. The British film industry is haunted by Kes, and Billy Elliot is no exception. It is the tale of a working-class boy who transcends his origins through his talent for ballet.

The film is set against the 1984 miners' strike, which is telling. In art as in life, the working classes of yesteryear are far more palatable than the working classes of today. By the same token, people have always had an easier time dealing with the fictionalisation of working-class culture than they ever had with the reality. In real life, there's nothing attractive about yobs scraping pen-knives across cars, single mums 'bleeding the country dry', or council blocks spoiling the view from your roof garden. However, on the screen, even the scariest bluecollar somehow achieves a Shirley Temple cuteness. 'Oh look,' they cry. 'He's swearing and hitting his son - isn't he downtrodden and sweet?'

The main charge against Billy Elliot has been one of sentimentality, but it is guilty of far worse than that. Daldry, and the screenwriter, Lee Hall, both come from working-class stock, but that doesn't give them the right to tell it how it isn't. There is no nobility in poverty, nothing remotely photogenic about life at the very bottom, very rarely a fast track out. Yet here Billy Elliot is, tap dancing and pirouetting out of the ghetto, and into the welcoming arms of the middle classes. The message is: if you're talented, if you work hard, you can escape, within 111 minutes. And this message is supposed to appeal to whom exactly - the working classes? Don't be silly.

It seems significant that when Hall was interviewed recently, he said that he realised that any child of his would be middle class - as if working-class culture disappears the moment success and money appears. It reminds you of when Tony Blair announced 'We're all middle class now.' It was generally assumed that this was meant as a sop to the working classes. However, to my ears, it seemed to be aimed at the middle classes, flattering them that their culture was still significant, something to be hankered after by people for whom olive oil is a character from Popeye. If Blair was addressing the working classes at all, it was as if he was saying: 'If you're a very good boy or girl, you could end up doing a bad impersonation of a middle-class person for the rest of your life.'

And so it seems with Billy Elliot, a well-meaning movie, which inadvertently raps home a thoroughly suspect message. Poorer children have enough to deal with, without cinema spreading the lie that working-class culture is only good enough for the first act.

barbara.ellen@observer.co.uk
